From: Tim Hockin <thockin@hockin.org>
Message-Id: <200301012033.h01KXDh11326@www.hockin.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Wed, 1 Jan 2003 12:33:13 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.5 PL3]

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Tantra

I was worried about it - but it was awesome.  I realized something last
night - some parties are about the music, some are about the people.  While
the music was AWESOME, this one was about the love.

It was sort of biorhythmic for me.  I always see some friends at whatever
party/club I hit.  Sort of rhytmically, though never in sync.  Last night
was a massive convergence of the upswing of almost everyone I ever
hang with.  A massive high point with everyone cresting together at the same
time and place.  Almost all my best friends, the boys and girls I have the
luck to call my friends, the people I love, were there last night (with a
very few exceptions).  Like I said, the music was great, but I spent the
vast majority of the night just sitting and talking with whatever friend
happened to walk by.  And there were plenty of those.

I'm not sure the rest of the year can follow through on the precedent set
last night, but I'm sure going to try.

Thanks to everyone for a great start to the new year.  I'm a lucky guy.

Tim

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

time to memorialize all of the real people in my life:

or purely phonetic sounds for everything that they

anyone of my personal choice and to welcome you

abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz! :)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Shared Room Available

Hi SFR
I have room available in my apartment for anyone that would be interested. 
The rent of $350/month is all the expenses you would need to pay, with the 
exception of Long Distance. That 350 will get you rent, electricity, water, 
DirecTV satellite service, high-speed broadband cable internet access, and 
unlimited Local phone calls. Your room comes with a huge walk-in closet 
that's bigger than some college dorm rooms, more than plenty for 2 people. 
The common areas are completely furnished-couch, dining table, entertainment 
center, and coffee table. I am looking for a respectable, clean male (no 
drugs or alcohol within the apartment) to share the room and apartment with 
myself, my 19 year-old brother, and my two adorable cats. We are very 
respectful of one's privacy and are very easy to get along with. It is a 
month to month lease with NO DEPOSIT! The complex is located in a very nice 
and safe area, right across the street from Del Mar high school. I am hoping 
for a mid-January move-in but I am flexible on that. If interested, you may 
contact me at 408-294-3908 or email me at rtahir22@hotmail.com

Not sure about the rest of you, but I'm more interested in how everyone's
new years adventures turned out.

Planet New Year, Tantra, Otherworld, XTort, The Backbeat and a flurry of
other parties, yet no details? ("oh-my-f%cking-god" is not details) Did
they all kick your ass or something?

music, great venue, great setup, small crowd....but damn did the
belligerent drunks come out in force and attempt to trash the place.
Thank God for Sonora's finest.

Anyway, my nye adventures were pretty uneventful, what about the rest of
you? We want stories!

Subject: [sfraves] Planet New Year - story in SFChronicle

Hello SFR community,

I was just contacted by a staff writer for the SF Chronicle doing a
story on Planet New Year.

He's looking to talk to anyone that was there, that might have information
or perspective to help balance out the story. Surprisingly (or not), there
were a couple OD's + possibly other tragic events, he has info from
police, coroners, and companies, but wants to talk to the rave community
to get their feedback.

If you're so inclined here's his contact info:

Matt Stannard
San Francisco Chronicle
Direct: (650) 299-8073
Fax: (650) 299-9208
PGP: 0xC5AA84B3
<mstannard@sfchronicle.com>

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0

In-Reply-To: <DAV28wFpGN1GGENsc9u000045c1@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Planet New Year - story in SFChronicle

quoth Dj Johnny Appleseed:
> Im sorry but i do not agree with anyone that contacts the news to talk
> about what went on. The news is notorious for taking an interview and
> cuting things to get the story they want. 

Right, it's much better to let the media make their *own* inferences as
to what happened... Or better yet, allow them to reach conclusions based
solely on the (presumed) experiences of law enforcement officials and/or
anti-drug proponents, who are more than willing to be interviewed When
Things Go Wrong at Raves.

> We are having enough problems keeping the scene alive. All this is
> going to do is make it harder and harder to bring it back.

Give me a friggin' break. What's keeping the "scene" from "coming back"
is the collective idiocy of giddy teens, greedy promoters, puritanistic
"rave experts" and anti-drug proponents alike. Honest ravers remaining
tight-lipped about the goings-on of underground events only helps to
fuel media speculation, resulting in the public's ever-distorting
perception of raves as drug-fueled sex orgies, or whatever.

Now, I could see why you wouldn't agree with a bunch of pre-teen candy
kids being interviewed after their first rave. But I would hope you
agree that there are enough intelligent, insightful people in the
community willing to participate in an interview, if nothing else but
for the sake of defending the already long-tarnished image of our
community as the public sees it. The enemies of EDM seek to discredit us
by pointing to OD's and arrests as proof that we're all evil people. Why
would you neglect an opportunity to prove them otherwise?

> Please think about the consiquences of your actions befor you make
> them.

And please spell-check your emails before sending them.

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

as we begin our 3rd year of Secret Society.

SECRET SOCIETY -  January 2, 2002
a reunion of people - a revival of culture

Chapter XCVII
Secret Society welcomes San Jose housemusic hometown heroes:

DJs:
TAMOTSU   (San Jose) That's right, you know the one from back in the early 
days... DJ Tamotsu has been spinning and pleasing musically educated 
housemusic crowds in the bay area for over 10 years... Come by tonight and 
see why we call him "excessively underrated"

GUNNAR   (Keep Tahoe Deep)  Hailing from the infamous Keep Tahoe Deep 
parties on the last Saturday of every month, DJ Gunnar has been a staple in 
the bay area housemusic scene for several years. Tonight he unleashes the 
sounds that keep us (and Tahoe) deep in the underground.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] .com merchandise

Since the subject is up, I've actually been wondering about this for quite a
while (at least as long as I've known about the domain squatters at that other
site)

Why DOESN'T Brian slap those SOBs down and take the name back???

I don't know ALL the details, and I know it take some time (Dancesafe's
recovery of Dancesafe.com STILL isn't final (It still redirects to those eztest
wankers...)) But there IS a process for taking your domain back from these sort
of people.  And domain name squatters are barely an evolutionary step above
spammers, after all.

Is it just not Brian's style or something?


cya,
john

From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: mike@atari
To: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org,  <johnv@hyperreal.org>,  <gregvp@attbi.com>, 
     <karina@menegroth.net>
In-Reply-To: <20030103003954.46690.qmail@web12304.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301021649590.1378-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] .com merchandise

>Since the subject is up, I've actually been wondering about this for
>quite a while (at least as long as I've known about the domain squatters
>at that other site)
>
>Why DOESN'T Brian slap those SOBs down and take the name back???

I'm fairly certain that most registrars won't spend too much time dealing
with domain squatting cases unless you can prove bad faith AND show
evidence that the name is yours, i.e. legally trademarked.

Besides, sharing names is sort-of the /point/ of having separate TLD's for
commercial, non-profit, military, educational, governmental or network
uses. Seems like sfraves.com is being pretty clearly used for commercial
purposes. ;)

Compare and contrast: gnu.net, gnu.org, and gnu.com.


>Is it just not Brian's style or something?

It is my understanding that Brian was the original owner of McDonalds.com,
and attempted to give it to the company but was turned down until they
figured out what the web was. Could be a small-scale urban legend, though.

Also, for us to "slap down" VORG would entail the use of the same legal
rationale that allowed etoys.com to slap down etoy.com, and I'm pretty
sure that allowing party merchandise to be sold online is ultimately the
greater good. (or lesser evil, depending on whether you like the shirts)

Date: Thu, 02 Jan 2003 19:57:57 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_5971354==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Tantra: The art of love 

--=====================_5971354==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Some define "tantra" as the spiritual art of love, connecting spirit with 
body.  The party Tantra at the SomArts Gallery on NYE was just that for me 
and many others this NYE.

A year ago the SFLNC attempted to throw this benefit party at SomArts but 
they couldn't obtain the permits.  This year Jimmy Wood and others worked 
on behalf of SomArts and had its entertainment permit re-instated, and 
these same lovely people along with the aid of many community members threw 
this awesome party.

For me, that evening was a reaffirmation of my faith in our community and 
its future.  I have been avoiding clubs and large parties lately, 
preferring to reconnect with the intimate family vibe I have been avidly 
seeking this past year.  We have made a strong effort to reestablish this 
vibe at the Moksha parties:  old school some call it.  Intentionally 
crafted events with a spiritual connection that seek to attract respectful 
and loving dancers.

Tantra was not a small, underground event.  I'd guess they had well over a 
thousand peeps in there.  And it was permitted.  I was pleasantly surprised 
to see the first all ages party going past 2 AM in San Francisco in quite 
some time.  It is quite difficult to manage an intimate, caring vibe at a 
large party but these people succeeded big time.

For those of you who have never been to SomArts, this venue is a dream come 
true:  spacious warehouse with multiple dance areas and outside space for 
the smokers.  Tantra productions used every inch of this vast space 
beautifully.  The genre-defined dance areas included the Psytrance Temple, 
devoted to goa trance;  the Bass Chamber with jungle, breaks and the 
like;  the Underworld serving up driving house, techno and breaks; and a 
very proper chill room.  I was delighted to see they brought all these 
genres and there adherents together in one loving place.  We have danced 
apart for too long, and it is time for the tribes to unite IMHO.

Vibe was definitely old school.  Visually, the underlying theme of tantra 
and related spirituality was carried through in each dance area with some 
truly magnificent altars as well as banners and other visual art.  There 
was even live oil projection in the psytrance room.  This art originated in 
the sixties, and involves the use of colored oils on glass projected with 
an overhead.  Still very effective.  The overall production here was very 
high value, with much attention paid to details.  Vibe, though, is not 
merely a function of the decorative arts, though it is supported by 
them.  Vibe arises from, I believe, a "contract" between the producer and 
the guests --  and this, by necessity, involves "promotion,"  that is, the 
delivery of a focused message that attracts dancers who are loving and 
respectful, delivered by people who have a reputation for creating safe, 
happy spaces for guests who are treated like family.  I never saw the 
small, four-color flier until the night of the party:  it had a dancing 
Shiva on the front.  The only notification I received was one email from 
John Wood and some info through SFLNC.  That was enough to assure me that 
Tantra was the place I would be on NYE.  I would have preferred a party 
with a bit more house, but I was aiming for vibe and I got what I expected 
from the promoters:  a thousand person event with love in such abundance 
that I'm still high on it all.

I talked with John Wood as he was leaving around 3 AM:  poor guy had to 
work the next morning.  Told him that his event was more evidence in my 
mind that this community is far from moribund, as some of the jaded 
believe.  Tantra had much of the positive, joyful, soul-connecting energy 
that rave parties had back in the early nineties.  With the same diversity, 
acceptance, respect, personal creativity and peace that I grew to 
passionately love in our tribe.

Further, the people who came to Tantra danced.  All night long.  So 
energizing, a party with dancers.  I confess my feet hurt severely at the 
end of the night, but my heart had touched so many others on those dance 
floors and our collective spirits were liberated from the self-centered 
darkness to freedom in the light.  That's what it's all about.

And yes, the amenities were those one expects at family parties.  Water for 
a dollar donation to SFLNC.  Chai teas (I liked the peach flavor).  Free 
fruit -- nothing like an orange at four in the morning when you've been 
sweating on the dance floor.  And plenty of toilets:)  Security:  no 
Draconian check at the door, and nearly invisible inside.

Deaths: 0.  People sent to the hospital: 0.  Folks lying about on the 
floor:  a mere handful.

I spent most of the evening dancing in the dark, "underworld" room where 
the house and techno resided.  But I sampled all of it and, since I am also 
a psytrance fan, spent the rest of my dance time with those in that light, 
energy-filled space.

Lots of old friends at this party.  I was really surprised to see Android5 
there -- he returned to SF from Detroit to be at this party.  Before he 
left town there it was a rare party where we didn't dance together.  So 
good having him at this party.

Tantra exemplifies the very best this community has to offer.  As for the 
other shit that went down in this town that night, let me restate what I 
have said before:  Coolworld has nothing to do with the rave community.  A 
couple of years ago a spokesperson for Coolworld issued a press release 
condemning raves as events that were destroying the dance 
community.  Coolworld events were not raves but music and dance 
festivals.  Fine.  I was satisfied with that then, and let's make sure that 
this distinction is made now.  Our community was never "mass market."  We 
were always about respect for ourselves and others, and providing familial 
love and care at our events which, for the most part, were and are given 
for the love of the music and dance and as vehicles to raise monies for 
good causes including protecting the rights of dancers.

I'm grateful to the Tantra crew for bringing me into the new year with such 
an awesome family party.  Let's have many more of them this new year.  Our 
community is strong and loving and we can and will withstand the oppression 
and commercialization.

A happy new year of music and dance to all of you, sfravers.

Much love,

Apollo








Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_5971354==_.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] NEU LIGHT: Secret Psychedelica // Sat. January 25th // $5   -bsp

***

Illumination Records and Neuroscience Creations present...

NEU LIGHT:Secret Psychedelica
Saturday, January 25th, 2003

As we start the new year, we would like to put the spotlight on Santa 
Clara's only psychedelic trance night. Secret Psychedelica, starting its 
third year on Monday, January 27th, continues to bring top notch 
goa/psychedelic trance music to the Silicon Valley on the 4th Monday of 
every month. Neu Light 5 will feature the resident DJs of this Monday night 
monthly. Each DJ has proven themselves worthy behind the decks at local 
clubs and parties to outdoor campouts and have greatly contributed to the 
growth of our psychedelic trance scene.

...into the light...
Illumination Records and Neuroscience Creations would like to thank all Neu 
Light supporters for a wonderful year. Because of you guys and gals, 2002 
has seen four successful Neu Light events. As our way of saying thanks, 
[b]Neu Light 5 will be only $5.[/b] And, as always, every pre-sale ticket 
holder will receive a special Neu Light CD package. Please note, Neu Light 5 
will be limited to [b]pre-sale admission only.[/b] No guest list.

...DJs...
MICHAEL LIU (Illumination Records/Secret Society)
NEUROPSYNTIST (Neuroscience Creations/Neu Light)
AEON (Theorem - Felton)
MUBALI (Straylight - Monterey)
ANDYW (Secret Society/Viberation)

...soundsystem...
Neuroscience Creations

...into the system...
Neu Light shines bright with the help of Viberation Graphics, Psyberdrum, 
Lucky Soul, Thump Radio, Straylight, PLM Productions, and the Phoenix 
Family.

...ticket outlets...
Santa Clara - Solid Grooves (408) 248-6399
Berkeley - Skills DJ Workshop (510) 704-9876
San Francisco - Distractions (415) 252-8751
San Francisco - Frequency 8 (415) 221-4142
Milpitas - Mojo's (408) 586-9319
Santa Cruz - Pipeline (831) 425-7473
Los Angeles - DMC Records - (323) 651-3520
Huntington Beach - Higher Source - (714) 965-5997
Tickets are also available online at www.groovetickets.com or 
www.spinfoil.com

...Neu Light information...
408.278.5211 or www.illuminationrecords.com

...further knowledge...
Solid Grooves, located on 2271 the Alameda, carries a variety of psychedelic 
trance on vinyl and CD.

Psychedelic trance on the radiowaves: KZSC Santa Cruz 88.1fm hosted by Aeon 
every Sunday from 10:30pm to 12:30am

From sfraves-return-97313-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jan 03 18:32:02 2003

Received: (qmail 63441 invoked from network); 3 Jan 2003 18:32:02 -0000
From: <carter@kartre.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: CommuniGate Pro Web Mailer v.4.0.2
Date: Fri, 03 Jan 2003 10:32:06 -0800
Message-ID: <web-7726368@mail.cedant.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"; format="flowed"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to House/Techno/Etc.?

Yeah, I'm posting this again, under a more descriptive 
subject line, because I honestly want it answered.

I feel many of the slings and arrows that are lobbed at 
trance -- it's repetitive, devoid of creativity, it 
doesn't go anywhere -- can be easily and forcefully thrown 
right back at most other EDM genres: house, techno, 
jungle.

So much of the criticism I've seen of trance isn't 
convincing: "it's cheesy," "e-tards listen to it," "it 
SUCKS!"  Sure there's plenty of bad trance.  There's 
plenty of crap in any music genre.  I've heard plenty of 
bad house, boring techno, and interminable jungle.  But I 
can't condemn any of them because when produced and mixed 
well, they're as good for dancing or listening to as good 
trance.

BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM... ;-)

> oh man - i love that one. and that other one that goes

> BOOM chick BOOM chick BOOM chick BOOM chick WEEP WEEP 
> WEEP WEEP... awwww shit!


Aside from the WEEPs, would someone care to explain how 
this is not a perfect descriptor of house or techno, in 
addition to trance?

This is already turning into another trance-bashing 
session... for my own education, I'd like to hear the 
house and techno adherents explain how their respective 
genres exceed trance in variety and creativity.

Don't interpret this request as snarky. I'm genuinely 
curious.

C.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


From sfraves-return-97314-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jan 03 18:51:54 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-97314-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 77797 invoked by uid 1103); 3 Jan 2003 18:51:54 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 77732 invoked from network); 3 Jan 2003 18:51:54 -0000
Date: Fri, 3 Jan 2003 10:51:57 -0800 (PST)
From: "jacob z." <jsz@eds.org>
To: carter@kartre.net
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <web-7719038@mail.cedant.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301031042590.31506-100000@zen.eds.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Best Trance Songs from 98-2002



On Fri, 3 Jan 2003 carter@kartre.net wrote:

> >oh man - i love that one.  and that other one that goes
> >
> >BOOM chick BOOM chick BOOM chick BOOM chick WEEP WEEP 
> >WEEP WEEP...  awwww shit!
> 
> Aside from the WEEPs, would someone care to explain how 
> this is not a perfect descriptor of house or techno, in 
> addition to trance?

nope.  that up there describes house or techno just about as well as
trance.  don't get me wrong, i ain't bashing trance...  just making fun.

i hang out with a lot of musicians and whenever this conversation
starts: "oh man, trance (or house, or techno, 99% of the world can't
tell the difference you know) is so boring and repetetive - i just tune
out when i hear BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM" i have to remind them that this stuff
is what a theorist would call "functional dance music."  by the same
token, i'm sure there were plenty of 19th century viennese hipsters saying
stuff like "oh man, waltzes are so boring and repetetive.  whenever i hear
BOOM chick chick BOOM chick chick i just tune out."

personally, i like a good drum n' bass mashup or maybe a little
braindance...  but the four on the floor stylee definitely is the great
equalizer.  anyway can dance and fucking go off to such a simple
framework, and music-makers are freed up by that simplicity to do all
kinds of interesting things on top of it.

j


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Date: Fri, 3 Jan 2003 18:58:01 -0800 (PST)
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301021253430.26895-100000@atari>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0301031845510.20062-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
From: Ed Colmar <ed@greengraphics.net>
X-Delivery-Agent: TMDA/0.65 (Johnstown)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Forget number games, how was your new years?


I went to the otherworld party.

The decorations were by far the best I have ever seen in there.  The main
room had a little pond and tons of greenery.  And there was a variety show
room that looked like it was straight out of a tv or movie set.  Nice
work!

The music in the main room was superior, and largely generated live.  I
think there were only 2 dj's all night.  In the other rooms there was tons
of diverse stuff, comedy, spoken word, hip hop, and some wacked out
music(s).

I played a live set in the main room which was going great until matter
accidentally pulled the power to my computer, and we had a few minutes of
silence before the pounding beats started again.

Matter and JP (plateshifter) played a live techy trancy set, which was
great despite some subtle sync issues.

Jack Clang played a solid (as always) techy set all live, then 396 and
Aneurysm played live madness with 396 scratching over it.  Insanity.

Dj Yap pounded a great hard techno Dj set.  Then there was a male/female
duo that played techy poppy stuff, with vocals...

At the very end mixmaster morris played cds.

I had a great time, always great to see the OW cru and friends.

::hugs::

-ed-



On Thu, 2 Jan 2003, Terry Estioko wrote:

> Not sure about the rest of you, but I'm more interested in how everyone's
> new years adventures turned out.

>because I honestly want it answered.

It's not.

The problem is, we live in an area (and time) whose mass-market rave
industry marketing machine is currently focusing its energies on trance.
Therefore, a larger volume of crappier trance gets produced and played
here & now than any other genre, so it's the most salient example of low
quality that we have.

If 92.7 (party!), mars, mystre and the rest of the f-8 hangers-on were
flogging techno or house, and trance was produced in the caring hands of
producers who gave a fuck instead of appeasing the marketing behemoth,
then maybe you wouldn't hear about how trance is bad.

BTW, headline in today's chron: dance party turns tragic!

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to
 House/Techno/Etc.?


<perspective flammability=low>

Personally I feel that trance was a highly creative and evolving music
genre from 92-95 (ish).  Somewhere around there it became /popular/ and
many duplicates and cross genres started emerging, generally with a very
low creative quotient.

In the Bay area, at a certain point the "goa" style (hum and
vibrate fingers against your lips) aquired the term trance, and the
original trance that started it, lost it's identity.

Now I'm not saying that there is NO creative trance out there.  For sure
there is, there are still artists that push the limits of trance induction
and make beautiful challenging tracks.  BUT, they are rare in the overall
sea of 92.7 ocean of crap pop 'trance'

Now I do realize that the lowest common denominator is just that, the
worst possible music that people can tolerate.  Still it boggles my mind
that people can still listen to (or ignore as the case may be) pop
anything.  Blech.

</perspective>

-e-

-- 
Green Graphics   :::   Print and Web Design   :::   510.923.0000

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to House/Techno/Etc.?


> I feel many of the slings and arrows that are lobbed
> at 
> trance -- it's repetitive, devoid of creativity, it 
> doesn't go anywhere -- can be easily and forcefully
> thrown 
> right back at most other EDM genres: house, techno, 
> jungle.

Hmmm.  I personally don't care for MOST trance.  There
are a FEW exceptions..very few actually!  As far as
trance not going anywhere - thats not really true, and
thats half the problem...it goes too damn far (to a
point it's just friggin' silly).  As a "DJ", I like to
be able to mix freely and express myself through the
mix, rather than let the song play while holding my
hands up in a prayer like pose!  The type of tunes I
like to play are songs that almost require quick
mixing and creativity with the mixer and decks.  Most
of the big trance dj's aren't dj's...they're guys (or
girls) standing there playing records...theres a
difference!  Come watch me (or any other hard working
techno dj) play and you'll see that I'm (we're) busy
the entire time (workin that shit!).  No time for
bullshit poses or dance moves and more time for
seriously rocking those peeps with your creativity and
not someones elses...


> But I 
> can't condemn any of them because when produced and
> mixed 
> well, they're as good for dancing or listening to as
> good 
> trance.

This is very true!  I agree 100%.  But you have to
understand that most of the trance that is played here
at the parties is complete shite!  Horribly mixed and
defunkt of any thought...unfortunatly thats what most
people know as being trance around here (thanks mars,
mystre, dyloot, tom slik and the rest of the garbage
posse).  Anyway, I hope that this helped a
little...and please remember that these are MY
feelings about it...just an opinion!

tech,

chris

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to House/Techno/Etc.?

i have to jump in here and insert my two cents.  well...it may end up being more than just two.
why does everyone have to follow everyone around like goddamn sheep and jump on the "trance sucks" bandwagon all the time? now, i haven't been too active in the scene, i must admit, but i have been raving since 96 (not that long, i know) and i've witnessed a strange phenomenon...there comes a point in most ravers' careers when they feel the need to say, "trance sucks, candie ravers suck, i'll never wear my candie again."  and other such denouncements.  in fact, i've seen people who were candy just months before actually look people in the eye and say, "i've never been a candie raver"  bull shit!  i have the pictures to prove it.  
what's that all about?  imo, that's just old fashioned elitism and snobbery entering yet again into a subculture.  and, raving as  a culture should be one of the last vestiges of society where this sort of snobbery exists.  
almost all of us were turned on by candie at first....turned on by trance even more.  why do we have to denounce those precious and beautiful aspects of the scene, just to feel or appear like a more "old school", refined and intelligent raver?  when i hear people say things like "trance sucks"  i just see them as narrow minded.  
this is not to say that they're aren't some real sucky trance songs out there...but to devalue the whole genre??   it's music people, and music is an art.  respect it.
sophia
ps....besides, i know when you "trance-haters" are all alone, you put in that mars and mystere, or whatever else....and dance.  i know you do, just as sure as you are afraid to don all your old school candy.  be yourself, and forget what everyone else says is cool, or right to believe.

I'll Start.

My name is Dominic Son.  I've been living in the Bay all my life.  I believe 
Dreams come true, so i got into the music industry when i was 17.  Making 
electronic pop songs at first, i went to my first homebase rave in 1997 by 
the ghost tribe crew, and said to myself, "I MUST BE HERE, THIS IS WHERE I 
SHOULD BE!" 
So I started making techno music.  I performed it live with the Asian scene 
and they ate it up.  Coolworld saw the market and they booked me for their 
New Year thing in 99. 

I love electronic music with passion.  When i say electronic, i mean ALL 
forms.  As long as there is a synthesizer, i'm all for it.  It's in my blood, 
it's the reason why i'm on this list, cause i know this is the one thing we 
all share.  

I thought by introducing everyone, we keep it real, and we get an idea of 
where all of us are coming from.  

Next?

Dominic Son 
creator of Mr Techno
www.mrtechno.com

--part1_7d.332780b0.2b474b53_boundary--

	That Posts.

Hi!  My name is Omid.  I'm a double-sagittarius, and I enjoy long walks on
the beach, romantic dinners, and making fun of CaNdY RaVeRz WhO TyPe LiKe
DiZ.

I, too, like just about all forms of electronic music, as long as it's done
well. Which probably means that I don't like any of my own, as I like making
music, but just don't do it well. That's why you will never hear it.  If
only more people would admit to their musical shortcomings... :)

My stage name is Omi-San, reflecting my half Japanese heritage, as well as
my innate elitism. I primarily spin house, but I always try to mix in
whatever the hell else I can, because sticking to one genre is, IMO, boring.
And I like to impose my tastes on anyone who'll listen. Willingly or not. :P
If you want your ears to hurt, check out www.radio1328.com

I was born in Iran (my other half, which makes me very popular with
government types), spent some time in London, and then spent the rest of my
time supposedly growing up in the South Bay.. until I left for Hell-A for a
while, cultivating my 'tude and intolerance for others. I've been back here
for a couple of years now but am dying to go somewhere else, as I have some
sort of life ADD or ADHD.

Been on and off SFR for just over 5 years now, but have only met maybe 4
people from it. (See "intolerance for others" above.)

Anyway, this year, I'm looking forward to not meeting more of you at my
nearly non-existent gigs, as I feel far more comfortable hiding behind my
digital soapbox ;)

 - omid

p.s. Geri Dahl is my "Fight Club"-like alter ego

my life in California (Redding, Sacramento, Novato and Redwood City) and
half in Utah (Provo, Murray, Holladay, West Valley, Taylorsville, Salt
Lake.)   As you can see I've moved a lot.  I'm on about my 18th or 19th
residence now.  I believe this has led me to be a very shy person as
I've constantly been having to be new places and meet new people.  You
may see me at parties, but most likely I won't talk to you first.. I'll
just be off in some back corner dancing.  Once the ice is broken though
my shyness disappears quickly.

When I was 17 I was looking at the Colorado Institute of Art in Denver
when my brother took me to my first rave.  He'd been trying to take me
for years but my parents wouldn't have it when he came to Salt Lake to
visit and went to Playschool parties.  I believe it was a birthday
party/rave in a skating rink for Hipp-E's mom.  Like most people's first
party, it changed my life.  I went home and as soon as I turned 18 moved
out of my house and started raving like it was the end of the world.  I
never really got into the drugs at parties because of how important they
were to me and I didn't want to be a statistic and bring down the scene.
I didn't even know about E until the year I moved out of Utah to
California.  Had never been offered a pill, didn't even know what it
looked like.

Upon moving out here and being 21, I found it easier to go to clubs than
to drive to parties far away only to find out they've been shut down.
I've slowly been getting more and more jaded over the years, but at the
same time, a lot of the small clubs have the same feelings as a good
rave.  Lately though I've been fiending for the old days so my new years
resolution is to hit clubs as little as possible and start going to what
made me fall in love with the music in the first place.  Also with my
friends we're trying to get a small recording studio/record label off
the ground but since I work so much my creativity is lacking in both
trying to set up the business aspects as well as recording music and
doing my photography.  This is all changing this year as well as I've
decided that what I love is more important than what I do for money to
keep a roof over my head.

New Years was really important to me this year in the fact that even
though I've been partying since '95, I finally got to help be a part of
setting up a party with my friend in Utah.  This two week vacation I'm
coming back off of has shown me that I still have a love for life that
is suppressed for my need to pay rent.  Expect to see me out and about
more this year, my jadedness is starting to fade.  

-Rayn

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

--0-1073710897-1041628367=:92573
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


 Planet New Year 03 brings in the New Year with thousands cheering!

 

 A capacity crowd brought in the New Year at the Cow Palace with Stellar performances by Paul Van Dyk, Planet B, Christopher Lawrence, Donald Glaude, Wish FM, DJ Dan and many others.  Complete recap, video & pictures will be available soon on our web-site @ www.coolworld.com

 

 Coolworld would like to extend its condolences & blessings to the families & friends of 2 individuals who passed away on New Years Day.  One of the two men was an up & coming DJ from Rohnert Park, Ca., and the other young man was from Stockton, Ca.  They will both be missed!  

 

 Coolworld wants to thank all the people, the Cow Palace, the City of Daly City, the Daly City police department, CSS, Volume services & all the other groups, artists, & individuals that helped to make this years festival happen.  

 

PLANET NEW YEAR 2003- RECAP

 

 Coolworld would like to thank the capacity crowd who attended this years Planet New Year @ The Cow Palace, making it a huge success!  PNY03 gave refuge to all music lovers and united people from all walks of life, religions, cultures, and creeds!  Making the Planet New Year celebration one of the most diverse multi cultural events in America! We had an array of performance artists who traveled across the Planet to entertain and perform @ this years massive festival!

 

 The Coolworld Mothership arena was full by 7:15pm with music lovers from everywhere wanting to catch Superstar DJ Paul Van Dyks first California festival appearance ever.  PVD opened the show with an amazing set, and took the crowd on an incredible musical journey that left them begging for moreHis set was so intense, that he decided to thrill the crowd with a special 30 minute encore that was well accepted and we thank him for this!  Next up, Frank Nitty & Ghost from Housenation, kept the crowd moving & Wish FM changed it up with a special Drum N Bass set that was both melodic & hard.  Americas favorite DJ,  DJ Dan took the stage @ 10:15 to a capacity coliseum crowd and took the event into full gear.  

 

 Upcoming Electronic Rock group Planet B hit the stage next & the crowd erupted into a adrenalin filled frenzy as the magnetic & charismatic group rocked the crowd with there unique & original all live sound.  Planet B took the crowd into the New Year with a techno rock cover of the Beatles, Come Together& closed with a New Years Countdown & fireworks ceremony that was nothing less then amazing.  Donald Glaude kept the New Year spirit bangn with his unique style of performance & turntablism & Christopher Lawrence closed the Mothership arena with such an incredible set that left the crowd cheering the whole way out.  Other arenas, featured stellar sets by DJ Craze, who always impresses, DJ Huey, Mystre, Tom Slik, Dyloot, St. John and many others.  

 

 Coolworld would also like to thank everyone for coming together peacefully and keeping PNY03 positive & friendly atmosphere for all.  We cant thank you enough for this

 

 Again, Coolworld would like to extend its condolences to the families & friends of 2 individuals  who passed away on New Years Day. They will both be missed.

 

  Please be on the look out for Coolworlds upcoming events, as we are right around the corner from the Winter Music Conferences most anticipated event; "The Ultra Music Festival"! Last years festival gave refuge to over 30,000 music revelers! This years festival is going to be even bigger as Coolworld & D'Vox Magazine are set to attract over 40,000 faithfuls!

 

 Coming up in April, Coolworld's "Spring Gathering" music & arts festival will showcase an array of artist and producers from around the nation and will be centrally located right here in the bay Area!

 

HAPPY NEW YEAR From COOLWORLD!

 



---------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

excellant idea, dominic.  
alright...i'm sophia, very lurker-ish, read-every day, post-once-every few-months sfraver.  i started going to raves, what to me seems sooo long ago, that in fact....i can't even name some/most of the parties i've been too.  or, er...maybe it's all the ecstacy i've ingested.  somehow...the memory's gone.  oh well, who needs a memory?
no really, the first party i went to was tiny!  it was in that little record shop on telegraph.  it was funny, actually because the fire dept. came and the crew made most of us go upstairs into the tiny little room above the stairs while they looked around.  it felt so secret...so exciting!  
i took ecstacy for the first time that night....and later in that same small room, i lay on the floor staring up at the "sky" the crew had created on the ceiling, when...what came out of the speakers...pink floyd!?  holy shit....it was a beauitiful, rolling perfect moment.  one of very few that remain as precious memories.
i still love to go to parties....i still like to take e once in awhile.  but neither my time or money will allow me to with the frequency i once did.  hanging out here on sfraves allows me to party vicariously through all of you.  
sophia
ps.  i don't even think i've met any of u...that will need to change.

From: Abby <abbysweets154@yahoo.com>
To: Coolworld <cwpsf@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

Dear Coolworld,

  I would like to thank you for that letter thanking
all your attendees and that oh so brief side note of
the two men that died at your party. At least you
chose to recognize it, although it was to a meager
degree.

  You can give all the sympathies you want and the
deaths will never directly be targeted at you,
however, please be aware that in a large way they
indeed should be.

  Dancesafe,  a nonprofit, harm reduction organization
promoting health and safety within the rave community,
as we understand was NOT permitted by any means at
your party. Your Production Crew, being a popular host
of these 'massive raves' is fully aware that there are
drugs like ecstacy present. It is only fact that many
of these pills are unsafe and harmful if not DEADLY to
its user. 

  But what can we expect from a large Production crew
who is solely there for profit? Of course you will
choose to be ignorant of these facts and take that
large risk to do what is 'politically correct' and not
allow this controversial yet postive group into your
parties. And look what it cost you? THE LOSS OF TWO
LIVES, who just maybe, otherwise wouldnt have been
lost if pill testing facilities were accesible. The
fact remains that there is little you can do to stop
drug use.

  I hope you actually choose to take these recent
events and do more than pretend to care abouth them by
offering less than a few words of your, "sympathies."

  On a side note, you are a disgrace to rave culture.
You take what is something meaningful and blow it up,
leaving little left of what the real culture in
reality was. I hope that being the influential group
you are, you will choose to do something more positive
and pay back the true culture you borrowed your ideas
from. We don't stand for money-making, or bright laser
beams, we're a community built solely on four things; 
peace, love, unity, and RESPECT. Please, don't kill
it.

Thank you.
Sincerely,

Abby
somone who truly cares






--- Coolworld <cwpsf@yahoo.com> wrote:
> 
>  Planet New Year 03 brings in the New Year with
> thousands cheering!
> 
>  
> 
>  A capacity crowd brought in the New Year at the Cow
> Palace with Stellar performances by Paul Van Dyk,
> Planet B, Christopher Lawrence, Donald Glaude, Wish
> FM, DJ Dan and many others.  Complete recap, video &
> pictures will be available soon on our web-site @
> www.coolworld.com
> 
>  
> 
>  Coolworld would like to extend its condolences &
> blessings to the families & friends of 2
> individuals who passed away on New Years Day.  One
> of the two men was an up & coming DJ from Rohnert
> Park, Ca., and the other young man was from
> Stockton, Ca.  They will both be missed!  
> 
>  
> 
>  Coolworld wants to thank all the people, the Cow
> Palace, the City of Daly City, the Daly City police
> department, CSS, Volume services & all the other
> groups, artists, & individuals that helped to make
> this years festival happen.  
> 
>  
> 
> PLANET NEW YEAR 2003- RECAP
> 
>  
> 
>  Coolworld would like to thank the capacity crowd
> who attended this years Planet New Year @ The Cow
> Palace, making it a huge success!  PNY03 gave refuge
> to all music lovers and united people from all walks
> of life, religions, cultures, and creeds!  Making
> the Planet New Year celebration one of the most
> diverse multi cultural events in America! We had an
> array of performance artists who traveled across the
> Planet to entertain and perform @ this years
> massive festival!
> 
>  
> 
>  The Coolworld Mothership arena was full by 7:15pm
> with music lovers from everywhere wanting to catch
> Superstar DJ Paul Van Dyks first California
> festival appearance ever.  PVD opened the show with
> an amazing set, and took the crowd on an incredible
> musical journey that left them begging for moreHis
> set was so intense, that he decided to thrill the
> crowd with a special 30 minute encore that was well
> accepted and we thank him for this!  Next up, Frank
> Nitty & Ghost from Housenation, kept the crowd
> moving & Wish FM changed it up with a special Drum N
> Bass set that was both melodic & hard.  Americas
> favorite DJ,  DJ Dan took the stage @ 10:15 to a
> capacity coliseum crowd and took the event into full
> gear.  
> 
>  
> 
>  Upcoming Electronic Rock group Planet B hit the
> stage next & the crowd erupted into a adrenalin
> filled frenzy as the magnetic & charismatic group
> rocked the crowd with there unique & original all
> live sound.  Planet B took the crowd into the New
> Year with a techno rock cover of the Beatles, Come
> Together& closed with a New Years Countdown &
> fireworks ceremony that was nothing less then
> amazing.  Donald Glaude kept the New Year spirit
> bangn with his unique style of performance &
> turntablism & Christopher Lawrence closed the
> Mothership arena with such an incredible set that
> left the crowd cheering the whole way out.  Other
> arenas, featured stellar sets by DJ Craze, who
> always impresses, DJ Huey, Mystre, Tom Slik, Dyloot,
> St. John and many others.  
> 
>  
> 
>  Coolworld would also like to thank everyone for
> coming together peacefully and keeping PNY03
> positive & friendly atmosphere for all.  We cant
> thank you enough for this
> 
>  
> 
>  Again, Coolworld would like to extend its
> condolences to the families & friends of 2
> individuals  who passed away on New Years Day. They
> will both be missed.
> 
>  
> 
>   Please be on the look out for Coolworlds upcoming
> events, as we are right around the corner from the
> Winter Music Conferences most anticipated event;
> "The Ultra Music Festival"! Last years festival gave
> refuge to over 30,000 music revelers! This years
> festival is going to be even bigger as Coolworld &
> D'Vox Magazine are set to attract over 40,000
> faithfuls!
> 
>  
> 
>  Coming up in April, Coolworld's "Spring Gathering"
> music & arts festival will showcase an array of

> be centrally located right here in the bay Area!

I was in the middle of the strip in Las Vegas for the midnight countdown. It
was my first time in Vegas, and OMG I had such a blast! I went with my
neighbors and their friend, and the four of us drove there on Tues, partied
all night long, then drove back yesterday. I had fun meeting and talking to
people from all over and dancing wherever I found music playing. Good Times!

Happy New Year everyone!

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 03 Jan 2003 22:28:53.0581 (UTC) FILETIME=[7F2B27D0:01C2B377]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Planet New Year - story in SFChronicle


Matt Stannard of the San Francisco Chronicle is one of the good guys.

I got jammed up around the time i first subbed to SFRaves, this was when I
was working temp at the Stanford Human Genome Center right around the time
the first draft of the human genome was sequenced, over a hit of e i got
busted with, and had to do a few weeks county time in San Mateo County Jail
in Redwood City, as a result.

This was prior to Prop 36.

Apollo and some others might remember some of my posts on this.

While I was in I met this guy who was like 4' 11', 120 lbs, smaller than my
g/f at the time, who had 38, 38 count 'em, 38, petty, misdemeanor priors,
because, well, he was a homeless, mental health case who should never have
been in the streets, and especially not in jail, but in a hospital,
receiving proper care for life.

Instead he lived in the streets and kept getting busted over the smallest of
shit.

Welcome to San Mateo County, the richest spot on earth, where being poor and
sick is the worst crime you can commit.

When i met him, he had some weird chafing  stuff going on on his arms, and
guys were avoiding him like the plague,  I'm curious as hell, by nature, so
i approached him to find out what was what.

His command of english was weak as well, but eventually got it out of him
and a few other guys who knew his story.

Turns out the flaking on his arms was from having his casts recently removed
by the doctors.

The reason why this guy was wearing casts was that he sassed back to a nurse
when she tried to get him to take his medication.

4 linebacker guards, each twice the size of me, rushed in on her say so and
broke both his arms for that.

Not only that, but they turned around and charged him with his *first* ever
felony for assault.

I called Matt when I got out, and he did what he could, they lawyered up on
him pretty good, and sealed records, but somehow realized that this might
not play in the court of public opinion and lowered the charge to a
misdemeanor, thanks to Matt's efforts.

So, there is trust there for him on my part.

I just left him a message to thank him for that, again.

I also asked that somehow, some counter-point gets worked into this
discussion.

I'll bet that there were more than two alcohol related traffic deaths, not
to mention, fights, emergency room visits, etc this past holiday period and
they aren't getting splashed over the Front Page, never mind that it's just
as tragic for the family and friends affected by that, yet two people die at
a rave this weekend and I get to hear about it here on the East Coast on a
local list because the story has been picked up and gone National?

Stop the press.

Matt, please, this is going to be a major ongoing story for the forseeable
future, and  a writer than can work some sense of rational perspective into
it will be a great asset.

Yes, we have drugs in this subculture and yes the attitudes towards them
don't carry the same emotional and moral freight as previous generations.

Yes, we stay up all dancing.

Yes, we see no need to constantly have apologize for this, never mind get
our parties busted and go to jail and have our Congress try to shut us down.

Yes, we are OK, productive members of our society, Matt, we wouldn't be
having this conversation if it weren't for the for the founder of this list,
he's a chief architect of a primary piece of software that makes the World
Wide Web run.

We're good people and we're tired of getting busted over nothing, and we
don't want to get mad about it, yet, but we would like someone to tell our
side of the story in a way that people can understand.

So, if it's all the same, we'd love it if you can help us out a little bit
and use your skills to add some balance to this otherwise hysterical
conversation.

Thank you.

Hope everyone had a great Nu Yrs, mine was pretty amazing, despite staying
in.

Regards,

nic

"My job as a journalist is to afflixct the comfortable and comfort the
afflicted."
HL Mencken


----- Original Message -----
From: "Terry Estioko" <terry@hyperreal.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, January 02, 2003 5:35 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Planet New Year - story in SFChronicle


Hello SFR community,

I was just contacted by a staff writer for the SF Chronicle doing a
story on Planet New Year.

He's looking to talk to anyone that was there, that might have information
or perspective to help balance out the story. Surprisingly (or not), there
were a couple OD's + possibly other tragic events, he has info from
police, coroners, and companies, but wants to talk to the rave community
to get their feedback.

If you're so inclined here's his contact info:

Matt Stannard
San Francisco Chronicle
Direct: (650) 299-8073
Fax: (650) 299-9208
PGP: 0xC5AA84B3
<mstannard@sfchronicle.com>

-terry

Abby, i can appreciate your response and we take note of your concerns.
I've responded below to your comments;
 
 Abby <abbysweets154@yahoo.com> wrote:
Dear Coolworld,

I would like to thank you for that letter thanking
all your attendees and that oh so brief side note of
the two men that died at your party. At least you
chose to recognize it, although it was to a meager
degree.

 

--> I would imagine that your perception is your own reality and since you cannot hear someones tone of voice and you cannot see our faces i would expect that you at the very least would give Coolworld the benefit of the doubt when we say that we are extremly sadened by the loss of these two young men. Coolworld is just the name of our company, but the people behind the brand are all human beings who are sympathtic to any death anywhere at anytime.



You can give all the sympathies you want and the
deaths will never directly be targeted at you,
however, please be aware that in a large way they
indeed should be.

 

---> You've already made the decision in your head that we are to blame for these tragic events. So trying to discuss this with your narrow views is going to be difficult, with all respect...



Dancesafe, a nonprofit, harm reduction organization
promoting health and safety within the rave community,
as we understand was NOT permitted by any means at
your party. Your Production Crew, being a popular host
of these 'massive raves' is fully aware that there are
drugs like ecstacy present. It is only fact that many
of these pills are unsafe and harmful if not DEADLY to
its user. 


 

---> Dance safe was told that they could not come and test pills because simply put; it's illegal. You cannot have people testing pills and giving them back to people. It's technically against the law. So we welcome any organization to bring liteature to educate people on dangers of usage, etc. To our knowledge members of dancesafe were present passing out condoms.

 


But what can we expect from a large Production crew
who is solely there for profit? Of course you will
choose to be ignorant of these facts and take that
large risk to do what is 'politically correct' and not
allow this controversial yet postive group into your
parties. And look what it cost you? THE LOSS OF TWO
LIVES, who just maybe, otherwise wouldnt have been
lost if pill testing facilities were accesible. The
fact remains that there is little you can do to stop
drug use.

 

---> Abby, your making a ton of assumptions and actually have no facts. Your saying that because dance safe wasnt present that these two people died. Thats incorrect. Although dance safe performs a service that many people feel is important it doesnt stop people from using Drugs. It also doesnt mean that everyone is going to utlize dancesafe. Your also assuming this person took bad drugs. Ever stop to think that this person may have took the same stuff that many of your friends or aquantances may have taken also. Drugs can be dangerous and you take the risk everytime you use them. Fact is, we dont even know if this guy took exstacy.....we dont know what he took? or when he took what ever he took. What if this consumption occured before he entered the venue....is that are fault too?

 



I hope you actually choose to take these recent
events and do more than pretend to care abouth them by
offering less than a few words of your, "sympathies."

 

--> Again, your making an asumption that we dont care. YOUR WRONG. Were devistated. We just had a kick ass event with alomost NO problems all night long. All city officials, Cow Palace staff, security, and police have all agreed that this years festivities were the smoothest on record. Then, we are hit with a hail storm of information that we are still trying to clarify.

 



On a side note, you are a disgrace to rave culture.
You take what is something meaningful and blow it up,
leaving little left of what the real culture in
reality was. I hope that being the influential group
you are, you will choose to do something more positive
and pay back the true culture you borrowed your ideas
from. We don't stand for money-making, or bright laser
beams, we're a community built solely on four things; 
peace, love, unity, and RESPECT. Please, don't kill
it.

 

--> Addy, you are trully mis-informed. Hopefully with a little time your views will open up and realize that not one organization can be blamed for the downfall of your personal scene. It's easy to point figures and say were the greedy evil. It's harder to do research and discover your wrong. Coolworld is comprised of artist, dj's, and performers who love the very essence of this culture and the people with in it. We dont throw small parties in vacant warehouses like you prefer. We host large multi cultural gatherings with a variety of artist from all accrss the globe in legal venues. Different strokes for different folks. 

 

---> We do not want to get into a huge battle over massive vs. underground. Greedy vs. non proffit, shady, blah, blah, blah....it's all old and this list has seen it's fair share of massive promoter hatred. 

---> Lets wait to see what the facts are and see what actually happend....so that we can react with FACTUAL data rather then EMOTIONAL data. Right now information is still coming in and it's unclear of exactly what happened and when.

respect,

Coolworld

 

 

 



Thank you.
Sincerely,

Abby
somone who truly cares






--- Coolworld wrote:
> 
> Planet New Year 03 brings in the New Year with
> thousands cheering!
> 
> 
> 
> A capacity crowd brought in the New Year at the Cow
> Palace with Stellar performances by Paul Van Dyk,
> Planet B, Christopher Lawrence, Donald Glaude, Wish
> FM, DJ Dan and many others. Complete recap, video &
> pictures will be available soon on our web-site @
> www.coolworld.com
> 
> 
> 
> Coolworld would like to extend its condolences &
> blessings to the families & friends of 2
> individuals who passed away on New Years Day. One
> of the two men was an up & coming DJ from Rohnert
> Park, Ca., and the other young man was from
> Stockton, Ca. They will both be missed! 
> 
> 
> 
> Coolworld wants to thank all the people, the Cow
> Palace, the City of Daly City, the Daly City police
> department, CSS, Volume services & all the other
> groups, artists, & individuals that helped to make
> this years festival happen. 
> 
> 
> 
> PLANET NEW YEAR 2003- RECAP
> 
> 
> 
> Coolworld would like to thank the capacity crowd
> who attended this years Planet New Year @ The Cow
> Palace, making it a huge success! PNY03 gave refuge
> to all music lovers and united people from all walks
> of life, religions, cultures, and creeds! Making
> the Planet New Year celebration one of the most
> diverse multi cultural events in America! We had an
> array of performance artists who traveled across the
> Planet to entertain and perform @ this years
> massive festival!
> 
> 
> 
> The Coolworld Mothership arena was full by 7:15pm
> with music lovers from everywhere wanting to catch
> Superstar DJ Paul Van Dyks first California
> festival appearance ever. PVD opened the show with
> an amazing set, and took the crowd on an incredible
> musical journey that left them begging for moreHis
> set was so intense, that he decided to thrill the
> crowd with a special 30 minute encore that was well
> accepted and we thank him for this! Next up, Frank
> Nitty & Ghost from Housenation, kept the crowd
> moving & Wish FM changed it up with a special Drum N
> Bass set that was both melodic & hard. Americas
> favorite DJ, DJ Dan took the stage @ 10:15 to a
> capacity coliseum crowd and took the event into full
> gear. 
> 
> 
> 
> Upcoming Electronic Rock group Planet B hit the
> stage next & the crowd erupted into a adrenalin
> filled frenzy as the magnetic & charismatic group
> rocked the crowd with there unique & original all
> live sound. Planet B took the crowd into the New
> Year with a techno rock cover of the Beatles, Come
> Together& closed with a New Years Countdown &
> fireworks ceremony that was nothing less then
> amazing. Donald Glaude kept the New Year spirit
> bangn with his unique style of performance &
> turntablism & Christopher Lawrence closed the
> Mothership arena with such an incredible set that
> left the crowd cheering the whole way out. Other
> arenas, featured stellar sets by DJ Craze, who
> always impresses, DJ Huey, Mystre, Tom Slik, Dyloot,
> St. John and many others. 
> 
> 
> 
> Coolworld would also like to thank everyone for
> coming together peacefully and keeping PNY03
> positive & friendly atmosphere for all. We cant
> thank you enough for this
> 
> 
> 
> Again, Coolworld would like to extend its

Subject: ATP: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

.hmm introductions.

I am a 23 year old [ virgo ] graphic designer located on the Peninsula. Many 
who do know also realize that my name is not Jack Triumph; It is simply an 
alter-ego that I like to become when I get to rock the decks. I am Jason 
when I design; I am Jack when I spin. It is my release. Since I don't 
partake in many chemical alterings, this is my high. I started dj'ing 2 
years ago because the music I wanted to hear was not easily accessible. I 
could only get it on vinyl, so the next step is obvious. I have lost my 
faith completely in rock/rap/hip hop/pop/whatever. Sorry, but, that is how 
it is. Everything seems minuscule compared to the "electronic" format.

While I am not as well known as say mighty Chris Jackson, ;), I hope that 
2003 will be a better year for me to gain exposure. I work extremely long 
hours as a designer, so I don't really get a chance to go to a lot of 
undergrounds, gatherings, etc. I have been telling myself that I want to go 
to secret society for months now, but, hey what are you going to do. This 
really limits my chances to network with people and acquire new gigs. And 
with the my nasty vinyl buying habit, in 2 years I have purchased over 500 
records, that also cuts my budget down for going out. But, I try my hardest 
every time I play and in everything I do. Anyone who does know me will tell 
you that if I am into something, I am all the way.

Some who have read my posts in the past, it is not hard to figure out I am 
about as right-wing conservative as you can get. Does that make me a nazi? 
no. And if you think so, that is probably because you aren't intelligent 
enough to think for yourself. To me racism = affirmative action. I mean 
c'mon giving people opportunities because they aren't white male 
heterosexuals? And yes I can be bitter. I lost out to many a scholarship 
because I am exactly that. And no, my "rich" white parents couldn't afford 
to send me.

So, sorry to rant, happy to be hear; Progressive heads hit me up. I want to 
know where you all are at in 2003. I think it is going to be a good year for 
the dark, dirty beats.

Anyone want to get together to spin some vinyl and have some pints, hit me 
back, I have a great home setup.

--
DJ Jack 7RIUMPH

and carved until I set him free"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

>---> Dance safe was told that they could not come and 
>test pills because simply put; it's illegal. You cannot 
>have people testing pills and giving them back to people. 
>It's technically against the law. So we welcome any 
>organization to bring liteature to educate people on 
>dangers of usage, etc. To our knowledge members of 
>dancesafe were present passing out condoms.

I'm not a member of Dancesafe so I may be incorrect in my 
following statement, but I was under the impression that 
their practice was to take a pill, scratch a bit off onto 
a plate, hand the pill back, and THEN test the pill.  I 
believe Dancesafe adheres to this practice without 
exception, because it IS illegal to give a pill back to 
someone when you KNOW it is a narcotic.  However, at the 
time the Dancesafe tester is handling the pill, they 
technically do not know if it is a narcotic or not... 
indeed it may not be, as many of their public test results 
show that some pills are just massive caffeine bombs.

Dancesafe's testing services should not be restricted from 
any event.  If promoters are afraid of the liability 
Dancesafe's presence may bring on, perhaps they should 
consider the greater ethical liability of prohibiting them 
from providing their harm reduction service.

C.

> community willing to participate in an interview, if nothing else but
> for the sake of defending the already long-tarnished image of our
> community as the public sees it.
> 
*takes a deep breath*. Okay. Once again, I need to stand up for all the 
responsible teen ravers out there *many* of which are candy ravers. If you 
would have checked your facts, the two people that died at PNY were nineteen 
and twenty-three, *both* adults. And there are plenty of other incidents of 
drug "overdoses" that involved adults, not "giddy preteen candy kids" as you 
so quickly blamed. I'm so fucking sick of this, I'm sorry. I really resent 
what you said and all the others through the years on this list who have made 
narrow-minded, stereotypical, holier-than-thou "because I'm an adult and I 
don't wear candy" judgments on teenage ravers. You have a bit of growing up 
to do yourself if you are so quick to point the finger at teenagers alone for 
the rate of drug overdoses in the scene. 

Though yes, I might agree that someone attending their first rave might in 
some cases be a poor representation of the scene and therefore unfit to 
participate in an interview, I strongly disagree at your once again 
stereotypical comment about teenage candy ravers and the risk it would run to 
our scene's image if they were to be interviewed. I know that in my nearly 
four years on this list from age fourteen to eighteen I have received 
numerous e-mails in response to my posts thanking me for my insight, 
congratulating me on my intelligence and commenting on my excellent 
perception of the scene. And yes, I WAS A TEENAGE CANDY RAVER. 

Yes, there are probably a greater number of people who have been in the scene 
for many years able to more poignantly sum up rave culture and point out the 
positive aspects of it, but there are also many young candy ravers who could 
do the same or even shed a better, less jaded and less JUDGMENTAL light on 
the subject. I certainly would not want you to represent our scene in an 
interview. You, yourself would only be contributing further to the image the 
media has painted of a business fueled by naive drug obsessed teenagers. How 
productive would your above comments really be? 

What about pointing out the break down of community values? When was the last 
time you took a moment to educate a younger raver, take them to these 
underground parties you speak of and show them what the full spectrum of the 
rave scene has to offer? I'm tired of people pointing their righteous fingers 
at teenagers and then sitting back and doing nothing. How about we stop 
arguing about who is to blame and start DOING something about it? As I've 
always said, when you point a finger, three point back at you. Take a look at 
how you're helping to find a solution. And no, continuing to go to your 
parties of choice and dancing till dawn is not as productive as you think. 
Yes, you may be supporting honest promoters and sending out a positive 
message that way, but what good does that do if those teenagers you speak of 
never see it? Never hear your message? To me, that's just turning a blind eye 
away from the problem and hoping it will go away.

heart,
Alida

--part1_103.233da243.2b477783_boundary--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to
 House/Techno/Etc.?

>there's no soul in trance.

What does "soul" mean?  Emotion?  Good trance has it.

>there's no funk.

Sometimes there is.  And funk does not always a good dance 
record make.

>it's not sexy.

Sometimes it is.  Delerium's "Silence" can be seen as 
sexy... not Peaches or Miss Kittin sexy, but it works.

>it's immature.

I have to agree with that one, but good trance can be 
appreciated outside the teen bracket... I'm several years 
out of the bracket myself.

>it's too cartoonish.

Gotta agree with that too, but again good trance can 
conjure up "Princess Mononoke" rather than "SpongeBob 
Squarepants".

>there's too much predictability.

Often true.  Also true of most other genres.

>it's dull and uncolorful.

Eh?  Again, also true of most other genres.  If anything 
trance gets TOO colorful.  Drum arrangements in trance can 
get dull, but good melodies and basslines can make up for 
it.  IMHO trance is one of the least dull genres out 
there... on the other hand I wish happy hardcore were a 
HELL of a lot duller.

>trance always puts in too much effort, but there's no 
>result.

???

>trance is simply wasted vinyl. it's just weak. fuck trance. 

And back to the unhelpful critique.  Thanks for the good 
points though.

C.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to

>>there's no soul in trance.

>What does "soul" mean?  Emotion?  Good trance has it.

"We await the day with relish that somebody dares to make a dance record
that consists of nothing more than an electronically programmed bass drum
beat that continues playing the fours monotonously for eight minutes.
Then, when somebody else brings one out using exactly the same bass drum
sound and at the same beats per minute (B.P.M.), we will all be able to
tell which is the best, which inspires the dance floor to fill the
fastest, which has the most sex and the most soul. There is no doubt, one
will be better than the other.  What we are basically saying is, if you
have anything in you, anything unique, what others might term as
originality, it will come through whatever the component parts used in
your future Number One are made up from."

-- http://klf.life.eu.org/Misc/the-manual.txt

 Although you make a technical point and it may seem perfectly legal and make all the sense in the world, when it comes to getting permits and permission to host a music festivals at a legal venues....pill testing isnt usually an option for the promoter. 
There is NO Legal Venue that we know of that can capacity over 10,000 people that allows pill testing. 
Dance safe has always been welcome to distribute liteature and they have at many of our events. 
I think it's important to realize that there are still risk and there are still dangers when consuming pure drugs. To say testing a pill is enough to prevent drug over doses is narrow minded. 
As for us taking a greater responsiblity for our patrons and there safety....I would inform you that Coolworld made Everyone with out exception take everything out of their pockets when searched and did not allow any bags or backpacks into the event. 
In addition Coolworld does not support or condone drug use period. We are not in the business of making it easier or safer for people to do drugs. Plain and simple. We dont want any illegal substances inside any of our events. 
I hope this clarifies are position on usage and testing. 
Again, since you cannot hear us and you can only read this, please do not think that we do not care about these recent occurences. Out tone is humble, and we are simply trying to investigate the matter and hopefully prevent this from happening again. 
Respect, 
Coolworld 
 
 
 carter@kartre.net wrote: >---> Dance safe was told that they could not come and 
>test pills because simply put; it's illegal. You cannot 
>have people testing pills and giving them back to people. 
>It's technically against the law. So we welcome any 
>organization to bring liteature to educate people on 
>dangers of usage, etc. To our knowledge members of 
>dancesafe were present passing out condoms.

I'm not a member of Dancesafe so I may be incorrect in my 
following statement, but I was under the impression that 
their practice was to take a pill, scratch a bit off onto 
a plate, hand the pill back, and THEN test the pill. I 
believe Dancesafe adheres to this practice without 
exception, because it IS illegal to give a pill back to 
someone when you KNOW it is a narcotic. However, at the 
time the Dancesafe tester is handling the pill, they 
technically do not know if it is a narcotic or not... 
indeed it may not be, as many of their public test results 
show that some pills are just massive caffeine bombs.

Dancesafe's testing services should not be restricted from 
any event. If promoters are afraid of the liability 
Dancesafe's presence may bring on, perhaps they should 
consider the greater ethical liability of prohibiting them 
from providing their harm reduction service.

C.

Thank you for the thoughtful reply...

>There is NO Legal Venue that we know of that can capacity 
>over 10,000 people that allows pill testing.

I was not aware of this.  Such venue owners bear heavy 
responsibility.

>I think it's important to realize that there are still 
>risk and there are still dangers when consuming pure 
>drugs. To say testing a pill is enough to prevent drug 
>over doses is narrow minded.

I completely agree.  If anything good comes out of these 
untimely deaths, I hope it's that they wake up young 
party-goers that they are neither immortal nor impervious 
to drugs' hazardous effects, whether they be pure or 
adulterated.

I'm not counting on it though.  :(

>As for us taking a greater responsiblity for our patrons 
>and there safety....I would inform you that Coolworld 
>made Everyone with out exception take everything out of 
>their pockets when searched and did not allow any bags or 
>backpacks into the event.

Security catches the big things -- guns, knives, a bag of 
2,000 pills, a giant bong -- but until they start 
crotch-fondling and anal-probing, those little pills will 
ALWAYS get in.  Security is necessary but will never be 
wholly effective.

>I hope this clarifies are position on usage and testing.
>Again, since you cannot hear us and you can only read 
>this, please do not think that we do not care about these 
>recent occurences. Out tone is humble, and we are simply 
>trying to investigate the matter and hopefully prevent 
>this from happening again.

Thanks again.  And I don't doubt your sorrow in this 
matter.

C.

Alida, again....do not be so haste and quick to judgment. Dance safe has always been allowed to pass out pamphlets. Thats a no brainer. No harm no foul. 
However, Regardless of any interview you may see or hear, pill testing is widely not acceptable by police agencies, venues, etc. 
It presents a clear conflict of interest to all parties involved. Also, dance safe does not guarantee or prevent people from over dosing. Thats hypothetical and not something that you can present hard statistics for. 
Coolworld has never banned any organization from spreading educational material regarding any cause. Are doors are open for any prevention or eco conscious outfits who would like to represent there cause in our forum. 
I caution everyone not to jump to conclusions as facts are still unclear and have yet to be fully released. 
Respect, 
Coolworld

>From the article written in the Chronicle, also featured at http://www.sfgate.com, about the event:

"We weren't allowed to bring any of our literature. We weren't allowed to bring our testing material," he said. "All we could do is pass out condoms."

So why is it that they were also not allowed to pass out their literature, Coolworld? Is the media perhaps right and you are in fact lying to us to protect your image as concerned, caring promoters?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

Coming from the legal/business side of your event I can't even imagine the
hoops that must be jumped through to make the event occur. With the raves
being scrutinized by law enforcement, media and the public anything that can
be taken as condoning drug use will be misinterpreted by anyone outside the
scene. It's all about the rules of the *real world* which in this case is
law enforcement, the city, the venue owner and probably most key, the
insurance company for the event. There is the view that by pill testing the
promoter is openly accepting drug use at their event. This puts the venue
owner at legal and financial risk should someone get stupid, overdose/mix,
and have an incident that results in a later lawsuit. I don't like Dancesafe
not being able to keep those that choose to take a substance safer and more
educated yet that's how it has to be at a 10,000 person mini-massive.
Ignorance to raving has passed and taken on the form of sensationalism in
the public eye.

Events like Tantra this past week help undo some of the negetivity that is
generated at large events. But what really helps are when promoters like
Coolworld actively state they don't condone drug useage at their parties and
make an effort to curb it. They have to with so many people and so much
liability. In a sense it's just a game of odds. More people increases the
odds that someone is going to do something stupid at an event. Raving and
ravers need to talk about what goes on at parties and downplay drug useage
and focus on what they're really there for. I go for friends and music.

When I had pictures from the Excite party printed in Jane the reporter
pressed about drug useage at the party. I kept telling her that there was
none and people were just drinking. I likened it to a house party in an
office complex with a handful of people smoking weed. The article ended up
saying *...the drugs of choice were alcohol and marijauna...* which kinda
sounded bad, but not as bad as mentioning ecstacy or something like
ketamine. Divert attention and keep things focused. The world will get bored
of watching us closely in time...

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com

----- Original Message -----
From: "Coolworld" <cwpsf@yahoo.com>
