Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...



Alida, again....do not be so haste and quick to judgment. Dance safe has
always been allowed to pass out pamphlets. Thats a no brainer. No harm no
foul.
However, Regardless of any interview you may see or hear, pill testing is
widely not acceptable by police agencies, venues, etc.
It presents a clear conflict of interest to all parties involved. Also,
dance safe does not guarantee or prevent people from over dosing. Thats
hypothetical and not something that you can present hard statistics for.
Coolworld has never banned any organization from spreading educational
material regarding any cause. Are doors are open for any prevention or eco
conscious outfits who would like to represent there cause in our forum.
I caution everyone not to jump to conclusions as facts are still unclear and
have yet to be fully released.
Respect,
Coolworld


 LittleEtoile@aol.com wrote: In a message dated 1/3/03 2:52:55 PM,
cwpsf@yahoo.com writes:

---> Dance safe was told that they could not come and test pills because
simply put; it's illegal. You cannot have people testing pills and giving
them back to people. It's technically against the law. So we welcome any
organization to bring liteature to educate people on dangers of usage, etc.
To our knowledge members of dancesafe were present passing out condoms.

>From the article written in the Chronicle, also featured at
http://www.sfgate.com, about the event:

"But increasing concerns among promoters about liability for drug use has
led many to bar DanceSafe from their events, Llenes said. Such was the case
at the Cow Palace party.
"We weren't allowed to bring any of our literature. We weren't allowed to
bring our testing material," he said. "All we could do is pass out condoms."

Hmm.. something is a tad inconsitent here. So what's the truth? Because I
find it hard to believe that it is also illegal to pass out educational
pamphlets. And considering you have also already been pointed out as wrong
in regards to Dance Safe's method of pill testing being illegal...

So why is it that they were also not allowed to pass out their literature,
Coolworld? Is the media perhaps right and you are in fact lying to us to
protect your image as concerned, caring promoters?

heart,
Alida

 Abby <abbysweets154@yahoo.com> wrote:Dear Coolworld,

I would like to thank you for that letter thanking
all your attendees and that oh so brief side note of
the two men that died at your party. At least you
chose to recognize it, although it was to a meager
degree.

You can give all the sympathies you want and the
deaths will never directly be targeted at you,
however, please be aware that in a large way they
indeed should be.

Dancesafe, a nonprofit, harm reduction organization
promoting health and safety within the rave community,
as we understand was NOT permitted by any means at
your party. Your Production Crew, being a popular host
of these 'massive raves' is fully aware that there are
drugs like ecstacy present. It is only fact that many
of these pills are unsafe and harmful if not DEADLY to
its user. 

But what can we expect from a large Production crew
who is solely there for profit? Of course you will
choose to be ignorant of these facts and take that
large risk to do what is 'politically correct' and not
allow this controversial yet postive group into your
parties. And look what it cost you? THE LOSS OF TWO
LIVES, who just maybe, otherwise wouldnt have been
lost if pill testing facilities were accesible. The
fact remains that there is little you can do to stop
drug use.

I hope you actually choose to take these recent
events and do more than pretend to care abouth them by
offering less than a few words of your, "sympathies."

On a side note, you are a disgrace to rave culture.
You take what is something meaningful and blow it up,
leaving little left of what the real culture in
reality was. I hope that being the influential group
you are, you will choose to do something more positive
and pay back the true culture you borrowed your ideas
from. We don't stand for money-making, or bright laser
beams, we're a community built solely on four things; 
peace, love, unity, and RESPECT. Please, don't kill
it.

Thank you.
Sincerely,

Abby
somone who truly cares

like raves ( or any even with large crowds ) but doesnt mind if I
go. Luckily for her and our marriage, like many who've been in
this scene for over a few years, I don't go out as much as I did .

 I mentioned in my old bio that I had hurt my back - it reoccurs,
in fact just this week, so we avoided all the big parties and just
went to a good little intimate house party.

 http://www.rhythmethod.com/dec99.picts.html

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List [LONG]

quoth DeezzerRec@aol.com:
> I thought by introducing everyone, we keep it real, and we get an idea
> of where all of us are coming from.  
> 
> Next?

Aw heck, why not? Here's where I'm coming from...

I grew up in Connecticut during the 80's, only child of single mom. She
taught me all about what she considered the classics: from Pink Floyd to
Donna Summer, Hendrix and the Eagles, Elvis Costello and James Brown,
Bowie and the Talking Heads, Bob Marley and the Wailers. As I grew
older, she accepted my changing musical tastes because she remembered
what it was like for her in the 70's. I vividly remember playing with
Legos while listening to Funk Master Flex on Hot97. As the sound
changed, and acts like Kriss Kross became popular, I turned my attention
back towards rock, just in time to catch the explosion of grunge.
Flannel shirts, ripped jeans: I dreamed of living in Seattle.

Then one day, I heard Nine Inch Nails' "Pretty Hate Machine" from start
to finish, and fell in love with dark, moody electronic music. From
there, I went on to listen mostly to industrial: Skinny Puppy, Front
Line Assembly, and Front 242. My interest in Bill Leeb lead me to the
ambient works of Delerium. In '95, I heard a track by Aphex Twin on a
NIN remix EP, and was introduced to IDM: RDJ and his crew of mad
scientists; Meat Beat Manifesto; Future Sound of London and Oribtal; The
Prodigy.

Eventually I found myself living in Florida, having already moved from
CT to Nebraska, then to Georgia... all during my 3 1/2 years in high
school. I never really had time to make many friends, so I worked odd
jobs on weekends, and spent every dime I made on music (only to have
all my CD's stolen, *twice* -- I've since vowed never to keep a large
collection of music in my car, or take it travelling... thank you MP3's
and the iPod!).

At one point I even fell in with the punk crowd, and for a while found
myself at shows nearly every weekend, rocking out to the likes of Less
than Jake, AFI, NOFX, et al. I still enjoyed the darker side of rock,
then embodied by Marilyn Manson and Nick Cave. But EDM eventually won me
back. When everything that wasn't pop generally became labelled as
"electronica", it was easy to get exposed to many different types of
music: the Bristol trip-hop sound (Portishead, Tricky, Smith and
Mighty); poppy techno (Underworld, Fluke); even trance (I really dug
Juno Reactor for a bit). Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers were at
one time my favorite acts. Then Massive Attack led me to Tracey Thorn,
and her involvement with Ben Watt in Everything But the Girl. Yet I
still had never heard the term "house" used in a musical context.

I graduated early from high school and took a scholarship at the
University of Central Florida as a computer science major. Two semesters
in, I spat in the face of the Florida educational system and packed up
for San Francisco. After a short stint at the Academy of Art (I was
already doing web design on the side, but I had to enroll somewhere if
my mom was to support my move), I took a job at a small web startup,
where I found myself working alongside Mike Migurski, who turned me on
to sfraves. At the same time, I started dating a cocktail waitress (with
a penchant for Jeno and Mark Farina) who worked at the Hi-Fi Lounge,
where I met the venerable Jesse Martinez and Dwight Johnson, who
formally introduced me to house music.

Little did I know, I also worked in the midst of a relatively popular
breaks DJ, Sheri Mosley (AKA Madame Mercury). Shortly before she quit to
persue a full-time music career, she convinced our boss to purchase
turntables and a pair of Mackie monitors for the office. I started
buying random records, and spent nearly every day after work teaching
myself to DJ. On weekends, I trainspotted at the Hi-Fi, and gleaned from
my mentors how (and where) to find decent vinyl.  Eventually, I
purchased the pair of Technics 1200's that I continue to use today.

My musical tastes fluctuated when I first started DJ'ing: from banging
vocal house, to 2-step, to dark drum and bass, to downtempo and hip-hop.
House, however, seems to have captured my heart because it brings
together so many other sounds: disco, jazz, dub, funk, techno... It just
seems "right" to me. I'm just thrilled to be in the bay area right now,
with so much talent focused on creating really good music.

A short time after I subscribed, Apollo announced on sfraves his
intentions for creating a new collective. Having already read the
entirety of this House 101 series, I giddily replied to his request for
interested members. The Moksha Tribe met for the first time at an
informal house party, where some 20-odd strangers DJ'd and socialized.
There, I met many of the people that would eventually become my best
friends, a talented, intelligent, and passionate group of like-minded
folks with the desire to change the world through music and dance.
Aboriginal was a truly life-altering experience for me.

Nowadays, I don't really go out much, and that's something I'm going to
work on for the new year. Because when I do, I am simply dumbfounded by
the dedication of the community in the bay area. Nowhere else have I
encountered such a genuine passion for music and dance. I only hope that
one day I'll be able to repay the scene... be it by continuing to throw
kick-ass parties with the Moksha Tribe, playing quality music for anyone
willing to listen, or perhaps even making some myself. :)

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Received: (qmail 30814 invoked from network); 4 Jan 2003 01:19:03 -0000
Message-ID: <20030104011912.41355.qmail@web80312.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 3 Jan 2003 17:19:12 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <7d.332780b0.2b474b53@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

Hey all, this is George Cochrane.  I play in the live-ish house duo
dj2- ya mighta seen us at the SFR 10-year party.  I run a tiny record
label called newstylesound.  We're about to release our second 12"
single.  I play bass and drums most of the time, but also play enough
keyboard to get parts down and I like to sing.  

I'm an experienced recording engineer and a fledgeling dj- I love love
love to spin funky, deep house, and scratch 70s synthesized classical
records on top.  I buy afro-cuban-influenced house records as fast as I
can find them.  Every time I try spinning a new genre, it's like
playing a new video game.  If I had the money to record shop like I
really want to, I'd have a house full of 12s!  :)

I love music an awful, awful lot, really most of it.  There are a few
genres I'm less into but you may be into them so I won't list them. 
I've been in a billion bands but these days find it more rewarding to
work up music by myself and with friends in the studio.  I find nothing
more fun or engaging than musical collaboration- even just relaxed,
smoky nights of knob twiddling and laughs.  

I plan to make music for the rest of my life.  In fact, I'd better,
because I start to go completely apesh*t when I'm unable to for more
than a day or so.  

I love this area, and the people I meet, the parties I go to, the
clubs, the djs, fellow producers and musicians..  It's just all so
good, so positive.  It all ebbs and flows, people come into the scene,
and exit it, and come back.  If you look at it too hard it looks
drama-prone but really we're all just a bunch of sensitive saps.  We
need to take ourselves less seriously and our future more seriously. 
This nye death stuff is very scary.  Here's a new years resolution for
the bay area- NO MORE MONEY-DRIVEN MEGA MASSIVES.  

Just my opinion.

Anyhow, that's me, I'm at newstylesound on AIM, feel free to say hey. 
There is a shedload of music of mine up at www.djorigami.com.

Cheers,
George C.
www.newstylesound.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

My name is Happy. I am fairly new to "the scene" compared to all the
oldskoolers here, but I've been a raver all my life and just didn't know it.
I am a very positive, optomistic and upbeat person. I try to give back to
the scene by educating the cynics and the "pre-teen candy ravers" about the
simple things like the value of hugging for hugging's sake, and the joy of
giving away things like toys and candy to total strangers. I try to follow
the golden rule and help those in need. I will never be a jaded raver
because I look to Apollo as my example of how you can be happy and positive
throught your life, even when many would say that you are too old to do the
things you do. 2002 was a great year for me. It was when I joined this list
and became a part of this wonderful family. I look forward to the new year
and wish you all health, happiness and success in all your endeavours.

Love,

Happy  :-)

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 44321 invoked from network); 4 Jan 2003 02:09:33 -0000
Message-ID: <20030104020942.17981.qmail@web12307.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 3 Jan 2003 18:09:42 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, LittleEtoile@aol.com, carter@kartre.net,
  cwpsf@yahoo.com, abbysweets154@yahoo.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

I find it amusring that coolworld will come on SFRaves and try to spread
bold-faced lies about DanceSafe, when it's no secret that more than a few
current and ex volunteers read and post, and one currently active DS volunteer
IS a pretty regular SFRaver.

I've been a volunteer with DanceSafe for just over a year and a half now.  And
both Alida and Carter are correct.  Pill testing is legal.  It's controversial,
yes.  But it *IS* legal.  Coolworld was flat out 100% lieing when they said
otherwise.

Carter is correct.  No volunteer at a DanceSafe table is EVER knowingly in
possetion of a controlled substance.  The testing procedure, to which ALL
chapters and volunteers MUST adhere, explicitly states that the pill is
scraped, returned to the raver, and then and ONLY then is the test performed. 
The test destroys the sample.  Thus we never knowingly posses ANY drug, real or
fake.  ALL chapters and volunteers MUST adhere to this procedure, the whole
point of which is to avoid breaking the law and shield us from liability.  If
anyone fails to do so, they are expelled from the organization.

Do you really think that we could exist as an incorperated organization (a
fully certified 501(c)3 non=profit even) if we hadn't consulted with legal
council about this point?

If pill testing were "illegal", as coolworld claims, then why were we
pill-testing out in the open, in full view of the public, and with the full
support of the committee AND the district attorney during ALL of Pride
(including the circuit party) this year?  What about at the Castro and Folsom
fairs, again in full view of the public and any patrolling police.  What about
at the innumerable other raves where pill testing was allowed.  None of this is
in dispute.  At Pride, the committee even advretised the pill testing service
for us in the Pride 2002 guide book, and gave us a choice spot in the parade
(yeah... my goofy ass was on TV...)!

FACT:  DanceSafe has never been alowed to pill-test at a coolworld event
because COOLWORLD refuses to allow it.  The buck stops there, nowhere else.

So long as I've been involved with the organization, DanceSafe has only been
allowed into ONE coolworld party, that being LAST year's PNY.  And even THEN it
was only due to the incessant and heroic efforts of one of our LOCAL promoters,
with whom coolworld had partnered that time around.

I was one of the volunteers working that one, actually.  Though you may not
have seen us.  Coolworld stuck us in an obscure corner of one of the secondary
rooms.  End even though we were there, all sorts of ridiculous restrictions
were placed on us.  For example, we were only allowed to distribute durex brand
condoms (one of our volunteers had to sort through ALL of our free condoms,
picking out and discarding all of the non-durex ones).  And pill testing, and
even sales of testing kits, was strictly verboten.

Personally, that experience was the final straw for me (granted, with their
unbroken recored of lies, deciet, and exploitation I didn't exactly have a
positive view of them, even going into that one), guaranteeing that I will
never ever set foot in a coolworld "event" for ANY reason. They just don't care
about anything except extracting every last possible dollar from the rave
scene. And if someone has to die for them to get that dollar, so be it.

It's important to note that this IS my personal opinion tho, not chapter
policy.  DS is there for ALL ravers, even those who support coolworld's
actions. And the SF chapter will be wherever there are ravers, *IF* the
promoters ask and/or allow us.


cya,
john



LittleEtoile@aol.com wrote:

>

>find it hard to believe that it is also illegal to pass out educational 
>pamphlets. And considering you have also already been pointed out as wrong in 
>regards to Dance Safe's method of pill testing being illegal...
>
>So why is it that they were also not allowed to pass out their literature,

IMO,

They don't need to be lying to us.  To have Dancesafe present at an event 
is acknowledging that their will be drugs there.  If DS isn't allowed, and 
searches are made, and security hired, Coolworld can claim that they tried 
to prevent drugs from entering the event.  Letting DS into the event is 
admitting that their screening process isn't perfect, which sets them up 
for liability.

sarilion

ps I'm not stoked about Coolworld, and I'm never happy to hear of any death.

Hmmm well ok here it goes...
I'm The Hopeles Wonder, known as Drew to most of my friends and co =
workers.  I am floundering in a meaningles exsistance working for Lithia =
Ford of Concord selling new Fords and assorted used cars (if anyone =
needs a car there is a raver discount! :-)  ).  I aspire to someday be a =
good DJ.  For now though I go crazy in the confines of my house.  I spin =
progressive and psy trance.  Not a big funky music fan at all.  Some D&B =
every once in awhile really hits the spot and I get a kick out of Breaks =
most of the time (except for that NuSkool stuff).  I'm 20 years old and =
living back with my mom after living and starving on my own for a little =
over a year.  I joined the list in October after moving up here from the =
Central Coast where I ran (and continue to run) the raver calendar there =
(http://www.ccraves.org).  My day to day activities as the depressed =
anti superhero can be tracked and influenced through my website: =
http://www.fozzee.net/drewby/ (my life is an interactive web =
experience.... oh what a loser I really am).  Anyway.... thats about me.

Drew the Hopeles Wonder

on 1/3/03 6:16 PM, His Highness at the_emperor99@hotmail.com wrote:

> Happened upon this site while surfing the web.
> 
> http://www.scamshield.com/Sighting.asp?country=none&state=California&article=1
> 
> Does anyone know anything about this? The comments are funny as hell

OMFG!! These guys are still doing this?

When I started as a freshman at UCLA in '92, a bunch of people in my dorm
fell victim to this scam.. Of course, back then, a pair of these "overstock"
speakers was $150 - that's inflation for ya!  Admittedly, the speakers did
sound pretty damn good, but after about a month or so, the coils would start
going bad.  I didn't feel TOO bad for the suckers that fell for it - college
freshmen who have that kinda money to burn on stuff sold out of white vans
don't have much of my sympathy! It took every bit of willpower not to spend
what few extra bucks I had on legitimately sold items... ;)

-- 
otavallai@
mac.com

Now, a question of etiquette. As I pass, do I give you the ass or the
crotch?

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 69997 invoked from network); 4 Jan 2003 11:56:47 -0000
Date: Sat, 4 Jan 2003 03:56:46 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: OishiiD@aol.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <137.1939ff99.2b476f44@aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301040258070.1017-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Chris/Andy/ANYONE: Why Is Trance Inferior to
 House/Techno/Etc.?


I'm not asking anybody to blindly follow me or opinions...

It's not "inferior", I just rarely hear creative trance, or wickedly mixed
trance, or trance that doesn't shop off a shelf of cliches in the
production or the mixing.

There are some good trance DJs in the bay area, but the pyramid is
completely upside down, and many of our local "big names" seriously
fucking suck.

We're welcome to our preferences.  I'm not trying to sway anybody cause
it's me saying it or because it's "cool" or whatever, I'm trying to sway
if what I say makes sense to you.

I happen to think the only honest way a DJ can play other people's records
and approach being an artist is by dropping what they are feeling and
going somewhere with it.  To me, that means crossing genres, having fun
with the mixer, playing a set that is based on what they're getting back
from the crowd right there and then (not just some set they worked out at
home).. and I don't hear that from most trance Djs, particularly the
biggest names of the area.

andyw

andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
you best get off your horse, drink your milk, get the freak out...

On Fri, 3 Jan 2003 OishiiD@aol.com wrote:
-&e->I wasn't aware that there was a CORRECT way to party.  I didn't realize that
-&e->there was a certain type of MUSIC that was good.  I didn't realize that some
-&e->of the people who have poured their hearts and souls out for our Bay Area
-&e->Scene were in fact money hungry talentless sell out bastards.
-&e->
-&e->I want to thank you finally showing me the light.  From now on I will only
-&e->play plastikman and squarepusher tunes.  From now on when I go to a party I
-&e->will just stand there with my budweiser and critque every move the DJ makes.
-&e->I will shop at GAP and Eddie Bauer for all my cloths.  I will make it a
-&e->mission to talk sh*t about every trance dj alive.

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_10281810==_.ALT"

Subject: [sfraves] Big-buck raves not all the rage to veterans:  Front Page
  Chronicle Article

--=====================_10281810==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed




--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Big-buck raves not all the rage to veterans
New Year's chaos proves dangers of excess, they say

James Sullivan, Chronicle Pop Culture Critic   Saturday, January 4, 2003

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------



San Francisco -- Two deaths at a New Year's Eve dance at the Cow Palace 
have drawn into sharp focus the generation gap between old raves and the 
newer mega-events.

The rave scene was created largely in the Bay Area by a network of devoted 
revelers who merged the psychedelic and cyber eras. As raves have gone 
commercial -- in sports arenas and civic auditoriums, with vendors, ATMs 
and $5 bottles of water -- some old-schoolers have returned to the 
underground, holding rave-style parties in private residences and galleries.

The suspected overdose deaths of Peter Hoang, 19, of Stockton and Michael 
James Uveges, 23, also known as DJ Mikey Vegas, of Rohnert Park have 
heightened concerns over huge dance parties such as the New Year's Eve 
event at the Cow Palace.

The vice mayor of Daly City pledged Friday to tighten restrictions on 
future events, while defenders said such measures would drive raves back 
underground, where there are no institutionalized health and safety 
precautions.

But many veteran ravers have already returned to the underground, or at 
least to a smaller scale. They say the enormous, chaotic arena bashes -- 
10, 400 attended promoter's Coolworld's Planet New Year 2003 at the Cow 
Palace -- are a far cry from the eccentric, intimate happenings they first 
envisioned.


LOWER-KEY EVENTS PREFERRED

Grant Davis, 35, a Salt Lake City native who manages the Dimension 7 video 
gallery and serves as treasurer of the San Francisco Late Night Coalition, 
moved to the Bay Area a decade ago to take part in the burgeoning, wildly 
creative rave scene. The size and mall-style atmosphere of today's large 
dance events hold little attraction for him.

"I honestly can't say I've been to a big event like that in a number of 
years."

His generation of ravers, he said, prefers their gatherings a little lower- 
key these days. "People my age don't need it to be so flashy, so loud."

As raves, first held in remote fields and abandoned warehouses, have gone 
mainstream in recent years, they have attracted a younger clientele.

That mainstreaming is precisely the turnoff for Sunshine Jones, whose 
raving dates back to the '80s. For him, there is little connection between 
the early clandestine dance parties and the huge aboveground events of today.

" 'Rave' as a concept was 10 years ago," said Jones, who runs a San 
Francisco record company, Imperial Dub Records, with his wife, Moonbeam. 
The New Year's Eve event at the Cow Palace "was just a big event," he said. 
"It wasn't a rave."

Many elements of raves -- the sternum-thumping beats, the visual stimuli -- 
remain in place from the early days. But for some of the old-schoolers, the 
organizing principle of "plur" (peace, love, unity, respect) has become 
just another selling point.

Once the events become "that pop or commercial," said Davis, "the whole 
'plur' thing becomes a commodity item, to sell the event. It definitely 
doesn't have that kind of idealism anymore."


DRUG CONNOTATIONS IN 'RAVE'

The term "rave" itself is becoming outdated. Promoters and venue operators 
are downplaying the word, which has taken on drug-related connotations over 
the years.

Michael Wegher, general manager of the Cow Palace, said he wouldn't 
categorize the New Year's Eve event as a rave at all. "It was booked as a 
youth festival. This was a mainstream event."

Barry Synoground is general manager of the DNA Lounge, the 11th Street 
nightclub in San Francisco that hosts many state-of-the-art events with 
disc jockeys.

"There's a big difference between going to a dance party where you feel a 
great connection to everyone -- and yeah, maybe a few people are high, but 
they're not causing problems -- as opposed to (an event with) a huge number 
of younger people experimenting with drugs and a new culture. It's not as 
enjoyable to people who have been going out a long time."

But if there is a growing generation gap among ravers, drug use is not 
necessarily the issue. Many dance enthusiasts of all ages argue that drug 
abuse is no more prevalent in their scene than it is in many other social 
contexts. The scene, they say, has always celebrated the euphoria of high- 
energy music and the welcoming diversity of the "tribal gatherings."

"Anyone who has been to a 49ers or Raiders game lately can tell you that 
there are more fights, injuries and ejections there than at any rave," said 
Tomas Palermo, editor of San Francisco's XLR8R Magazine, which covers the 
dance scene.


CANCELLATIONS BRING LAWSUITS

Promoter Coolworld, which declined comment, has hosted past events marred 
by busy paramedics and multiple arrests, primarily for the sale of 
marijuana and ecstasy. The promoter is suing Santa Clara County for 
canceling events booked into the County Fairgrounds in summer 2000, 
according to Deputy County Counsel Gregory Sebastinelli.

In canceling the shows, the county cited the "predictable and widespread 
use of illegal drugs by crowds, including thousands of juveniles" at 
earlier Coolworld events. The New Year's Eve event at the Cow Palace was 
open to all ages.

Representatives of one safety advocacy group, DanceSafe, say they are 
increasingly forbidden to set up booths at commercial events by promoters 
mindful of any suggestion that there might be drugs on the premises.

Instead of prohibiting events, authorities should concentrate on enhancing 
safeguards, argued John Wood, legal analyst for the San Francisco Late 
Night Coalition.

"There's a chain reaction that occurs. Rather than intelligent policy, it 
leads to authorities trying to take away people's rights to gather.

"I don't feel that it's in the interest of the city to do that, because 
then people are gathering in unpermitted parties. They don't go home. They 
don't stop trying to have a good time. And if they're going to do drugs, 
they're going to do them."

Chronicle reporter Chuck Squatriglia contributed to this report. / E-mail 
James Sullivan at jamessullivan@sfchronicle.com.

  http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/01/04/MN169659.DTL



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_10281810==_.ALT--

Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Hi there, guys...

        I was really worried about this article, especially after
all of our discussions and remembering all of the trouble that came
about with ppl from the scene trusting 20/20, ABC and other such
major media outlets in the past.  Personally, I thought that this
was one of the most fair articles that I've read in a long time,
with outstanding quotes from our scene being featured quite
prominently.

    It did not focus on the drug-rave connection; rather it made
great inroads at dispelling that relationship myth and showing how
it is not any different than the drug/alcohol relationship at any
other large event.  Barry's quote and Thomas Palermo's quote are
some of the best one's printed by others in our scene in a long
time.  Sunshine Jones' quote also pointed out a very important
distinction that needed to be told to the general public between
what we now consider "raves" and large, mainstream dance parties.
Makes me proud of our scene here in SF.

    The absolute tragedy of the two deaths, however, bears a heavy
cloud on all of this optimism.  Take care...







     Ward Kadel
  <<<dr_XeNo>>>
drXeNo@drxeno.net
   www.drxeno.net

Breathe SF
www.djhoj.com/breathe/

Jondi&Spesh
Looq Records
www.looq.com

Big-buck raves not all the rage to veterans
New Year's chaos proves dangers of excess, they say

James Sullivan, Chronicle Pop Culture Critic   Saturday, January 4,
2003

--------------------------------------------------------------------
------------

have drawn into sharp focus the generation gap between old raves and
the

The rave scene was created largely in the Bay Area by a network of
devoted

galleries.

Michael

at

nightclub in San Francisco that hosts many state-of-the-art events
with
disc jockeys.

"There's a big difference between going to a dance party where you
feel a
great connection to everyone -- and yeah, maybe a few people are
high, but
they're not causing problems -- as opposed to (an event with) a huge
number
of younger people experimenting with drugs and a new culture. It's
not as
enjoyable to people who have been going out a long time."

But if there is a growing generation gap among ravers, drug use is
not
necessarily the issue. Many dance enthusiasts of all ages argue that
drug
abuse is no more prevalent in their scene than it is in many other
social
contexts. The scene, they say, has always celebrated the euphoria of
high-
energy music and the welcoming diversity of the "tribal gatherings."

"Anyone who has been to a 49ers or Raiders game lately can tell you
that
there are more fights, injuries and ejections there than at any
rave," said
Tomas Palermo, editor of San Francisco's XLR8R Magazine, which
covers the
dance scene.


CANCELLATIONS BRING LAWSUITS

Promoter Coolworld, which declined comment, has hosted past events
marred
by busy paramedics and multiple arrests, primarily for the sale of
marijuana and ecstasy. The promoter is suing Santa Clara County for
canceling events booked into the County Fairgrounds in summer 2000,
according to Deputy County Counsel Gregory Sebastinelli.

In canceling the shows, the county cited the "predictable and
widespread
use of illegal drugs by crowds, including thousands of juveniles" at
earlier Coolworld events. The New Year's Eve event at the Cow Palace
was
open to all ages.

Representatives of one safety advocacy group, DanceSafe, say they
are
increasingly forbidden to set up booths at commercial events by
promoters
mindful of any suggestion that there might be drugs on the premises.

Instead of prohibiting events, authorities should concentrate on
enhancing
safeguards, argued John Wood, legal analyst for the San Francisco
Late
Night Coalition.

"There's a chain reaction that occurs. Rather than intelligent
policy, it
leads to authorities trying to take away people's rights to gather.

"I don't feel that it's in the interest of the city to do that,
because
then people are gathering in unpermitted parties. They don't go
home. They
don't stop trying to have a good time. And if they're going to do
drugs,
they're going to do them."

Chronicle reporter Chuck Squatriglia contributed to this report. /
E-mail
James Sullivan at jamessullivan@sfchronicle.com.

  http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/01/04/MN169659.D
TL



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow,
you are
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Date: Sat, 4 Jan 2003 15:45:03 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.2.20030103182918.01b78b98@mail.sarilion.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301041436480.1017-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...


I think the issue is that promoters think it's easier to walk the party
line, which is there won't be any drugs here.  That's impossible, it's
writing a check they simply cannot cash... a gamble that this year
resulted in at least two deaths.  Adding security and on hand medical
staff is expensive, but it *increases* your probablity of getting a
permit.  Having DanceSafe at your event is free, but reduces the
probability of landing those same permits.  The issue is more municipal
government (the entities that handle permit approval) and less the
promoters themselves.

Reality is that drugs get in.  Despite searches, metal detectors, no
backpack rules, etc... "good kids" get their grubby little paws on drugs.
When good kids take good drugs, well, that's considered an issue to most
(myself included, I hate hearing about the stuff like 15 year old girls
brought in for hospital visits, it's sick).  But when good kids take bad
drugs, a second issue arises, one that can result in far more problems,
hospital visits, permanent health damage and death.

DanceSafe works in this reality based realm, in a harm reduction capacity.
We know that there is a risk associated with the judicious use of MDMA.
But it's nothing compared to the risks associated with ingestion of PMA,
DXM, and other substances used in "street E".

A cursory glance at the eyes of many people at nightclubs, raves and
"music festivals" will tell you the truth.

The same way that handing out condoms passes a certain vibe of "it's ok to
have sex", drug testing passes out a vibe of "it's ok to use drugs"... but
remember that in both cases the punishment for failing these safety checks
can be severe illness and death.  It's not what we want our kids doing,
but isn't it worth reducing the risks of such behavior if it is a
widespread issue?  Chances are an urban youth *will* be exposed to drug
use, sex, gangs and other elements.  The best way to protect them is
through a multi layer strategy of information, morality, harm reduction
and communication.  Refusing to admit that those things exist, and
blanketly stating that "drugs are bad don't take them" results in what we
have here.  I'd like to think that none of those kids thought they were
signing up for anything worse than a night of pretty lights and hanging
out with friends to pounding music, but now it's a different situation.
They died.  The end.

To anybody who thinks they are somehow better than those two guys, ask
yourself if you have every taken untested E, and ask yourself what kind of
deal you'd be making with your creator as you saw the lights going dim and
realized you might have taken something that was killing you.  Or your
friend.  Or your brother.  Or just some kid who bumped into you earlier
that night and smiled as he turned around to apologize.

It's not Coolworld's policy, it's a city-county-state policy thing.  It's
hard to get permits together for a large event, but the fact is that
policies that Coolworld agreed to because of permit pressures might have
made the difference between 2 deaths and a couple people out $20 and
feeling like suckers.

Is promoting morality more important than preserving life?
andyw

Being a veteran of 12 + years in the scene  I agree with most of this except the psychedelic part is mainly a hippie spin. If anything it was a virtual reality/computers and techno/technology thing with synthetic dance beats and sounds. the rest is a hippie spin that i'm not a part of nor did i present that in my events. buzzwords like plur was never used with us. sf is that way though, you go to l.a. and the hippie stuff is non existant. other than that i agree that these aren't even raves. true raves died in 93 imo. please don't get mad that's just how i saw it. 
 
 >Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Big-buck raves not all the rage to veterans
New Year's chaos proves dangers of excess, they say

James Sullivan, Chronicle Pop Culture Critic Saturday, January 4, 2003

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------



San Francisco -- Two deaths at a New Year's Eve dance at the Cow Palace 
have drawn into sharp focus the generation gap between old raves and the 
newer mega-events.

The rave scene was created largely in the Bay Area by a network of devoted 
revelers who merged the psychedelic and cyber eras. As raves have gone 
commercial -- in sports arenas and civic auditoriums, with vendors, ATMs 
and $5 bottles of water -- some old-schoolers have returned to the 
underground, holding rave-style parties in private residences and galleries.

The suspected overdose deaths of Peter Hoang, 19, of Stockton and Michael 
James Uveges, 23, also known as DJ Mikey Vegas, of Rohnert Park have 
heightened concerns over huge dance parties such as the New Year's Eve 
event at the Cow Palace.

The vice mayor of Daly City pledged Friday to tighten restrictions on 
future events, while defenders said such measures would drive raves back 
underground, where there are no institutionalized health and safety 
precautions.

But many veteran ravers have already returned to the underground, or at 
least to a smaller scale. They say the enormous, chaotic arena bashes -- 
10, 400 attended promoter's Coolworld's Planet New Year 2003 at the Cow 
Palace -- are a far cry from the eccentric, intimate happenings they first 
envisioned.


LOWER-KEY EVENTS PREFERRED

Grant Davis, 35, a Salt Lake City native who manages the Dimension 7 video 
gallery and serves as treasurer of the San Francisco Late Night Coalition, 
moved to the Bay Area a decade ago to take part in the burgeoning, wildly 
creative rave scene. The size and mall-style atmosphere of today's large 
dance events hold little attraction for him.

"I honestly can't say I've been to a big event like that in a number of 
years."

His generation of ravers, he said, prefers their gatherings a little lower- 
key these days. "People my age don't need it to be so flashy, so loud."

As raves, first held in remote fields and abandoned warehouses, have gone 
mainstream in recent years, they have attracted a younger clientele.

That mainstreaming is precisely the turnoff for Sunshine Jones, whose 
raving dates back to the '80s. For him, there is little connection between 
the early clandestine dance parties and the huge aboveground events of today.

" 'Rave' as a concept was 10 years ago," said Jones, who runs a San 
Francisco record company, Imperial Dub Records, with his wife, Moonbeam. 
The New Year's Eve event at the Cow Palace "was just a big event," he said. 
"It wasn't a rave."

Many elements of raves -- the sternum-thumping beats, the visual stimuli -- 
remain in place from the early days. But for some of the old-schoolers, the 
organizing principle of "plur" (peace, love, unity, respect) has become 
just another selling point.

Once the events become "that pop or commercial," said Davis, "the whole 
'plur' thing becomes a commodity item, to sell the event. It definitely 
doesn't have that kind of idealism anymore."


DRUG CONNOTATIONS IN 'RAVE'

The term "rave" itself is becoming outdated. Promoters and venue operators 
are downplaying the word, which has taken on drug-related connotations over 
the years.

Michael Wegher, general manager of the Cow Palace, said he wouldn't 
categorize the New Year's Eve event as a rave at all. "It was booked as a 
youth festival. This was a mainstream event."

Barry Synoground is general manager of the DNA Lounge, the 11th Street 
nightclub in San Francisco that hosts many state-of-the-art events with 
disc jockeys.

"There's a big difference between going to a dance party where you feel a 
great connection to everyone -- and yeah, maybe a few people are high, but 
they're not causing problems -- as opposed to (an event with) a huge number 
of younger people experimenting with drugs and a new culture. It's not as 
enjoyable to people who have been going out a long time."

But if there is a growing generation gap among ravers, drug use is not 
necessarily the issue. Many dance enthusiasts of all ages argue that drug 
abuse is no more prevalent in their scene than it is in many other social 
contexts. The scene, they say, has always celebrated the euphoria of high- 
energy music and the welcoming diversity of the "tribal gatherings."

"Anyone who has been to a 49ers or Raiders game lately can tell you that 
there are more fights, injuries and ejections there than at any rave," said 
Tomas Palermo, editor of San Francisco's XLR8R Magazine, which covers the 
dance scene.


CANCELLATIONS BRING LAWSUITS

Promoter Coolworld, which declined comment, has hosted past events marred 
by busy paramedics and multiple arrests, primarily for the sale of 
marijuana and ecstasy. The promoter is suing Santa Clara County for 
canceling events booked into the County Fairgrounds in summer 2000, 
according to Deputy County Counsel Gregory Sebastinelli.

In canceling the shows, the county cited the "predictable and widespread 
use of illegal drugs by crowds, including thousands of juveniles" at 
earlier Coolworld events. The New Year's Eve event at the Cow Palace was 
open to all ages.

Representatives of one safety advocacy group, DanceSafe, say they are 
increasingly forbidden to set up booths at commercial events by promoters 
mindful of any suggestion that there might be drugs on the premises.

Instead of prohibiting events, authorities should concentrate on enhancing 
safeguards, argued John Wood, legal analyst for the San Francisco Late 
Night Coalition.

"There's a chain reaction that occurs. Rather than intelligent policy, it 
leads to authorities trying to take away people's rights to gather.

"I don't feel that it's in the interest of the city to do that, because 
then people are gathering in unpermitted parties. They don't go home. They 
don't stop trying to have a good time. And if they're going to do drugs, 
they're going to do them."

Chronicle reporter Chuck Squatriglia contributed to this report. / E-mail 
James Sullivan at jamessullivan@sfchronicle.com.

http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/01/04/MN169659.DTL

At 12:36 PM 1/4/2003 -0800, dr_XeNo wrote:
>Hi there, guys...
>
>         I was really worried about this article, especially after
>all of our discussions and remembering all of the trouble that came
>about with ppl from the scene trusting 20/20, ABC and other such
>major media outlets in the past.  Personally, I thought that this
>was one of the most fair articles that I've read in a long time,
>with outstanding quotes from our scene being featured quite
>prominently.

I was initially fearful when I opened the paper this morning and found the 
article on the front page.  I agree, however, that this journalism was the 
most objective I've seen on the subject in some time.

I came into raving through the Wicked FMRs ten years ago.  Wonder what I 
would have thought of the community if my entry point was the commercial 
massives.  There are many houses in the general dance community,  and I 
believe philosophically that it's good for everyone, young and old, to 
dance.  I wish, however, that pre-college age kids had better options than 
large commercial dance festivals.  I came to raving after nearly twenty 
years in club culture and raving for me was an energizing and 
transformative experience -- a welcome break from the booze and booty 
focus.  Things changed when the FMRs went from a couple hundred on the 
beach to thousands.  I doubt I would have become the radical devotee of the 
raving scene that I am if my first party was a 10,000 person event.

I do see the massives as a possible entry point for many into the more 
intimate, underground parties.  There will always be those who become bored 
and/or disenchanted with the commercial scene and find their way to the 
underground driven by curiosity and their passion for the music and 
dance.  That's why I believe in keeping the ug all ages.  We should welcome 
those who diligently search for more.

Massives are mass market EDM, and that is fine and American.  But to throw 
massives one must adhere to majority beliefs about drug use which eschews 
harm reduction for abstinence and operates, as in the sexual arena, on 
beliefs that are dangerously unrealistic.  When problems occur, as they 
will, all of the dance community suffers.  This is a larger societal issue 
of course, but the blame falls in our laps.  Harm reduction and treatment 
programs for abuse are rational approaches to this issue but we, 
unfortunately, don't live in a reasonable society.

Love,

Apollo

events are more on a larger scale, but who else brings out that kind of 
talent?  Obviously none of the smaller collectives/promoters don't.  Why?  I

festivals.  These festivals solely rotate around "electronica/techno" music.

promoters who throw the same type of event, but different genre of music.

them for stuff they can not control.  Ridicule them for not allowing "dance 
safe" into their event. blah blah blah.  People it really is getting old.  I 
know half of you don't even go to "massive festivals" simply because of what 
goes on at these type of events.  The people that do go on the other hand

>Being a veteran of 12 + years in the scene  I agree with most of this 
>except the psychedelic part is mainly a hippie spin. If anything it was a 
>virtual reality/computers and techno/technology thing with synthetic dance 
>beats and sounds. the rest is a hippie spin that i'm not a part of nor did 
>i present that in my events. buzzwords like plur was never used with us. 
>sf is that way though, you go to l.a. and the hippie stuff is non 
>existant. other than that i agree that these aren't even raves. true raves 
>died in 93 imo. please don't get mad that's just how i saw it.

Ha...I'm beyond quibbling with terms these days.  They are only meaningful 
when one is under attack:)  I throw non-profit, unpermitted parties for the 
love of it.  Call them undergrounds, call them "saves"...no matter.  Point 
is, the motivation is not commercial but, rather, to create free spaces 
where people can celebrate life through EDM and dance.  Hippies, techno 
rebels, candy kids, virtual reality freaks, insurance salesmen, and 
everyone else is welcome if they wish to dance in a respectful, peaceful 
environment.  The term PLUR wasn't around at the time of the Wicked or 
Moonshine FMRs, but the vibe they represented were IMHO.  Hell, all this is 
evolutionary...

Love,

Apollo

"Compound Records San Francisco will be closing its doors for business on

support during the last four years and ask that you keep watching us for
bigger and better projects coming soon. From now until Jan 24 everything in
our inventory will be 60% off (12.s, EPs, LPs, CDs). This means all 12"
singles are $3.99!! We also just finished taking inventory so our online
stock is now completely accurate. Questions and comments may be directed to
info@compoundrecords.com. 

Thanks once again, 
Compound Records"

From: DJ Pat <djpat@dj-pat.com>
Organization: TEKNIQUE
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.0.1) Gecko/20020823 Netscape/7.0

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: Aaron Dixon <aaronhdixon@hotmail.com>
CC:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <F62oO7SACagnzGZkKbI0000379d@hotmail.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Jan 2003 03:42:53.0176 (UTC) FILETIME=[86DAF780:01C2B46C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

You make some good points, and I'm not speaking for everybody here, but 
it would seem as though the current situation is a little bit different. 
 Yes bad things happen at all large scale events, regardless of their 
purpose.  Its just a fact of life when masses of people get together, 
shit happens.  

However, I don't see the media portraying rock concerts, hip hop shows 
or sporting events in the same light that they shine on the EDM scene. 
 The simple fact of the matter is that the massive promoters have 
hijacked something and turned it into something it was never meant to 
be, nor capable of being, and the result has been a nonstop train of 
disasters.  When bad things happen at a big rock show, you don't see 
senators up on their podiums thumping their fists and condeming all rock 
shows, big and small alike, as being death traps and drug havens that 
they must rid the world of.  

The reason massive promoters in the EDM scene get criticism when shit 
goes wrong at their events, while other massive promoters of other 
entertainment media don't get criticised, is probably an answer to a 
question that nobody will fully be able to answer, but trying to 
analogize the situation isn't going to make things any easier to 
explain.  Massives are not raves, yet the 'rave' scene is who ends up 
dealing with their disasters.  I personally am tired of going through 
hell to get a permit for a party, just because some druggies died at a 
kewlworld event, and I'm sure a lot of other people are too.  I 
personally don't think that there is anything inherently wrong with a 
kewlworld type event (hell I've even played at one) but as long as 
stupid people do stupid things at their shows and WE (as in 
real/ug/[your word here] ravers) get the finger pointed at us, people 
will bitch.  Crticicism of koolworld might not exactly be waranted, as 
they aren't the ones that got fucked up and died, but then again 
criticism of the 'rave' scene by the media/authorities isn't waranted 
either, as these deaths didn't even happen at a 'rave'....

As far as massive-attendees criticizing smaller collectives, what 
possibly could they have bad to say about them?  Other than they haven't 
been lucky enough to attend one of their events, I can't imagine anybody 
having anything bad to say about a smallish/UG type party or the crews 
that put them on.  Certainly they aren't going to be complaining about 
how there are deaths now days at every little UG, because that doesn't 
happen.  But for some strange reason it does seem to happen at every big 
show these days...

Keep it Wet & Hard...
XXX,
p a t

yeah, yeah, me too...
    I have been partying (raving) for about four years and my first party 
was a Harmony Massive at the 2nd and Jackson venue in Oaktown.  Does anybody 
else remember that party b/c it was off the chain!  I went with DJ 
Drag'nfly, Terry, Shanebo, and bunch of other cool ass cats.  It was the 
moment I stopped ditching school and doing massive amounts of 
self-destructing narcotics.  Raves and the rave community has absolutely 
changed my life for the better.  Some love me and some hate me, and believe 
you me, there are those who do both at the same time.  I go to school at 
SFSU and I turn 21 in a month and a half.  I hope y'all will come out and 
celebrate with a brotha.  Anyway, I guess I'll thrown down a little more 
about me now:  I love electronica.  I started listening to trance, moved 
onto a house phase, and now I am adicted to Jungle, Trance, and House.  I go 
to school at SFSU and I am currently single (wink, wink).  Dancing is my 
drug and love is my philosophy.  Email me if you want to meet up and party 
as a cohesive unit.  Lots of love and little pinch on the butt.  -Trendy 
Mormon Boy, aka Malacai, aka Joe.

--0-572537446-1041742691=:34472

>Hippies, techno rebels, candy kids, virtual reality freaks,

Perhaps i'm being anal but words are important to me. 'rebels' reffered to 'house rebels' which was not a "big" part of the rave scene in it's glory days. Techno was the dominant force which pushed it. Now i'm not even into techno anymore so bash away. The point is that these things likes house rebels, candy kids and that sort of crap is what really started to happen when the scene was deteriorating. That''s what we witnessed anyway.  Things get too big, a bandwagon happens. The virtual reality aspect leaves and you're left with "play dough" tables, candy beads and people looking just wearing pants down to their ankles, you know the scene has been over already. I'm not stuck in the past, oh no, but those are facts that happend. 

>insurance salesmen, and everyone else is welcome if they wish to dance in a respectful, peaceful environment.  The term PLUR wasn't around at the time of the Wicked or Moonshine FMRs, but the vibe they represented were IMHO.  Hell, all this is evolutionary...

 

personally i'd like to see a little more reality put back into them but unfortunatly i can only work on myself and not the majority of promoters.

Subject: [sfraves] poem nrr

i thought i knew where i was going
i thought i knew where it was
then i started to get tired
then i realized i need a buzz
i looked at the map, before coffee
i found that i might get lost
i wanted to write an excuse note
then i thought, maybe not
maybe i will not wear latex
maybe i will not be late
maybe i might arrive early
but i doubt it at any rate
i just hope that i won't get in trouble
i just hope that i won't fall asleep
and i hope that if i don't make it
that you won't get pissed by my cheap poem, follower:)

   | free before 10pm. $5 after.

......................................................
who----------------|Shane Knapp

John, i can see by your tone of your email that your out to make a point and your point is that Coolworld is a bunch of liers and we shouldnt be believed right?
I can also tell that you PERSONALLY do not like Coolworld so anything you say or feel is going to be slightly biased.
So in short, I answered your concerns below. 
 
 "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
I find it amusring that coolworld will come on SFRaves and try to spread
bold-faced lies about DanceSafe, when it's no secret that more than a few
current and ex volunteers read and post, and one currently active DS volunteer
IS a pretty regular SFRaver.

 

---CW---> Coolworld is not spreading bold faced lies and were also very aware that their are members from all parts of the community, not just dance safe. This list is pretty old and i would imagine there is a little of everyone on this forum.



I've been a volunteer with DanceSafe for just over a year and a half now. And
both Alida and Carter are correct. Pill testing is legal. It's controversial,
yes. But it *IS* legal. Coolworld was flat out 100% lieing when they said
otherwise.

 

---CW--> Thats an incorrect statement. Hands Down. You should do more research so that you can furnish actual legality rather then what "you've been told". Again, Coolworld doesnt have to Flat out lie, simply because Coolworld managment has had a tremendous amount of police interaction and has a pretty good understanding of whats legal vs liable vs. moral.



Carter is correct. No volunteer at a DanceSafe table is EVER knowingly in
possetion of a controlled substance. The testing procedure, to which ALL
chapters and volunteers MUST adhere, explicitly states that the pill is
scraped, returned to the raver, and then and ONLY then is the test performed. 
The test destroys the sample. Thus we never knowingly posses ANY drug, real or
fake. ALL chapters and volunteers MUST adhere to this procedure, the whole
point of which is to avoid breaking the law and shield us from liability. If
anyone fails to do so, they are expelled from the organization.

 

---CW--> Although you make a technical statement, the fact of the matter is that law enforcement views that as one of the same thing. Your best bet is to stop calling Coolworld a bunch of liers and Call the DALY CITY Police department yourselves. Then call the cow palace. The you can report back to sfraves and tell us what they told you.



Do you really think that we could exist as an incorperated organization (a
fully certified 501(c)3 non=profit even) if we hadn't consulted with legal
council about this point?

 

---CW--> your existance is based on harm reduction and Coolworld supports that. We offer Dance Safe a Space @ any of our events to had out liteature.



If pill testing were "illegal", as coolworld claims, then why were we
pill-testing out in the open, in full view of the public, and with the full
support of the committee AND the district attorney during ALL of Pride
(including the circuit party) this year? What about at the Castro and Folsom
fairs, again in full view of the public and any patrolling police. What about
at the innumerable other raves where pill testing was allowed. None of this is
in dispute. At Pride, the committee even advretised the pill testing service
for us in the Pride 2002 guide book, and gave us a choice spot in the parade
(yeah... my goofy ass was on TV...)!

 

---CW--> I'm not sure what your circumstances were at pride as Coolworld was not apart of that festivity. I can assure you that we are not allowed to have pill testing at the cow palace, which is a whole other animal.



FACT: DanceSafe has never been alowed to pill-test at a coolworld event
because COOLWORLD refuses to allow it. The buck stops there, nowhere else.

So long as I've been involved with the organization, DanceSafe has only been
allowed into ONE coolworld party, that being LAST year's PNY. And even THEN it
was only due to the incessant and heroic efforts of one of our LOCAL promoters,
with whom coolworld had partnered that time around.

I was one of the volunteers working that one, actually. Though you may not
have seen us. Coolworld stuck us in an obscure corner of one of the secondary
rooms. End even though we were there, all sorts of ridiculous restrictions
were placed on us. For example, we were only allowed to distribute durex brand
condoms (one of our volunteers had to sort through ALL of our free condoms,
picking out and discarding all of the non-durex ones). And pill testing, and
even sales of testing kits, was strictly verboten.

Personally, that experience was the final straw for me (granted, with their
unbroken recored of lies, deciet, and exploitation I didn't exactly have a
positive view of them, even going into that one), guaranteeing that I will
never ever set foot in a coolworld "event" for ANY reason. They just don't care
about anything except extracting every last possible dollar from the rave
scene. And if someone has to die for them to get that dollar, so be it.

It's important to note that this IS my personal opinion tho, not chapter
policy. DS is there for ALL ravers, even those who support coolworld's
actions. And the SF chapter will be wherever there are ravers, *IF* the
promoters ask and/or allow us.

 

---CW--> John, maybe you shouldnt be so quick to judge Coolworld since you really dont know any of the local codes and you have no idea of what were able to perform at the cow palace. Your whole email was based on the liitle bit of knowledge you have and your own personal biased opinions of Coolworld. Even going as far as saying we stuck you in a "Far obscure corner of the building" as if Coolworld has something against dance safe. Please john, thats ridiculous....we have nothing against Dance Safe.

 

--CW--> I would ask people not to distort the facts. Which at this moment there are still very little facts known other then these two young men died of a drug overdose (and that still has to be determined by the toxicology reports). 

 

--CW--> What if these two people died from something else? like GHB? or another drug? then what will you say? Everyone seems to be ASSUMING that these guys died from exstacy which we dont even know? How can we debate what dance safe could of tested if we dont even know what they took? Again, theres ACTUAL DATE and EMOTIONAL DATA. Dont be so quick to judge until you have the facts.

 

respect,

COOLWORLD

 

 




cya,
john

Received: (qmail 23909 invoked from network); 6 Jan 2003 01:28:46 -0000
From: JonnyR@aol.com
Message-ID: <154.19ebc0a9.2b4a35cf@aol.com>
Date: Sun, 5 Jan 2003 20:28:47 EST
To: cwpsf@yahoo.com, SFRaves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_154.19ebc0a9.2b4a35cf_boundary"
X-Mailer: AOL 8.0 for Windows US sub 230
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Suggested compromise, if Dance Safe can't conduct pill testing 

--part1_154.19ebc0a9.2b4a35cf_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hello, I just wanted to suggest that, if Dance Safe is prohibited from 
testing pills at parties, perhaps they could offer some different type of 
literature to distribute. I do feel that they should be able to conduct pill 
testing, but if the venue prohibits it, maybe a new kind of flyer would help 
a little. 

Here's what I'm thinking: in addition to the glossy, informational flyers 
that they distribute, how about a photocopied "cheat sheet" describing the 
pills that have been in recent circulation? Of course there would have to be 
an appropriate disclaimer saying use is not condoned, and there is no 
guarantee that people won't issue counterfeit versions, BUT at least there 
would be a chance to tell people, "Please stay away from the [red / yellow / 
blue] 'whatevers' -- they're a mix of MDA and ketamine and don't even contain 
any MDMA."
Tell the parents, this isn't very different from Wavy Gravy at Woodstock, 
warning the kids that there was a lot of bad brown acid around. "And if 
you're going to take it, just have half a tab."  
I think that if the word gets around that a certain pill is bad, it stops 
showing up. That's what happened a few years back when those DXM Green 
Triangles were around. Dance Safe publicized how bad they were, and they went 
away. 

So, if it just isn't possible to have testing at  a party, I think Dance Safe 
should at least be able to give out info saying which are the bad pills. They 
could show people color printouts and then partiers could just see for 
themselves, without the potential legal issues of actual testing. Maybe a 
whiteboard, like they had at the Megga Buzz campout, that described what was 
around and whether it was bunk.

I hope my ideas have some potential for increasing public health & safety 
without increasing anybody's liability.

[As Cool World points out, we don't even know if pills have anything to do 
with the two unfortunate deaths at Planet NY. I've heard ER doctors say that 
complications due to e alone are fairly rare; GHB and/or alcohol are often 
involved, though. On New Year's Eve, I would not be surprised if people mix 
alcohol with drugs.  Please be safe, everyone.] 
John in Berkeley

--part1_154.19ebc0a9.2b4a35cf_boundary--

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

Look, you've obviously repeated your little "pill testing is illegal" lie
enough times that even you believe it.  But that doesn't make it true.

Frankly, I don't care what you think the cops say.  I actually HAVE talked to a
LAWYER on the issue, and been informed that, yes, it IS legal for me to test
someone's pill via the DanceSafe procedure.  You know the difference between a
cop and a lawyer, yes?  One is a knuckle-dragger mostly concerned with beating
non-white people over the head, and believes that the "law" is whatever strikes
its whimsey that day.  The other is a professional who spends the better part
of a decade learning the actual LAW inside and out, and is rigorously tested on
the facts before being allowed by the Bar Asscoiation before being allowed to
practice.

And yes, when I did consult, I WAS told that what I was doing was legal and
that the chances that I'd EVER be prosecuted were so miniscule that I could
mostly ignore them.  And that if anybody ever DID try to prosecute, any
competent defence attorney could get any charges dropped almost instantly.  I
see no reason at all why said advice wouldn't apply to EVERY DanceSafe
volunteer.

So, either my old lawyer (who can be censured, disbarred, or even prosecuted if
proven to have given deceptive council) is a liar; or you (who has no
accountability, and a record as the most exploitave promoter in the scene, with
a years-long string of lies) is.  I wonder whom?

As for Pride, even WE were concerned that pill-testing might not go over so
well.  But we were invited by the Pride committee with the specific request
that pill-testing be done.  When we voiced our concerns, the committee brought
the issue to the districe attorney, Terence Hallinan (you know... the guy who
would be prosecuting any DanceSafe volunteer if pill-testing WERE, as you
claim, illegal.  Mr. Hallinan, at the behest of the Pride committee, actually
took the step of contacting US, and assuring us that pill-testing *IS* legal,
that the government fully supports harm reduction, and that none of us, NOR
anyone who came to have their pills tested, would be prosecuted.  We had this
in a written statemwnt that we posted at the booth for all to see.

So, I can take the word of both my old lawyer AND the district attorney; or I
can believe coolworld.  Hmmmm...


cya,
john

Well... you may have a point that I shouldn't have injected so much of my
personal opinion into my first post on that topic.   But deliberately spreading
falsehood and lies is one of the most loathesome and contemptable things I can
think of.  And coolworld was trying to tarnish the reputation, by lieing about
us, of an organization of which I am quite fond, and which I believe does very
positive and helpful work.

Fact is:  I caught coolworld in a lie, and I called them on it.

And if you go through the archives of SFRaves, you'll find me doing the very
same thing on a variety of topics, from stuff drug related (like heroin in
pills) to technical issues (what sort of kernel Mac OS X is built upon).  Whan
I've caught people spreading lies on topics with which I am familiar, I've
slapped them down.

Sometimes, yes, maybe I've been too harsh.  On at least a couple of occasions I
was so harsh that I felt bad about it and apologised later.  But seperating out
the emotions, I still don't think that any apology was really called for. 
Maybe it's just a pet peeve of mine.  It's hard as hell for me to hold a grudge
and take most things personallt.  And a lot of things are easy for me to
forgive.  But lies and deciet are not among them.

I'll go ahead and quit posting on the PNY topics.  If coolworld wants to have
the last word they're welcome to it.  All I ask now, is that people check the
facts before believing any more lies that they try to spread.  Everything I
have said wrt/ DanceSafe is fully public information that you could get either
from our public websites, or by having observed the booths (especially the one
at Pride) in the past.


cya,
john



Aaron Dixon wrote:

> I don't get it?  Why must we always criticize coolworld after every 
> damn rave/festival they throw?  We all know that the same stuff is 
> going to happen each and every rave/festival they throw.  This event 
> oh so sadly ended in death.  Which is VERY unfortunate.  Trust me I am 
> no way shape or form associated with/wanting to be associated with 
> coolworld.  I am just dissapointed in some of you.  You guys 
> constantly say that you are in it for the "scene", the "scene" this, 
> the "scene" that, I am protecting the scene blah blah blah....Why is 
> it that you always criticize the massive promoters?  All they are 
> trying to do is host an event that WE(yes, you and i SFRaves) can go 
> to and dance our asses off to some great music.  Sure coolworld's 
> events are more on a larger scale, but who else brings out that kind 
> of talent?  Obviously none of the smaller collectives/promoters 
> don't.  Why?  I don't know.  When you get 10,000+ people under one 
> roof havok will evolve.  It's just like high school.  Try and fuse the 
> freshmans and the seniors together.  It won't work.
> Coolworld in reality doesn't throw "raves", but throw massive music 
> festivals.  These festivals solely rotate around "electronica/techno" 
> music.  Look at woodstock, look at up in smoke tour, look at all the 
> massive promoters who throw the same type of event, but different 
> genre of music.  Why, why, why must we always critique promoters in 
> the rave scene.  Ridicule them for stuff they can not control.  
> Ridicule them for not allowing "dance safe" into their event. blah 
> blah blah.  People it really is getting old.  I know half of you don't 
> even go to "massive festivals" simply because of what goes on at these 
> type of events.  The people that do go on the other hand don't 
> criticize smaller collectives for throwing parties.  Do they?
>
>
> thanks for reading.....

> peace,
> Aaron

<BR>
<BR>
<BR>
Look, you've obviously repeated your little "pill testing is illegal" lie<BR>
enough times that even you believe it.&nbsp; But that doesn't make it true.<BR>
<BR>
Frankly, I don't care what you think the cops say.&nbsp; I actually HAVE talked to a<BR>
LAWYER on the issue, and been informed that, yes, it IS legal for me to test<BR>
someone's pill via the DanceSafe procedure.&nbsp; You know the difference between a<BR>
cop and a lawyer, yes?&nbsp; One is a knuckle-dragger mostly concerned with beating<BR>
non-white people over the head, and believes that the "law" is whatever strikes<BR>
its whimsey that day.&nbsp; The other is a professional who spends the better part<BR>
of a decade learning the actual LAW inside and out, and is rigorously tested on<BR>
the facts before being allowed by the Bar Asscoiation before being allowed to<BR>
practice.<BR>
<BR>
And yes, when I did consult, I WAS told that what I was doing was legal and<BR>
that the chances that I'd EVER be prosecuted were so miniscule that I could<BR>
mostly ignore them.&nbsp; And that if anybody ever DID try to prosecute, any<BR>
competent defence attorney could get any charges dropped almost instantly.&nbsp; I<BR>
see no reason at all why said advice wouldn't apply to EVERY DanceSafe<BR>
volunteer.<BR>
<BR>
So, either my old lawyer (who can be censured, disbarred, or even prosecuted if<BR>
proven to have given deceptive council) is a liar; or you (who has no<BR>
accountability, and a record as the most exploitave promoter in the scene, with<BR>
a years-long string of lies) is.&nbsp; I wonder whom?<BR>
<BR>
As for Pride, even WE were concerned that pill-testing might not go over so<BR>
well.&nbsp; But we were invited by the Pride committee with the specific request<BR>
that pill-testing be done.&nbsp; When we voiced our concerns, the committee brought<BR>
the issue to the districe attorney, Terence Hallinan (you know... the guy who<BR>
would be prosecuting any DanceSafe volunteer if pill-testing WERE, as you<BR>
claim, illegal.&nbsp; Mr. Hallinan, at the behest of the Pride committee, actually<BR>
took the step of contacting US, and assuring us that pill-testing *IS* legal,<BR>
that the government fully supports harm reduction, and that none of us, NOR<BR>
anyone who came to have their pills tested, would be prosecuted.&nbsp; We had this<BR>
in a written statemwnt that we posted at the booth for all to see.<BR>
<BR>
So, I can take the word of both my old lawyer AND the district attorney; or I<BR>
can believe coolworld.&nbsp; Hmmmm...<BR>
<BR>
<BR>
cya,<BR>
john<BR>
<BR>
<BR>

&gt;---CW--&gt; Although you make a technical statement, the fact of the matter is<BR>
&gt;that law enforcement views that as one of the same thing. Your best bet is to<BR>
&gt;stop calling Coolworld a bunch of liers and Call the DALY CITY Police<BR>
&gt;department yourselves. Then call the cow palace. The you can report back to<BR>
&gt;sfraves and tell us what they told you.<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;Do you really think that we could exist as an incorperated organization (a<BR>
&gt;fully certified 501(c)3 non=profit even) if we hadn't consulted with legal<BR>
&gt;council about this point?<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt; <BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;---CW--&gt; your existance is based on harm reduction and Coolworld supports<BR>
&gt;that. We offer Dance Safe a Space @ any of our events to had out liteature.<BR>

&gt;<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;If pill testing were "illegal", as coolworld claims, then why were we<BR>
&gt;pill-testing out in the open, in full view of the public, and with the full<BR>
&gt;support of the committee AND the district attorney during ALL of Pride<BR>
&gt;(including the circuit party) this year? What about at the Castro and Folsom<BR>
&gt;fairs, again in full view of the public and any patrolling police. What about<BR>
&gt;at the innumerable other raves where pill testing was allowed. None of this<BR>
&gt;is<BR>
&gt;in dispute. At Pride, the committee even advretised the pill testing service<BR>
&gt;for us in the Pride 2002 guide book, and gave us a choice spot in the parade<BR>
&gt;(yeah... my goofy ass was on TV...)!<BR>

&gt;---CW--&gt; I'm not sure what your circumstances were at pride as Coolworld was<BR>
&gt;not apart of that festivity. I can assure you that we are not allowed to have<BR>

Subject: [sfraves] dancesafe and [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

I have talked to a narcotics office about this subject in depth. And
after the debate went on and on, this is what I gathered. 


-testing the pill is not illegal. But taking the pill and then giving it
back is. Basically, he said, dancefsafe is giving the pill back, and
that is what is putting them in violation. 

"if you handed the gun to the bank robber as he walked into the bank,
after the bank is robbed, would you be an assessory?"

Basically to have a pill is illegal. To distribute is illegal. And those
two are needed to test the drug. Also possession of mdma does not have a
minimum amount, so that little amount would be seen as possession in the
eyes of an officer. 


And when I brought up the argument about dirty needle trading and how
the government allows that. He brought up the fact that those laws were
passed due to an obvious epidemic. And that when deaths to dirty club
drugs reaches epidemic levels, it would make it easier to pass similar
laws. But that just fuels the law enforcement stance to shut down the
arenas used to take these potentially dirty drugs. So we an in turn,
shooting ourselves in the foot by wanting to have pill testing for bad
illegal drugs while trying to have parties that aren't about the drugs,
which is illegal. 



That was at least a narcotics officers standpoint. 

-andy

-----Original Message-----
From: Coolworld [mailto:cwpsf@yahoo.com]
