Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...


John, i can see by your tone of your email that your out to make a point
and your point is that Coolworld is a bunch of liers and we shouldnt be
believed right?
I can also tell that you PERSONALLY do not like Coolworld so anything
you say or feel is going to be slightly biased.
So in short, I answered your concerns below. 
 
 "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
I find it amusring that coolworld will come on SFRaves and try to spread
bold-faced lies about DanceSafe, when it's no secret that more than a
few
current and ex volunteers read and post, and one currently active DS
volunteer
IS a pretty regular SFRaver.

 

---CW---> Coolworld is not spreading bold faced lies and were also very
aware that their are members from all parts of the community, not just
dance safe. This list is pretty old and i would imagine there is a
little of everyone on this forum.



I've been a volunteer with DanceSafe for just over a year and a half
now. And
both Alida and Carter are correct. Pill testing is legal. It's
controversial,
yes. But it *IS* legal. Coolworld was flat out 100% lieing when they
said
otherwise.

 

---CW--> Thats an incorrect statement. Hands Down. You should do more
research so that you can furnish actual legality rather then what
"you've been told". Again, Coolworld doesnt have to Flat out lie, simply
because Coolworld managment has had a tremendous amount of police
interaction and has a pretty good understanding of whats legal vs liable
vs. moral.



Carter is correct. No volunteer at a DanceSafe table is EVER knowingly
in
possetion of a controlled substance. The testing procedure, to which ALL
chapters and volunteers MUST adhere, explicitly states that the pill is
scraped, returned to the raver, and then and ONLY then is the test
performed. 
The test destroys the sample. Thus we never knowingly posses ANY drug,
real or
fake. ALL chapters and volunteers MUST adhere to this procedure, the
whole
point of which is to avoid breaking the law and shield us from
liability. If
anyone fails to do so, they are expelled from the organization.

 

---CW--> Although you make a technical statement, the fact of the matter
is that law enforcement views that as one of the same thing. Your best
bet is to stop calling Coolworld a bunch of liers and Call the DALY CITY
Police department yourselves. Then call the cow palace. The you can
report back to sfraves and tell us what they told you.



Do you really think that we could exist as an incorperated organization
(a
fully certified 501(c)3 non=profit even) if we hadn't consulted with
legal
council about this point?

 

---CW--> your existance is based on harm reduction and Coolworld
supports that. We offer Dance Safe a Space @ any of our events to had
out liteature.



If pill testing were "illegal", as coolworld claims, then why were we
pill-testing out in the open, in full view of the public, and with the
full
support of the committee AND the district attorney during ALL of Pride
(including the circuit party) this year? What about at the Castro and
Folsom
fairs, again in full view of the public and any patrolling police. What
about
at the innumerable other raves where pill testing was allowed. None of
this is
in dispute. At Pride, the committee even advretised the pill testing
service
for us in the Pride 2002 guide book, and gave us a choice spot in the
parade
(yeah... my goofy ass was on TV...)!

 

---CW--> I'm not sure what your circumstances were at pride as Coolworld
was not apart of that festivity. I can assure you that we are not
allowed to have pill testing at the cow palace, which is a whole other
animal.



FACT: DanceSafe has never been alowed to pill-test at a coolworld event
because COOLWORLD refuses to allow it. The buck stops there, nowhere
else.

So long as I've been involved with the organization, DanceSafe has only
been
allowed into ONE coolworld party, that being LAST year's PNY. And even
THEN it
was only due to the incessant and heroic efforts of one of our LOCAL
promoters,
with whom coolworld had partnered that time around.

I was one of the volunteers working that one, actually. Though you may
not
have seen us. Coolworld stuck us in an obscure corner of one of the
secondary
rooms. End even though we were there, all sorts of ridiculous
restrictions
were placed on us. For example, we were only allowed to distribute durex
brand
condoms (one of our volunteers had to sort through ALL of our free
condoms,
picking out and discarding all of the non-durex ones). And pill testing,
and
even sales of testing kits, was strictly verboten.

Personally, that experience was the final straw for me (granted, with
their
unbroken recored of lies, deciet, and exploitation I didn't exactly have
a
positive view of them, even going into that one), guaranteeing that I
will
never ever set foot in a coolworld "event" for ANY reason. They just
don't care
about anything except extracting every last possible dollar from the
rave
scene. And if someone has to die for them to get that dollar, so be it.

It's important to note that this IS my personal opinion tho, not chapter
policy. DS is there for ALL ravers, even those who support coolworld's
actions. And the SF chapter will be wherever there are ravers, *IF* the
promoters ask and/or allow us.

 

---CW--> John, maybe you shouldnt be so quick to judge Coolworld since
you really dont know any of the local codes and you have no idea of what
were able to perform at the cow palace. Your whole email was based on
the liitle bit of knowledge you have and your own personal biased
opinions of Coolworld. Even going as far as saying we stuck you in a
"Far obscure corner of the building" as if Coolworld has something
against dance safe. Please john, thats ridiculous....we have nothing
against Dance Safe.

 

--CW--> I would ask people not to distort the facts. Which at this
moment there are still very little facts known other then these two
young men died of a drug overdose (and that still has to be determined
by the toxicology reports). 

 

--CW--> What if these two people died from something else? like GHB? or
another drug? then what will you say? Everyone seems to be ASSUMING that
these guys died from exstacy which we dont even know? How can we debate
what dance safe could of tested if we dont even know what they took?
Again, theres ACTUAL DATE and EMOTIONAL DATA. Dont be so quick to judge
until you have the facts.

 

respect,

COOLWORLD

 

 




cya,
john

At 05:38 PM 1/5/2003, John B. wrote:

>Look, you've obviously repeated your little "pill testing is illegal" lie
>enough times that even you believe it.  But that doesn't make it true.

And you keep coming back to confront them about it, but that doesn't mean 
you are any more correct.  Pill testing may or may not be illegal, but the 
issue is, Coolworld isn't allowed to have pill testing going on at their 
event, and this comes from the local police and venue owners.  Until you 
have notarized statements from both the police and the venue owners, STFU!

>Frankly, I don't care what you think the cops say.  I actually HAVE talked 
>to a
>LAWYER on the issue, and been informed that, yes, it IS legal for me to test
>someone's pill via the DanceSafe procedure.  You know the difference between a
>cop and a lawyer, yes?  One is a knuckle-dragger mostly concerned with beating
>non-white people over the head, and believes that the "law" is whatever 
>strikes
>its whimsey that day.  The other is a professional who spends the better part
>of a decade learning the actual LAW inside and out, and is rigorously 
>tested on
>the facts before being allowed by the Bar Asscoiation before being allowed to
>practice.

You'd hold a lawyer above a cop?  I don't like Pigs myself, but I'd never 
insult a cop by making such an insinuation.  At least cops are honest 
pricks.  Furthermore, a lawyer is going to help you in court.  after you 
get arrested.  after the event gets shut down.  CW is trying to avoid that 
happening in the first place, and I applaud their logic.  It makes sense.

>So, either my old lawyer (who can be censured, disbarred, or even 
>prosecuted if
>proven to have given deceptive council) is a liar; or you (who has no
>accountability, and a record as the most exploitave promoter in the scene, 
>with
>a years-long string of lies) is.  I wonder whom?

ROFLMAO.  Yeah John, I'm sure everyone believes you're unbiased and 
truthful.  Excuse me while I go laugh some more.

>As for Pride, even WE were concerned that pill-testing might not go over so
>well.  But we were invited by the Pride committee with the specific request
>that pill-testing be done.  When we voiced our concerns, the committee brought
>the issue to the districe attorney, Terence Hallinan (you know... the guy who
>would be prosecuting any DanceSafe volunteer if pill-testing WERE, as you
>claim, illegal.  Mr. Hallinan, at the behest of the Pride committee, actually
>took the step of contacting US, and assuring us that pill-testing *IS* legal,
>that the government fully supports harm reduction, and that none of us, NOR
>anyone who came to have their pills tested, would be prosecuted.  We had this
>in a written statemwnt that we posted at the booth for all to see.

He's the DA of San Francisco, not Daly City.  You never answered my 
question: was the Pride parade a restricted event?  Were participants 
searched, or have to pay to get in?  You're comparing apples to 
trucks.  Face it, you don't have all the facts about the event, and using a 
different event in a different city is not evidence of a lie.


sarilion

Subject: [sfraves] legal / illegal... doesn't matter!!!  Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

The way i see all this is quite simple...

Regardless of whether or not Pill Testing is legal or illegal, if the venue
owner says no pill testing, then there will be no pill testing [period]!

it's that simple...

if you straight up go against what the venue owner says i am sure they would
shut it down down mid-stream... i mean, what kind of venue owner would NOT
put something like this in the Contract? and if YOU break the contract
first, you cannot sue them for shutting the event down early...

John, although i enjoyed reading this whole topic (as well as thought it to
be quite informative), i think that you wasted a whole lot of time and
breath trying to show your views... sure maybe you pointed out that pill
testing may be legal and that coolworld may be liars... but does it really
matter? when it comes down to renting a space and getting permits, you have
to abide by what the Rental Agreement / Contract says, otherwise, your event
will most certainly get shut down...

does this make sense?

Timothy
**Cheese**
itswidow@hotmail.com

real

> > fake. ALL chapters and volunteers MUST adhere to this procedure, the

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

Scan. Well.

I'm Sean. I was born in SoCal and was a properly sheltered youth, marred only by
internet access and a library card. I've lived in the bay area for a net 2 1/2
years, by my estimate, but I can't be sure -- I've moved around. A lot. Spent
most of my childhood moving around with family, then got the travel bug at 17,
during my 2nd year at COM. Fucked up royally, dropped out, and hit the road for
the following ~3 years.

My interest in electronic music is pretty new, all things considered. My ear was
drawn away from a steady diet of prepackaged 'rock' by experimental 'electronic'
music, noise, and a steady diet of the ilk of Skinny Puppy and Aphex twin.

I got pushed in the direction of grooveradio back when they were still on the
air, and my interest in EDM began there. Never did dig the reggae, though.

I went to my first party in Texas, no more than 10 months ago. Having already
developed a healthy sphincter-clench in response to clubs (especially the almost
antirave atmosphere of so many goth clubs), I was doing a variety of things I
oughtn't have, and got invited to some parties thrown by the DigDug Underground
in Dallas. The Levy got my attention, the music got my soul, the peeps got my
love, and the drugs ... well. 
 
Well.

Peace. -_^

TRH

PS: 'Together', Portland: Kicked Ass

  Wow, I think someone needs to calm down and work on their anger managment issues. ; )
 "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:Look, you've obviously repeated your little "pill testing is illegal" lie
enough times that even you believe it. But that doesn't make it true.

Frankly, I don't care what you think the cops say. I actually HAVE talked to a
LAWYER on the issue, and been informed that, yes, it IS legal for me to test
someone's pill via the DanceSafe procedure. You know the difference between a
cop and a lawyer, yes? One is a knuckle-dragger mostly concerned with beating
non-white people over the head, and believes that the "law" is whatever strikes
its whimsey that day. The other is a professional who spends the better part
of a decade learning the actual LAW inside and out, and is rigorously tested on
the facts before being allowed by the Bar Asscoiation before being allowed to
practice.

And yes, when I did consult, I WAS told that what I was doing was legal and
that the chances that I'd EVER be prosecuted were so miniscule that I could
mostly ignore them. And that if anybody ever DID try to prosecute, any
competent defence attorney could get any charges dropped almost instantly. I
see no reason at all why said advice wouldn't apply to EVERY DanceSafe
volunteer.

So, either my old lawyer (who can be censured, disbarred, or even prosecuted if
proven to have given deceptive council) is a liar; or you (who has no
accountability, and a record as the most exploitave promoter in the scene, with
a years-long string of lies) is. I wonder whom?

As for Pride, even WE were concerned that pill-testing might not go over so
well. But we were invited by the Pride committee with the specific request
that pill-testing be done. When we voiced our concerns, the committee brought
the issue to the districe attorney, Terence Hallinan (you know... the guy who
would be prosecuting any DanceSafe volunteer if pill-testing WERE, as you
claim, illegal. Mr. Hallinan, at the behest of the Pride committee, actually
took the step of contacting US, and assuring us that pill-testing *IS* legal,
that the government fully supports harm reduction, and that none of us, NOR
anyone who came to have their pills tested, would be prosecuted. We had this
in a written statemwnt that we posted at the booth for all to see.

So, I can take the word of both my old lawyer AND the district attorney; or I
can believe coolworld. Hmmmm...


cya,
john

> this forum.
> 
> 
> 
> I've been a volunteer with DanceSafe for just over a year and a half now. And
> both Alida and Carter are correct. Pill testing is legal. It's controversial,
> yes. But it *IS* legal. Coolworld was flat out 100% lieing when they said
> otherwise.
> 
> 
> 
> ---CW--> Thats an incorrect statement. Hands Down. You should do more
> research so that you can furnish actual legality rather then what "you've
> been told". Again, Coolworld doesnt have to Flat out lie, simply because
> Coolworld managment has had a tremendous amount of police interaction and has
> a pretty good understanding of whats legal vs liable vs. moral.
> 
> 
> 
> Carter is correct. No volunteer at a DanceSafe table is EVER knowingly in
> possetion of a controlled substance. The testing procedure, to which ALL
> chapters and volunteers MUST adhere, explicitly states that the pill is
> scraped, returned to the raver, and then and ONLY then is the test performed.
> 
> The test destroys the sample. Thus we never knowingly posses ANY drug, real
> or
> fake. ALL chapters and volunteers MUST adhere to this procedure, the whole
> point of which is to avoid breaking the law and shield us from liability. If
> anyone fails to do so, they are expelled from the organization.
> 
> 
> 
> ---CW--> Although you make a technical statement, the fact of the matter is
> that law enforcement views that as one of the same thing. Your best bet is to
> stop calling Coolworld a bunch of liers and Call the DALY CITY Police
> department yourselves. Then call the cow palace. The you can report back to
> sfraves and tell us what they told you.
> 
> 
> 
> Do you really think that we could exist as an incorperated organization (a
> fully certified 501(c)3 non=profit even) if we hadn't consulted with legal
> council about this point?
> 
> 
> 
> ---CW--> your existance is based on harm reduction and Coolworld supports
> that. We offer Dance Safe a Space @ any of our events to had out liteature.
> 
> 
> 
> If pill testing were "illegal", as coolworld claims, then why were we
> pill-testing out in the open, in full view of the public, and with the full
> support of the committee AND the district attorney during ALL of Pride
> (including the circuit party) this year? What about at the Castro and Folsom
> fairs, again in full view of the public and any patrolling police. What about
> at the innumerable other raves where pill testing was allowed. None of this
> is
> in dispute. At Pride, the committee even advretised the pill testing service
> for us in the Pride 2002 guide book, and gave us a choice spot in the parade
> (yeah... my goofy ass was on TV...)!
> 
> 
> 
> ---CW--> I'm not sure what your circumstances were at pride as Coolworld was
> not apart of that festivity. I can assure you that we are not allowed to have
> pill testing at the cow palace, which is a whole other animal.
> 
> 
> 
> FACT: DanceSafe has never been alowed to pill-test at a coolworld event
> because COOLWORLD refuses to allow it. The buck stops there, nowhere else.
> 
> So long as I've been involved with the organization, DanceSafe has only been
> allowed into ONE coolworld party, that being LAST year's PNY. And even THEN
> it
> was only due to the incessant and heroic efforts of one of our LOCAL
> promoters,
> with whom coolworld had partnered that time around.
> 
> I was one of the volunteers working that one, actually. Though you may not
> have seen us. Coolworld stuck us in an obscure corner of one of the secondary
> rooms. End even though we were there, all sorts of ridiculous restrictions
> were placed on us. For example, we were only allowed to distribute durex
> brand
> condoms (one of our volunteers had to sort through ALL of our free condoms,
> picking out and discarding all of the non-durex ones). And pill testing, and
> even sales of testing kits, was strictly verboten.
> 
> Personally, that experience was the final straw for me (granted, with their
> unbroken recored of lies, deciet, and exploitation I didn't exactly have a
> positive view of them, even going into that one), guaranteeing that I will
> never ever set foot in a coolworld "event" for ANY reason. They just don't
> care
> about anything except extracting every last possible dollar from the rave
> scene. And if someone has to die for them to get that dollar, so be it.

 "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote: Well... you may have a point that I shouldn't have injected so much of my
personal opinion into my first post on that topic. But deliberately spreading
falsehood and lies is one of the most loathesome and contemptable things I can

us, of an organization of which I am quite fond, and which I believe does very
positive and helpful work.

Fact is: I caught coolworld in a lie, and I called them on it.

And if you go through the archives of SFRaves, you'll find me doing the very
same thing on a variety of topics, from stuff drug related (like heroin in
pills) to technical issues (what sort of kernel Mac OS X is built upon). Whan
I've caught people spreading lies on topics with which I am familiar, I've
slapped them down.

Sometimes, yes, maybe I've been too harsh. On at least a couple of occasions I
was so harsh that I felt bad about it and apologised later. But seperating out
the emotions, I still don't think that any apology was really called for. 
Maybe it's just a pet peeve of mine. It's hard as hell for me to hold a grudge
and take most things personallt. And a lot of things are easy for me to
forgive. But lies and deciet are not among them.

I'll go ahead and quit posting on the PNY topics. If coolworld wants to have
the last word they're welcome to it. All I ask now, is that people check the
facts before believing any more lies that they try to spread. Everything I
have said wrt/ DanceSafe is fully public information that you could get either
from our public websites, or by having observed the booths (especially the one
at Pride) in the past.


cya,

Sounds good. I have lived for the most part on & off(~4 years?) in good old 
Chico. Jumped headalong into the raving world very recently, October 18th 
2002 to be precise with the wue and then the eta neotokyo party the next 
day.
I simply love dancing in all its different forms; it all started with 
ballroom, moving on to clubbing, the irish step and now raving.(what can I 
say, the new york street hustle goes smooothly with most electronic music :) 
My march continues to learn newer dance forms and mix them all up.
Besides that, I am very passionate about the outdoors. I spent all my summer 
mountaineering in the Range of light(the sierra nevadas).
Let's see what else, I have this big fascination with celtic culture, I have 
taken up playing the celtic fiddle, I love meeting people, art/independent 
movies, writing, english literature, etc.
Having worked in the bay for a year before getting laid off, I have to say 
work life sucks for me. I've met more people going to school. When I try 
visualizing my future, I see "TRAVEL all over the world" splashed in big 
green letters:)
Meeting people from this list? I've met a couple, would love to meet more. 
Yes, I did add my profile to the site.
Oh yeah, my name is Vishal.

	"Albert's Mom" <fabucat@hotmail.com>

	<denisio50@yahoo.com>
References: <F248VM3BxVPAnPEw8WY0000927f@hotmail.com>
Date: Mon, 6 Jan 2003 15:16:21 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <OE16XzJr45YC8lpeVbr00000054@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 06 Jan 2003 20:16:22.0294 (UTC) FILETIME=[7B124B60:01C2B5C0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A New Year, Let's Re-Introduce Everyone On the List That Posts.

hi, i'm nic i'm a pisces/dragaon, (which means i blow steam), i'm 38 and,
since Apollo has posted elsewhere that his dancing/ravin' career started @
Woodstock, mine began on  May Day, 1979, when I split from parents home and
attended my first cannabis smoke-in in NYC's Washington Square Park,
followed by my first Rock Against Racism concert @ the Bandshell in Central
Park.

I hooked up with the organizers of those events that very day, moved in with
them, and I'd like to say I never looked back, but I did, by moving back to
my parents home every now and then.

Prolly one of the dumber decisions I ever made, but oh well.

But my focus was with these good people and I lived with them on and off for
a three year period, @ 9 and 10 Bleecker Street in NYC, at what is now the
current World Headquarters for the http://www.cures-not-wars.org/ these are
the same people who are doing some cutting edge work in the field of
'addiction interruption' by dissemenating information they have compiled
over the last few years on the use of the psychedelic plant, ibogaine.

They've just been written up in JAMA, which is major huge.

Turns out, that while we were partying across the street they were busy
putting this work together.

Who knew?

Additionally, they are one of the major forces in America today for the
repeal of Cannabis Prohibition that we are currently suffering under in this
country.

'The Million Marijuania March" this coming May 3rd is also them.

Why I say my raving career began there is, while 9 Bleecker Street was the
office space, #10 was actually:

'Studio 10'

a live work space that we held parties in at least 3 nights a week, much
like today's UG's for a period of a few years, it was hella fun, but the
space was lost in a landlord tenant dispute, and so it goes.

I was young then and dinn't know that this was something I wanted to pursue,
so in a word, I went straight for over a decade, did college, enlisted in
the service, worked on Wall Street and SF's Financial District and
essentially never went out, save to Clubland, from time to time.

The closest i came to a rave was hearing B.A.D. mention raves in a song of
theirs almost 12 years ago, and I kinda knew something was up, because the
line was:

'It's one am, let's go out to a rave...'

Everyone knows that at that time things are *closing* not starting, so my
interest was piqued, but I dinn't follow-up on it, since my focus was on
that brass ring thing, which in the end left me broke, physically injured
with a mild chronic upper back problem, and more trouble than you can shake
a stick at.

As you can imagine, I was pretty unhappy with all this.

Some other things came up, I moved to Silicon Valley, and it still didn't
dawn on me that there was/is another way.

In 1998, i hooked up w/some people, rediscovered my love of music through
them and attended my first local party in November, on Friday the 13th, were
we coming from the first house party I had ever thrown.

The party we went to was crewed by the Enchanted Broccoli Forest people and
they had taken over a space 100 times larger than Studio 10.

I was the guy in the Marine Corps Dress Blue uniform costume, in case anyone
here remembers that party.

Was struck by a couple things right off the bat.

#1 Dinn't see any alcohol being served
#2 A chill room, which changes everything, cuz the last thing clubs want you
to do is sit still, think, and not not buy alcohol
#3 People seemed pretty happy
#4 Every other damned raver in there was wearing those red blinky LED's
incorporated into jewelry, which was kinda irksome because my Dad held a
patent on those LED's and actually tried to market them as jewelry in the
late 1970's, I'm just glad i was able to tell him about it before he passed
away, he thought it was hella cool.

>From that point on, I'd like to say raving became my life, but alas and
alack that was not the case, if anything my involvement has been glacial, it
was another 6 months before I even subbed here on sfraves.

For the last two years i wanted to step up my involvement past posting on
this list, but I made a few decisions around work and my personal life that
impeded that goal, so i only got to go to a few parties in that period, and
i'm just now only starting to catch on to EDM.

Having a g/f with hundreds of CD's and thousands upon thousands of vinyl
records in the basement *really* helps, and it doesn't hurt that she's been
going out to parties for years, as a matter of fact we met on another list,
so yeah, she's a raver babe, lucky me.

that, and through her, i'm beginning to puzzle out the differences between
genres, Ishkur helped a bit, but there's nothing like being taught one to
one.

we don't have any decks yet, since we can't afford them yet, the move was
costly, since I'm now clear across the country in DC, which, surprise,
surprise, also has a bright and vibrant scene, which some say may be on par
with the Bay Area's, though UG's are a lil way off, but there is some
cross-pollination and some locals have recently visited the Bay Area and are
looking to start some of their own.

I've been to more parties in the two months that i've been here than i have
in the last two years, and before I left the Bay Area, DJ Jack Triumph asked
me to try my hand at promoting him and I'd be remiss without mentioning his
site, www.JackTriumph.com and letting you know you can DL his breakthrough
release :

"Rome Rebuilt - The Studio Sessions,"

as well as his latest:

"Paganism,"

from the site's DL page, enjoy, it's pretty thumping.

Also, SiliconSalon.com is in the middle of a DNS transfer as we speak.

My original concept was something along the lines of what www.hyperreal.org
was already doing, but I dinn't even know they existed when i founded it in
1997 and they had like a 5 year headstart on me, and my focus ended up being
more on the goings on in Silicon Valley, as it turned out, but I'm switching
gears and am going to focus on rave and EDM culture, as well as host of
other topics and am looking for raver fellow travellers to work with with
this, i'll kepp you posted as this process moves further along....

Apollo, any chance we can mirror your House Music 101History Book?

We'd love to have you contribute, if you don't mind.

I got a great deal on the hosting from another raver on a local list here
who runs www.epitomized.com and I promised him to refer people by word of
mouth, so I just did.

So, yeah, I'm a raver, and i'm not going anywhere, and look forward to a
long and healthy future in 'the scene' as it were, and where it will take me
I don't know, tho' i don't see any downside to keeping my nose clean, my
head straight and going out and dancing, dancing, dancing the night away.

As the Eminem sez, it's good to be back.....

nic


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: Angelica Kuhl <akuhlangel@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] it's a new year....introduce yourself....

--0-442736264-1041884389=:60916
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


hi all,

name is angelica. i guess at my age i'd be considered old skool. first massive was in 91, here in the sf bay. 

grew up in modesto, moved to sf in 99.

i am one of the original members of the sflnc, celebrating over 3 years of service to dance culture. still serving as grassroots co-chairperson.

i haven't posted much in the past but i do enjoy reading the conversations. i enjoy the more community oriantated post, and try and laugh at some of the silly, or mean shit posted.

as a member of dance culture i am proud to have worked in some capacity, to preserve, protect and promote dance culture. i am saddened by the recent events at PNY, but it's incidents like that, that have discouraged me from attending massives anymore.....

at 31, i just can't stand to see the over-indulgence of some people. i hate to admit it, but i feel like some mom figure or something. yet i realize it's part of the individual experience to explore. like when someone says "don't touch it's hot", yet we find some need to get burned to feel the heat.....

i certainly, am not trying to come across as some old fuddy duddy house head who doesn't like to boogie or participate in extra curricular activities, i just know my personal limits. i guess my issues with drug addiction play a part in why i feel the way i do. both my brother (27) and my father are addicted to heroin, i just don't understand the over indulgence and enjoyment of being so intoxicated you can't even take care of yourself.

which is why i like 21+ parties. yes, there are peeps at every age who make it rough for other along with themselves, but the chances of a 25 year old loosing control vs an inexperienced 16, is less.

i have tried in the past to understand the younger members of dance culture as they must share some of the same experiences i did in my early raver days, but back in the day, you didn't have so many choices to make, k,e, 2cb, coke, speed bla bla bla....

so i can see how a sea of choices can be hard to navigate.....i worked with the dance safe national office and the local chapter last year, but found there wasn't much support for education. yes, people like what dancesafe does, but do many volunteer, donate money, invite them to table at a party? get to the JUST SAY KNOW...in stead of just say no?

drugs have taken the life of my father, my brother and many other relationships in my life....it's hard for me to see drugs the focus of our culture....

dance culture is more than the boogie, drugs or even the music....it's about the fellowship+ing and comeraderie we share....and the music is MY guide.

i just wish we could find the happily ever after....

thanks for letting me post me .02. i am not trying to debate any issue with anyone. just opening up and letting it out....

no judgments please....

i believe protecting dance culture is about our civil rights....

our right to choose!!

i'm looking forward to participating in more conversations!!!!!





the rumor is love,
the word is peace,

start a rumor!
spread the word!!



---------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] PNY03 Aftermath & Re-cap...

Okay it's this fucking simple....

Coolworld or ANY other dance event production company cannot hold an event 
at the Cow Palace and allow pill testing.   Allowing dancesafe to pill test 
isn't a decision coolworld can make -   IT SIMPLY IS NOT AN OPTION.  Get it 
though your head yet????

YOU DON'T EVEN KNOW THE CAUSE OF DEATH -  Frankly the odds are VERY high 
that it was NOT caused by ecstasy.   So unless dancesafe starts testing 
GHB, Special K, Herion and every other drug out there, shut your mouth 
until the official results are out.

Some of you people make me sick.   Two people are dead and you are 
obsessing over pointing fingers.   Why the hell would you want to blame 
someones death on someone else when it was completely out of their 
control?   Have some fucking respect!!  Playing the 'blame game' over 
peoples lives is DISGUSTING.

-Ross

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) 01.18.03 FAULTLINE v2.0 progressive dnb

Saturday, Jan. 18
FreeBeats Collective presents
FAULTLINE v2.0 
Progressive and Atmospheric Drum 'n Bass

Featuring the Testflight Recordings Tour:

Orion (Testflight Recordings/Breakbeat Science, AZ)
With more releases on the top atmospheric labels than
we can count over the last couple years, Orion is on
top of the resurgent atmospheric scene.  We are proud
to bring him back to the Bay Area.

Transit vs. Aaron Myers (Testflight Recordings, DC)
The founders of Testflight Recordings are touring in
support of their label launch.  Be prepared for a slew
of fresh tunes from all the top progressive Drum 'n
Bass labels.

Plus very special guest:

Clever (Offshore Recordings/Breakbeat Science, NY)
His new label has already made a mark with releases by
Paradox and Tundra and is set to blow up in 2003 with
new material from the likes of Deep Blue and Pieter K.
 Don't sleep on the futuristic roughness.

And residents:

DJ M (FreeBeats/Tenderloft)
Agent Sunshine (FreeBeats)

10pm to 6am / free water / proper sound / all ages
$10 all night 
underground san francisco location
call 415.789.8360 on the day of the party
for more info: 
info@freebeats.org 
http://freebeats.org

From: Angelica Kuhl <akuhlangel@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1353852101-1041891330=:37308"

Subject: [sfraves] Dance Culture

--0-1353852101-1041891330=:37308
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


hi....

i should have introduced myself before posting, i know. i just usually lurk. nothing has caught my attention much till this thread.....

i am one of the original memebrs of the SFLNC, also worked in the dancesafe national office before all the drama....that's what i have given to dance culture. my first massive was in 91. my first "session" was in 91. i consider myself old skool....at 30, i have scene our culture evolve, a lot. i moved from modesto, ca three years ago, gave up a carrer in selling new homes to move to sf and DO SOMETHING, do something to stop the misconceptions regarding dance culture. .....enough of my background.

dance culture means so much to me. the most important people in my life i met on the dance floor. the fellowshiping and the comeraderie of everyone comming to gether and sharing themselves, thier energy theyre being. it's amazing, it's what we all yearn for....frinedships, love, understanding tolleramnce.....it's all there if you look for it. thats what i see when i see the dance floor. it's what i give when i am dancing.....

it upsets me when the media or the powers that be try and define dance culture by candy ravers or by glowsticks....(no offense to either, i used to love both but i'm 30 now)....... ;)
we are memebrs of the general populas and we should be respected for being adults who make adult descions. i can't speak for the under 18 crowd cause i haven't been under age for so long....but for us adults who can vote, we can do something. the underground is special because you are more free to do as you wish.....the club scenen is much different because you have to "follow" the rules. which i don't mind, but trying to criminalize our culture by defining it by drugs or unresponsible behavoir is just wrong. which is why i tried to help out with dancesafe, now known as the share project. I feel that our cicil liberties are challanged when permits are hard to get our parties are shut down for permitting issues.

 

i am interested in knowing and undertsanding what others are doing to help the scene. i have recently lost some of my inspiration to promote, protect and preserve after hours dance culture. 





the rumor is love,
the word is peace,

start a rumor!
spread the word!!



---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Mail Plus - Powerful. Affordable. Sign up now
--0-1353852101-1041891330=:37308--

test

it 
though your head yet????

that it was NOT caused by ecstasy.   So unless dancesafe starts testing 
GHB, Special K, Herion and every other drug out there, shut your mouth 
until the official results are out.

Some of you people make me sick.   Two people are dead and you are 
obsessing over pointing fingers.   Why the hell would you want to blame 
someones death on someone else when it was completely out of their 
control?   Have some fucking respect!!  Playing the 'blame game' over 
peoples lives is DISGUSTING.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Need your help

on 1/7/03 1:17 PM, Dustin Bowls at djdustinbowls@yahoo.com wrote:

> Have a friend who has an MP3 player but doesn't know
> where to get any music from.
> Do any of you know of some places where you can
> download some music?

I generally pay for my music, then rip them from CDs to my iPod, never
sharing them with others. Any other way might be construed as illegal, and
there's no room for that kind of criminal activity on the Internet! I would
highly suggest you refer your "friend" to http://www.riaa.org to learn the
truth about the deleterious effects of unauthorized digital music exchange
upon the health of the music industry. Remember: You're one click away from
robbing an artist of his/her hard-earned royalties.

  - omid, trying hard to keep a straight face

After missing two different flights I am finally going to Bangkok, 
Thailand tonight. They have SO MANY pirated CDs in Thailand it is 
totally nutty. You can buy collections of 128k encoded mp3 cds for, 
like, 2 dollars! That's where I'd get my music, if I was into pop music 
: )  ...

Personally, I like to support the artists who's music I enjoy. I 
couldn't see pirating a John Digweed or Sasha CD because the more I 
contribute, the more I support the music in which I love, and then they 
make more music : )

Or.. just start listening to music that isn't over-looked by the RIAA.. 
You think the RIAA care about non-pop dance music? I think not : ) If 
it ain't on Mtv; they don't care!

downwith92.7

Chris

well, just because religious groups rejected the idea that cannibus really 
has been used 'back in the day' doesnt necessarily mean that it wasnt true. 
yea, maybe the subject 'jesus was a pothead' has nothing to do with the 
article, but it could be a possibility that it weed was used in oil. 
religious groups dont want to accept it because of the effects weed has on 
people today, as a drug use. the non-acceptance of it is merely ignorance of 
the fact that it could be real, and they just dont want to admit it. i mean 
dont get me wrong, im not saying that it is true, im just sayin that it could 
be true, and no one wants to take the time to see if it really is. to say 
that a possible issue like this is lame is just being ignorant, ok maybe that 
term is a little too harsh, but non-accepting yes. THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX, is 
all im sayin.

peace sign to you,
-TENA-

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Jesus was a poophead? (logic class in session...)

actually, that would be if he had said that he "tends to not agree with *everything* any of you have
not said so far."   what he said is a logical conundrum.   it can be taken both ways depending on
the logical sense of the starting negation "not."   it is essentially like saying absolutely
nothing.   silly i know...  these smart asses that just get done with their symbolic logic finals
and think they're an instant mensa puke *shakes head, waives finger*

someday he'll take critical thinking and learn that the correct way to end a thread is by mentioning
"Hitler." ;)

-=dave

Subject: [sfraves] reintroduce...

hey everyone.. i'm monikat, i don't post a lot, and i
don't read this list every day (just too much mail,
and i try not to do too much internetting at times)
but i figured i'm on today so i'll say hello.  been
dancing to edm and loving it since '92, and it's an
integral part of my life.  i've thrown lots of parties
(mostly UGs and benefits), mixed together partying and
protests a lot (reclaim the streets, and a recent
experiment in sonick/sound system resistance at the
gates of the nevada test site, and i like cats,
anarchism, creative resistance, and books.  oh, and
going to the gym, which is a newfound source of
pleasure for me.  i'm also pagan, and currently
interested in sacred sites and earth energy.  and i
need a trip out of this country right now.  what else?
 i love detroit techno, heaven would be a party in the
woods on a balmy night w/ jay denham and dj rush (i
know he's chicago), nah, make that a wild, unpermitted
street party w/ jay denham and dj rush on a balmy
night in some city under a full moon.  dislikes
include wage work, the whole wage system, capitalism,
environmental devastation, and people's alienation
from and lack of respect for the earth that nourishes
us and susains us, cuz you know, the world could be so
much better.  

ok, back to work.
monikat

i am thinking a lot about shoes, and then, i started thinking about how sometimes some people have enough money for some good shoes, and then they still don't have them, and why does that happen? well, here is one answer...sometimes, the person is asleep when all of the shoe stores are opened, and the shoe stores are all closed when the person has the time to go and look for the shoes at the shoe store....oh, i was going to post another poem, i guess...here, i'll write one up real quick with a rave theme:

it was all day-glow in the twilight of the hum

there were baggie pants and adults sucking their thumbs

we used to use pacifiers, but then those got pegged

even if your not on ecstacy, you can surely still rave

it's too bad a lot of people don't know that 

for reasons untold

i miss my green glowsticks

other lights are legal, i'm told

if trance is a hobby

and dance is a lie

then i guess we'd all be candied

and happily, sooooooooooooo fly...........okay, that is enough easy poem writing for now....oh, other things? maybe,,,,i have other things on my brain like i accidentally erased a couple of newsletters and that is okay, i guess, but also, i would have liked to have read them.........ummmmmmmm, maybe more later. :)

actually, the artist gets shit for royalties, it ALL goes to the record=20
company.=A0 MP3s are the best thing for the artist since....uh....sliced=20
bread??=A0 anyway, support MP3s, cuz they're gonna help the artist get back=20
control of their music.

basically, the artist signs away a song to the record company for an upfront=
=20
bunch of money...after that, any and all profits go to the record company.=
=A0=20
so as long as an artist keeps producing big hits, they stay rich.=A0 but onl=
y=20
one song=3Dnice car but no money for food...ya know?=A0 all this info came f=
rom=20
an article that courntey love wrote in i think it was rolling stone...i'm no=
t=20
sure.=A0 my bf read it and explained it to me, so this is all second hand=20
info...but the overall idea is the same.=A0 support MP3s!!! :-D=A0 but still=
 buy=20
CDs or they'll crack down on MP3s more so than they are now (that's my 2=20
cents there :) )

totally unrelated, but good to know
joanna

joanna

Subject: Re: [sfraves] MP3s (RE: Need your help)

>actually, the artist gets shit for royalties, it ALL goes to the record
>company.=A0 MP3s are the best thing for the artist since....uh....sliced
>bread??=A0 anyway, support MP3s, cuz they're gonna help the artist get bac=
k
>control of their music.
>
>basically, the artist signs away a song to the record company for an
>upfront bunch of money...after that, any and all profits go to the record
>company.=A0 so as long as an artist keeps producing big hits, they stay
>rich.=A0 but only one song=3Dnice car but no money for food...ya know?=A0 =
all
>this info came from an article that courntey love wrote in i think it was
>rolling stone...i'm not sure.=A0 my bf read it and explained it to me, so
>this is all second hand info...but the overall idea is the same.=A0 suppor=
t
>MP3s!!! :-D=A0 but still buy CDs or they'll crack down on MP3s more so tha=
n
>they are now (that's my 2 cents there :) )

The article he's talking about is probably this one:
http://dir.salon.com/tech/feature/2000/06/14/love/index.html

Give it a read, your summary is pretty far off the mark.

Personally, I have no issues with sharing music if it's fair-use - i.e.
reasonably limited, not in mass quantities like the heydey of napster.
(The idea of measuring your music collection in Gigabytes is like
evaluating Faulkner's writing "by the pound.") When I do buys CD's, I try
to stick to the used stores:  Amoeba, Rasputin's are two great examples
with large selection and a few locations to pick from.

On the other hand, MP3's alone do nothing to help artists.

They're just a file format, and can often hurt the artist: take the case
of poorly-encoded files that misrepresent the kind of quality production
an artist or producer is capable of. (That's Andy's usual point, and
quite a good one I think)

My take on this is that an artist should be proactive about distributing
digital media of their work, providing widely-available MP3 or OGG files
that are copiously tagged with creator and contact information, and
encoded to the /artist's/ satisfaction. We're on the cusp of a massive
change in the way that media is distributed and controlled - the RIAA is
bungling the transition, trying to apply 1920's rules to a market that's
being pulled out from under their feet. The people who can succeed in a
world of freely exchangeable music are the ones who can use the medium to
its best advantage. I don't know what that implies, though - I'm hoping I
won't end up having to put up with plugs for Sprite in the middle of
tracks I like. :-P

Fred Von Lohmann of the EFF summarized the case for fair use pretty well
in an interview on techfocus.org:

=09"Oh, and by the way, once you've busted all the "Sopranos"
=09sharers, don't be surprised if you see a drop in new HBO
=09subscriptions, as you've ended up killing off a free, viral
=09marketing channel that most consumer-products companies would have
=09given their right arm for. But hey, it always pays to ignore your
=09marketing staff and let the lawyers run the show, doesn't it?"

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

	sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] MP3s (RE: Need your help)

quoth PacoG383@aol.com:
> actually, the artist gets shit for royalties, it ALL goes to the
> record company.

In more "traditional" agreements, that's usually the case. More and more
independent labels are working out better deals for artists though, so
be sure to research your labels, and even solicit information from the
artists yourself, if you need to know how they're being treated before
buying their music.

> MP3s are the best thing for the artist since....uh....sliced bread??
> anyway, support MP3s, cuz they're gonna help the artist get back
> control of their music.

Supporting artists involves a lot more than just firing up your favorite
file sharing app and grabbing every single track you can find. If you're
really interested in supporting artists, try getting involved with the
effort to restructure the industry compensation and royalty systems...
And if you can, buy direct from labels and artists :)

> but still buy CDs or they'll crack down on MP3s more so than they are
> now (that's my 2 cents there :) )

I don't buy that at all. The RIAA's been blaming the "slump" in CD sales
on file sharing for years now, when the stats prove otherwise: people
that are exposed to new music in a collaborative environment in fact
tend to buy *more* CD's.

But they're also starting to raise the prices of CD's to "compensate"
for the "loss" in profit due to file sharing, resulting in some
exorbitantly high prices. Meanwhile, people are starting to realize,
thanks to the introduction of consumer CD burning software and hardware,
how *cheap* it is to actually make them. If anything, I say *boycott* CD
retailers until they start making music more affordable.

Tell the big record companies to eliminate wasteful packaging, and give
potential listeners incentives to buy CD's, like discounts on concert
tickets. Make individual tracks available online for cheap, instead of
forcing people to buy $18 discs that they just end up ripping to MP3.
And most importantly, promote and practice diversity on public radio and
television. Why anyone would buy a CD without even hearing a single
track off it (artist obsession, trusted recommendation, or word of mouth
nonwithstanding) is beyond me.

Furthermore, if you just want to stick it to the RIAA, just support
independent music. Solicit DJ's for mix tapes, and look for new music at
record stores (where you can listen to the vinyl even if you're not
going to buy it!). Go to more live shows, and attempt to contact artists
you like to tell them how great they are. :)

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Rave Culture and Religion (see abstract below) is a collection of essays=20
edited by yours truly and to be published by Routledge in 2003. Im=20
currently looking for appropriate b&w images for the collection. If you=20
have any material you think might be appropriate or know of someone else=20
who might, please get back to me or forward this message. Images can be=20
scanned at 300 dpi or sent to me at the address below (please send your=20
address for the return of originals).

The book will be published in print and ebook formats.

Photographers of material used will be provided a copy of the book and will=
=20
be credited for any work published.

If you are interested in contributing, please get back to me very soon, as=
=20
I'm hoping to wrap this up as soon as possible.

Thank you

Graham St John


Graham St John
18 Jackson St
Northcote Vic
Australia 3070

email to graham@wild.net.au


Abstract:

Rave Culture and Religion is an edited collection of 16 essays written by=20
academics and experienced cultural commentators who explore the=20
socio-cultural and religious dimensions of the rave, 'raving' and=20
rave-derived phenomena. Scholars of contemporary religion, dance=20
ethnologists, sociologists and other cultural observers unravel this core=20
cultural practice amongst contemporary youth. Though various commentators=20
have initiated research on this youth cultural moment, Rave Culture and=20
Religion will be the first venue devoted to such research.

Despite its diasporic fragmentation and hybridisation throughout the=20
nineties, the dance party rave - involving masses of youth dancing=20
all-night to a syncopated electronic rhythm mixed by DJs - maintains=20
rapturous popularity in the West. Commonly accorded effects ranging from=20
personal 'healing' or replenishment, to transformations on social, cultural=
=20
or political scales, the rave - from clubland, to outdoor doof, to=20
technomadic festival - is a hyper-crucible of contemporary youth=20
spirituality. The question thus arises: What is the role of the=20
technocultural rave in the spiritual life of contemporary youth?

Emerging in London in 1988 and subsequently exported around the world, the=
=20
rave has proliferated and mutated alongside associated music (electronic)=20
and body ('ecstasy') technologies. Throughout the nineties, vast numbers of=
=20
western youth attached primary significance to raving and post-rave=20
experiences. Regularly regarded by participants as a site of=20
'self-transcendence', a kind of temporary utopia, the rave grew prevalent=20
in the experience of urban youth. With the combined stimulus of electronic=
=20
musics, psychotropic lighting and chemical alterants, young novices and=20
experienced habitues transcended the mundane in converted warehouses,=20
wilderness areas, beaches, deserts and streets.

Participants and observers have variously reported 'communion',=20
'telepathy', 'trance' states, 'ecstasy' or the 'sacred' along with a=20
transcendence of subject, ethnic or gender categories at rave and post-rave=
=20
events. Producers of rave soundscapes and visual components (from video=20
images to d=E9cor) reportedly possess 'shamanic' characteristics. Events are=
=20
often deemed 'tribal' celebrations  even 'corroborees'. And, experienced=20
habitues of dance champion psychedelic 'sacraments', sometimes claimed to=20
accelerate the reception of esoteric knowledge.

Yet a torrent of inquiry issues from our initial question. Is the rave a=20
nascent rite de passage  and, if so, what is its telos? What is its level=20
and quality of efficacy? Is it a ritual of communion, a mass 'return' to a=
=20
'womb' which sees co-inhabitants secure in a nutrient rich and numinous=20
pre-separation stage, or an anomic post-partum 'dead-zone' catering for=20
'escapist' desires and tragic careers in over-expenditure? An 'oceanic=20
experience' or a kind of prolonged youth suicide? Does the rave or=20
post-rave more closely approximate a Church, Disney World=99 or a =93detenti=
on=20
camp for youth=94 (Reynolds, Energy Flash 424). Has the=20
cyber-chemical-millenarianism which flourished under the roof of the=20
original acid house been domesticated - the rapture contained and smothered=
=20
in regulated and commodified leisure sites? Or has its technospiritual=20
fervour been smuggled away into furtive temporary autonomous zones where it=
=20
percolates still?


--=====================_8831466==.ALT--

Added to the lineup:

DDR (Hazchem, Coshh, Las Vegas)

Sarah Fab (Fab Distribution, Las Vegas)

Online flyer: http://ohm.halogen.org/tt/web



Techno Truth and H8< Less Productions invite you to:

Stay Up Forever

Friday, January 10th, 2003

featuring:

Chris Liberator (Maximum Minimum, chrisliberator.com, UK)

The techno legend returns to California to start the new year off with a
bang.

Chris regularly plays throughout the UK and across Europe and with the other
Liberator DJs was one of the first western DJs to work in the former iron
curtain states, pioneering the acid techno sound there. As they say in
England, "He's fuckin 'avin it!"

Ant (Powertools, Smitten, UK)

His unique style of techno, tech-house, acid & hard-trance has earned him
recognition across the globe. Ant plays throughout the US, Canada, South
Africa, Venezuela & Japan.

Dj Rackit (Kinetec, bangingtunes.com, UK)

Her style, 'Hard Edged, Funky Acid Techno', has taken her throughout the
country playing a wide range of events from clubs to festivals, as well as
the occasional gig abroad such as 'Input' in Amsterdam and 'The Warehouse'
in Canada.

Dj Morgan (Lotek Records, djmorgan.com, SF)

Dj Cat (H8< Less Productions)

Dj Hoj (Breathe, djhoj.com, SF)

G.A.M.M.A. (Techno Truth, Stilldream)

Dirt (Techno Truth, Stylus)

Mek (Techno Truth, Stilldream)

Eli Bryant (H8< Less Productions)

David Aaron (Metropolis, Annihilation Productions, Reno)

Headcase (Turntable Tuesdays)


Cost: $15 at the door

Amazing visual and sound production by Lite Brite

Spacious Venue, 100% fully permitted

All ages, All night!

He promises he'll be bringing a hard, sweaty, dance mix of funky and new
school breakbeat madness to replace this morning's rain wetness with
some sweaty wetness.

http://www.stinginbeats.com

DJ BreakBeat Buddha as his guest.

Subject: [sfraves] RITMOS DE BRASIL EP [Jan. 20th 2003]

OUT JANUARY 20TH 

TAMBOR Y BAJO II - RITMOS DE BRASIL EP
Puturo Recordings - ditributed by S.T. Holdings 

1. sambarock - drumagick 
2. wild - mikrob 
3. good vibes - marnel 
4. zionite - telefunken 

*audio links in dubplate page DOA 

RITMOS DE BRASIL EP 
Phuturo/US/2x12 
An amazing selection of bits straight from the heart of the drum & bass revolution: Sao Paolo, Brazil. Featuring the likes of four fresh faces, the skills on display here are actually quite different than what youd imagine. Drumagicks Sambarock is the only bit that shakes and boogies with that still-addictive Brazilian flavor. Mikrob follows up with the most wicked street-level hitter on Wild before DJ Marnel dips into deep-house influenced territory on the jaw-dropping Good Vibes.  Be sure to save some love for the twisting, turning Zionite by Telefunken, an essential bit of future-dub bizness for all the electro-rastas. 

xlr8r magazine feb 2003

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] bsp! record sale! 375 records!

Hello everyone. I am slimming down my record collection. I have 375 records
I don't need any more. Actually, some of these are LPs or EPs with more than
one record in them (I have two hip-hop LPs with four slabs of vinyl apiece)
so the total number of actual physical records is actually probably closer
to 400.

The records for sale span a wide, wide range. The following genres are all
represented:

hip-hop
jungle (all subgenres)
techno
house
breaks (new-school and old)
turntablism
downtempo
trance
psytrance
breaktrance
acid trance
cybertrance
epic trance
melodic trance
every other damn kind of trance
2-step garage
regular garage
happycore
80s favorites
classical music

etc., etc., etc!

the best-represented genre is jungle. the bulk of the collection is hip-hop.

there are some definite winners in the collection - rare old-school Amen
jungle white labels, the first record DJ Z-Trip ever released, a Muppets
album, a happycore version of "It's A Fine Day," and so on and so forth.
however there are some definite losers as well. for example, the Journey
album "Infinity," which is free to anyone who wants it (but you have to pay
postage).

additionally, not all the records have been posted yet, especially in the
house or techno sections, and the categories are loose at best. there are
jungle remixes in the breaks section, and there are Madonna remixes in the
downtempo section (but these have already been spoken for). the wisest thing
to do is check out the section you're most interested in, and also scroll
thru the other sections just in case. this is the same as in a real-life
record store. in order to make it interesting, I started adding detailed
descriptions, especially in the jungle section, but I had to stop, because
it took too long, and in some cases the descriptions didn't even tell you
that much about the record. (as an example, my description of a Seba ambient
jungle track consists entirely of a story about a time when I climbed forty
feet up a tree while under the influence of Red Bull.)

for reasons which are unlikely to ever make sense to anyone, least of all
myself, I live in New Mexico. New Mexico is part of the United States. it's
located between Arizona and Texas. therefore in order to buy any of these
records, you need to send me cash (or Paypal) and INCLUDE BOTH YOUR ADDRESS
AND THE RECORDS YOU WANT TO BUY. last year I sold a bunch of records on eBay
and you'd be surprised how many people didn't figure out that I needed these
particular pieces of information.

these records themselves are also destined for eBay, but I'm posting them
here first for the sake of good karma. last year an old-school rare electro
compilation I bought for $15 sold on eBay for over $70. obviously, profit is
good, but part of me would almost rather let some sfraver grab some of this
stuff before I go trolling for dollars on eBay.

finally, everybody on sfr who doesn't want to buy my records, apologies for
the long-ass post.


peace, love, underwear, and rabbits,
Giles


ps!!! the song "Hyperreal," after which hyperreal.org was originally named,
is included in this collection. :-)

PPS!!! sorry - in order to view the records, you need the web link. here it
is.

http://www.livejournal.com/talkread.bml?journal=dreamstooloud&itemid=77303

ppps - I will try to get all the remaining records posted in the near
future.



---------------------------------------------------------------------

VJTV =AD Showcasing VJs and Visual Artists from Around the World
san francisco :: chicago :: manhattan :: portland :: toronto :: vjtv.net


VJTV :: Tonight 11pm-12am

Channel 29 - San Francisco Digital Cable TV


http://www.vjtv.net

Happy New Year everyone! We're very excited about our new year: we've got a
fresh new edition of VJTV for everyone. Full guest segments with C-TRL (SF)
and Reline artists Swipe (SF) and Seed (SF), as well as amazing visuals by
Amoeba (UK), Blasthaus vs. Om Records (SF), and a preview from the upcoming
pimp mix by Videoking (Hamburg).

Tell your friends to watch!

Amoeba (State ov Creation, UK) --
A fantastic and captivating short tackling the deeper issues facing a 4 yea=
r
old VJ girl of the future.

C-TRL (C-TRL, Blasthaus, SF) --
A variety of short works and installations by retro-tech visual artist Deva=
n
Simunovich (aka C-TRL).

Blasthaus vs. Om Records (Blasthaus, OM Records, SF) --
visual mix set created by Blasthaus artists exclusively for OM Records, wit=
h
DJ mix by Kaskade.

VideoKing vs. Moonbootique (VJ-Hamburg, Moonbootique, Hamburg) --
We've been holding on to this for months. Now a sneak peak at their pimp
mix. 20 minute mix coming in February!

Swipe (Neither-Field, Form Records, SF) --
Interview with Scott Pagano (aka Swipe) featuring visual works, footage fro=
m
Obscura Digital, and clips from the Reline DVD which he co-produced.

Seed (Reline, SF) --
Short interview and clip from his Reline project featuring the world's firs=
t
plant-as-artist VJ performance. Really.


Don=B9t forget to check out DMTV (Drum Machine TV) right after at midnight!!



upcoming:

ELECTRONICA-OPTICA
2 Year Anniversary Celebration
SATURDAY -- MARCH 8 2003
SAN FRANCISCO USA

Over 14 hours of digital media madness and fun featuring live audiovisual
performances, DJ/VJ mix sessions, visual screenings, software demos, booths=
,
and more!

http://www.electronica-optica.com/events/2year/



2pm-8pm daytime attractions

Visual Screenings ::
A free visual screen featuring works by leaders in the visual community.
Featured artists include Yeast Films, Dimension 7, VJTV and more.

Open Symposium ::
A series of daytime events for anyone who's interested in this growing
culture, including talks, workshops, booths, and software demos.



8pm-4am night celebration

Live Performances ::
A great night out featuring leading audiovisual artists, VJs and DJs.
Line-up to be announced soon.

Visual Screenings - submission guidelines
We're currently seeking new works by artists from the VJ community.
Details on the event site.


EVENT DETAILS=20

We'll be posting event details mid-January.

The techno legend returns to California to start the new year off with a =
bang.=20

Chris regularly plays throughout the UK and across Europe and with the =
other Liberator DJs was one of the first western DJs to work in the =
former iron curtain states, pioneering the acid techno sound there. As =
they say in England, "He's fuckin 'avin it!"

DDR (Hazchem, Coshh, Las Vegas)

A twelve year veteran of the London underground dance scene, DDR has =
unleased his own brand of techno/trance all accross the globe.=20

Ant (Powertools, Smitten, UK)

His unique style of techno, tech-house, acid & hard-trance has earned =
him recognition across the globe. Ant plays throughout the US, Canada, =
South Africa, Venezuela & Japan.=20

Dj Rackit (Kinetec, bangingtunes.com, UK)

Her style, 'Hard Edged, Funky Acid Techno', has taken her throughout the =
country playing a wide range of events from clubs to festivals, as well =
as the occasional gig abroad such as 'Input' in Amsterdam and 'The =
Warehouse' in Canada.

Sarah Fab (Fab Distribution, Las Vegas)

Sarah FAB has filled dance floors at many underground parties from =
London to San Francisco, Melbourne to Las Vegas.=20

Dj Morgan (Lotek Records, djmorgan.com, SF)

Recognized as America's HardNRG pioneer, Morgan can usually be found =
playing underground parties. He uses the music as the catalyst to create =
an explosion of energy.. a wicked burning frenzy of mad stomping kids!

Dj Cat (H8< Less Productions)

Dj Hoj (Breathe, djhoj.com, SF)

G.A.M.M.A. (Techno Truth, Stilldream)

Dirt (Techno Truth, Stylus)

Mek (Techno Truth, Stilldream)

Eli Bryant (H8< Less Productions)

David Aaron (Metropolis, Annihilation Productions, Reno)

Headcase (Turntable Tuesdays)

Subject: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?

J,
You don't have to tape over the BPM counter!  LOL  It's ok to have it there :)  It's up to you
whether or not you wanna use it.  And I haven't seen one built into a mixer that's very accurate
anyway.

Do you scratch?  Or plan on scratching with your mixer?  If so, I recommend a Vestax.  I have the
PMC 07 Pro ISP.  I use it for cutting, and of course, for mixing.  The only thing I don't like
about it is that it's not compatible with my Final Scratch.  Do you plan on getting FS?

> whether or not you wanna use it.  And I haven't seen one built into a mixer that's very accurate
> anyway.

throw me off...

> Do you scratch?  

possibly but it's not my biggest concern.  i want to do smooooov mixing of
idm/glitch/ambient/dub techno and microhouse styles...

> Or plan on scratching with your mixer?  If so, I recommend a Vestax.  I
have the
> PMC 07 Pro ISP.  I use it for cutting, and of course, for mixing.  The only thing I don't like
> about it is that it's not compatible with my Final Scratch.  Do you plan on getting FS?

yeah, i would like to get final scratch.  it's fucking awesome.  i saw
amon tobin dj a set using it, and it was like he was mystically refreshing
his tracks without ever putting on a new record.  people in the crowd kept
saying "how is he doing that?"

j

From sfraves-return-97633-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jan 10 18:40:53 2003

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk

list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 16353 invoked from network); 10 Jan 2003 18:40:52 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [65.212.189.254]
From: "DJ Howlin' Bob" <djhbomb999@hotmail.com>
To: jsz@eds.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 10:40:56 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F186rfPnaJHQj1qkHbM0001fede@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 10 Jan 2003 18:40:56.0594 (UTC) FILETIME=[CFF0CF20:01C2B8D7]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?

i have a Behringer DX 1000 mixer which i bought off the Net last spring, 
because it was reasonably featured and HELLA cheap.  two microphone input 
channels (mono) which i use when i record radio stuff for Burning Man, five 
stereo inputs, decent cuing but a bit twiddly compared to more 
straightforward monitoring.  no BPM counter.  seems to clip below the 
red-line level when you REALLY push the bass (but one usually doesn't want 
to do a +12dB bass boost anyway).  i wish there was more than +/-12dB of 
bass boost/cut, but it's adequate for switching from one track's bottom-end 
to the other with the bass kill switches.  it's pretty big physically, and 
the knobs are a bit small.  nice long throw on the channel faders.  works 
well in a home-studio setting; i also brought it out to Strange Brew (the 
happy-hour thing at the Savoy i had a residency at last year) once to use 
for a 2x4 with Andy Tie-Die, and it sounded good in the live setting as 
well.  very clean sound as long as you keep the level below peak.  hope this 
helps.

--hb

>anyone try the behringer mixers?  they have bpm counters, which turns me 
>off, but i suppose i could cover them with tape so as not to distract 
>myself.

      I would recomend a Rane. You can find a used one for pretty cheap (like $300 )and you won't find a better sounding mixer. 
 I just got rid of my pioneer 600 (they f*cking suck donkey dick) and got a new MP 44. The difference in sound quality has me as giddy as a school girl! Love it love it love it! The only thing that sucks is I have gone through hell trying to find a coffin that will fit it, but I just put in an order to have one custom made for it by odyessey. The difference in sound quality was well worth the coffin drama though.
Kj

From: ZephyrNewYork <zephyrhawaii@yahoo.com>
To: "jacob z." <jsz@eds.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301101034230.22255-100000@zen.eds.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?

J,
My Vestax does just fine for mixing too-- the crossfader AND both up & down faders have adjustable
curve.  So they can be adjusted for scratching OR for mixing-- whichever you feel like doing at
the time.  It'll be nice to get a mixer with adjustable faders (crossfader at the minimum) if you
wanna scratch later on.

If you wanna get the Final Scratch, make sure you get a mixer with phono AND line inputs with a
switch.  Unfortunately for me, the 07 Pro ISP is one of the very few mixers that doesn't have a
phono/line input switch.  I had to get a cheapie mixer to hook my FS up to.

Have fun shopping!  And shop around!  Use that "lowest price guarantee" to your advantage.  And if
you're on a budget, check out slightly used mixers.  Mine was a return or a floor model.  It got
shipped to me in the box and looked (and performed) like brand new-- it still does!  But I got it
for a used price...

this is precisely what i'm using the Behringer for...post-Basic Channel 
stuff and ambient/experimental soundscapes.  the cross-fader is really good, 
but you'll probably want to take the bottom plate off the mixer and twiddle 
with the two adjustments for the VCA crossfader which are available on the 
circuit board.

line of mixers, from way expensive to inexpensive.

Date: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 12:50:13 -0800 (PST)
From: Senorita Razmatazz <scarpetta80@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, jsz@eds.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer? 

i use a vestax pmc 170A, w/ platinum connectors.  kill
switches on each of the highs, mids and lows, that and
it shines (for the aesthetic in you).  i've had it
almost 3 years and i'm just now having to replace the
crossfader (ooh..optical).  here's a link:

http://www.vestax.com/products/pmc17a.htm

i think the best thing is the pfl doesn't fade in
volume when you adjust the knobs, unlike other mixers
where you have to keep them at normal keel in order to
hear the queue.

razz

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?

I have an 07 PRO ISP and a Final Scratch.  And yes, they don't work together.  BUT  I just got in an inverted RIAA converted, and am in the process of building a 19" rackmountable FS interface that will hold the FS and the RIAA converter, alowing any mixer to interface to the FS...

If anyone is interested I might consider selling some of the units for those other 07 PRO ISP users that don't want to change mixers just to use their FS... it probablly won't be more than 100$ in total... but I won't know for sure..

J

> 
> From: ZephyrNewYork <zephyrhawaii@yahoo.com>
> Date: 2003/01/10 Fri PM 01:47:28 EST
> To: "jacob z." <jsz@eds.org>
> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?
> 
> J,
> My Vestax does just fine for mixing too-- the crossfader AND both up & down faders have adjustable
> curve.  So they can be adjusted for scratching OR for mixing-- whichever you feel like doing at
> the time.  It'll be nice to get a mixer with adjustable faders (crossfader at the minimum) if you
> wanna scratch later on.
> 
> If you wanna get the Final Scratch, make sure you get a mixer with phono AND line inputs with a
> switch.  Unfortunately for me, the 07 Pro ISP is one of the very few mixers that doesn't have a
> phono/line input switch.  I had to get a cheapie mixer to hook my FS up to.
> 
> Have fun shopping!  And shop around!  Use that "lowest price guarantee" to your advantage.  And if
> you're on a budget, check out slightly used mixers.  Mine was a return or a floor model.  It got
> shipped to me in the box and looked (and performed) like brand new-- it still does!  But I got it
> for a used price...
> 
>

A very good point.. Vestax makes some great mixers for turntablists in
particular - Upmarket brands like Rane or Allen & Heath make some killer
club/pro gear, etc. etc.  Though I'm just as likely to take a friend's
endorsement as much as some celebrity DJ, knowing that everyone swears by
whatever brand they've been loyal to forever.

> This is like
> saying that all SUVs suck because you like sports cars.

Actually, they DO suck ;)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX SUCKS?!  WHATEVER!!!  RE: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] he

Ummm..

Vestax kicks ass (I own an 05 and an 07-pro isp)...

Rane kicks ass (TTM 56 especially) (I never used any of their battle mixers until I HAD to battle on one at a battle where I was told they would have an 07, it was like going to bed with Camerson Diaz, and waking up with a woody on J-lo's booty... different, unexpected, but was I complaining?)... 

I am looking into Tascam X-9 myself currently... any skilled turntablists have an opnion there? particularly for DnB mixing?


And Redheads and Blondes BOTH SUCK!!!






if you're nice to 'em...





most mixer's released today are pretty fucking decent... my buddy just bought the newer NuMark against my recommendations... and besides it's gimmiky effects section.. it's pretty damn nice.. every company caught on to the crossfader curve fad started by vestax.. so that little game is over...

I even got drunk enough at a club the other night and some poor progressive house DJ got to watch me fill the room when he let me cut on his $150 Behringer... 


point being.... no matter what you buy... work on your skillz... cuz it ain't the mixer... it's the DJ...


and as an ex-promoter I can tell you Swamp, Craze, Qbert, and A-Trak.. all top notch turntablists... list at least Vestax, Rane and Pioneer in their contracts...

many top Junglists are now listing Allen Heath, Rane, Vestax AND Pioneer in their contracts...


so don't get all bent up on one brand of mixers... when you get good.. it won't matter that much...

if you're new... don't spend much... just PRACTICE until you REALLY feel like you've hit the limits... by then you'll have played enough shows on enough gear to know EXACTLY what you want...

ok... due to popular request.. I'll shut the fuck up now..

J

Subject: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX SUCKS?!  WHATEVER!!!  RE: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves] hey djs - what mixer?

> > How can you people say stuff like this, when MYRIAD deejays like QBert and
> > Craze and H.O.P. swear
> > by Vestax?!  Just because you have no use for such a mixer doesn't mean it
> > sucks.  
>
> A very good point.. Vestax makes some great mixers for turntablists in
> particular - Upmarket brands like Rane or Allen & Heath make some killer
> club/pro gear, etc. etc.  Though I'm just as likely to take a friend's
> endorsement as much as some celebrity DJ, knowing that everyone swears by
> whatever brand they've been loyal to forever.

Thanx for the kind words, Omid!  At least someone here knows their mixers!  :)  (As a matter of
fact, one of those celebrity DJs is a very good friend of mine-- I based my Vestax purchase
decision on its quality & cost and not on who endorsed it.)

I've used several brands (good and bad-- I'm not ashamed to admit) of mixers and owned a few--
Rane, Numark, Pioneer, Gemini, Realistic, GLi, Vestax, and several more that you prolly heard of. 
They ALL have their applications.  Even the GLi had its application-- I only had a C note in my
wallet, and I was in a hurry to hook up my Final Scratch.  I didn't want to fly all the way to
Hawaii just to get one of my other mixers out of storage.  So I got it.  Is its sound quality
inferior?  Yes!  But did it work?  Yes!  And I got my FS hooked up with change to spare in my
pocket.  Enough to get cables, slipmats and a few slices of real East Coast pie!

> 
> > This is like
> > saying that all SUVs suck because you like sports cars.
> 
> Actually, they DO suck ;)

Not if you're camping near a stream just as a storm's about to hit, and the water/mud goes up to
your waist ;)  Or in some other similar predicament...

Do they swallow?!  LOL  I was thinking along the same lines, but didn't wanna get flamed, so I
didn't put a similar line in there  LOL

I totally agree with you, J.  Equipment does not make a good deejay, SKILLZ MAKE A GOOD DEEJAY. 
Remember back in the day when we used to cut on the old Numarks?  Compared to today's crossfaders,
cutting/mixing on my old Numark was like being a 300-pound fat kid trying to swim through
quicksand.  But we used to do it!  I may be dating myself here, but my boys and I used to spin on
the old Technics turnies with the rotary pitch knobs!  Anyone remember those?  LOL  It was hard as
f#*k, but we managed without today's top of the line equipment...

and PERFECT PRACTICE MAKES PERFECT!
