Subject: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX SUCKS?!  WHATEVER!!!  RE: [sfraves] VESTAX
	Re: [sfraves] he

on 1/10/03 1:56 PM, AUDiOTACTiX at audiotactix@hotmail.com wrote:

> i have a gemini scratchmaster, picked it up in '93, works great 10 years
> later.
> 
> No kill switches, no fancy doodads just lines and a cross. well worth the
> money

Agreed. I'm currently using an old-school Gemini as well, and although I'm
looking to replace it (the audio throughput is getting muddy), it's good
enough for now and - if anything - its lack of whiz-bang gadgetry is (I
think) making me a better DJ.

Until my friend and I returned it - buyer's remorse w/ a $1300 price tag - I
loved the Allen & Heath Xone 62 to death.  It was the smoothest,
best-sounding, oh-my-god-this-thing-runs-itself mixer I'd ever touched
(IMO).  But then I realized why we loved it so much - its various
equalization and DSP effects made it far too easy to cover up fuck-ups.
Granted, if I had a gig and the venue was supplying a Xone 62, I'd be giddy
over the prospect of fewer trainwrecks, but I know now that using a bare
bones mixer is going to reveal any imperfections and force me to acquire
more "skillz," as one might say.  :)

  - omid


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Comments: BlackMail headers - Mail to abuse@featureprice.com to report spam.

X-HELO-From: dpc000
X-Mail-From:  <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com>
X-Sender-IP-Address: 66.82.40.1
Message-ID: <004f01c2b8f3$ce6e6420$f665020a@direcway.com>
From: "Giles Bowkett" <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <20030110213155.21331.qmail@web41406.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 15:01:09 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] vestax is good

I gotta stand in defense of Vestax. I've had a Vestax mixer for years. if I
had the cash I'd plunk down for an Allen & Heath (and this is in fact one of
the reasons I'm selling my Vestax) but among hip-hop DJs and turntablists
Vestax is the industry standard.

Allen & Heath mixers are British, and they're just like anything British -
for instance, British SUVs. the top British SUV is the Land Rover. I live on
the side of a mountain, and up here, everybody knows that the Land Rover is
**the** SUV to have. they're completely indestructible. the guy who wrote
"Cryptonomicon" wrote this about British design:

"there's no in-between with these people. you have to walk four miles before
you find a telephone box, but when you do, it's built as if the senseless
dynamiting of telephone boxes was a serious problem in the past."

I'm quoting from memory so I could be slightly off, but you get the idea.

Allen & Heath mixers are built as if the senseless dynamiting of mixers was
a serious problem in the past.

Vestax mixers are built to be useful. plain as that. they have high-end
models and low-end models. they have models designed for turntablists - and
models designed BY turntablists - as well as models designed specifically
for New York house DJs. and they have loads of multi-purpose models designed
for everybody.

I dunno about Rane. personally I've always thought Rane mixers were bulky,
inelegant, and over-rated. but you can't be over-rated without being quality
in the first place.


Giles



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: Re: [sfraves] VESTAX SUCKS?!  WHATEVER!!!  RE: [sfraves] VESTAX Re: [sfraves

Very true...

My first setup was a pair of Technics SLD-2's (the rotary knobs, but they were directdrive.  actually I had a pioneer belt drive and a cd player first, but that doesn't really count to me).. and a Pyramid 19" mixer that had a click in the middle of the crossfader and a raised corssfader plate so you would rub the skin off your knuckles cutting...

did I sound good on 'em?  well.. mixing house wasn't bad... but hip-hop? hell nah... but I got my hand eye coordination down so that when i finally got some 12's and a vestax (well gemini scratchmaster first, but vestax about a year later)... I could school any cat that came up on the 12's that their daddy bought 'em... haha...


oh and as far as getting flamed... i'm sure the ladies on here have a sense of humour... and realize I'm not a sexist pig...







unless they try to vote, or work.. or wear shoes or some crazy shit like that!!!




j/k - please don't have my house burned to the ground grrrls.. :)





and to prove the "you don't need gear to be dope" theory as it pertains to production... check out the ill style ragga DnB my boy Tangent has produced using his comp, an o1V, an EPS16, and some alesis monitor ones...

www.hooknpull.com for all ya junglists!!!!!!! str8 sickness!!

ok... enough shameless plugs for now..

peas.

J

> My first setup was a pair of Technics SLD-2's (the rotary knobs, but they were directdrive.  actually I had a pioneer belt drive and a cd player first, but that doesn't really count to me).. and a Pyramid 19" mixer that had a click in the middle of the crossfader and a raised corssfader plate so you would rub the skin off your knuckles cutting...
> 
> did I sound good on 'em?  well.. mixing house wasn't bad... but hip-hop? hell nah... but I got my hand eye coordination down so that when i finally got some 12's and a vestax (well gemini scratchmaster first, but vestax about a year later)... I could school any cat that came up on the 12's that their daddy bought 'em... haha...

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 75781 invoked from network); 10 Jan 2003 23:17:15 -0000
User-Agent: Microsoft-Outlook-Express-Macintosh-Edition/5.0.5
Date: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 15:17:22 -0800
From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <BA449482.35A2%otavallai@mac.com>
In-Reply-To: <cd.217a2929.2b50ab62@aol.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Allen & Heath (Was Re: VESTAX SUCKS?! )

on 1/10/03 3:04 PM, Drgracer54@aol.com at Drgracer54@aol.com wrote:

> whats does everyone think of the Allen & Heath XONE 62?


It rocks... perhaps a little too hard :)  From my previous email:

<< Until my friend and I returned it - buyer's remorse w/ a $1300 price tag
- I loved the Allen & Heath Xone 62 to death.  It was the smoothest,
best-sounding, oh-my-god-this-thing-runs-itself mixer I'd ever touched
(IMO).  But then I realized why we loved it so much - its various
equalization and DSP effects made it far too easy to cover up fuck-ups.
Granted, if I had a gig and the venue was supplying a Xone 62, I'd be giddy
over the prospect of fewer trainwrecks, but I know now that using a bare
bones mixer is going to reveal any imperfections and force me to acquire
more "skillz," as one might say. >>

Pound for pound, the best damn mixer on earth.  Ok, that's kind of a joke or
maybe not, because the thing weighs like half an ounce (exaggeration) - it's
one of the drawbacks to the unit, actually. Although they have a reputation
for being as bulletproof as 1200's, the material of the Xone62 felt VERY
light and chintzy. In fact, ours shipped with an ugly ding in it from the
box being jostled around by UPS.  You can seriously pick this thing up with
one hand and (if you dare) twirl it around on your finger like a basketball.

My other complaint about it is the non-standard size.. it's not nearly as
narrow as a scratch mixer, but it's not a 19"-er either, and it doesn't have
rackmount ears.  I heard there are kits for them, but that's an added
expense on an already expensive unit.  *sigh*

They have another model - I forget the number - which is full-size, has more
inputs and doubles as a recording board, which is good for gigging musicians
and for recording, as well as DJing. Totally up my alley!  The near-$2k
sticker price, though, is rather offputting. It does look like a super-solid
unit, but I have yet to see it in person.

 - omid

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & Heath (Was Re: VESTAX SUCKS?! )

i love allen & heath.  they're tied w/rane for making the highest quality,
most durable, best sounding mixers out there.  period.

you can run them redlined for *days*, and there will never be a peep,
clip, crackle or sound degradation.

i'm also the proud daddy of the xone:32...  had that baby for almost three
years now and i can't sing it's praises high enough.  8^)

shane

other Liberator DJs was one of the first western DJs to work in the =
former iron curtain states, pioneering the acid techno sound there. As =
they say in England, "He's fuckin 'avin it!"

unleased his own brand of techno/trance all accross the globe.=20

him recognition across the globe. Ant plays throughout the US, Canada, =
South Africa, Venezuela & Japan.=20

country playing a wide range of events from clubs to festivals, as well =
as the occasional gig abroad such as 'Input' in Amsterdam and 'The =
Warehouse' in Canada.

London to San Francisco, Melbourne to Las Vegas.=20

playing underground parties. He uses the music as the catalyst to create =
an explosion of energy.. a wicked burning frenzy of mad stomping kids!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & Heath (Was Re: VESTAX SUCKS?! )

The only funky thing about that mixer is having the gains on the rear panel.
Crossfader adjust doesn't offer a sharp enough cut either. Excellent
studio/club mixer. I have a Xone 64 in the house right now which is
beautiful to learn on. Just doesn't work so well when you want to try
learning turntablism. But damn... clean clean sound off that unit. I'm going
to get Marshal to bring his Rane Empath over. That mixer seems to be the
answer for quality and features.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com


----- Original Message -----
From: "Plastic Nuclear Ferret" <donut@bayarea.net>
To: "Omid Tavallai" <otavallai@mac.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, January 10, 2003 3:34 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & Heath (Was Re: VESTAX SUCKS?! )


i love allen & heath.  they're tied w/rane for making the highest quality,
most durable, best sounding mixers out there.  period.

you can run them redlined for *days*, and there will never be a peep,
clip, crackle or sound degradation.

i'm also the proud daddy of the xone:32...  had that baby for almost three
years now and i can't sing it's praises high enough.  8^)

shane

On Fri, 10 Jan 2003, Omid Tavallai wrote:

> on 1/10/03 3:04 PM, Drgracer54@aol.com at Drgracer54@aol.com wrote:
>
> > whats does everyone think of the Allen & Heath XONE 62?
>
>
> It rocks... perhaps a little too hard :)  From my previous email:
>
> << Until my friend and I returned it - buyer's remorse w/ a $1300 price
tag
> - I loved the Allen & Heath Xone 62 to death.  It was the smoothest,
> best-sounding, oh-my-god-this-thing-runs-itself mixer I'd ever touched
> (IMO).  But then I realized why we loved it so much - its various
> equalization and DSP effects made it far too easy to cover up fuck-ups.
> Granted, if I had a gig and the venue was supplying a Xone 62, I'd be
giddy
> over the prospect of fewer trainwrecks, but I know now that using a bare
> bones mixer is going to reveal any imperfections and force me to acquire
> more "skillz," as one might say. >>
>
> Pound for pound, the best damn mixer on earth.  Ok, that's kind of a joke
or
> maybe not, because the thing weighs like half an ounce (exaggeration) -
it's
> one of the drawbacks to the unit, actually. Although they have a
reputation
> for being as bulletproof as 1200's, the material of the Xone62 felt VERY
> light and chintzy. In fact, ours shipped with an ugly ding in it from the
> box being jostled around by UPS.  You can seriously pick this thing up
with
> one hand and (if you dare) twirl it around on your finger like a
basketball.
>
> My other complaint about it is the non-standard size.. it's not nearly as
> narrow as a scratch mixer, but it's not a 19"-er either, and it doesn't
have
> rackmount ears.  I heard there are kits for them, but that's an added
> expense on an already expensive unit.  *sigh*
>
> They have another model - I forget the number - which is full-size, has
more
> inputs and doubles as a recording board, which is good for gigging
musicians
> and for recording, as well as DJing. Totally up my alley!  The near-$2k
> sticker price, though, is rather offputting. It does look like a
super-solid
> unit, but I have yet to see it in person.
>
>  - omid
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

On Fri, 10 Jan 2003, innocentchild wrote:

> The only funky thing about that mixer is having the gains on the rear panel.

this is called "dj darwinism".  if the dj can't find the fucking gains, he
shouldn't be adjusting them!  8^)

> Crossfader adjust doesn't offer a sharp enough cut either. 

this is slightly rectified if you get the upgraded penny&giles crossfader,
but you're right:  the curve isn't steep enough for serious scratch djs.

> Excellent studio/club mixer. I have a Xone 64 in the house right now
> which is beautiful to learn on. Just doesn't work so well when you
> want to try learning turntablism. But damn... clean clean sound off
> that unit. 

word to that.  in this case, you truly do get what you pay for (and then
some!  pricey....).

> I'm going to get Marshal to bring his Rane Empath over.
> That mixer seems to be the answer for quality and features.
> 
the xone 32 was the king of the smaller dj mixers, but the empath methinks
has taken the crown now.  i haven't had a chance to play on one of them,
but it's a rane, and i'm quite sure it's sex-a-liscous!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] odorless dancing nrr( Geri's posts smell)

Do you know what is even more annoying than a Geri post? Reading replies to 
her from other people.

I have been filtering Geri's post to the trash for over a year now. Get 
this...I haven't seen a SINGLE post from her since. But I have seen multiple 
people bitching and whining about Geri. Do yourself a favor. Hell, do *me* a 
favor. Use your filters. You will never have to see her emails again. You 
really have nothing to lose.

And please try and think of what a hypocrite you are. You have posted 
multiple times today about how obnoxious and non rave related Geri's emails 
are. And what have your emails contributed? Trash, trash, trash. Although my 
inbox isn't cluttered with nrr emails from Geri, my inbox *is* cluttered 
with your nrr crap.

Use your filters. If that's too complicated for you, go through your mail 
before you start reading and delete anything you don't want to read.

Thanks.

-Veronica

Date: Fri, 10 Jan 2003 19:45:28 -0800 (PST)
From: ZephyrNewYork <zephyrhawaii@yahoo.com>
To: Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <004f01c2b8f3$ce6e6420$f665020a@direcway.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] ZEPHYR FINALLY REVEALS THE ANCIENT LONG LOST SECRET OF THE BEST MIXER!!  Re: [sfraves] vestax is good

ZEPHYR FINALLY REVEALS THE ANCIENT LONG LOST SECRET OF THE BEST MIXER!!  Re: [sfraves] vestax is
good

Well, I'm glad that we came to the conclusion that Vestax mixers are in fact of good quality. 
Thanx, Giles :)  And thanx to all the other Vestax fans...  And to the other mixer fans too.

Please PLEASE do your homework, people, before you start talkin' $h!+ about equipment you're not
very familiar with.  Just because you may think the bare bones model of a mixer brand sucks
doesn't mean that all of the other models suck too.  This is called STEREOTYPING.  All bare bones
models have their shortcomings, so I could say that they ALL SUCK, but I'm not like that.

Well, my advice to all the mixer shoppers is...

Get the most bang for your buck.  Save as much money as you can, or beg, borrow and steal...  Do
whatever you gotta do to get the best mixer you can possibly afford.  You get what you pay for
usually.  Look online for deals on new and used mixers.  Check out the stores to see if they have
any returns/floor models they wanna get rid of.  Just because a mixer is returned doesn't mean
it's broken.  Maybe a broke-dick DJ realized that he couldn't make rent for that month if he kept
the mixer, so he sent it back.  Look in the papers for ads-- a lotta deejays or wanna-be deejays
wash out and sell their equipment.  It could be due to loss of interest of lack of funds for
bills.

And if you really wanna know the secret of the best mixer brand...  The best mixer is... *drum
roll*








...THE ONE YOU LIKE MOST AND ARE MOST COMFORTABLE WITH!!  You could buy the most expensive high
quality mixer in the world, but if it doesn't "feel" right in YOUR hands, guess what!  You're not
gonna practice on it!!  And what use is a mixer that you don't use and practice on?  USELESS! 
(Well, maybe you can use it as an expensive paper weight)  Go to your friends' houses and get on
their mixers, go to the stores and demo the floor models...  Happy shopping!


--- Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com> wrote:
> I gotta stand in defense of Vestax. I've had a Vestax mixer for years. if I
> had the cash I'd plunk down for an Allen & Heath (and this is in fact one of
> the reasons I'm selling my Vestax) but among hip-hop DJs and turntablists
> Vestax is the industry standard.
> 
> Allen & Heath mixers are British, and they're just like anything British -
> for instance, British SUVs. the top British SUV is the Land Rover. I live on
> the side of a mountain, and up here, everybody knows that the Land Rover is
> **the** SUV to have. they're completely indestructible. the guy who wrote
> "Cryptonomicon" wrote this about British design:
> 
> "there's no in-between with these people. you have to walk four miles before
> you find a telephone box, but when you do, it's built as if the senseless
> dynamiting of telephone boxes was a serious problem in the past."
> 
> I'm quoting from memory so I could be slightly off, but you get the idea.
> 
> Allen & Heath mixers are built as if the senseless dynamiting of mixers was
> a serious problem in the past.
> 
> Vestax mixers are built to be useful. plain as that. they have high-end
> models and low-end models. they have models designed for turntablists - and
> models designed BY turntablists - as well as models designed specifically
> for New York house DJs. and they have loads of multi-purpose models designed
> for everybody.
> 
> I dunno about Rane. personally I've always thought Rane mixers were bulky,
> inelegant, and over-rated. but you can't be over-rated without being quality
> in the first place.
> 
> 
> Giles
> 
> 
>

>
>Well, I'm glad that we came to the conclusion that Vestax mixers are 
>in fact of good quality. 
>Thanx, Giles :)  And thanx to all the other Vestax fans...  And to 
>the other mixer fans too.
>
>Please PLEASE do your homework, people, before you start talkin' 
>$h!+ about equipment you're not
>very familiar with.  Just because you may think the bare bones model 
>of a mixer brand sucks
>doesn't mean that all of the other models suck too.  This is called 
>STEREOTYPING.  All bare bones
>models have their shortcomings, so I could say that they ALL SUCK, 
>but I'm not like that.
>
>Well, my advice to all the mixer shoppers is...
>
>Get the most bang for your buck.  Save as much money as you can, or 
>beg, borrow and steal...  Do
>whatever you gotta do to get the best mixer you can possibly afford. 
> You get what you pay for
>usually.  Look online for deals on new and used mixers.  Check out 
>the stores to see if they have
>any returns/floor models they wanna get rid of.  Just because a 
>mixer is returned doesn't mean
>it's broken.  Maybe a broke-dick DJ realized that he couldn't make 
>rent for that month if he kept
>the mixer, so he sent it back.  Look in the papers for ads-- a lotta 
>deejays or wanna-be deejays
>wash out and sell their equipment.  It could be due to loss of 
>interest of lack of funds for
>bills.
>
>And if you really wanna know the secret of the best mixer brand...  
>The best mixer is... *drum
>roll*
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>...THE ONE YOU LIKE MOST AND ARE MOST COMFORTABLE WITH!!  You could 
>buy the most expensive high
>quality mixer in the world, but if it doesn't "feel" right in YOUR 
>hands, guess what!  You're not
>gonna practice on it!!  And what use is a mixer that you don't use 
>and practice on?  USELESS! 
>(Well, maybe you can use it as an expensive paper weight)  Go to 
>your friends' houses and get on
>their mixers, go to the stores and demo the floor models...  Happy 
>shopping!
>
>

>miles before

>senseless

Subject: [sfraves] traktor 2.0 dj studio w/ m-audio oxygen-8 *wow*

going by a sugestion from a guy on socal-breaks, i decided to wire in my
oxygen-8 as a controller for my laptop/traktor setup. holy wow is it neat!
i'm still getting the hang of the controls and tweaking the device mappings,
but i must say, i've been playing for the last hour with one turntable and a
laptop and it's becoming more and more easy the more i play with it.

it's pretty damn easy to setup, u can actually use /any/ midi controler. i
use the o8 bcuz: it's usb, my laptop has no midi in, it's small, it has lots
of knobs. to set it up in traktor you just click 'learn' on the master
window, select your midi device, and go through the list of actions to
configure, and 'learn' them from your controller. the one's i'm using the
most are 'pitch', 'pitch fine', 'track forward', 'track back', and the other
'digital' speed fx.

according to the traktor-dj.com forums, there's even a guy out of germany
that's building a complete midi dj mixer for use with traktor (looks just
like a generic technic mixer, only cooler). 

anyway, hopefully i'll have enough practice to debut this setup at incognita
this thursday, so if you swing by, i'll give you a looksee.

l8r,
-xs


--
Greg Albrecht <gba@ambreaks.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

Speaking of disco... In my grunge-and-techno-fueled days of the early 90's
(I liked anything aggressive, and I still do, even some of that n=FC-metal
crap), I absolutely HATED disco and its revival. It wasn't hard enough, it
wasn't dark enough, and it sounded overproduced to me.

I don't know what it is, but I guess my greater appreciation for dance musi=
c
in general has made me a bit of a disco fiend in recent years.  Not the
overplayed standards, but the less vocally-oriented, funkier extended tunes
of the genre. I now find the 4-on-the-floor beats and funky basslines to be
some sort of natural calling. The porno-style wah guitar riffs just make it
that much sexier.  There's a certain fluidity to the style, which has passe=
d
on to a lot of modern house, that I simply find addictive now.

Unfortunately, I haven't found many places to indulge in this. Somehow I
doubt there are any venues that feature a decent amount of disco mayhem
without bringing along with it a load of camp and cheese.  :(  Fortunately,
though, much of SF house seems to carry on the legacy, which is certainly
cool, but does anyone know of a party (regular or otherwise) that mixes the
two up? I want some genuine discotheque music, sans "I Will Survive"
sing-alongs...

--=20
otavallai@
mac.com

Their tiger-style kung fu is strong. But our dragon style will defeat it.

i hope everyone is continuing to enjoy themselves at the numerous local events that are being put on every single night in the bay area....events that are free of the troubles you might have experienced in the past at music venues....you can read about some of the things that happen here on this list...don't loose the party momentum that you gained over your positive experiences over the holidays :).....i am a very creative person, and most of the techie people can see that....i am glad to share my gifts, if even briefly, to help people to keep their attention spans up, if that is the case, as more often than not it is...:) cheers to any tech heads who think that people like me are "aliens" "strange" or even "wierd"...i know that means that you care and that you notice our differences and even appreciate them...i like working with computer people very much....anyway, something else that some people might not know yet, so i will tell you, is that  if you post to the list, you will probably be placed on a few lists of people who feel that you might match up well with their target crowd. this has been my experience...that and maybe you might receive some interesting information regarding music, art and  dance from all parts of the globe. sfraves is a wonderful resource for all sorts of goodies. you might even meet your soulmate here. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

--=====================_14204779==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

At 11:25 AM 1/11/2003 -0800, Omid Tavallai wrote:
>Speaking of disco... In my grunge-and-techno-fueled days of the early 90's
>(I liked anything aggressive, and I still do, even some of that n=FC-metal
>crap), I absolutely HATED disco and its revival. It wasn't hard enough, it
>wasn't dark enough, and it sounded overproduced to me.

Well, there was "disco,"  the commercial stuff that most people associate=20
with the genre, and then there was Disco, the off the map music that could=
=20
be found primarily in the gay underground clubs of the period, like the=20
Paradise Garage.


>I don't know what it is, but I guess my greater appreciation for dance=
 music
>in general has made me a bit of a disco fiend in recent years.  Not the
>overplayed standards, but the less vocally-oriented, funkier extended tunes
>of the genre. I now find the 4-on-the-floor beats and funky basslines to be
>some sort of natural calling. The porno-style wah guitar riffs just make it
>that much sexier.  There's a certain fluidity to the style, which has=
 passed
>on to a lot of modern house, that I simply find addictive now.
>
>Unfortunately, I haven't found many places to indulge in this. Somehow I
>doubt there are any venues that feature a decent amount of disco mayhem
>without bringing along with it a load of camp and cheese.  :(  Fortunately,
>though, much of SF house seems to carry on the legacy, which is certainly
>cool, but does anyone know of a party (regular or otherwise) that mixes the
>two up? I want some genuine discotheque music, sans "I Will Survive"
>sing-alongs...

There are a number of disco revival evenings in venues about town, but I've=
=20
never attended so I can't attest to their quality.

If you're interested, West End Records and Strut (2000) released on both=20
CDs and vinyl live recordings of Larry Levan at the Paradise Garage in=20
1979.   Also, there are live sets floating around SF that were recorded at=
=20
the Trocadero in the late 70's.  I have the full sets recorded at the=20
Halloween Party there in 1979 -- I also attended that party.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are=20
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & Heath (Was Re: VESTAX SUCKS?! )

> On Fri, 10 Jan 2003, innocentchild wrote:
>
> > The only funky thing about that mixer is having the gains on the rear
> > panel.
>
> this is called "dj darwinism".  if the dj can't find the fucking gains, he
> shouldn't be adjusting them!  8^)

actually you shouldn't really be adjusting the gains even if you can find
them. adjusting the gains is an emergency measure best excluded from
mission-critical applications.

it might even be wise to rewire the gains so that the only way to adjust
them without getting electrocuted would be to turn off the mixer first.

this is called "dj behavioral modification."


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Brazil

> I'm heading out to Brazil next week, and since I know there are tons of
> world travelers on the list...
>
> I'd like to do some record shopping while i'm there..  Anybody know of any
> good record shops in Sao Paulo or Rio de Janeiro???

not I, but for what it's worth, Sao Paolo has more people in it than New
York. Layo and Bushwhacka! debuted their live show there a few months ago.

I once had a girlfriend from Sao Paolo. she was gorgeous, but things between
us were often a bit enigmatic, because she didn't speak English. luckily I
learnt some Portuguese.

the only words I remember now are "princess" and "kiss."

in retrospect, that relationship did not actually make a lot of sense.

the amazing thing is this: not only was she not the first girl who spoke no
English that I hit on successfully, she wasn't even the first girl from
South America who spoke no English that I hit on successfully. that honor
goes to a beautiful blonde Argentinian I met on a bus in Oakland, who agreed
(using hand motions, mostly) to go on a date with me.

anyway, Urb ran a feature on Brazil a little while back. they might have
something on their web site.


Giles

guess I'll try to find a funk night with maybe a house spin. I spent the

talent, and intellectualizing the track selections - this year, I just wanna
get out and shake my ass.

Subject: [sfraves] Mp3 Mix Sets from NewYearsDay Selekta Broadcast

Hello all~
  First I would like to start by saying Thank You to all the Djs who made
time on New Years Day to come to my pad and PUT IT DOWN! on my selekta show
Progressive Soul (PSOL).  Yes the 12 Hour Live Broadcast did go down for
those of you who
didnt,forgot too or couldnt listen on 1-1-03...It was 12hours of dope UG
music and Dj skillz.  Much love to all the listeners ...a few of you stuck
around for most of the show ..I hope you enjoyed it and props cause I was
passin out towards the end...whew.  As tired as I was.. I can say I had a
lot of fun kickin it and having the FATTEST DJ SESSION I think Ive ever
hosted.
  I will be posting the sets from the show and I hope all of you take
advantage of downloading the 12..well 11 sets... the first set was not
recorded.

Due to webspace the sets will be posted in groups.
FIRST GROUP:

12pm-Christopher Matsumoto (PressRoom)
NoRecording

1pm-Terence (s:one)
www.djcantos.com/mixes/SelektaPSOLNewYearsDay-03-Terence.mp3

2pm-DjUndecided (Urban-Breaks,NaughtyVibes)
www.djcantos.com/mixes/SelektaPSOLNewYearsDay-03-DjUndecided.mp3

3pm-Gabe Xavier (www.goversatile.com)...sorry Gabe missed your first 2cuts
www.djcantos.com/mixes/SelektaPSOLNewYearsDay-03-GabeXavier.mp3

4pm-Fooders and MadPlanet (Zulu Nation)
www.djcantos.com/mixes/SelektaPSOLNewYearsDay-03-Fooders-Madplanet.mp3

In a few days Ill post the next group.
ON DECK:
5pm-E.M.P. (Summit Sessions Sound)
6pm-Mikey J. (selekta.com)
7pm-Jimmy Zimms(zimms.com,NaughtyVibes)/Cantos(selekta.com,djcantos.com)
8pm-Kelly Groove (United State, KDVS 90.3)

After that...
IN THE HOLE:
9pm-Dj Pat (Teknique,Fresno/MFS,Berlin)
10pm-Djohn (Stealth,Stockton)
11pm-Cantos ...feeling pretty spent =)

Dont sleep on these sets!!!!  Also playlists for some sets available.

Look out for future guests on PSOL www.selekta.com....got some bangers
commin by to play wax for yah all!  Some guests are already posted on
selekta.com

Okay time to sleep....Techno Truth put on a good production at "Stay Up
Forever" its to bad more people didnt make it out.  Good shiet guys even
though you didnt have the attendance you were shooting for.....ANT tore
shit up!!!!! w/DDR on the synths vs. stylee...off the chain!...crazy

Peace n Nappy Hair Grease!
Sean Canty

>
> > The only funky thing about that mixer is having the gains on the
rear
> > panel.
>
> this is called "dj darwinism".  if the dj can't find the fucking

find

mission-critical applications.

From sfraves-return-97706-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Jan 12 16:44:43 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-97706-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 67031 invoked by uid 1103); 12 Jan 2003 16:44:43 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 67017 invoked from network); 12 Jan 2003 16:44:42 -0000
Message-ID: <01C2BA13.3A6A86C0.gregvp@attbi.com>
From: Greg Van Pelt <gregvp@attbi.com>
Reply-To: "gregvp@attbi.com" <gregvp@attbi.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.org" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Sun, 12 Jan 2003 08:18:38 -0800
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet E-mail/MAPI - 8.0.0.4211
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Last night:  'clowns'  (short review)

Wow, I had such a good time at that GodDamn Clowns party last night. One of 
the things that I love about sfraves is the spontaneity that arises when 
you happen to read a last-minute BSP and something clicks (besides your 
mouse).

I mean, I had a feeling that this was going to be an East bay event, so I 
called the info line and dragged my ass over to one of the warehouse 
districts of Oakland. Found a parking spot, walked down the street and ran 
into my good friend Evan, whom I have not seen in ages. He is still working 
and going to school, so we talked and then went inside the space to dance.

Inside, the DJ was in a "pit" below the main floor, which was decorated 
with wild clown pictures. And the clowns themselves were everywhere, some 
of them half-naked (like a guy in a thong outfit, with a whip). Picture an 
S&M clown. Later there was some clown spankings going on but I did not 
participate in the fun (just watched on the sidelines).

Some of Evan's other friends told me that they always see me at these 
undergrounds, like the Moksha tribe parties. Lucky me, I guess I have 
learned how to figure out the underground since I am a dancer, seeking the 
best beat.

The space also had a large chill room (behind the main room), and a 
secondary refreshment/chill room behind that room. Plus, there was a "fun 
house" room, decked out with mirrors and strobe lights (and black paint), 
so it was groovy, baby. This room was more like a long hallway, actually, 
and it did not seem to get used as much as it could have. But I enjoyed the 
strobe lighting effect.

I got tired at around 2 am, from all of that dancing, and I had to leave so 
I said goodbye to Evan. He was sitting beside an Asian woman in the chill 
room, and I guess she thought I was cute or something because she asked for 
my phone number (and asked if I had a girlfriend). I could not understand 
her English, so I said, "No" and pretended to understand the rest of the 
conversation.

She walked away and left us alone, and the highlight of my night was when 
Evan said, "It wouldn't be a party without you here, Greg," which made me 
feel really happy. Then he showed me his color phone, and punched my number 
into his address book.

That's all, I just wanted to tell my story. It was great fun.

Greg VP




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Message-ID: <20030113002159.95351.qmail@web40503.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sun, 12 Jan 2003 16:21:59 -0800 (PST)
From: Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] recommended reading :) nrr

i am testing out a new computer...had to start writing
all over again and other things have already happened,
so basically, i do not want this computer....okay, now
back to the subject at hand...gene simmons of the band
KISS...the man who wears a lot of black and white
makeup on his face, like the other band members...the
member of the band who always sticks his tongue out
and waggles it around...the band that i used to be
kind of afraid of in a "who is ozzy osbourne too? i am
scared of those pictures in sixteen magazine that i am
looking at after church on sunday with my family while
we are shopping at the grocery store for eggo waffles"
sort of way...gene simmons has a magazine out now
called "tongue". you should read that magazine...it is
a lot of fun....they probably have it at the record
store or at a big newsstand that carries lots of
magazines...probably not at the grocery store, because
jenna (porn star jenna) is on the cover and there is a
good interview with her in there amongst lots of other
coolness, like a muscle girls wall calender.....okay,
bye. :)

Illumination Records and Neuroscience Creations present...

NEU LIGHT:Secret Psychedelica
Saturday, January 25th, 2003

As we start the new year, we would like to put the spotlight on Santa 
Clara's only psychedelic trance night. Secret Psychedelica, starting its 
third year on

Monday, January 27th, continues to bring top notch goa/psychedelic trance 
music to the Silicon Valley on the 4th Monday of every month. Neu Light 5 
will

feature the resident DJs of this Monday night monthly. Each DJ has proven 
themselves worthy behind the decks at local clubs and parties to outdoor 
campouts

and have greatly contributed to the growth of our psychedelic trance scene.

...into the light...
Illumination Records and Neuroscience Creations would like to thank all Neu 
Light supporters for a wonderful year. Because of you guys and gals, 2002 
has

seen four successful Neu Light events. As our way of saying thanks, [b]Neu 
Light 5 will be only $5.[/b] And, as always, every pre-sale ticket holder 
will

receive a special Neu Light CD package. Please note, Neu Light 5 will be 
limited to [b]pre-sale admission only.[/b] No guest list.

...DJs...
MICHAEL LIU (Illumination Records/Secret Society)
NEUROPSYNTIST (Neuroscience Creations/Neu Light)

MUBALI (Straylight - Monterey)
ANDYW (Secret Society/Viberation)

...soundsystem...
Neuroscience Creations

...into the system...
Neu Light shines bright with the help of Viberation Graphics, Psyberdrum, 
Lucky Soul, Thump Radio, Straylight, PLM Productions, and the Phoenix 
Family.

On Sun, 12 Jan 2003, Greg Van Pelt wrote:
-&e->Wow, I had such a good time at that GodDamn Clowns party last night. One of
-&e->the things that I love about sfraves is the spontaneity that arises when
-&e->you happen to read a last-minute BSP and something clicks (besides your
-&e->mouse).

It was a damn good time, agreed.  Aside from some struggle to get the
turntables to do what I wanted them to (skippy needles - must bring my own
carts if I intend to goof off at all), it was a good underground
reminiscent of some of the really small UGs I fell in love with in SF a
few years back.  Thoughtful decor, good people, Mike dropping "we like the
cars" and um... half naked clowns wearing fetish gear whipping each
other in the hallway.

How can you go wrong with Ouchy, $1.50 Rockstar, and a ton of people I
haven't seen in a while.  The crew executed a safe, fun event with
shitloads of class and creativity...

andyw

Master, one the UK's most legendary downtempo djs, is going to be
playing at a little spot in SF tonight.  its quite a rare opportunity.

here's the info:

MINIMAL MONDAY - 01/13/2003

	Mix Master Morris (Ninja Tune, UK)
     Joe Rice
     Creamy Goodness
 
@ The Hush Hush Lounge (496 14th St. & Guerrero), 21+, 9pm-2am, free.


see you there,

james

From: =?iso-8859-1?q?ross=20donaldson?= <rossantonio@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1769176638-1042488646=:60934"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] somehow connected to clubbing

--0-1769176638-1042488646=:60934
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Here in Mallorca we just had a blinding weekend, the New Years Eve 
hangovers 
had faded sufficiently for everyone to be firing an all cylinders 
again. I 
was first invited to the staff party for the Country Club, which was a 
beautiful traditional meal & piss up in one of the mountain 
restaurants. At 
about 2am we made it to Made in Brazil, for a bit of sexy dancing with 
the 
admin dept. The club's dancers make you learn the routines they have 
made up 
for that week, its hip wrigglin, saucy line dancin done the latin way, 
and we 
raved it up enough to all be pretty embarressed this morning!  After 
that a 
quick trip to the Torino in Ca'n Barbara to hear dj Cannus finishing 
his set. 
KIDSTUFF / KOMISKI PARK / HONCHOS  NRK was playing as we stumbled in, 
and 
after the main crowd had left, the staff came out from behind the bar 
for a 
dance to that Dirty Vegas track.We wont play it in the set, but we love 
it 
for its out and out rudeness. At 5am we made it to Pacha where I heard 
a 
blinding set by dj Sarah Maine who is the Ibiza resident. She was 
presenting 
the Winter Session tour and had us all going hammer & tongs on the 
pista..the 
best thing about Pacha? People actually dancing together, girls & boys 
getting it on! After such a good night it was impossible to lay down so 
it 
was time to forget those new years resolutions and head up to the 
afters, 
Club 64 where dj Silvio Dee from Italy twists and spins until the late 
afternoon. A lot of faces, handshakes, the odd scary moment ( I 
remembered 
with a shudder late on Sunday evening how I stopped a Morroccon head 
butting 
the crew who took a bit too long in the bogs by grabbing his necks 
scruff ) 
but most importantly loud twisted house that makes you forget about all 
that 
shit, and throw your hands up! Thanks to all the dj's, producers, and 
beverage companies for making it such a great weekend.  



---------------------------------

--0-1769176638-1042488646=:60934--

 Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com> wrote:on 1/11/03 2:05 PM, Apollo at apollo@speakeasy.org wrote:

> Well, there was "disco," the commercial stuff that most people associate
> with the genre, and then there was Disco, the off the map music that could
> be found primarily in the gay underground clubs of the period, like the
> Paradise Garage.

I guess the commercial stuff in each genre almost always gives it a bad name
to the non-enthusiasts after the trend is over, eh? In the meantime, I
guess I'll try to find a funk night with maybe a house spin. I spent the
last couple of years merely bobbing my head, trainspotting, appreciating DJ
talent, and intellectualizing the track selections - this year, I just wanna
get out and shake my ass.

> If you're interested, West End Records and Strut (2000) released on both
> CDs and vinyl live recordings of Larry Levan at the Paradise Garage in
> 1979. 

Thanks, Apollo! :)

quoth dry throats:
> discos been around since 76-77, 79 was when it died.  hence the gays

At the risk of feeding a troll, let me say this: Disco was a part of gay
culture *long* before '79. Being gay certainly wasn't "mainstream" in
those days, either. Read up:

<http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm>

> no offense, my dad was a disco dj in new yaaaawk.

Riiiight... if anything, that only seems to have made you biased toward
the "mainstream gays" that "picked up" the genre. If it weren't for all
those crazy "gays", a lot of us wouldn't be here, doing what we do (in
the bay area, raving). Show some friggin' respect.

At 12:27 PM 1/13/2003 -0800, dry throats wrote:

>discos been around since 76-77, 79 was when it died.  hence the gays 
>picked it up.
>to me that's mainstream.

My Dear Mr. Throats,

Read my House History 101 or any other history of disco and the origins of 
EDM.  Disco began in the gay subculture and then was adopted in mainstream 
clubs.  And I was there in New Yaaaawk too.  Give your dad my best:)

Love,

Apollo

>get out and shake my ass.
>
> > If you're interested, West End Records and Strut (2000) released on both
> > CDs and vinyl live recordings of Larry Levan at the Paradise Garage in
> > 1979.
>
>Thanks, Apollo! :)

Just a note regarding online shops... if you're patient, or looking for
stuff that didn't just come out, you can special order at most local
shops.

A lot of local record stores are sufferring due to competition with these
sites.  Two years it still wasn't that bad as stores still had event
ticket sales supporting them, but please buy at least some of your stash
at the local shops and keep some of the last remaining centers of dance
music culture around.

andyw

andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Online Vinyl Shops

>A lot of local record stores are sufferring due to 
>competition with these
>sites.  Two years it still wasn't that bad as stores 
>still had event
>ticket sales supporting them, but please buy at least 
>some of your stash
>at the local shops and keep some of the last remaining 
>centers of dance
>music culture around.

I admit I haven't tried this.  Is special ordering through 
Solid Grooves comparable in price to buying vinyl at 
online shops with big back catalogues?

The biggest reason I have for going online is it's 
relatively inexpensive.  Most records are $10 online vs. 
$11 in-store... not a big deal by itself, but if you buy 
from an out-of-state online shop you avoid sales tax, and 
three of the four shops I listed waive shipping if your 
order exceeds from $50 (Dance Records) to $75 (Global 
Beats).  I don't even drive up to Skills anymore because I 
figure the cost to me in gas just adds a few more bucks to 
the cost of those pricey imports.

Of course I'm sure my aversion to Skills meets with a bit 
of your approval, Andy.  LOL, only kidding.  ;-)

I do stop by Solid Grooves from time to time to bug Keith 
or pick up some records when I'm on an impulse buying 
kick.

Carter

cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F115XsegSwjwoEKa00b00017ae8@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301131742310.889-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Online Vinyl Shops


tweakin, solid grooves, housewares, open mind... it really doesn't matter.
find out what distributors carry the stuff you want and request that your
favorite shops carry them.  if you give them feedback, and you're
seriously buying the stuff you order, they'll work with you!  hell, i've
got it worked out that i pick what i want at solid, and then they let me
needle drop each track on the monitors they have there... which helps me
determine which records are gonna sound good on a bigger system.  you
can't really do that with a low quality mp3 on your computer.  you can't
tell a lot of other stuff buying on line either... even little things like
whether the track is cut at 33 or 45 really matter (i want 33 rpm records
for tricks, but 45 records sound better for banging hard stuff with solid
bass, etc).

andyw

andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
you best get off your horse, drink your milk, get the freak out...

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Townshend arrested in porn inquiry Jan 14 2003




The Western Mail - The National Newspaper Of Wales


ROCK legend Pete Townshend was last night arrested by police in connection 
with child pornography offences.

The 57-year-old Who star, who admitted paying to access a website 
advertising child pornography but claimed it was purely for re-search 
purposes, was escorted by officers to a south-west London police station 
where he is currently in custody.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said, "He has been arrested under the Protection 
of Children Act 1978 on suspicion of possessing indecent images of 
children, suspicion of making indecent images of children and on suspicion 
of incitement to distribute indecent images of children."

The spokesman said that a number of items, including computers, had been 
removed from the residential address for forensic examination.

Townshend, whose home was searched by police officers, admitted using his 
credit card on one occasion to view a site advertising child porn "purely 
to see what was there" and insisted he was not a paedophile.


   http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0200wales/page.cfm?objectid=12530157&method=full&siteid=50082






Moksha Tribe


House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

-Henry Adams

clubs. And I was there in New Yaaaawk too. Give your dad my best:)

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

--0-1452799501-1042563829=:89616
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


magazines shmagazines. post a picture of your old magazine from 73 up here. that's all spin from later. my dad lived the era. and you can put that, in your fucking lame-o scene biter magazne. 
 
 sugarsf <sugarsf@pacbell.net> wrote:Dear dry throats,

Please note the following with an open mind:

1. Disco has been around since at least 1973, evidenced by music articles
written at the time by national magazines which refer to a new style of
music called "disco." Additionally, the classic disco tune "Never Gonna Give
You Up" by Barry White was on the music charts that same year.

2. Disco did not die in 1979. True, it was critically wounded on several
counts that year and unquestionably past it's prime, but it wasn't dead.
Some of disco's biggest and greatest tunes were released in 1979; "I Will
Survive" by Gloria Gaynor, "Ring My Bell" by Anita Ward, "We Are Family" by
Sister Sledge, "Hot Stuff/Bad Girls" by Donna Summer, "Born To Be Alive" by
Patrick Hernandez - to name a few. The following year saw massive disco hits
by Blondie, Irene Cara, Diana Ross, and Kool & The Gang - to name a few.

3. Your implication that because something died it was therefore picked up
by the gays is homophobic on so many levels. Incidentally, "the gays"
involvement in disco pre-dates 1979 by a long shot.

4. Your other implication that what constitutes "mainstream" are dead things
that "the gays" "pick up" is illogical from a grammatical point of view and
absurd from a socially historical point of view.

No offense.


> From: dry throats 
> Date: Mon, 13 Jan 2003 12:27:14 -0800 (PST)

> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?
> 
> 
> discos been around since 76-77, 79 was when it died. hence the gays picked it
> up.
> to me that's mainstream.
> no offense, my dad was a disco dj in new yaaaawk.

unless you dj'd or knew someone personally who helped create the scene(like my dad), back in the early days of disco, not the later days, then all you're really doing is biting on the scene and trying to make it for what it was not.  i.e. a gay scene. 
it was a party scene for sure, drugs, sex etc. but to say it started as a gay scene as the forefront is really naive. i don't blame some of you for thinking that way because you follwed knuckles and laven. but newsflash, they didn't create the scene. 
take care
rip maurice gibb

Give
> You Up" by Barry White was on the music charts that same year.
>

> counts that year and unquestionably past it's prime, but it wasn't dead.
> Some of disco's biggest and greatest tunes were released in 1979; "I Will
> Survive" by Gloria Gaynor, "Ring My Bell" by Anita Ward, "We Are Family"
by
> Sister Sledge, "Hot Stuff/Bad Girls" by Donna Summer, "Born To Be Alive"
by

hits
> by Blondie, Irene Cara, Diana Ross, and Kool & The Gang - to name a few.

> by the gays is homophobic on so many levels. Incidentally, "the gays"

is right, because there's no one bigger, stronger, smarter, or cooler than
my dad. Did you know my dad played football for the Polk High School
football team? That's right. The team that won the Cook County, Illinois
sectional championship in '67. My dad INVENTED the 4-man blitz with his
buddies on the defensive line. You know why? Because he's so big, strong,
smart, and cool, that everything he says is right, especially when he's
talking about football. So that makes me an expert in football now. Go
ahead. Ask me anything. I know more than Madden.

Loving this thread. Back when I was first throwing raves (many, many years
ago) I rented an old, closed down gay nightclub in San Diego. Had the best
set-up for dancing. Was awesome.

We went exploring into the back rooms. Found this old locked room. Didn't
know what it was. After a few weeks at this place, one of the managers came
through for something, opened up the door...

It was FILLED with old disco record. At least 10,000.

Very curious about that old room.


-radley

--0-470343955-1042569398=:37550
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


Hey everyone...

My name is Piper.

I try and read through all these posting at least once a week. I post very seldom unless I'm looking for a party to go to.

I started raving about 4 years ago, mostly underground......Worked at a club which used to shut down after hours and host raves until the wee hours of morning light. (about 4 a month) I have been to most of the clubs in Las Vegas and listened to tons of wild-ass remixes. Woo Hoo!!!

I was in San Francisco last month for business and had the opportunity to go to a little mexican restaurant/bar on 16th Street and met some of the crew from Elastique. I guess, after hours (10:00 p.m. -1:30 a.m.) on Wednesday nights they get Dj's to come in and spin.

It was quite a treat... the music was phenominally great and I had a blast. A couple of the guys even helped me with my sticks to get a better light trail.

Anyway.... I'm moving to the Sacramento area in March/April for work and I'm looking for a couple of different things:

1) A place to live that is party (raver) friendly and nice. (You know with all of the amenities, kitchen, bathroom, bedrooms, garage, etc...) Maybe, multiple bedrooms and I'll get room mates since I'll be there for about a year.

2) A place to party.... You know the one... without all the drama, just a place to hang out and get my groove on.

3) Good people to party with... YEP.... the ones without a lot of drama that know how to party and have respect for others, while still making sure everyone is safe and having a good time.

 

I know this is a lot to ask....... Way too much for a lot of people I've met in the past however, the older I get, the more faith I have in Humanity.

If you know of any of these things, PLEASE get back to me ASAP.

 

Thanks

 

Piper

 



"Listen, Hear, Feel, Be Inspired"

Fulfill Your Destiny

*******Reunite the Tribes*******

<BR>
&gt;Last year you helped the Drug Policy Alliance stop the RAVE Act from<BR>
&gt;becoming law. This year supporters of the draconian drug war bill are<BR>
&gt;back with a vengeance.&nbsp; They have stopped calling it the &quot;RAVE Act&quot;<BR>
&gt;and have stuck its provisions in a popular omnibus domestic security<BR>
&gt;bill. This is a common Congressional ploy: put controversial bills<BR>
&gt;that can't go anywhere on their own into important bills, so that<BR>
&gt;Members of Congress are forced to vote for them.<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;Your help is needed to stop these disguised RAVE Act provisions from<BR>
&gt;becoming law!!!<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;The bill, S.22, is sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD). The<BR>
&gt;troubling drug war provisions are in the section entitled &quot;Crack<BR>
&gt;House Statute Amendments&quot;<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;ACTIONS TO TAKE<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;*** Call your two Senators. You can contact your Senators through the<BR>
&gt;Capitol Switchboard at 202-224-3121. To find out who your Senators<BR>
&gt;are go to: <a href="http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm.">http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm.</a><BR>
&gt;Tell them:<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1) You oppose the &quot;crack house statute&quot; amendments in S.22.<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 2) These provisions are just like the provisions in the RAVE Act<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; last year.<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 3) The provisions would endanger public health, free speech, and<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; property rights.<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 4) Urge them to contact Daschle's office and work to get these<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; provisions removed from S.22.<BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;** Fax Senator Daschle (even if he is not one of your two Senators).<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp; To fax Senator Daschle go to:<BR>
&gt;<a href="http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448.">http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&amp;item=1448.</a><BR>
&gt;<BR>
&gt;** Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. The<BR>
&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp; Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.<BR>

Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030114121425.0259b910@mail.speakeasy.org>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.org

Subject: [sfraves] RAVE Act Re-Introduced!! Urgent Action Needed 

--=====================_9822656==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Last year you helped the Drug Policy Alliance stop the RAVE Act from
becoming law. This year supporters of the draconian drug war bill are
back with a vengeance. They have stopped calling it the "RAVE Act"
and have stuck its provisions in a popular omnibus domestic security
bill. This is a common Congressional ploy: put controversial bills
that can't go anywhere on their own into important bills, so that
Members of Congress are forced to vote for them.

Your help is needed to stop these disguised RAVE Act provisions from
becoming law!!!

The bill, S.22, is sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD). The
troubling drug war provisions are in the section entitled "Crack
House Statute Amendments"

ACTIONS TO TAKE

*** Call your two Senators. You can contact your Senators through the
Capitol Switchboard at 202-224-3121. To find out who your Senators
are go to: http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm.
Tell them:

1) You oppose the "crack house statute" amendments in S.22.

2) These provisions are just like the provisions in the RAVE Act
last year.

3) The provisions would endanger public health, free speech, and
property rights.

4) Urge them to contact Daschle's office and work to get these
provisions removed from S.22.

** Fax Senator Daschle (even if he is not one of your two Senators).

To fax Senator Daschle go to:
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448.

** Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. The
Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.
For more information on the RAVE Act and how the S. 22 "crack house"
provisions will affect public health, free speech, and property
rights see: http://www.nomoredrugwar.org/music/rave_act.htm



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_9822656==_.ALT--

At 09:14 AM 1/14/2003, dry throats wrote:


>unless you dj'd or knew someone personally who helped create the 
>scene(like my dad), back in the early days of disco, not the later days, 
>then all you're really doing is biting on the scene and trying to make it 
>for what it was not.  i.e. a gay scene.
>it was a party scene for sure, drugs, sex etc. but to say it started as a 
>gay scene as the forefront is really naive. i don't blame some of you for 
>thinking that way because you follwed knuckles and laven. but newsflash, 
>they didn't create the scene.
>take care
>rip maurice gibb
>
>
>
>
>  dry throats <drythroats@yahoo.com> wrote:
>magazines shmagazines. post a picture of your old magazine from 73 up 
>here. that's all spin from later. my dad lived the era. and you can put 
>that, in your fucking lame-o scene biter magazne.
>
>sugarsf wrote:Dear dry throats,
>
>Please note the following with an open mind:
>
>1. Disco has been around since at least 1973, evidenced by music articles
>written at the time by national magazines which refer to a new style of
>music called "disco." Additionally, the classic disco tune "Never Gonna Give
>You Up" by Barry White was on the music charts that same year.
>
>2. Disco did not die in 1979. True, it was critically wounded on several
>counts that year and unquestionably past it's prime, but it wasn't dead.
>Some of disco's biggest and greatest tunes were released in 1979; "I Will
>Survive" by Gloria Gaynor, "Ring My Bell" by Anita Ward, "We Are Family" by
>Sister Sledge, "Hot Stuff/Bad Girls" by Donna Summer, "Born To Be Alive" by
>Patrick Hernandez - to name a few. The following year saw massive disco hits
>by Blondie, Irene Cara, Diana Ross, and Kool & The Gang - to name a few.
>
>3. Your implication that because something died it was therefore picked up
>by the gays is homophobic on so many levels. Incidentally, "the gays"
>involvement in disco pre-dates 1979 by a long shot.
>
>4. Your other implication that what constitutes "mainstream" are dead things
>that "the gays" "pick up" is illogical from a grammatical point of view and
>absurd from a socially historical point of view.
>
>No offense.
>
>

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0301141512320.18408-100000@freke.odin.pdx.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?


Give it 30 years.

Everyone will be swearing up and down that all those "gosh darn electronic
moozic deejays" were both homosexual and addicted to ecstasy, sometimes
gnoshing down upwards of eight pills a night.

Then someone will pipe in "Uh, I had a relative who spun house from
'95-00, and he wasn't gay. Furthermore, he was pointedly against the
widespread drug abuse in the scene."

And there will be a long ha ha my dad ha ha spiel in their futuristic
avatar-driven vmail, and someone will get pissed off and run someone else
over with their flying car. Or fly them over. Suck them into their
turbines, whatever. And little billy will be left an orphan.

An orphan. Can you bear that on your conscience?

You cannot make a blanket statement like 'disco was a 100% gay culture'
and expect to be taken any more seriously than Mr. Superdad over here.

I'd assume, as ravers, most of you would be more willing to trust word of
mouth than the mainstream media. I realize we're in SF and all, so this
kind of stuff gets kinda hyperbole... but come on, guys.

Next we're going to hear how everyone in the 80s was doing cocaine.
And was gay.
And owned a BMW.

Pfft. Does it even matter? :P

The (ir)Rational Hatter

> >sugarsf wrote:Dear dry throats,
> >
> >Please note the following with an open mind:
> >
> >1. Disco has been around since at least 1973, evidenced by music articles
> >written at the time by national magazines which refer to a new style of
> >music called "disco." Additionally, the classic disco tune "Never Gonna Give
> >You Up" by Barry White was on the music charts that same year.
> >
> >2. Disco did not die in 1979. True, it was critically wounded on several
> >counts that year and unquestionably past it's prime, but it wasn't dead.
> >Some of disco's biggest and greatest tunes were released in 1979; "I Will
> >Survive" by Gloria Gaynor, "Ring My Bell" by Anita Ward, "We Are Family" by
> >Sister Sledge, "Hot Stuff/Bad Girls" by Donna Summer, "Born To Be Alive" by
> >Patrick Hernandez - to name a few. The following year saw massive disco hits
> >by Blondie, Irene Cara, Diana Ross, and Kool & The Gang - to name a few.
> >
> >3. Your implication that because something died it was therefore picked up
> >by the gays is homophobic on so many levels. Incidentally, "the gays"
> >involvement in disco pre-dates 1979 by a long shot.
> >
> >4. Your other implication that what constitutes "mainstream" are dead things
> >that "the gays" "pick up" is illogical from a grammatical point of view and
> >absurd from a socially historical point of view.
> >
> >No offense.

Quite true, but I don't think (by my cold medication-addled recollection)

are accurate, at least some people did take the time to try to back up their
claims (or refute Mr. Superdad's) with more than hearsay. And that's a hell
of a lot more than I can say for a lot of the opinions masquerading as facts
here, as well as on other culture-oriented mailing lists/boards.

Thanks to all of you who came last week, it was a great
night, with many tasty house beats and yummy drinks.

This week we are happy to present Dyloot (Skills), who'll
treat you to a special concoction of progressive and tech
trance.


_ DYLOOT ________________________________________________

One of the top trance DJs and producers in the San
Francisco Bay Area, Dyloot is half owner of Skills DJ
Workshop in Berkeley, and the Skills Recordings record
label. A DJ since 1996, Dyloot's original techno influences
began in college with a group of fellow students and skaters.

His minimal-filtered techno style 'tranceformed' once he
"saw the light at F-8". Tom Slik & Dyloot started Slik-e-Loot
in 1997, and eventually changed their name to SKILLS. They
now throw some of the largest and most successful trance
events in the SF Bay Area.

Info: http://www.fatemanagement.com/flash/dyloot.html

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

At 03:20 PM 1/14/2003 -0800, Sean Griffith wrote:


>You cannot make a blanket statement like 'disco was a 100% gay culture'
>and expect to be taken any more seriously than Mr. Superdad over here.
>

Now, here's the real inside info on the origin of disco.

Some aliens were cruising about New Jersey one summer's eve, and decided to 
administer anal probes to several hundred hard-core rock fans at a local 
concert.  After that event, these "normal" folk started a shakin' and 
movin', throwin' their arms up in the air, wearin' polyester and chain, and 
began what the government in secret files called the "alien-probe 
conversion"  event.  Many were apparently affected by this probing, which 
it turns out, introduced some sort of contagious jitterbug virus into 
straight New Jersey folk who, when they crossed the bridge and tunnels into 
Manhattan, spread this virus to gays, African Americans, and other less 
"normal" people.  Soon all of New York, and the country, were infected with 
"Saturday Night Fever" virus, alien in origin.

So, yes, disco originated in straight former rock culture in New Jersey and 
spread into the dark corners of New York and beyond.

The government deliberately suppressed all this info, and rewrote history, 
including magazines, billboard top sellers, and culture rags to avoid mass 
hysteria.

Come on guys.  Seriously.  I don't think anyone believes disco was 100% 
gay, or whatever.  But, like many musical genres, disco originated in 
marginalized subcultures -- in this case, African American and gay -- and 
moved on into the mainstream.  This is undeniable fact, whether one is 
comfortable with it or not.  I sense underlying homophobia in some this 
discussion.

I admire dry throats' blind devotion to his father, but he can't even spell 
the names of some of the major players correctly and apparently has never 
investigated this part of musical history on his own.

Barry Lederer wrote me recently asking me if I was willing to write a more 
comprehensive history of disco, since he believes such a work is long 
overdue.  My focus has been on the origins of house music but when one 
hears some of the strange shit that begins to circulate over time I can see 
why some objective and comprehensive treatment is necessary.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

> administer anal probes to several hundred hard-core rock fans at a local
> concert. 

Dude!  I was there! I was outside of the Meadowlands, waiting to get into
the big, rockin, hetero Judas Priest show, and next thing you know, my
mullet became a 'fro, my leather pants a set of bell bottoms, and my muscle
shirt turned into this striped butterfly-collar number. A week later, I
bought a faux gold medallion the size of a manhole cover and a set of roller
skates. I shit you not, man! Thanks for reawakening these suppressed
memories, Apollo. 

 - omid

Subject: [sfraves] Fw:RAVE Act Reintroduced


OK, looks like they dinn't waste any time.

Same as last year, call/write your Senator/Congressman to voice your
disapproval.

btw, this looks like a rider on another bill.

-n


SR. 22 (108th Congress)

Part 4-Crack House Statute Amendments
   Sec. 5131. Offenses. Amends crack house statute (21 U.S.C. $B!x(B856) to make
it apply to those who (1) knowingly open, lease, rent, use or maintain a
place either permanently or temporarily for the purpose of manufacturing,
distributing or using any controlled substance and (2) manage or control any
place, whether permanently or temporarily, for the purpose of unlawfully
manufacturing, storing, distributing, or using a controlled substance. These
changes clarify that the law applies not just to ongoing drug distribution
operations, but to ``single-event'' activities. This section also applies
the law to outdoor as well as indoor venues.

   Sec. 5132. Civil penalty and equitable relief for maintaining
drug-involved premises. Establishes the civil penalty for violating 21
U.S.C. $B!x(B856 as amended to either $250,000 or two times the gross receipts
that were derived from each violation of that section.

   Sec. 5133. Declaratory and injunctive remedies. Authorizes the Attorney
General to commence a civil action for declaratory or injunctive relief for
violations of 21 U.S.C. $B!x(B856 as amended.

   Sec. 5134. Sentencing Commission guidelines. Requires the Sentencing
Commission to review Federal sentencing guidelines with respect to offenses
involving gammahydroxybutyric acid and consider amending Federal
sentencing guidelines to provide for increased penalties.

   Sec. 5135. Authorization of appropriations for a demand reduction
coordinator. Authorizes $5.9 million to the Drug Enforcement Administration
to hire a special agent in each State to coordinate demand reduction
activities.

   Sec. 5136. Authorization of appropriations for drug education. Authorizes
such sums as may be necessary to the Drug Enforcement Administration to
educate youths, parents, and other interested adults about the drugs
associated with raves.

X-Originating-IP: [204.193.184.215]
From: "His Highness" <the_emperor99@hotmail.com>
To: apollo@speakeasy.org, srg@pdx.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Wed, 15 Jan 2003 02:00:52 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F53s6D8d2ng8nr8fL1R0002c353@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 15 Jan 2003 02:00:52.0762 (UTC) FILETIME=[EEEF67A0:01C2BC39]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: In defense of/ Disco?

Regardless of where Disco originated from (and I believe Apollo's version 
sans alien embellishment;) there is no doubt about one thing when you 
consider the chronology of events, were it not for Disco, there would be no 
House, which means there would have been no raves.

It is unfortunate that Disco's name got so tarnished in the late 70's early 
80's thanks to the cookie cutter commercial mindless crap the labels started 
turning out, not unlike so much of rap music today. Someone recently gave 
props to the 70's disco hit by the Bee Gees Stayin' Alive. (Hats off to 
Maurice Gibb, rest in peace good brother)Well I'd like to add to the list. 
Pardon me as I reminisce. Who can deny the incredible songwriting talents of 
Nile Rodgers & Bernard Edwards from the group CHIC("I want your 
love","Forbidden Lover" - talk about a phat bassline), who also wrote and 
produced for the 70's hit group SISTER SLEDGE of "We are a family" fame. 
This was some of the best music ever written and performed, true disco - 
creative, heavy on musicianship, soulful, excellent arrangements, steeped in 
Rhythm and Blues.

Let's not forget PRINCE either. Most of you are too young to know this but 
PRINCE's early recordings were released in the 70's (ha, and you thought 
prince is 80's! Purple Rain, Red Corvette yada yada) If you can find it, 
check out the outro in the "Sexy Dancer" release in '78 -it's like listening 
to a House track. Hmmm come to think of it, I might just bust out that track 
at a party.  Like him or not, the man was ahead of his time and a genius.


Oh yeah, and so what if gays brought the World Disco. True Disco is amazing 
stuff, even if it got handed down by gay aliens;)


In defense of Disco.


Paulie Paul
Dammit, I'm just too old for my own good.



"It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses an 
ocean of mistrust and hate"
(The Outer Limits)





>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: Sean Griffith <srg@pdx.edu>,sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?
>Date: Tue, 14 Jan 2003 17:01:02 -0800
>
>At 03:20 PM 1/14/2003 -0800, Sean Griffith wrote:
>
>
>>You cannot make a blanket statement like 'disco was a 100% gay culture'
>>and expect to be taken any more seriously than Mr. Superdad over here.
>>
>
>Now, here's the real inside info on the origin of disco.
>
>Some aliens were cruising about New Jersey one summer's eve, and decided to 
>administer anal probes to several hundred hard-core rock fans at a local 
>concert.  After that event, these "normal" folk started a shakin' and 
>movin', throwin' their arms up in the air, wearin' polyester and chain, and 
>began what the government in secret files called the "alien-probe 
>conversion"  event.  Many were apparently affected by this probing, which 
>it turns out, introduced some sort of contagious jitterbug virus into 
>straight New Jersey folk who, when they crossed the bridge and tunnels into 
>Manhattan, spread this virus to gays, African Americans, and other less 
>"normal" people.  Soon all of New York, and the country, were infected with 
>"Saturday Night Fever" virus, alien in origin.
>
>So, yes, disco originated in straight former rock culture in New Jersey and 
>spread into the dark corners of New York and beyond.
>
>The government deliberately suppressed all this info, and rewrote history, 
>including magazines, billboard top sellers, and culture rags to avoid mass 
>hysteria.
>
>Come on guys.  Seriously.  I don't think anyone believes disco was 100% 
>gay, or whatever.  But, like many musical genres, disco originated in 
>marginalized subcultures -- in this case, African American and gay -- and 
>moved on into the mainstream.  This is undeniable fact, whether one is 
>comfortable with it or not.  I sense underlying homophobia in some this 
>discussion.
>
>I admire dry throats' blind devotion to his father, but he can't even spell 
>the names of some of the major players correctly and apparently has never 
>investigated this part of musical history on his own.
>
>Barry Lederer wrote me recently asking me if I was willing to write a more 
>comprehensive history of disco, since he believes such a work is long 
>overdue.  My focus has been on the origins of house music but when one 
>hears some of the strange shit that begins to circulate over time I can see 
>why some objective and comprehensive treatment is necessary.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>
>
>Moksha Tribe
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>

>not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a

Subject: [sfraves] FW: Peace marches this Saturday



(from Otto of Tiki News)

A friend of mine created this website and poster image to use for the
upcoming
peace rallies and future peace rallies as needed
I think it is pretty cool so I am now sharing it with you
____________________________________

In response to our government's apparent determination
to go to war with Irag, some friends and I have
created a website for distributing anti-war art on a
mass scale. Please check it out at
http://www.anotherposterforpeace.com/

If you like it, please do us all a favor and pass it
on.

As a citizen of the United States, I am deeply
concerned about where we are headed. Real patriots ask
questions: Does it make sense to attack a country over
what it MIGHT do in the future when we can easily
monitor such activities by satellite? What kind of a
precedent does this set for international relations?

Is this war really going to make us safer, or will a
pre-emptive strike anger Arab nations, making
terrorist acts against the U.S. more likely?

We MUST speak up and say this war is wrong. Using art
as a tool for public discussion is one way we can do
this. If enough of us print these posters out and put
them in our cars and windows, we can raise the level
of public awareness to the point where politicians
will HAVE to listen to us. If enough of us voice our
dissent, we will be heard.

=====
Kimberly Cross
Another Poster For Peace

Tiki News
2215-R Market Street #177
San Francisco, CA 94114
www.tikinews.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR:  Crossfader help...

Hi Adrian,

I would just buy a new crossfader. Three years is a long time.
De-Ox is what you want to use if you want to squeeze one or two more seasons
out of your cross fader. De-Ox is available under a generic name at Radio
Shack.

If you got the dough, buy the X-Fader, though. Electronics have a way of
giving out at the worst time.

World of stereo on Market can be the cheapest if you do some research and
check other stores prices. (google 'PSSL' for the definitive discount price
on all DJ gear)

-----Original Message-----

dancefloor etc etc etc.
