Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

Heh. I have here a magazine dated 1973 with some terrific pictures of mysel=
f
getting arrested at a New York Dolls concert on Halloween at the Waldorf
Astoria in NYC. All the cool straight people were into proto-punk and/or
glitter at the time.

Anyway, after being fingerprinted and released at the 19th Precinct after
promising never again to stand in the middle of a smoke bomb wearing silver
lam=E9 getting photographed in the Waldorf lobby, I grabbed a cab and went to
Le Jardin and ended up winning $25 in a costume contest. Le Jardin was most
definitely a gay disco in 1973. The Loft (from 1970!) and later Paradise
Garage were too. Ditto the Ice Palace in the city and better yet Fire
Island, along with the Monster and the Boatel. So was Studio 54--straight
people were welcome only as long as they were fabulous (and preferably
accompanied by beautiful young men) at least while it was in its glory
years. Of course after disco peaked in 1977, just about anyone got past the
door at Studio, and then Xenon opened and, well, ugh.

Apollo has it right. You can believe me (lol) because both my roommates wer=
e
gay men and one of them was Grace Jone's twin brother, who was a DJ at
Hurrahs. Jeez, ask Grace Jones about gay men belatedly "discovering" disco
in 1979.=20

vix

On Tuesday, Jan 14, 2003, at 12:43 US/Pacific, Dragn'fly wrote:

> With things going as they are: the economy, this talk of war, terrorism
> - I find it incredible that this issue is still being addressed with
> such ferver.  I mean, geebus, isn't there enough to worry about?

That is  WHY they want to do this now.
They don't want us to think about the economy.
They don't want us to think  about this perpetual war they want to have.
They just want us to make us hate and fear whomever they say.
They deal in the very opposite of PLUR.
They will try to destroy anything that interferes with their 
hatemongering.

Why is it that they spend so much more effort trying to stop raves than 
gangs?
Why do they bust all of the Ecstasy, LSD and  pot, but let the  crank 
go through?
Why is it that even the most popular electronic dance music is almost 
never on the radio
but Eminem is all over it?

Ride the Music

AndyTiedye

>> From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]

>>
>> Last year you helped the Drug Policy Alliance stop the RAVE Act from
>> becoming law. This year supporters of the draconian drug war bill are
>> back with a vengeance. They have stopped calling it the "RAVE Act"
>> and have stuck its provisions in a popular omnibus domestic security
>> bill. This is a common Congressional ploy: put controversial bills
>> that can't go anywhere on their own into important bills, so that
>> Members of Congress are forced to vote for them.
>>
>> Your help is needed to stop these disguised RAVE Act provisions from
>> becoming law!!!
>>
>> The bill, S.22, is sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD). The
>> troubling drug war provisions are in the section entitled "Crack
>> House Statute Amendments"
>>
>> ACTIONS TO TAKE
>>
>> *** Call your two Senators. You can contact your Senators through the
>> Capitol Switchboard at 202-224-3121. To find out who your Senators
>> are go to: http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm.
>> Tell them:
>>
>> 1) You oppose the "crack house statute" amendments in S.22.
>>
>> 2) These provisions are just like the provisions in the RAVE Act
>> last year.
>>
>> 3) The provisions would endanger public health, free speech, and
>> property rights.
>>
>> 4) Urge them to contact Daschle's office and work to get these
>> provisions removed from S.22.
>>
>> ** Fax Senator Daschle (even if he is not one of your two Senators).
>>
>> To fax Senator Daschle go to:
>> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448.
>>
>> ** Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. The
>> Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.
>> For more information on the RAVE Act and how the S. 22 "crack house"
>> provisions will affect public health, free speech, and property
>> rights see: http://www.nomoredrugwar.org/music/rave_act.htm

> >> property rights.

> >> provisions removed from S.22.
> >>

> >>

> >> Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.

> >> rights see: http://www.nomoredrugwar.org/music/rave_act.htm

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Crossfader help...

CaiLube can work wonders at times, but if you have serious bleed, it's
probably time for a new fader.  That sort of behavior speaks of wear,
the likes of which some lubrication isn't going to do much about.

But try it first- it's a lot cheaper than a new crossfader, and you'll
find other uses for it even if it doesn't do the trick on this
conundrum.

GeorgeC
www.djorigami.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?

If you mean the kind that don't require you to stop, and pop out the
wheels...

http://www.heelys.com/window.asp

otherwise you might have seen these:
http://www.streetflyers.com/cgi-bin/ncommerce3/ExecMacro/home.d2w/report

Personally I like the heelys for being a normal looking skate shoe that with
a pivot of the ankle becomes a skate. It's eerie when you see kids at
parties with them. I'll never forget the Serenity party at Metreon where I
saw 3 kids just float across the ground and then stop and keep walking. I
keep thinking about getting a pair this spring when I start taking bart into
work more. The streetflyers just seem a bit ghetto to me. Too chunky of a
shoe and you have to stop and flip out your skates.

Heely's are at Copelands and are under $100 usually. Apollo also mentioned
Skates On Haight which is a great local shop. Used to buy all of my wheels
there back in the day!

ryan.bailey

Date: Wed, 15 Jan 2003 10:54:23 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, srg@pdx.edu, drythroats@yahoo.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?


> Pfft. Does it even matter? :P

(No offence intended to disco's fans here... but ugh...)

Not really.  Disco is one of the few genres of music I can honestly say I have
no love for.  When someone spinning house starts to make it sound too much like
disco, I leave the room.  And I'm kinda glad I'm too young to have suffered
through the disco era.  (I kinda woulda liked to catch the last bit of the '60s
tho.  But then I would've had to go into hibernation for most of the '70s, and
wake back up during the days of punk rock (good music's rebellion against
disco), and '80s new wave.)

So nah... I wasn't there, and neither was, I'm sure, 99% of this list.  And it
all really DOES come down to trusting one person's word vs another (the hearsay
reported by another, actually).

First off tho, I don't remember Apollo ever claiming that everyone in the disco
scene was gay and there were no straight people there.  That'd be just silly. 
For example, there's a significant straight contingent that goes to Faith every
week.  Why would anyone claim or believe that it is different at New York
discos?!?!?

But even if he HAD claimed that the disco scene was 100% totally gay with no
exceptions; I'd be far more inclined to believe Apollo (who has a long history
of being one one of the most positive contributors to the list and the scense)
over some random homophobic bigot who appeared out of nowhere and started
trolling (and whose arguement, as others have pointed out, is bases all around
the "my dad can beat up your dad" theme).

It's just a matter of credibility.


cya,
john

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Disco?

I wore Heely's for a year straight, they're awesome..  At work, at
parties and clubs, everywhere. :)  They're wonderful but damn can it
hurt when you fall.  I probably knew the kids you're talking about at
serenity, unless they were really young.  The ones I'm thinking of look
early 20's but they're pushing 30+.

The way Heely's are designed are very non-intrusive.  I could jog in
them, dance in them etc with no problems.  Cracks in the streets and
sidewalks are what always posed my biggest problems, but I love crusin'
down Steiner comin' from Haight... That's about the perfect hill for
speed and safety.  Get goin' like 15 - 20 miles an hour :)

-Rayn

From: c <cloude_sf@yahoo.com>

In-Reply-To: <20030115192041.43782.qmail@web41107.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] Jazz / blues venues?

boom boom room (across from the fillmore, at
fillmore/geary) has a late night permit.  on the
weekends, their shows go past 2am sometimes, and i've
even been to shows that have gone on till almost 7am
there.  

there are some other venues downtown, but i'm not too
familiar with them, plus i don't think they go late
night, and are more tourist geared.  

http://jambase.com/search.asp?city=San+Francisco 
for upcoming jazz/blues/jam shows in the city.

have fun,
c

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Re: In defense of/ Disco?

And tag on in front of disco Ken Kesey's Electric Kool-Aid Acid Tests
which by all descriptions sound like some of the coolest raves I've ever
heard of (The Greatful Dead in small venues/broken into houses, with
people blissfully dancing in extasy anyone?) with an honorable mention
to Kraftwerk for creating the first drum machine and totally electronic
music ;)  Then we can go way back to the Theramin's invention..
Chronology is really amazing as to how many places back things can be
related to and where they spread from and combine again for a new genre.

-----Original Message-----
From: His Highness [mailto:the_emperor99@hotmail.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, January 14, 2003 6:01 PM
To: apollo@speakeasy.org; srg@pdx.edu; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Re: In defense of/ Disco?


Regardless of where Disco originated from (and I believe Apollo's
version 
sans alien embellishment;) there is no doubt about one thing when you 
consider the chronology of events, were it not for Disco, there would be
no 
House, which means there would have been no raves.

It is unfortunate that Disco's name got so tarnished in the late 70's
early 
80's thanks to the cookie cutter commercial mindless crap the labels
started 
turning out, not unlike so much of rap music today. Someone recently
gave 
props to the 70's disco hit by the Bee Gees Stayin' Alive. (Hats off to 
Maurice Gibb, rest in peace good brother)Well I'd like to add to the
list. 
Pardon me as I reminisce. Who can deny the incredible songwriting
talents of 
Nile Rodgers & Bernard Edwards from the group CHIC("I want your 
love","Forbidden Lover" - talk about a phat bassline), who also wrote
and 
produced for the 70's hit group SISTER SLEDGE of "We are a family" fame.

This was some of the best music ever written and performed, true disco -

creative, heavy on musicianship, soulful, excellent arrangements,
steeped in 
Rhythm and Blues.

Let's not forget PRINCE either. Most of you are too young to know this
but 
PRINCE's early recordings were released in the 70's (ha, and you thought

prince is 80's! Purple Rain, Red Corvette yada yada) If you can find it,

check out the outro in the "Sexy Dancer" release in '78 -it's like
listening 
to a House track. Hmmm come to think of it, I might just bust out that
track 
at a party.  Like him or not, the man was ahead of his time and a
genius.


Oh yeah, and so what if gays brought the World Disco. True Disco is
amazing 
stuff, even if it got handed down by gay aliens;)


In defense of Disco.


Paulie Paul
Dammit, I'm just too old for my own good.



"It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses
an 
ocean of mistrust and hate"
(The Outer Limits)





>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: Sean Griffith <srg@pdx.edu>,sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Disco?
>Date: Tue, 14 Jan 2003 17:01:02 -0800
>
>At 03:20 PM 1/14/2003 -0800, Sean Griffith wrote:
>
>
>>You cannot make a blanket statement like 'disco was a 100% gay 
>>culture' and expect to be taken any more seriously than Mr. Superdad 
>>over here.
>>
>
>Now, here's the real inside info on the origin of disco.
>
>Some aliens were cruising about New Jersey one summer's eve, and 
>decided to
>administer anal probes to several hundred hard-core rock fans at a
local 
>concert.  After that event, these "normal" folk started a shakin' and 
>movin', throwin' their arms up in the air, wearin' polyester and chain,
and 
>began what the government in secret files called the "alien-probe 
>conversion"  event.  Many were apparently affected by this probing,
which 
>it turns out, introduced some sort of contagious jitterbug virus into 
>straight New Jersey folk who, when they crossed the bridge and tunnels
into 
>Manhattan, spread this virus to gays, African Americans, and other less

>"normal" people.  Soon all of New York, and the country, were infected
with 
>"Saturday Night Fever" virus, alien in origin.
>
>So, yes, disco originated in straight former rock culture in New Jersey

>and
>spread into the dark corners of New York and beyond.
>
>The government deliberately suppressed all this info, and rewrote 
>history,
>including magazines, billboard top sellers, and culture rags to avoid
mass 
>hysteria.
>
>Come on guys.  Seriously.  I don't think anyone believes disco was 100%
>gay, or whatever.  But, like many musical genres, disco originated in 
>marginalized subcultures -- in this case, African American and gay --
and 
>moved on into the mainstream.  This is undeniable fact, whether one is 
>comfortable with it or not.  I sense underlying homophobia in some this

>discussion.
>
>I admire dry throats' blind devotion to his father, but he can't even 
>spell
>the names of some of the major players correctly and apparently has
never 
>investigated this part of musical history on his own.
>
>Barry Lederer wrote me recently asking me if I was willing to write a 
>more
>comprehensive history of disco, since he believes such a work is long 
>overdue.  My focus has been on the origins of house music but when one 
>hears some of the strange shit that begins to circulate over time I can
see 
>why some objective and comprehensive treatment is necessary.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>
>
>Moksha Tribe
>
>House Music 101:  
>http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It

>is
>not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a 
>purpose."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you 
>are
>only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
>-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
>
>"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
>-Henry Adams

one small factual point: to my knowledge, all of the Acid Tests were held 
either at rented venues or at peoples' homes which were offered 
willingly...there was never an Acid Test at a "broken-into house."

> >Date: Tue, 14 Jan 2003 17:01:02 -0800
> >
> >At 03:20 PM 1/14/2003 -0800, Sean Griffith wrote:
> >
> >
> >>You cannot make a blanket statement like 'disco was a 100% gay
> >>culture' and expect to be taken any more seriously than Mr. Superdad
> >>over here.
> >>
> >
> >Now, here's the real inside info on the origin of disco.
> >
> >Some aliens were cruising about New Jersey one summer's eve, and
> >decided to
> >administer anal probes to several hundred hard-core rock fans at a
>local
> >concert.  After that event, these "normal" folk started a shakin' and
> >movin', throwin' their arms up in the air, wearin' polyester and chain,
>and
> >began what the government in secret files called the "alien-probe
> >conversion"  event.  Many were apparently affected by this probing,
>which
> >it turns out, introduced some sort of contagious jitterbug virus into
> >straight New Jersey folk who, when they crossed the bridge and tunnels
>into
> >Manhattan, spread this virus to gays, African Americans, and other less
>
> >"normal" people.  Soon all of New York, and the country, were infected
>with
> >"Saturday Night Fever" virus, alien in origin.
> >
> >So, yes, disco originated in straight former rock culture in New Jersey
>
> >and
> >spread into the dark corners of New York and beyond.
> >
> >The government deliberately suppressed all this info, and rewrote
> >history,
> >including magazines, billboard top sellers, and culture rags to avoid
>mass
> >hysteria.
> >
> >Come on guys.  Seriously.  I don't think anyone believes disco was 100%
> >gay, or whatever.  But, like many musical genres, disco originated in
> >marginalized subcultures -- in this case, African American and gay --
>and
> >moved on into the mainstream.  This is undeniable fact, whether one is
> >comfortable with it or not.  I sense underlying homophobia in some this
>
> >discussion.
> >
> >I admire dry throats' blind devotion to his father, but he can't even
> >spell
> >the names of some of the major players correctly and apparently has
>never
> >investigated this part of musical history on his own.
> >
> >Barry Lederer wrote me recently asking me if I was willing to write a
> >more
> >comprehensive history of disco, since he believes such a work is long
> >overdue.  My focus has been on the origins of house music but when one
> >hears some of the strange shit that begins to circulate over time I can
>see
> >why some objective and comprehensive treatment is necessary.
> >
> >Love,
> >
> >Apollo
> >
> >
> >
> >Moksha Tribe
> >
> >House Music 101:
> >http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >
> >"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It
>
> >is
> >not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a
> >purpose."
> >-Helen Keller
> >
> >"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you
> >are
> >only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
> >-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
> >
> >"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
> >-Henry Adams

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

This weeks guest:
Dj Dub (D.E.N. Entertainment [Sac] / Faze Frequency)

    Dub began spinning in the winter of '99 and has been developing his
skills as an up and comer in the Northern California scene.  His taste for
house, and the progressive side of music, was inspired by such big names as
DJ Dan and John Digweed.  Dub likes his house deep and progressive and his
sets are just that, with trippy blends of spacey sounds and tribal beats.
Dub keeps the energy of his sets on the same wavelength as his style,
progressive, constantly pushing the people on the dance floor forward.  The
roller-coaster ride of a DJ Dub set is nothing to miss out on, he keeps the
groove locked and the beats rocking.

      YOU HAVE HEARD HIM AT:
     Till Dawn and Beyond('00), Palindromes('01), Block Party('02), Jamaica
House Residency('01-'02) Reggetechplosion (12.15.02)

      FUTURE RELEASES:
     Stay tuned for the single "Levitated" the first of many releases to
come from this talented progressive house dj, due out in Mid 2003.

For Bookings: 916-223-2372 or Email at dj-dub@earthlink.net

Up in Oregon my friends put together a party called Rave 'n' Roll and it was
held at an old rollerskate ring, donald glaude hauled ass from Seattle to
Eugene just to get there and play at 6am.  probably one of the best parties
i've ever been to.  the vibe was incredible, and there aint nothing like
watching people walk around outside in roller skates to smoke...then try to
walk back up the stairs to go dance...hehehe.  luckily there were no
injuries and there were some people there who could incorperate
liquid/popping and roller skating into and insanely beautiful dance.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mad Hatter?

On Wed, 15 Jan 2003, Alex wrote:

> hey, i'm new to the list (and the east bay). i heard about something called
> the mad hatter in oakland from a friend who used to live in the area. does
> this thing still happen? what's the scoop?

 Used to be a weekly back in 2000, maybe 2001 (?). Here's one of their
old notices ( thanks to Google ):

 "Tuesday, December 19th 2000
Technostate and Mad Hatter present Mad Jam
@ the Bench and Bar, 120 11th Street, Downtown Oakland - DJ's TBA - The
Mad Hatter is a weekly event put together by Technostate, TechnoFetish,
LFC, and Overworld"

 Some folks from Cloud Factory and Urban Wasteland were also involved.

 - Larry Ching

From sfraves-return-97827-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jan 16 06:59:36 2003

From: James Lovette-Black <jimbonsf@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] new poster kinda bio

Folks,

I'm new to sfraves and I've been reading the past couple of week's 
mailings. Raver culture, in particular, embraces much of the
fun and joy that has departed from the post-modern world. Who wants to 
live in a world of dot.com 70 hour/week jobs? Not me,
been there - done that.

I've found so much helpful info on sfraves and corresponded with a 
couple of helpful souls - thanks for the pointers to free music,
raver resources, events, clubs, djs, etc. - and the generally 
cooperative energies that I've observed and experienced.
It's nice to see PLUR practiced.

Apollo's description/history of disco resonates well with me, a nearly 
49 y/o gay man who came out when disco was in its ascension. (And,
yeeeeessssss, I'm still dancing my butt off, thankyouverymuch.)

[mini-soap box:ON]

Having said that, I guess it is strange to hear things like 'so what 
if?' and things said that seem to mimic much of the racist and
homophobic comments made about disco and disco-influenced contemporary 
culture during conservative America's 'disco sucks' crap.

As a Southerner who grew up as a musician in a culture with a strong 
folk music tradition, both Celtic-American and African-American,
the first disco I heard was either in African-American churches or from 
African-American choirs and later wholeheartedly embraced
by Celtic-American Southerners. Disco's roots are without doubt a 
synthesis between these musical traditions, laced with bass and rhythm.
The music is compelling and provocative and was embraced quickly and 
broadly by underground clubs - gay bars in large numbers and
other venues, too. So-called black music that energized and united a 
sexual minority: a revolutionary experience, truly. Makes you wonder
why large, largely white-owned record companies wanted disco dead, 
doesn't it?

At any rate, I find that that these experiences make me appreciate 
techno, goa, house/progressive house/disco, and
raver music, generally, as a true love of music and dance. EDM 
generally is interesting, in a different and musical way. Seems that 
people who
dismiss a single genre without trying to consider for themselves 
whether/not they either appreciate or like it or both miss out on some 
truly
great stuff.

[mini-soap box:OFF]

Thanks for reading this queer's 2c worth.

James Lovette-Black (Jim)
==========================
Tune into streaming progressive house-dance-techno at

RADIO FREE SF at

"http://www.live365.com/cgi-bin/directory.cgi?autostart=jimlbnsf".

(not flawless, just fun)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] =?iso-8859-1?Q?NRR__John_le_Carr=E9?=

Opinion

January 15, 2003

The United States of America has gone mad
John le Carr



America has entered one of its periods of historical madness, but this is
the worst I can remember: worse than McCarthyism, worse than the Bay of Pigs
and in the long term potentially more disastrous than the Vietnam War. The
reaction to 9/11 is beyond anything Osama bin Laden could have hoped for in
his nastiest dreams. As in McCarthy times, the freedoms that have made
America the envy of the world are being systematically eroded. The
combination of compliant US media and vested corporate interests is once
more ensuring that a debate that should be ringing out in every town square
is confined to the loftier columns of the East Coast press.

The imminent war was planned years before bin Laden struck, but it was he
who made it possible. Without bin Laden, the Bush junta would still be
trying to explain such tricky matters as how it came to be elected in the
first place; Enron; its shameless favouring of the already-too-rich; its
reckless disregard for the world's poor, the ecology and a raft of
unilaterally abrogated international treaties. They might also have to be
telling us why they support Israel in its continuing disregard for UN
resolutions.

But bin Laden conveniently swept all that under the carpet. The Bushies are
riding high. Now 88 per cent of Americans want the war, we are told. The US
defence budget has been raised by another $60 billion to around $360
billion. A splendid new generation of nuclear weapons is in the pipeline, so
we can all breathe easy. Quite what war 88 per cent of Americans think they
are supporting is a lot less clear. A war for how long, please? At what cost
in American lives? At what cost to the American taxpayer's pocket? At what
cost - because most of those 88 per cent are thoroughly decent and humane
people - in Iraqi lives?

How Bush and his junta succeeded in deflecting America's anger from bin
Laden to Saddam Hussein is one of the great public relations conjuring
tricks of history. But they swung it. A recent poll tells us that one in two
Americans now believe Saddam was responsible for the attack on the World
Trade Centre. But the American public is not merely being misled. It is
being browbeaten and kept in a state of ignorance and fear. The carefully
orchestrated neurosis should carry Bush and his fellow conspirators nicely
into the next election.

Those who are not with Mr Bush are against him. Worse, they are with the
enemy. Which is odd, because I'm dead against Bush, but I would love to see
Saddam's downfall - just not on Bush's terms and not by his methods. And not
under the banner of such outrageous hypocrisy.

The religious cant that will send American troops into battle is perhaps the
most sickening aspect of this surreal war-to-be. Bush has an arm-lock on
God. And God has very particular political opinions. God appointed America
to save the world in any way that suits America. God appointed Israel to be
the nexus of America's Middle Eastern policy, and anyone who wants to mess
with that idea is a) anti-Semitic, b) anti-American, c) with the enemy, and
d) a terrorist.

God also has pretty scary connections. In America, where all men are equal
in His sight, if not in one another's, the Bush family numbers one
President, one ex-President, one ex-head of the CIA, the Governor of Florida
and the ex-Governor of Texas.

Care for a few pointers? George W. Bush, 1978-84: senior executive, Arbusto
Energy/Bush Exploration, an oil company; 1986-90: senior executive of the
Harken oil company. Dick Cheney, 1995-2000: chief executive of the
Halliburton oil company. Condoleezza Rice, 1991-2000: senior executive with
the Chevron oil company, which named an oil tanker after her. And so on. But
none of these trifling associations affects the integrity of God's work.

In 1993, while ex-President George Bush was visiting the ever-democratic
Kingdom of Kuwait to receive thanks for liberating them, somebody tried to
kill him. The CIA believes that "somebody" was Saddam. Hence Bush Jr's cry:
"That man tried to kill my Daddy." But it's still not personal, this war.
It's still necessary. It's still God's work. It's still about bringing
freedom and democracy to oppressed Iraqi people.

To be a member of the team you must also believe in Absolute Good and
Absolute Evil, and Bush, with a lot of help from his friends, family and
God, is there to tell us which is which. What Bush won't tell us is the
truth about why we're going to war. What is at stake is not an Axis of
Evil - but oil, money and people's lives. Saddam's misfortune is to sit on
the second biggest oilfield in the world. Bush wants it, and who helps him
get it will receive a piece of the cake. And who doesn't, won't.

If Saddam didn't have the oil, he could torture his citizens to his heart's
content. Other leaders do it every day - think Saudi Arabia, think Pakistan,
think Turkey, think Syria, think Egypt.

Baghdad represents no clear and present danger to its neighbours, and none
to the US or Britain. Saddam's weapons of mass destruction, if he's still
got them, will be peanuts by comparison with the stuff Israel or America
could hurl at him at five minutes' notice. What is at stake is not an
imminent military or terrorist threat, but the economic imperative of US
growth. What is at stake is America's need to demonstrate its military power
to all of us - to Europe and Russia and China, and poor mad little North
Korea, as well as the Middle East; to show who rules America at home, and
who is to be ruled by America abroad.

The most charitable interpretation of Tony Blair's part in all this is that
he believed that, by riding the tiger, he could steer it. He can't. Instead,
he gave it a phoney legitimacy, and a smooth voice. Now I fear, the same
tiger has him penned into a corner, and he can't get out.

It is utterly laughable that, at a time when Blair has talked himself
against the ropes, neither of Britain's opposition leaders can lay a glove
on him. But that's Britain's tragedy, as it is America's: as our Governments
spin, lie and lose their credibility, the electorate simply shrugs and looks
the other way. Blair's best chance of personal survival must be that, at the
eleventh hour, world protest and an improbably emboldened UN will force Bush
to put his gun back in his holster unfired. But what happens when the
world's greatest cowboy rides back into town without a tyrant's head to wave
at the boys?

Blair's worst chance is that, with or without the UN, he will drag us into a
war that, if the will to negotiate energetically had ever been there, could
have been avoided; a war that has been no more democratically debated in
Britain than it has in America or at the UN. By doing so, Blair will have
set back our relations with Europe and the Middle East for decades to come.
He will have helped to provoke unforeseeable retaliation, great domestic
unrest, and regional chaos in the Middle East. Welcome to the party of the
ethical foreign policy.

There is a middle way, but it's a tough one: Bush dives in without UN
approval and Blair stays on the bank. Goodbye to the special relationship.

I cringe when I hear my Prime Minister lend his head prefect's sophistries
to this colonialist adventure. His very real anxieties about terror are
shared by all sane men. What he can't explain is how he reconciles a global
assault on al-Qaeda with a territorial assault on Iraq. We are in this war,
if it takes place, to secure the fig leaf of our special relationship, to
grab our share of the oil pot, and because, after all the public
hand-holding in Washington and Camp David, Blair has to show up at the
altar.

"But will we win, Daddy?"

"Of course, child. It will all be over while you're still in bed."

"Why?"

"Because otherwise Mr Bush's voters will get terribly impatient and may
decide not to vote for him."

"But will people be killed, Daddy?"

"Nobody you know, darling. Just foreign people."

"Can I watch it on television?"

"Only if Mr Bush says you can."

"And afterwards, will everything be normal again? Nobody will do anything
horrid any more?"

"Hush child, and go to sleep."

Last Friday a friend of mine in California drove to his local supermarket
with a sticker on his car saying: "Peace is also Patriotic". It was gone by
the time he'd finished shopping.





The author has also contributed to an openDemocracy debate on Iraq at
www.openDemocracy.net


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

----- Original Message -----
From: "James Lovette-Black" <jimbonsf@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, January 15, 2003 10:59 PM
Subject: [sfraves] new poster kinda bio


> Folks,
>
> I'm new to sfraves and I've been reading the past couple of week's
> mailings. Raver culture, in particular, embraces much of the
> fun and joy that has departed from the post-modern world. Who wants to
> live in a world of dot.com 70 hour/week jobs? Not me,
> been there - done that.
>
> I've found so much helpful info on sfraves and corresponded with a
> couple of helpful souls - thanks for the pointers to free music,
> raver resources, events, clubs, djs, etc. - and the generally
> cooperative energies that I've observed and experienced.
> It's nice to see PLUR practiced.
>
> Apollo's description/history of disco resonates well with me, a nearly
> 49 y/o gay man who came out when disco was in its ascension. (And,
> yeeeeessssss, I'm still dancing my butt off, thankyouverymuch.)
>
> [mini-soap box:ON]
>
> Having said that, I guess it is strange to hear things like 'so what
> if?' and things said that seem to mimic much of the racist and
> homophobic comments made about disco and disco-influenced contemporary
> culture during conservative America's 'disco sucks' crap.
>
> As a Southerner who grew up as a musician in a culture with a strong
> folk music tradition, both Celtic-American and African-American,
> the first disco I heard was either in African-American churches or from
> African-American choirs and later wholeheartedly embraced
> by Celtic-American Southerners. Disco's roots are without doubt a
> synthesis between these musical traditions, laced with bass and rhythm.
> The music is compelling and provocative and was embraced quickly and
> broadly by underground clubs - gay bars in large numbers and
> other venues, too. So-called black music that energized and united a
> sexual minority: a revolutionary experience, truly. Makes you wonder
> why large, largely white-owned record companies wanted disco dead,
> doesn't it?
>
> At any rate, I find that that these experiences make me appreciate
> techno, goa, house/progressive house/disco, and
> raver music, generally, as a true love of music and dance. EDM
> generally is interesting, in a different and musical way. Seems that
> people who
> dismiss a single genre without trying to consider for themselves
> whether/not they either appreciate or like it or both miss out on some
> truly
> great stuff.
>
> [mini-soap box:OFF]
>
> Thanks for reading this queer's 2c worth.
>
> James Lovette-Black (Jim)
> ==========================
> Tune into streaming progressive house-dance-techno at
>
> RADIO FREE SF at
>
> "http://www.live365.com/cgi-bin/directory.cgi?autostart=jimlbnsf".
>
> (not flawless, just fun)
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

PLEASE FORWARD THIS ANNOUNCEMENT TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW....

Saturday, January 18
National Marches in Washington DC & San Francisco
NO WAR AGAINST IRAQ!
On the Martin Luther King anniversary weekend and the 12th anniversary of 
the Gulf War
San Francisco march:
Assemble 11 am Market & Embarcadero, March to Civic Center for 1 pm rally

For more information, call 415-821-6545, email answer@actionsf.org, or see 
www.InternationalANSWER.org

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said, "The greatest purveyor of violence in the 
world today is my own government?for the sake of humanity I cannot be 
silent." On January 18, join thousands across the U.S. and around the world 
who will honor Dr. King by doing what he would have done, were he alive 
today -- raise our voices against the war!

Partial List of Endorsers & Initiators:
A.N.S.W.E.R. Coalition (Act Now to Stop War & End Racism); U.S. Rep. 
Cynthia McKinney; Ramsey Clark, former U.S. Attorney General; Bishop Thomas 
Gumbleton, Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit; Rev. Herbert Daughtry, House of 
the Loard Pentecostal Church; Rev. Jesse Jackson; Rev. Graylan Hagler, 
Plymouth Congregational Church; National Lawyers Guild; San Francisco Labor 
Council, AFL-CIO; Muslim American Society Freedom Foundation; American Arab 
Anti-Discrimination Committee-SF; San Francisco Bay View; Black Voices for 
Peace; Dr. Hans Christof von Sponek, former director of the UN Oil for Food 
Program; Bayan-USA-International; Korea Truth Commission; International 
Action Center; Middle East Children's Alliance; Muslim Student Association 
of the US/Canada; Mexico Solidarity Network; Green Party USA; Global 
Exchange; Not In Our Name Project; Patti Smith; Howard Zinn, International 
Campaign Against US Aggression on Iraq and many many more...

--==========356380237==========

house, supplied by DJ/Producer DJ Darque.  He's a bit of a traveler,
beginning his DJ career in Dallas 6 years ago, then moving to Oklahoma
City, Chicago, L.A., and now the bay area, continuously spreading his
funky house vibe.  His favorite spot?  Chicago.  So you know his sound.

his songs are online here:

out and about.

guestlists, so write down 650-723-9010 so you can call in and win.

Subject: [sfraves] [nrr] Book clouds and echo chambers


 From a guest blogger's link on boingboing.net ,

 People read books that reinforce their political beliefs much more
than books that challenge their beliefs (duh) :

 http://www.orgnet.com/leftright.html

 Given human nature, people's book buying habits are almost a given,
but it's interesting to see it reflected in actual research data.

 Have you challenged your beliefs recently ?

 Larry Ching <larryc@cloudfactory.org> wrote:

>From a guest blogger's link on boingboing.net ,

People read books that reinforce their political beliefs much more
than books that challenge their beliefs 

i don't...i was out shopping for political and social commentary yesterday, and i was specifically looking around for authors who might profess a different point of view than some of the views i've been considering lately....why? because i like growth not stagnancy of thought...anyone who favors intellectual stimulation to fried foods knows this....for instance, i am now contemplating psychology v.s. ideology...of course, i am looking at noam chomsky again. :)

Have you challenged your beliefs recently ?

no, not really... let me explain....i don't think that an genuine belief changes. if you believe something, then you believe it, that is why it is a belief and not a theory of some sort..i don't really believe much..i do almost believe that i will die..actually, i pretty much accept that most of my body will die, but i am not sure of the spirit...there are mysteries, i suppose...there are also all sorts of preservatives out there and innovations to make sure that i can be around for when walt disney wakes up again...:)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [nrr] Book clouds and echo chambers

He's got a good point, not enough people read opposing views, they like
to read the same views and get riled up about others.  Right now I'm
reading a far umm.... Well, far-left and far-right are the two main
parties... Would it be dark green for the green party?  Anyways, Running
on Emptiness: The Failure of Symbolic Thought is what I'm reading right
now.  While I don't believe a lot of what he says can or should happen,
he poses a lot of great points about things I haven't thought of before.
He's all about abandoning technology and going back to our primitive
roots without a centralized government or even society...  But at the
same time he's kinda hypocritical in the fact he has a pretty decently
designed website and still uses paper for books ;)  But, he's got to get
his message out there somehow to the masses and what he goes against is
what he has to use to get it out there.

-Rayn

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301161019480.11377-100000@cumulonimbus.cloudfactory.org>
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] [nrr] Book clouds and echo chambers

Marshal McLuhan said that people read advertisements not to decide what to
buy but rather to confirm the appropriateness of purchases they've already
made.  While it is important to remember that much of what McLuhan wrote and
said was presented in the form of poetic aphorisms to stimulate thought, it
is true that many people read ads for products or general product categories
that they already own.

They do this simply to confirm that the items that they own fit their self
image, desired socio-economic status, political viewpoint, etc.  Documented
examples include automobiles, clothes, and liquor.  In this context it is
not particularly surprising that people read political articles, books, etc.
which confirm their existing belief systems whether those happen to be
leaning to the left or right.

Consider your own recent consumption of media and information.  How much of
it was within categories or from sources you were already familiar and
comfortable with?  Did you listen to any country and western music recently?
Lawrence Welk?  Watch the 700 Club or Rush Limbaugh?  Probably not.

Its really fairly challenging to avoid consuming self affirming information
consistently.

Regards,

Peter Rothman


-----Original Message-----
From: Larry Ching [mailto:larryc@cloudfactory.org]
Sent: Thursday, January 16, 2003 10:27 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] [nrr] Book clouds and echo chambers



 From a guest blogger's link on boingboing.net ,

 People read books that reinforce their political beliefs much more
than books that challenge their beliefs (duh) :

 http://www.orgnet.com/leftright.html

 Given human nature, people's book buying habits are almost a given,
but it's interesting to see it reflected in actual research data.

 Have you challenged your beliefs recently ?

 - Larry

	boundary="=====================_2055589==_.ALT"

Subject: [sfraves] The Right To Rave:  Glenn Reynolds

--=====================_2055589==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Jan. 17, 2003 / 10:21 AM ET

        THE RIGHT TO RAVE:     Glenn Reynolds

        Police and prosecutors in Racine County, Wisc. have backed down on=
=20
prosecutions against individuals arrested for, basically, attending a rave.=
=20
(=93Individuals who attend rave parties ... have certain constitutional=20
rights,=94 noted Municipal Court Judge Rob Weber in a news report published=
=20
in the Racine County Journal Times.)

        Police swept in and cited people indiscriminately, ultimately=20
charging 442 with being =93inmates of a disorderly house=94 for the=
 non-crime=20
of being somewhere in a building where a few people were arrested with=20
drugs. The fine for this non-crime? $968.

        You could have made the same kind of mass arrest at a Willie Nelson=
=20
concert, of course, but that would have been an obvious political=20
non-starter. Besides, the point was to shut down the rave scene in Racine.=
=20
This raid was one of many around the country (the Electronic Music Defense=
=20
and Education Fund lists several others) organized as part of a national=20
strategy against electronic music events. (Full disclosure: I produce=20
electronic music =97 see below =97 and I worked with the ACLU and the EMDEF=
 on=20
another case, which the authorities also lost).

        This strategy of targeting raves has come about because the DEA and=
=20
other law enforcement authorities have been miserably unsuccessful in=20
blocking the spread of Ecstasy and other club drugs. The result has been a=
=20
series of highly publicized assaults on public events (since they=92re=20
public, even the most inept investigators can find them) that are designed=
=20
more to make the law enforcement agencies look like they=92re doing=
 something=20
than to actually accomplish anything. Call it appearance-oriented law=20
enforcement.

        The Racine authorities backed down on this one rather than risk=20
ruinous lawsuits for false arrest. That=92s a good thing, I guess, but I=20
almost wish that the lawsuits had gone ahead, since that would have=20
produced a more thoroughly cautionary example. Law enforcement officials=20
should focus on keeping the streets safe from real criminals of the=20
rapist/robber/terrorist variety - something that they don=92t appear to have=
=20
fully mastered yet =97 rather than mounting showy operations designed to=20
intimidate honest citizens and to give the illusion of progress in the war=
=20
on drugs. Especially as we have a real war to fight now.

        Somebody needs to tell Senate Minority Leader Tom Daschle (D-SD),=20
though, as he just introduced a new bill to make it easier to prosecute=20
rave promoters. Remember when the Democrats used to be for civil liberties?

http://www.msnbc.com/news/856672.asp?0cv=3DCB20

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are=20
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_2055589==_.ALT--

Message-ID: <F92c7g1f1fpe32nd4DE0001f863@hotmail.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Acid Test history (was: RE: [sfraves] Re: In defense of/ Disco?)

I went and pulled out my copy of "The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test" last 
night, and here's what it says about the Muir Beach Test:

"The third Acid Test was scheduled for Stinson Beach, 15 miles north of San 
Francisco...there was a nice solid brick recreation hall on the beach, all 
very nice--but at the last minute that deal fell through, and they shifted 
to Muir Beach, a few miles south...Muir Beach had a big log-cabin-style 
lodge for dances, banquets, and the like.  The lodge was stilted up out in a 
waste of frigid marsh grass.  A big empty nighttime beach in winter.  The 
lodge had three big rooms and was about 100 feet long, all logs and rafters 
and exposed beams, a tight ship of dark wood and Roughing It.  The Grateful 
Dead piled in with their equipment and the Pranksters with theirs..." (pp. 
213-14, paperback edition)

I also checked in other places, including the oral Prankster history "On The 
Bus" and McNally's recent history-of-the-Dead book, and nowhere can i find a 
reference to Muir Beach being a break-in.  and it's pretty unlikely, 
considering that Muir Beach is a small town, and a couple of hundred 
extremely stoned people dancing to a LOUD rock band--in 1965!--would have 
been very noticeable.  and they'd already gotten written up in the San Jose 
newspapers for their previous "drug orgy" (per the "On The Bus" book).

sorry to be so anal...i'm not in any way disputing the role of the Acid 
Tests as prototype-for-later-events.  it's just that if one is going to make 
historical analogies--especially ones to events in recent historical time 
and living memory--one should strive to be as accurate as possible, or risk 
discrediting the larger point by bobbling the details.

--hb

>According to the book, they broke into a cabin at Muir Beach for the
>second one after cops being at their first location at Stinson.

http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

Subject: [sfraves] DRCNET: Racine Caves Before the Ravers (fwd)



---------- Forwarded message ----------
...
10. Newsbrief:  Racine Caves Before the Ravers
    http://www.drcnet.org/wol/272.html#racinecaves

The city of Racine, WI, has dropped all charges against more than
400 people slapped with $968 tickets for "inhabiting a disorderly
house" at an electronic music benefit concert there in November
(http://www.drcnet.org/wol/266.html#raverebellion).  City
prosecutors admitted they couldn't prove their case and agreed to
dismiss all of the citations.  Persons who earlier pleaded guilty
or no contest to receive a reduced fine will also get their money
back.

The agreement, reached between the city and the American Civil
Liberties Union of Wisconsin, promises the city only that the ACLU
will now not sue.  The city also agreed to change its policies on
policing raves and to erase all records indicating that the
citations had ever been written.  The news came late Thursday
night, too late for DRCNet to seek comment.

Police had also arrested three people on drug charges at the
concert held to benefit a local community theater group, but also
outraged ravers and civil libertarians across the country by
ticketing the hundreds of other attendees.

Faced with a strong and largely unified resistance from those
ticketed, Racine prosecutors offered early on to drop the fines to
$100 in return for guilty pleas.  That didn't work.  Neither did
the offer to remove any mention of drugs from the charges.  Most
of the ticketed ravers pleaded not guilty and demanded trials, a
move that would cost the city untold dollars in legal expenses and
untold hours of police time as officers would be called to
testify.

Last week, the city blinked for a third time.  During a status
conference before the court, Racine prosecutors and attorneys
representing the electronic music fans agreed to cancel court
appearances set for the following today and enter into
negotiations to resolve the matter.  According to Racine attorney
Erik Guenther, who is volunteering with the American Civil
Liberties Union of Wisconsin, he and Racine officials were seeking
an "amicable resolution" of the matter.  Negotiations were
ongoing, Guenther told DRCNet, but he declined to provide details.
In the meantime, "individual pretrials set for January 10 have
been cancelled, as have all other appearances," Guenther said.
"We are now able to also instruct those people who have pled
guilty or no contest, but have not paid their fines, not to do so
for the time being."

Or ever, now that Racine has backed down.

No problem..  Unlike a lot of people I like to be corrected... I'm anal
about being wrong.. I didn't have my copy anywhere near me at the time
so I couldn't check myself.  Thanks :)   Since they didn't mention a who
and that most of the houses were empty in winter at that time (I'm
pretty sure they said Muir beach at that time pretty much shut down for
winter?) I just assumed it meant they broke into a lodge...  That said,
I still believe their idea of the Acid Tests being multimedia
extravaganza's and the 2 page description of the ideas behind it, it
just screamed of raves.  Espicially the one done with Bill Graham.

-Rayn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fuck DJ Dimitris?

steps to rid yourself of this spam....

look at the headers to see what IP address (mailserver) the email came from,
then do a whois lookup on the IP address and contact the owner of the IP
address letting them know that they are sending unsolicited spam... i would
add in that you never OPTED-IN to this mailing list and have tried
"unsubscribing" multiple times, yet you keep receiving their spam...

I did this earlier today to hopefully rid myself of the spam i get from
reactionSF.com (which is hosted on an XO ip address) and i will be doing
this next time i get an email from either Dj Dimitris or Harry Denton or any
of those other wankers that like to send out spam in the bay area...


Timothy

  http://www.spamgourmet.com

[A BayRaves.com Sponsored Movement....]

The infamous "RAVE Act" has returned.  Disguised as 'amendments' to the 
current "Crack House" laws, these laws target and effect the entire 
music culture.   

Event promoters could be fined and IMPRISONED for up to 20 Years for 
drugs being inside their event.   Now ask yourself, when was the last 
time you've been to ANY music event that was completely drug-free?    
Probably never.  Which is why this law goes way beyond "raves". 

This will effect:
Raves
DJs
Nightclubs
Concerts
Festivals
Rally
Bars
Motels
Cruise Ships
....and MUCH MORE!!!

When the government attacks our freedom, we FIGHT BACK!!  

We realize "fighting back" takes time and effort.  But make the 
commitment, WE NEED EVERYONE TO COME TOGETHER.  If this law passes, 
you'll be at home Friday and Saturday night wishing you took action.

WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW:
Sign the Letter/Petition Tom Daschle (The sponsor of this bill) Online @ 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448 - 
This only takes about 30 seconds.

Contact our California Senators...
Barbara Boxer - http://boxer.senate.gov/contact/webform.html
Dianne Feinstein - http://feinstein.senate.gov/email.html

If you're dedicated to protecting the scene, contact EVERY Senator in 
the Country!  You can find a complete list at
http://www.senate.gov/general/contact_information/senators_cfm.cfm

WHAT'S TO COME:
If our E-Mails, Faxes and Phone calls are not enough, we take to the 
streets in a Nationwide high-profile protest for our rights.  Stay 
tuned....

>[A BayRaves.com Sponsored Movement....]
>
>The infamous "RAVE Act" has returned.  Disguised as 'amendments' to the
>current "Crack House" laws, these laws target and effect the entire
>music culture.
>
>Event promoters could be fined and IMPRISONED for up to 20 Years for
>drugs being inside their event.   Now ask yourself, when was the last
>time you've been to ANY music event that was completely drug-free?
>Probably never.  Which is why this law goes way beyond "raves".
>
>This will effect:
>Raves
>DJs
>Nightclubs
>Concerts
>Festivals
>Rally
>Bars
>Motels
>Cruise Ships
>....and MUCH MORE!!!
>
>When the government attacks our freedom, we FIGHT BACK!!
>
>We realize "fighting back" takes time and effort.  But make the
>commitment, WE NEED EVERYONE TO COME TOGETHER.  If this law passes,
>you'll be at home Friday and Saturday night wishing you took action.
>
>WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW:
>Sign the Letter/Petition Tom Daschle (The sponsor of this bill) Online @
>http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448 -
>This only takes about 30 seconds.
>
>Contact our California Senators...
>Barbara Boxer - http://boxer.senate.gov/contact/webform.html
>Dianne Feinstein - http://feinstein.senate.gov/email.html
>
>If you're dedicated to protecting the scene, contact EVERY Senator in
>the Country!  You can find a complete list at
>http://www.senate.gov/general/contact_information/senators_cfm.cfm
>
>WHAT'S TO COME:
>If our E-Mails, Faxes and Phone calls are not enough, we take to the
>streets in a Nationwide high-profile protest for our rights.  Stay
>tuned....
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Thought for this Weekend

--=====================_17812488==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

"A time comes when silence is betrayal. Even when pressed by the demands of 
inner truth, men do not easily assume the task of opposing their 
government's policy, especially in time of war. Nor does the human spirit 
move without great difficulty against all the apathy of conformist thought 
within one's own bosom and in the surrounding world....

"Some of us who have already begun to break the silence of the night have 
found that the calling to speak is often a vocation of agony, but we must 
speak. We must speak with all the humility that is appropriate to our 
limited vision, but we must speak. For we are deeply in need of a new way 
beyond the darkness that seems so close around us....

"We still have a choice today: nonviolent coexistence or violent 
coannihilation. We must move past indecision to action. If we do not act, 
we shall surely be dragged down the long, dark, and shameful corridors of 
time reserved for those who possess power without compassion, might without 
morality, and strength without sight.

"Now let us begin. Now let us rededicate ourselves in the long and bitter, 
but beautiful struggle for a new world...."

Martin Luther King, Jr.,  April 4, 1967 in Riverside Church , New York City

Hope to see some of you at the Civic Center Rally tomorrow.

Love and Peace,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Subject: [sfraves] beans nrr

so, i will share a story....i know a man who has a
good heart, and sometimes a short fuse...one of my
friends always says, "men make mistakes...men make
mistakes." when my good hearted male friend "makes
mistakes", he goes away and hides his head under his
pillow, but, since he is also extremely curious, he
always leaves a little, tiny space so he can see
what's going on outside the pillowhead world...so
today, i was thinking that i will start calling him
beans sometimes...you know what i mean? like, "hi,
beans..i love you, beans." :)

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Have you seen that Kotex ad campaign that claims that their feminine =
pads are "More secure than an email password?" WTF? This just blows me =
away. Now I don't expect everyone to be technically savvy, but I find it =
hard to believe that this campaign could make it on the air without =
someone raising a red flag. For those of you who are not big fat geeks =
like me, email (except for web based like hotmail) is accessed when your =
mail client, such as outlook express, sends your username and password =
IN CLEAR TEXT over the internet to your mail server. Anyone who wants to =
can sniff the traffic and grab your password. Plus, most people use =
passwords that are not too hard to guess if you do a little digging into =
the life and personality of your target. So, an email password is one of =
the LEAST secure things on the internet. I am astounded that Kotex would =
compare their product to it. I know, I know, I'm a huge nerd for being =
bothered by this, but what if it was Trojan that was making this =
comparison?  :-) 'nuff said.

Happy  :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs


------=_NextPart_000_01B9_01C2BE65.3C9901F0--

Actually, it raised the opposite red flag with me.  My passwords are 
non-words combinations of alpha-numeric characters.  You can't possibly 
guess them, and a dictionary cracker is useless.  Email passwords are far 
MORE secure than any maxi pad.  A max pad's bond can be broken (as per the 
commercial) using physical means: your hands.  Email passwords cannot be 
broken by physical means unless someone was stupid enough to write it down 
AND lose it.


sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Rant

Lol, ok, let me amend that. You are one of the very small minority of people
who don't use easy to crack passwords. The following is from an article
posted on Cnet: http://news.com.com/2009-1001-916719.html

"Fortune 100 corporations, small firms and even Internet service providers
with strong security have an Achilles heel: users who pick easily guessable
passwords. Some choose words straight out of Webster's dictionary, others
use a pet's name, and still more choose the name of a secret lover. Many who
think themselves tricky append a digit or two on the end of their chosen
word. Such feeble attempts at deception are no match for today's computers,
which are capable of trying millions of word variations per second and often
can guess a good number of passwords in less than a minute."

    Thus, I stand by my original statement, that email passwords are
inherently insecure.

I dunno, personally, I use IMAP+SSL.


Happy wrote:
> Have you seen that Kotex ad campaign that claims that their feminine pads are "More secure than an email password?" WTF? This just blows me away. Now I don't expect everyone to be technically savvy, but I find it hard to believe that this campaign could make it on the air without someone raising a red flag. For those of you who are not big fat geeks like me, email (except for web based like hotmail) is accessed when your mail client, such as outlook express, sends your username and password IN CLEAR TEXT over the internet to your mail server. Anyone who wants to can sniff the traffic and grab your password. Plus, most people use passwords that are not too hard to guess if you do a little digging into the life and personality of your target. So, an email password is one of the LEAST secure things on the internet. I am astounded that Kotex would compare their product to it. I know, I know, I'm a huge nerd for being bothered by this, but what if it was Trojan that was making t
his comparison?  :-) 'nuff said.
> 
> Happy  :-)
> 
> "A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
> but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs
> 
>

ok, still need help. please. 
still need venues.  still need djs.  /8P
we wanna still do a friday a.m. part every week. and a sunday monthly
day party. one of the hosts digs hip hop and deep house and one loves
just deep house. i do not, much.
our friday morning/day party rocks. we have some really good breaks
shit,  good funky house.  the locale is very cool, etc.   the hosts want
the sunday thing to be more house. i'm makng her do half n half.  trying
to get her to keep the friday gig as is,  too.
i'd like to be able to stay where we are, but don't know yet.  a locale
with a patio area would be great for the sunday party, since it'll be a
2p-12a party, and it's getting nice out.  

we really want to give newer djs a place to play, too, alongside
established better known local djs.

so...
SF locales?
djs?
which sunday would be open?

come on, guys, gimme some ideas.  /:)

Subject: [sfraves] SRR I marched today   :)  Huge crowd, no war on Iraq, impeach Bush! 

--part1_47.29262e40.2b5b9e6b_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The anti-war march today in San Francisco had a huge crowd. I heard there 
were lines several blocks long at some of the Bart stations. ? 200,000 people 
jamming Market Street and absolutely packing the plaza at the Civic Center 
and adjacent streets. People had the greatest signs, very creative. I didn't 
have a sign but I jumped in and marched to the Civic Center. 
The resistance to the actions of "our" war-mongering regime is huge, and 
growing, C-Span has been showing extensive footage of today's march and rally 
in Washington DC. Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark presented a very 
strong case as to why President Bush should actually be impeached, on the 
basis of "high crimes and misdemeanors." Everyone in the National Mall just 
ROARED at the idea, chanting "Impeach Bush!" over and over. 
I'm about to leave to go to Love All Stars, and "love" in the name reminds me 
why this is an SRR instead of an NRR:   Peace Love Unity Respect     I think 
each letter, really, says "It's not right to invade another country to get 
control of their oil."  A lot of kids who go to parties are the age where 
they could get sent off to war. It really will hit close to home. 
To Peace and Love     :)
John

--part1_47.29262e40.2b5b9e6b_boundary--

At 10:26 PM 1/18/2003 -0800, Jason Andrews wrote:

>I heard the SF march was amazing here in Portland there were about 40,000 
>marchers which is good for a city this size. It is so nice to see so many 
>people agree on one thing. I am sure all of you have been discussing our 
>new monarchy over the last months king Bush is going to be the death of 
>what freedoms we have left. Peace
>  Jason

Yes, this afternoon was extraordinary.  I have been to many gatherings and 
marches to Civic Center and this was one of the largest I have ever 
seen.  Such diversity.  I walked for awhile with a WW II veteran who must 
have been near eighty.  Then there was the very elegant older woman with a 
cane, white hat and gloves, and long blue dress.  I thought she was 
beautiful.  The paraplegic in his mobile chair.  Punks.  Union 
folks.  Clergy.  Kids.  The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence.  Stick 
Walkers.  Wondrous and colorful masks.  Painted faces.  All of us together 
with one common belief:  let's not have bloodshed in the Middle East.

The crowd was so big that it took us nearly three hours to go from the 
Embarcadero to Civic Center.  Caused much drama, I think, in SF Center with 
all the marchers crowding into that lower lever bathroom:)

I don't think the press can much longer ignore the ever growing opposition 
to this immoral preemptive oil war.  The numbers of dissenters grow with 
each march.  Perhaps we can prevent this Republic from becoming the Empire 
Bush and his associates desire.

Love and Peace,

Apollo







>>From: JonnyR@aol.com

>>impeach Bush! Date: Sun, 19 Jan 2003 01:23:39 EST

>>The anti-war march today in San Francisco had a huge crowd. I heard there
>>were lines several blocks long at some of the Bart stations. ? 200,000 people
>>jamming Market Street and absolutely packing the plaza at the Civic Center
>>and adjacent streets. People had the greatest signs, very creative. I didn't
>>have a sign but I jumped in and marched to the Civic Center.
>>The resistance to the actions of "our" war-mongering regime is huge, and
>>growing, C-Span has been showing extensive footage of today's march and rally
>>in Washington DC. Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark presented a very
>>strong case as to why President Bush should actually be impeached, on the
>>basis of "high crimes and misdemeanors." Everyone in the National Mall just
>>ROARED at the idea, chanting "Impeach Bush!" over and over.
>>I'm about to leave to go to Love All Stars, and "love" in the name reminds me
>>why this is an SRR instead of an NRR:   Peace Love Unity Respect     I think
>>each letter, really, says "It's not right to invade another country to get
>>control of their oil."  A lot of kids who go to parties are the age where
>>they could get sent off to war. It really will hit close to home.
>>To Peace and Love     :)

avenue with an estimated 300,000 people.  It was quite the experience.  By 
far the largest protest that I have ever participated in.  The only thing 
that the protest really lacked was some good EDM.  All in all, I think that 
we have made our opinions known.  It is now time for the swine to respond.

international freedom.  Lots of love, -Trendy aka Malacai

On Saturday, Jan 18, 2003, at 22:49 US/Pacific, Apollo wrote:

> I don't think the press can much longer ignore the ever growing 
> opposition to this immoral preemptive oil war.

They are really trying to.   Yesterday's march must have been twice as 
big as the one in October, yet it got less press coverage, there was 
less media there covering the march,  and they gave *lower* estimates 
for the number of people.   No way!!  You couldn't even sit down on 
City Hall plaza at the peak of it.  BART is usually pretty quiet on a 
Saturday morning, but it was jammed full of people of all ages and 
walks of life with protest signs.   They were was so overwhelmed with 
people coming on at Colma (not exactly a hotbed of radicalism!)  to get 
to the demonstration that they opened the fare gates and gave people a 
free ride.

I hear we got good coverage on CSPAN,  I wouldn't know, our cable 
system doesn't offer CSPAN (is that lame or what?)


>  The numbers of dissenters grow with each march.  Perhaps we can 
> prevent this Republic from becoming the Empire Bush and his associates 
> desire.

We will never get any decent coverage in the mainstream press.
If we are 110% peaceful and well-behaved, they will downplay and 
underreport our protests.
Anything else and they will applaud as the government locks us up and 
shoots us as terrorists.

They will continue to try to marginalize us
to make us look like a few radical malcontents.

But those who came into the City yesterday (for whatever reason) knew 
otherwise.

Whey these people watched the coverage on evening news
They could see that they were not getting the whole story.

Who Owns The News?

Ride the Music

AndyTiedye

Subject: [sfraves] pretty girls and sweaty pits nrr

do you think that girls look for sweaty pits? not
really asking, just posing a thought...today, i was
talking to a pretty girl, and i stretched my arms up
over my 
head to straighten my hairclips, and when i did, her
eyes went immmediately to my armpits, and after that,
i was thinking about what we were talking about and
feeling really intensely about what she might have
seen, 
because, sometimes, i am sweaty even though i do make
a point of using some good antiperspirant...even
though i try to 
do everything in my power to prevent getting wet under
the arms....so, when she finally left, i was not
dissappointed...i was relieved, because then i felt
comfortable taking a look 
under my arms, and, mercifully, it was all dry under
there, and even though i was wearing an old white
blouse, it was still white under the arms too...no
spots, no rings...i was very relieved...why was she
looking under my arms anyway? oh my gosh. oh, also,
yesterday, it was very crowded where i live...there
were hoards of people walking in the opposite
direction as me, and i was the only one eating a
banana. :)

My roommate moved out so there is a room now available in my house. : )

     The house is located in Marin in San Rafael in a safe, quiet set back=20
neighborhood but only minutes away from downtown (which hosts a major transi=
t=20
center), 101 and 580. It is 20 mins to Berkeley, 15 to the Golden Gate, and=20
35-45 to Santa Rosa.
=A0=A0=A0=A0 The house has a large semi-landscaped backyard, fireplace, dish=
washer=20
and washer. There is a laundry mat all of five houses down if you need to us=
e=20
a dryer. The laundry mat is also across the street from a quaint market with=
=20
nearly everything you need, there is a racquet club just up the hill if you=20
like to swim or play tennis, plenty of parking in addition to the four space=
s=20
for the house and many hiking trails surrounding the area. The house is also=
=20
usually filled with fresh flowers and plants that I receive from work (an=20
added bonus at no extra charge ; ) ).
=A0=A0=A0=A0 You get the largest room with your own phone line already=20
installed/hooked up. There is also a cable line installed ready to be hooked=
=20
up. The dimensions of the room are 11'x12.5' with a closet and two windows.=20
Rent is 650 which *includes* utilities. It should be noted though, that it i=
s=20
a vegetarian kitchen. You can keep meat in the house, I would just prefer yo=
u=20
didn't cook it (though microwave stuff is okay). If you *really* need to coo=
k=20
it I just ask that you use your own pots/pans and clean thoroughly. You=20
should also know that I have a cat (short-haired). He is *very* sweet and=20
social and welcome to another kitty buddy if you have one. : D

And a bit about me- I'm an eighteen year old college student studying to be=20=
a=20
pyschoneuroimmunologist at the local college. I've been partying for four=20
years and I still go out regularly because I *love* to dance (why else would=
=20
I be on this list? ; ) ) and I'm a very social person. I'm a big house whore=
,=20
but I my taste in music is very eclectic ranging from Bjork, Tori Amos,=20
Porishead, De La Soul, Black Eyed Peas, Blackalicious, Badly Drawn Boy, Cibo=
=20
Matto, Billie Holiday, Chet Baker and yes, even Ace of Base. I've been raise=
d=20
Buddhist with a Shamanistic influence by my family to whom I am very close=20
with. I love to sing, read, clean and eat chocolate. Now that I'm writing=20
this I'm realizing it's very hard to summarize yourself...=A0 : D

The room is available immediately so if you are interested, know anyone who=20
is or just have some questions e-mail me back.

heart,
Alida

Subject: [sfraves] anti-war protest - good media resources & report

Hello from the Deep South!

Jim from SF here, visiting a friend in Hot Springs,
Arkansas.

I was at the anti-war protest and I think it was closer to
250-300,000 people, since it compared in size to Pride
celebrations.

Ignore the corporate-run media, use the independent media
such as

Independent Media Centers at

http://www.indymedia.org

IMC was founded around the Seattle 1999 anti-WTO protests
(where I was tear-gassed by out of control, storm-trooper
outfitted civilian cops)

and click on whichever city/region link you'd like: SF or
DC or whatever

Not in Our Name (global pledge of huge numbers against war)

http://www.notinourname.net

United for Peace

http://www.unitedforpeace.org

and all of the groups springing up much quicker than at a
comparable point in time during the Vietnam era, according
to activists from then.

At any rate, yeah, let's have Ravers for Peace in future
protests!

PLUR, always!

Jim

=====
Radio Free SF --->>>
http://www.jimboland.com/radiofreesf.html
=====

PS - If you've got some tunes to share, email me with info
for play on Radio Free SF.

Subject: [sfraves] ESC live set from new years eve 


I just uploaded my set from new years eve at the otherworld warehouse.

It was a combination of elements from my tracks, and other people's
tracks, so I call it hybrid live...  Since this was the first (since the
old industrial days) live performance I've done, there is a new section
"live performances".  Go figure...

The set is all techno.

Everything was totally flawless, until matter pulled out the power cable
from the computer...  ugg...  But I cleaned up the empty space in the
recording, so this file is seamless.

Enjoy, and please let me know what you think.

The file is here (with all my other archives):

http://typhoon.enabled.com/~esc/

HAHAHAHAHA!!  The BRAT!  I always used to lust after those for some
unknown reason back in high school.

As far as Bush doing "anything immoral or illegal"..  Well, he may not
have violated any particular laws, but launching a manhunt for a
specific group and its leader, and then halfway through that, kind of
just going, "Uhh, I'm tired of that, my dad said Iraq was kind of fun..
 Maybe I'll go after that!", and redirecting the entire effort towards
a very random and largely uncalled-for war, is not a moral action.

Does anyone else remember the media transformation, almost in a single
day, from "Let's get Bin Laden and the Al-Quieda!", to "Let's blow up
Iraq again!"?  Did anyone else do a double-take and say, "wait, how'd
we get back to Saddam again?"?

I mean, the man bald-facedly took the presidency after a race that was
very clearly bungled, and perhaps even deliberately.  He lost the
frickin' vote, but the powers that be said, "Uh, Bush gets it", and he
took it with a smile.

I shouldn't be at work- it's MLK day.  

GeorgeC

Hi everyone-
I would just like to say how proud I am of all of you who went to the march 
on Saturday. At Love Allstars, countless people from the list came up to me 
and told me they went because of my post. The march was awesome. I saw on the 
news that morning that "an estimated 10,000 people will be there"...ha ha ha 
try 200,000 people. All day long I ran around and told older activists about 
PLUR and what it represents. One person told me if we all lived by those 4 
basic principles, we wouldnt be at that march, we wouldnt need to be. 
Saturday was my frist massive demonstration and I will never forget it. Thank 
you to all who came and remember, with enough people, we can make a difference
Britty

--part1_28.3239903f.2b5dd2d3_boundary--

>I saw a bicycle-powered float with a PA for a small band in the demo.

>how well their sound system was working.

>It doesn't have to be all that loud, maybe we can do it solar-powered.
>I've been wanting to do something like that for Burning Man anyway.

I'm going to contact the parade organizers tomorrow to see what exactly 
their permits allow.  We may have to be creative about this for a number of 
reasons.  A truck would have to have several monitors surrounding it to 
assure safety (I've done this before for other march/events), and one must 
remember that many in the march are very eco minded and might not be happy 
with a motorized vehicle.  I know I can get hold of a flatbed, but I think 
that would be overkill.

I'll be setting up the list tomorrow also, so I'll keep all of you posted.

Love,

Apollo

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Subject: [sfraves] Anybody want a '70 VW Bug?

'Sup all!

For those of you that know me, I'm sure you'll be familiar with my old ride, a
1970 VW Bug.  However, no charities will take it (it's older than 1976), so I'm
going to sell it and donate the profits to the San Francisco SPCA.

Please forward this E-mail to anybody that you think would be interested.  I'm
willing to negotiate on the price, I just want to get as much to the SPCA as I
can.

Peace!

- G

Here's the URL for my craigslist ad:
http://www.craigslist.org/cgi-bin/smp

Here's the text of the ad:

1600cc stock motor, in good shape. Runs great, compression is consistent and
good on all 4 cylinders. Lots of new parts. Here's what's been done in the last
6 months: New clutch & cable, new carburetor, new chrome 360 air cleaner, new
fuel/oil hoses, 5 new tires (yes, the spare too!), new plugs/wires/cap/rotor,
and new oil cooler seals. Title and registration are clean. 

The bad: Needs some body work and paint. "Standard" hole in passenger rear
floorpan due to battery acid. Needs upholstery work. Probably will also need a
brake fluid flush & refill and new front shoes. 

Pics to come soon.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nina

nic... that was a random, non-referenced post along the lines of ms.
dahl.

huh?


p,


c. got it right off the bat.

but, since you asked....

'Pattern Recognition'

http://tinyurl.com/4ogh

is the spankin' brand new novel by William Gibson, starring another 'Case',
tho' her name is
spelled 'Cayce' and she deals with corporate logos and their origin, hence
the title.

'Pattern Recognition...'

is also used by our Armed Forces intelligence and one of the tests they use
to see if candidates
have any aptitude for that sort of thing is to see if they can quickly spot
the word 'NINA,' (the title of this post), in drawings by the caricturist,
Al Hirschfeld.

In his line drawings since 1945 Hirschfeld buried the word NINA as a tribute
to his daughter, Nina.

http://tinyurl.com/4ofp

Hirschfeld died today, hence the 'another one bites the dust' ref.

and yes,  Bob Hope is still with us, good catch.

anyone making book on him making it to his cenntarial b-day on 5/29/03?

btw, the last time we were hit with the 'myth of they go in threes' was
around Father's Day 2001
when, along with my Dad, Jack Lemmon, John Lee Hooker and Caroll O'Connor
all went in the same week.

Bob would round this week's death toll out nicely.

nic


p
