Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Acid Test history (was: RE: [sfraves] Re: In defense of/ Disco?)


My last trip down 84 was with my ex-roommate who wanted to buy a hat at the
General Store @ San Gregorio and asked me to go with.

His mom knows the couple that the La Honda Prankster House was sold to, and
once introduced them to me as they were having coffee at La Dolce Vita in
Palo Alto as I was passing through on my way to work.

Of course they didn't tell me at the time, that they were living there.

This time I got smart and insisted, while passing through La Honda, that
since he has been on the property for a party that he and his mom got
invited to, that he show me the house, which he did, but refused to stop the
car since he was eager to get that damn hat.

Whatever.

There is a *lot* of psychedelic history in the Bay Area that got
steamrollered over by the dot.com gold rush, ist eine schade, but i've
already posted on that at length and i won't bore u any further with it

I was reading Hunter S. Thompson's Song's of the Doomed today where he
describes dropping acid for the first time at that house, the occasion being
the first meet btwn the hell's angel's and the Pranksters that he helped
arrange.

He described it as being a hotbed for police activity that night, which must
have been something since the road today is a two laner.

Anyways, I don't how anyone, even with the most slightest of readings, could
not see the Prankster's 'Tests' as being a precursor of today's parties, but
maybe that's just me.

-n

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's

------=_NextPart_000_0026_01C2C0B4.600CE7E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Just a little FYI if you have Wells Fargo as a bank.

Have you ever heard of a Returned Statement Fee?  Well, I never have and
it showed up on my statement.  Its amazing how many little things can pop
up on statements that you may miss, but I saw this one and I was like what
the hell does that mean?

So, I sent an email to them.

This is what they said:

The $5.00 fee was charged to your account because your monthly statement
was returned by the Post Office as undeliverable.  It was mailed to the
address we currently have on file.

Umm excuse me! Take it up with the POST OFFICE I have lived at my current
address for over 8 months if not longer and I have received statements from
them regularly.  So, who sets the policies for their banks and their fees?
I think it is terrible customer service to charge a fee for something like
that.  It is my problem if I do not receive my statements, it certainly does
not put them out in anyway.

So, The Moral of the story, ALWAYS check your bank statements (Credit Cards)
too, and if you do end up moving make sure you let your bank know first so
they dont start charging you fees for all I know they may charge it every
time a statement goes out?

Has anyone else heard of a bank doing this? $5.00 seems like a little bit of
money but if they hit people all over the place regularly, it could
certainly add up for them.

Jeanavive,
Dont let the man hold us down.



TheNetworkGirl
http://www.thenetworkgirl.com/
"Artists Welcome!"
ICQ 62337266
1.877.567.9402

the most majestic of creatures. He does not belong here on the ground among
the chickens. You must encourage him to be all that he can be. .. you must
set him free." [ "Fly, Eagle, Fly" ]

----- Original Message -----
From: "TheNetworkGirl" <thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 9:47 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's


Just a little FYI if you have Wells Fargo as a bank.

Have you ever heard of a "Returned Statement Fee"?  Well, I never have and
it showed up on my statement.  It's amazing how many little things can pop
up on statements that you may miss, but I saw this one and I was like what
the hell does that mean?

So, I sent an email to them.

This is what they said:

"The $5.00 fee was charged to your account because your monthly statement
was returned by the Post Office as undeliverable.  It was mailed to the
address we currently have on file."

Umm excuse me! Take it up with the POST OFFICE I have lived at my current
address for over 8 months if not longer and I have received statements from
them regularly.  So, who sets the policies for their banks and their fee's?
I think it is terrible customer service to charge a fee for something like
that.  It is my problem if I do not receive my statements, it certainly does
not put them out in anyway.

So, The Moral of the story, ALWAYS check your bank statements (Credit Cards)
too, and if you do end up moving make sure you let your bank know first so
they don't start charging you fees for all I know they may charge it every
time a statement goes out?

Has anyone else heard of a bank doing this? $5.00 seems like a little bit of
money but if they hit people all over the place regularly, it could
certainly add up for them.

Jeanavive,
Don't let the man hold us down.



TheNetworkGirl
http://www.thenetworkgirl.com/

the most majestic of creatures. He does not belong here on the ground among

set him free." [ "Fly, Eagle, Fly" ]

From sfraves-return-97950-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jan 21 03:35:28 2003

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 88189 invoked from network); 21 Jan 2003 03:35:27 -0000
Message-ID: <001f01c2c0fe$6c253880$0a01a8c0@damn>
Reply-To: "P. Sutton" <micromu@sbcglobal.net>
From: "P. Sutton" <micromu@sbcglobal.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <NFBBKBPLPJDLCNANMCFIOEKFDBAA.thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>
Date: Mon, 20 Jan 2003 19:37:27 -0800
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.50.4133.2400
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's

Wells Fargo is evil.  I was with Wells for 6 years and was on direct deposit
and this happened to me:

Quit my job after 5+ years...had 3 checks ready to clear after my deposit,
checks were about $20, $42,
and $70, had about $65.00 in the bank.  My work decided to cancel my direct
deposit for the final pay
period w/out telling me and so then.....Wells ran the $70 check first, it
bounced of course causing a $25.00
NSF fee....then they ran the $42.00 check (now i have $40.00 in the bank) it
bounced, $25 more NSF,
then they ran the $20 check (now I have $15.00 in the bank) it bounced, $25
more NSF.  Now I'm negative
$10.00, but wait it gets better!

They also charged me $25 (or so) "returned item fee" for each check.
Then....they ran each check TWO more
times ($25 NSF x 3 x 2) and charged me a $25 return item fee per check per
run ($25 x 3 x 2).  All this
happened in 3 days!  So upon calling to check on my account expecting a
buncha money (my pay minus those
three checks) I found out I had sometime along the lines of -$390.00.  While
grappling with my work to
get my my pay (via check, as i found out at this point) my "bank charge" of
$7.00 per month is due....I got whacked
for an NSF for that....then they tried to run it again....and again, whack,
whack.  Within 7 days of when I should have
gotten my pay via direct deposit I was in the hole about $475.00 or so.  The
funny part is that I actually had
enough money in the bank to pay the 20 and 42 checks, but of course they
didn't run them that way even though
they all (the first time) ran through the same night :)  Evil Evil Evil!

Piers

Just a little FYI if you have Wells Fargo as a bank.

Have you ever heard of a "Returned Statement Fee"?  Well, I never have and
it showed up on my statement.  It's amazing how many little things can pop
up on statements that you may miss, but I saw this one and I was like what
the hell does that mean?

So, I sent an email to them.

This is what they said:

"The $5.00 fee was charged to your account because your monthly statement
was returned by the Post Office as undeliverable.  It was mailed to the
address we currently have on file."

Umm excuse me! Take it up with the POST OFFICE I have lived at my current
address for over 8 months if not longer and I have received statements from
them regularly.  So, who sets the policies for their banks and their fee's?
I think it is terrible customer service to charge a fee for something like
that.  It is my problem if I do not receive my statements, it certainly does
not put them out in anyway.

So, The Moral of the story, ALWAYS check your bank statements (Credit Cards)
too, and if you do end up moving make sure you let your bank know first so
they don't start charging you fees for all I know they may charge it every
time a statement goes out?

Has anyone else heard of a bank doing this? $5.00 seems like a little bit of
money but if they hit people all over the place regularly, it could
certainly add up for them.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's

My wells fargo story:

Terri has electronic Bill Pay through Golden One.
She accidentally  chose "Wells Fargo" as her Payee instead of "Working
Assetts", so a check for $50 went to Wells Fargo.  A laser check was cut
& sent to WF by mistake and it was cashed - even tho she has had no open
account with them since 1995.  And worse, they are now saying that they
have no record of the check - even tho Golden One sent us an copy of it
(which has the Wells Fargo endorsement stamp and a "routing" number on
the back of the check.  They have so far refused to refund her her money
- even tho we have proven to them it was their fault and they have
agreed... But so far have given nothing but a runaround on how to get
our $$ back.

4 months and this is still an ongoing battle...

I HATE WF!!!

>> >more NSF.  Now I'm negative
>> >$10.00, but wait it gets better!

>> >happened in 3 days!  So upon calling to check on my account

>> >"bank charge" of
>> >$7.00 per month is due....I got whacked
>> >for an NSF for that....then they tried to run it again....and
>> >again, whack,
>> >whack.  Within 7 days of when I should have
>> >gotten my pay via direct deposit I was in the hole about

Subject: [sfraves] lipstick and bondage nrr

okay, lipstick: so, i had a little cash, and i've been
going kook-a-monga on the cosmetics lately, and in the
interim (sp?), i have been learning a few things about
lipsticks...for the extra girlie girl or boy, of
course...goes without saying, but then again, i do
know that i am sort 
of writing to an audience of sorts, and i know what
that means....anyway, i was having a chat with a group
of ladies who were in a good mood, and we were all
enjoying 
speaking freely about lace and cosmetics as many girls
do, and one of them recommended this book that is
called something like, "Don't Go To The Cosmetics
Counter Without Me", 
and basically what that book and our conversation
is/was about is that you should be careful not to get
too 
wound up in how much your products cost, but buy for
quality...okay? okay...so, back to lipsticks
again...i've been buying a few lipsticks...there are
some new kinds...you can get lipstick with a sunscreen
in 
it now...there are also a lot of sheer color lipsticks
available (i've been wearing a few different sheers
made by loreal...they are all very pretty and they
smell sweet)....some of them are shiney...like a lip
gloss, but are rich in color like a lipstick...oh, and
then there are still the ones that are creme, frost or
have a matte finish to them...one girl recommended
that i try one 
of those kinds of lipsticks that you paint the color
on first, then let it dry, and then you paint a
moisterizer over the top of it, and then when you kiss
or drink tea, it doesn't come off....i think that i
might not like those, so i haven't bought any
yet...maybe later...i imagine that they might be
drying, and i don't mind reapplying...that is part of
the fun....reapplying...especially in public
places...i have some lipsticks that aren't supposed to
be long wearing like 
that, but they do just basically stain your lips and
not come off anyway for whatever reason, and i don't
like that...i mean, once, i put vaseline on my lips
something like three times in a row and wiped firmly
across 
my mouth, and there was still i pink stain there, and
it was kind of disturbing..maybe i might like
something like that at another time, which is why i
didn't throw the two 
lipstick  that i have like that that aren't supposed
to be long wearing but are away...oh, this is getting
kind of  long...i can't believe your still reading,
especially if your not interested...why do you do
that...just delete..i do...okay, so bondage...i used
to have a 
really good book on bondage and i can't remember the
name of it, but it had a black cover and it was
hardcovered, and well, you can make your own decisions
and all 
about lipsticks and bondage and such, but there are
some things that you should make yourself aware of, if
you are not already aware...like things like flogging
can potentially kill a person or tying them up the
wrong way could seriously injure them...there's a
whole science 
behind the bondage s/m scene...so, if i can remember
the name of the book, i'll try to remember to post it,
but basically do your homework and read up on stuff,
and don't let someone you don't trust put their hands
on you...i haven't come across too many people in my
life who are totally hardcore, but i have had some 
things come up where basically, i had to help
people...i had to do things like find a good and
trustworthy 
professional take care of my mates for me...so,
anyway, i guess you could learn a few things from the
folsom street fair or something...i've just been
thinking about 
this a lot lately, because i see a lot of people
becoming more interested in the scene, but also, maybe
they shouldn't 
be becoming directly involved in any serious s/m role
playing games until they know what they are
doing...you have to be completly honest with
yourself...i mean, firstly, you have to be emotionally
mature...there's purpose and intent in
everything...good intentions are meaningless when
anyone gets hurt..also, just because you are enjoying
your fantasy, doesn't mean that anyone else
is.....like, for example, when i go out dancing or to
a small party, i don't like the smell of some
strangers or 
even friends having sex...body odor is just that, and
also, i don't get off on anyone else's
business....things happen though, i know, i see, and i
am just tolerant up to a point....okay, over and out,
even though this was probably gett'in darned good for
you. :)

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

SMILE 8 - JANUARY 24, 2003

Jon Doe - First USA appearance for this pioneer of hard dance.
Responsible for No Trix, DHSS, CLSM, UK Hard, Space Race and a countless
amount of releases on the worlds largest labels including Ministry of
Sound, Cleveland City, Tidy Trax, Honey Pot, Tripoli Trax, Virgin, Nu
Life, Eve, Hard Trax, Cannon, Public House and Mohawk. Jon will be
playing a very special set that will take us on a journey through his
dicography of UK Hardhouse, Hardcore, NRG, breakbeat and Hard Dance.

Kevin Energy - The creator of the Nu Energy Collective and innovator of
the Freeform sound and probably the worlds shortest Dj! Kevin comes back
to California with a bag full of dub plates that are guaranteed to rock
the house.

Dragn'fly - Northern California's favorite Hard Trance Diva

Simon Apex vs Lostboy - The west coast hardcore technicians are back.
Beware no nursery rhyme bollocks from these boys!

Jay Vigor - Banging upfront UK Hardhouse & Freeform

Orion vs Ion - Hard hitting Freeform & UK Hardcore

Boon - Taking us back with a classic breakbeat hardcore set 

$15.00 presales go on sale December 1, 2002. Get them early as Smile 8
is sure to sell out!

Skills - Berkeley - 510.704.9876
Marsupials - Sacramento - 916.442.4014
Mail Order / Credit Card / Subsonic Underground 916.441.2775 or email
sales@subsonicunderground.com

9pm till 4am / all responsible ages welcome / info: 916.484.3728 
 
  <http://www.djdragnfly.com>

only fighting a $5.00 fee error on their part but that is certainly the
stepping-stone to bigger things as you have proved.

I found this great site for consumers: It rates companies as well and you
can read other letters that are addressed to the correct individuals in each
company. It is free as well.

"The http://www.planetfeedback.com Web site gives consumers power through
communication. You can craft and send the perfect letter to any company.
Copy the letter to others! Resend it! Track it! PlanetFeedback.com helps you
get answers, responses and results!"

----- Original Message -----
From: "TheNetworkGirl" <thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 9:47 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's


Just a little FYI if you have Wells Fargo as a bank.

Have you ever heard of a "Returned Statement Fee"?  Well, I never have and
it showed up on my statement.  It's amazing how many little things can pop
up on statements that you may miss, but I saw this one and I was like what
the hell does that mean?

So, I sent an email to them.

This is what they said:

"The $5.00 fee was charged to your account because your monthly statement
was returned by the Post Office as undeliverable.  It was mailed to the
address we currently have on file."

Umm excuse me! Take it up with the POST OFFICE I have lived at my current
address for over 8 months if not longer and I have received statements from
them regularly.  So, who sets the policies for their banks and their fee's?
I think it is terrible customer service to charge a fee for something like
that.  It is my problem if I do not receive my statements, it certainly does
not put them out in anyway.

So, The Moral of the story, ALWAYS check your bank statements (Credit Cards)
too, and if you do end up moving make sure you let your bank know first so
they don't start charging you fees for all I know they may charge it every
time a statement goes out?

Has anyone else heard of a bank doing this? $5.00 seems like a little bit of
money but if they hit people all over the place regularly, it could
certainly add up for them.

Jeanavive,
Don't let the man hold us down.

Subject: [sfraves] RE: lipstick and bondage nrr

Did you know lipsticks and cosmetics are pretty much manufactured in about
three major companies across the countries and then they are shipped out to
L'Oreal, Prescriptives what ever, who repackage and mark them up insanely.
There is not much difference in products unless you are looking into skin
care.

My make-up instructor said "it is all about the application not the product
she could use mud and make it work."

As well as a make-up artist, I have direct access to some of these
manufacturers and lipsticks and shadows for about $2's plus depending on
which dazzling solution you are into.  Perhaps if you are all dying to break
away from the system perhaps I can arrange to share the scoop.
And well the Bondage I have tips for that to but I will get into that when I
know you better, but to start every women should own a leather corset, not
the PVC crap either. Nothing beats the feeling of leather on your skin.

From: Geri Dahl [mailto:eeelips@yahoo.com]
Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 8:32 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: lipstick and bondage nrr

okay, lipstick: so, i had a little cash, and i've been
going kook-a-monga on the cosmetics lately, and in the
interim (sp?), i have been learning a few things about
lipsticks...for the extra girlie girl or boy, of
course...goes without saying, but then again, i do
know that i am sort
of writing to an audience of sorts, and i know what
that means....anyway, i was having a chat with a group
of ladies who were in a good mood, and we were all
enjoying
speaking freely about lace and cosmetics as many girls
do, and one of them recommended this book that is
called something like, "Don't Go To The Cosmetics
Counter Without Me",
and basically what that book and our conversation
is/was about is that you should be careful not to get
too
wound up in how much your products cost, but buy for
quality...okay? okay...so, back to lipsticks
again...i've been buying a few lipsticks...there are
some new kinds...you can get lipstick with a sunscreen
in
it now...there are also a lot of sheer color lipsticks
available (i've been wearing a few different sheers
made by loreal...they are all very pretty and they
smell sweet)....some of them are shiney...like a lip
gloss, but are rich in color like a lipstick...oh, and
then there are still the ones that are creme, frost or
have a matte finish to them...one girl recommended
that i try one
of those kinds of lipsticks that you paint the color
on first, then let it dry, and then you paint a
moisterizer over the top of it, and then when you kiss
or drink tea, it doesn't come off....i think that i
might not like those, so i haven't bought any
yet...maybe later...i imagine that they might be
drying, and i don't mind reapplying...that is part of
the fun....reapplying...especially in public
places...i have some lipsticks that aren't supposed to
be long wearing like
that, but they do just basically stain your lips and
not come off anyway for whatever reason, and i don't
like that...i mean, once, i put vaseline on my lips
something like three times in a row and wiped firmly
across
my mouth, and there was still i pink stain there, and
it was kind of disturbing..maybe i might like
something like that at another time, which is why i
didn't throw the two
lipstick  that i have like that that aren't supposed
to be long wearing but are away...oh, this is getting
kind of  long...i can't believe your still reading,
especially if your not interested...why do you do
that...just delete..i do...okay, so bondage...i used
to have a
really good book on bondage and i can't remember the
name of it, but it had a black cover and it was
hardcovered, and well, you can make your own decisions
and all
about lipsticks and bondage and such, but there are
some things that you should make yourself aware of, if
you are not already aware...like things like flogging
can potentially kill a person or tying them up the
wrong way could seriously injure them...there's a
whole science
behind the bondage s/m scene...so, if i can remember
the name of the book, i'll try to remember to post it,
but basically do your homework and read up on stuff,
and don't let someone you don't trust put their hands
on you...i haven't come across too many people in my
life who are totally hardcore, but i have had some
things come up where basically, i had to help
people...i had to do things like find a good and
trustworthy
professional take care of my mates for me...so,
anyway, i guess you could learn a few things from the
folsom street fair or something...i've just been
thinking about
this a lot lately, because i see a lot of people
becoming more interested in the scene, but also, maybe
they shouldn't
be becoming directly involved in any serious s/m role
playing games until they know what they are
doing...you have to be completly honest with
yourself...i mean, firstly, you have to be emotionally
mature...there's purpose and intent in
everything...good intentions are meaningless when
anyone gets hurt..also, just because you are enjoying
your fantasy, doesn't mean that anyone else
is.....like, for example, when i go out dancing or to
a small party, i don't like the smell of some
strangers or
even friends having sex...body odor is just that, and
also, i don't get off on anyone else's
business....things happen though, i know, i see, and i
am just tolerant up to a point....okay, over and out,
even though this was probably gett'in darned good for
you. :)

Please don't ever go on judge judy Dina.  I would die laughing, and I'm 
too young to die as I don't even have kids yet (although it turns out 
the bitch is probably pregnant which is just friggin great...)  but 
anyways.... as far as well fartgo goes, they are the most evil company 
on the planet.  BUUUUUT, I've been with them now for 10 years, after all 
the rediculous fees because when i've been in europe at 9am there (which 
is midnight here) and had drama with my ATM card, there was always a 
live person on the other end of the wellsfargo phone to fix my shit.  So 
while 90% of the time I have problems with my account its their fault 
and they are ripping me off blind, I just consider the fees payment for 
having a live person on the phone to fix my crap when im sitting in a 
berlin train station starving my ass off.  They are evil, shady and the 
most greedy fucks on the planet, but their ATM cards work on every 
european atm i've ever used, and when they didn't a simple phone call 
was all it took to fix it.  So while they are probably not the best bank 
in the world by any means, I think they are still with the pain if you 
travel a lot.

Keep it Wet & Hard...
XXX,
p a t

>>>>-----Original Message-----
>>>>From: P. Sutton [mailto:micromu@sbcglobal.net]
>>>>Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 7:37 PM
>>>>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Wells Fargo is evil.  I was with Wells for 6 years and was on
>>>>direct deposit
>>>>and this happened to me:
>>>>
>>>>Quit my job after 5+ years...had 3 checks ready to clear after
>>>>my deposit,
>>>>checks were about $20, $42,
>>>>and $70, had about $65.00 in the bank.  My work decided to
>>>>cancel my direct
>>>>deposit for the final pay
>>>>period w/out telling me and so then.....Wells ran the $70
>>>>check first, it
>>>>bounced of course causing a $25.00
>>>>NSF fee....then they ran the $42.00 check (now i have $40.00
>>>>in the bank) it
>>>>bounced, $25 more NSF,
>>>>then they ran the $20 check (now I have $15.00 in the bank) it
>>>>bounced, $25
>>>>more NSF.  Now I'm negative
>>>>$10.00, but wait it gets better!
>>>>
>>>>They also charged me $25 (or so) "returned item fee" for each check.
>>>>Then....they ran each check TWO more
>>>>times ($25 NSF x 3 x 2) and charged me a $25 return item fee
>>>>per check per
>>>>run ($25 x 3 x 2).  All this
>>>>happened in 3 days!  So upon calling to check on my account 
>>>>        
>>>>
>>expecting a
>>    
>>
>>>>buncha money (my pay minus those
>>>>three checks) I found out I had sometime along the lines of
>>>>-$390.00.  While
>>>>grappling with my work to
>>>>get my my pay (via check, as i found out at this point) my
>>>>"bank charge" of
>>>>$7.00 per month is due....I got whacked
>>>>for an NSF for that....then they tried to run it again....and
>>>>again, whack,
>>>>whack.  Within 7 days of when I should have
>>>>gotten my pay via direct deposit I was in the hole about
>>>>$475.00 or so.  The
>>>>funny part is that I actually had
>>>>enough money in the bank to pay the 20 and 42 checks, but of
>>>>course they
>>>>didn't run them that way even though
>>>>they all (the first time) ran through the same night :)  Evil
>>>>Evil Evil!
>>>>
>>>>Piers
>>>>
>>>>----- Original Message -----
>>>>From: "TheNetworkGirl" <thegirl@thenetworkgirl.com>
>>>>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

>>>>Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Beware of Wells Fargo's sneaky Fee's

>>>>
>>>>Just a little FYI if you have Wells Fargo as a bank.
>>>>
>>>>Have you ever heard of a "Returned Statement Fee"?  Well, I
>>>>never have and
>>>>it showed up on my statement.  It's amazing how many little
>>>>things can pop
>>>>up on statements that you may miss, but I saw this one and I
>>>>was like what
>>>>the hell does that mean?
>>>>
>>>>So, I sent an email to them.
>>>>
>>>>This is what they said:
>>>>
>>>>"The $5.00 fee was charged to your account because your
>>>>monthly statement
>>>>was returned by the Post Office as undeliverable.  It was 
>>>>        
>>>>
>>mailed to the
>>    
>>
>>>>address we currently have on file."
>>>>
>>>>Umm excuse me! Take it up with the POST OFFICE I have lived at
>>>>my current
>>>>address for over 8 months if not longer and I have received
>>>>statements from
>>>>them regularly.  So, who sets the policies for their banks and
>>>>their fee's?
>>>>I think it is terrible customer service to charge a fee for
>>>>something like
>>>>that.  It is my problem if I do not receive my statements, it
>>>>certainly does
>>>>not put them out in anyway.
>>>>
>>>>So, The Moral of the story, ALWAYS check your bank statements
>>>>(Credit Cards)
>>>>too, and if you do end up moving make sure you let your bank
>>>>know first so
>>>>they don't start charging you fees for all I know they may
>>>>charge it every
>>>>time a statement goes out?
>>>>
>>>>Has anyone else heard of a bank doing this? $5.00 seems like a
>>>>little bit of
>>>>money but if they hit people all over the place regularly, it could
>>>>certainly add up for them.
>>>>
>>>>Jeanavive,
>>>>Don't let the man hold us down.

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <BA52CF01.3711%otavallai@mac.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] More Wells Fargo BS!  [NRR]

Hey, let's add fuel to the anti-Wells fire!

Oooh, looks like all of a sudden, Wells Fargo online banking is blocking
alternate browsers (e.g. non-IE or Netscape).

  http://www.powerpage.org/story.lasso?newsID=10465

Corporate whores! :)

I left them years ago, tired of being charged for going inside to actually
interact with a teller. Seriously. This is the banking equivalent of being
charged $8 for a bottle of water at a party.

At my old branch, they would give each teller a sticker to put on deposit
envelopes with their employee number on it - that way, for every live
customer they referred to an ATM (after waiting in line for half an hour),
they would receive a bonus. Can you believe that? They were paying employees
extra to not serve people.

I switched to Glendale Federal, which was great until they merged with Cal
Fed and got into the nickel-and-diming bullshit. I ended up paying at least
$35 in fees a month on my checking and savings accounts.

Last year I changed over to Washington Mutual and couldn't be happier. The
only fees I pay are if I use oddball ATMs or - god forbid - bounce a check,
and even then it's only $10. For the record, my ATM card *did* work in
Europe perfectly, and at a very good exchange rate at that. So they have my
wholehearted endorsement. So you don't necessarily need a big, bullyish bank
like Wells or BofA to use your card internationally.

Your best bet, IMO, is to keep a safe amount in your checking account for
your regular bills, etc.... and then go Mafioso and keep everything else in
mattresses ;)

  - omid

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] More Wells Fargo BS!  [NRR]

I have used BOA, Washington Mutual and Wells Fargo. I can say that I like
Wells Fargo the best. I never need to go inside ( DUH THAT WHAT ATM'S ARE
FOR) So the only time I get charged two bucks in when I call, witch is like
once a month. BOA is a bunch of thieves, and their online banking system is
horrible. Washington Mutual would take up to a month to clear checks and
rarely made all of my deposit available within 4 days. I love Wells Fargo's
online banking system, it's up to the minute and it helps me manage me
account. From what I understood there are several types of accounts you can
get with Wells Fargo and if you pick the right one for you chances are you
wont be paying any more than your normal account fees each month.

Nick

From sfraves-return-97984-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jan 21 21:19:10 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-97984-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 65814 invoked by uid 1103); 21 Jan 2003 21:19:10 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 65800 invoked from network); 21 Jan 2003 21:19:09 -0000
Message-ID: <20030121211915.67298.qmail@web12306.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 2003 13:19:15 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Security at parties...

A friend of mine pointed me, earlier today, to a thread over on bayraves asking
what everyong thinks about security at parties thesedays.  I sat down to make a
quick reply.  And, as is my habit, wound up with more of a short article, about
five times longer than the post I intended.

As I sat back and re-read it, I think I made some good points.  And, honestly,
I care more about SFRaves' opinion than I do about bayraves'.

So I'm curious as to wether or not you my points, especially the six I
enumerated and the ones about simple respect and how parties used to avoid
getting busted, have any validity.  It really does seem to me like fixing those
six points alone would fix up a LOT of the ill will that sometimes spawns
between ravers (yes, even (perhaps especially) me) and security.  (But
promoters actually respecting the people who attend their parties would go even
further.)

Or am I wrong?

I, for a change, suceeded in staying pretty levelheaded and non-flameish
throughout writing it.  So I'll just repost the whole thing below here:


I think the level of security shows a fundamental hipocracy in some promoters. 
Sure, you need a couple of guys around in order to eject someone unruly, but...

Perhaps it's a bit cheezy to mention it, but what doed the "R" in PLUR stand
for?  RESPECT.

Promoters tell us all the time on flyers, on infolines, on messageboards, and
the like, to "respect the venue" or "respect the party" or "respect the scene"
or "respect the underground".  But then, from before we even get in the door,
promoters have their hirelings treating the attendees with complete DISrespect,
as though we were criminals before the fact.  This sort of "do as I say, not as
I do" hipocracy has annoyed the living crap out of me for as long as I can
remember.

And I don't buy the "we HAVE to do it to keep the party from being busted"
line.  While that mat be true at some *venues*, I could list plenty of parties
that, if they had security at all, had completely invisible and non-intrusive
security, and did NOT get busted.

It seems like there was a shift somewhere...  Parties used to avoid getting
busted by not overuseing venues, by being discrete, by employing map and
shuttle points.  Somewhere along the line, the way parties avoided getting
busted changed to "have them all in Campbell and have increasingly draconian
security".  It's not a change I like at all.  And even THEN, I've heard of some
Campbell parties shutting down early.

All that said though, I do have to agree that if security *IS* going to be
strict, Arnie and crew are the way to go.  At least they generally behave
professionally and courteously about it.  I ESPECIALLY like the way that, if
the line's not too busy, they'll let you go back and drop off whatever they're
not allowing in in your car, and come right back to the front of the line.  And
Arnie himself will often be near the end of the line to fill you in in advance.
 (Tho even Arnie is pretty random about what he will allow into the party
sometimes.  Once (at Circuit Breaker) he even made me go put my Photon Lights
back in the car.)

I can't think of any security crew other than Arnie's that I've actually ever
actually liked.  I've been indifferent toward a few others.  But, by and large,
outside of Arnie's crew they're just a bunch of thugs.

Tho I think that a lot of the ill will that some people have for security would
go away if they (including even Arnie) were to acknowledge some basic common
sence:

 1)  People HATE to wait in line.  It's just human nature, especially if they
can hear the music just on the other side of the wall or if they drove alone
and are meeting their friends inside.  If people have to wait more than ten,
fifteen minutes tops, after parking to get into the party then you're going too
slow.  If you have to be less strict to speed things up, suck it up and bring
more people next time.  The half-hour to an hour waits at SOME parties in
recent memory are just flat out inexcusable.
 
 2)  Nothing short of a strip-search is going to stop every twerp with one or
two pills for his own use from getting them in.  A decent patdown WILL find the
thugs with the guns, and it WILL find the bag of 200 pills taped to the thigh
of a dealer.  The whole "empty your pockets onto the table" routine is just
flat-out insulting.
 
 3)  If something doesn't need to be in the party, it doesn't need to be in the
party.  And it shouldn't make a damn bit of difference if it's stuffed into a
pocket or in a BACKPACK!  This is doubly annoying, as it's a long established
tradition that some ravers make parties into something of a costume affair,
with cutsey backpacks completing the outfit.
 
 4)  While we're at it... it seems that certian securtity types missed the ACLU
slapping down the cops and establishing, in federal court, that the various
raver toys (glowsticks, bottled water, binkies, Photons, candy beads, etc) are
*NOT*, in fact, drug paraphanelia.
 
 5)  Believe it or not, some ravers don't bring pens and paper/books into
parties to make drug connections.  Some of us (*GASP*) make new *friends* at
parties, and would like to exchange contact information so we can keep in
touch.
 
 and finally... (this one is rapidly becoming my pet peeve...)
 
 6)  If someone's decided to do drugs at that party, they're going to do them. 
Taking away or disallowing gum and candy (edible this time... like blow-pops,
jolly ranchers, breath mints, and the like) won't stop them.  It just annoys
those of us who plan to be sober that night, but would like to taste something
other than the inside of our own mouth for the next eight hours!!!
 
 
 cya,
 john

__________________________________________________

>getting busted, have any validity.  It really does seem to me like fixing 
>those
>six points alone would fix up a LOT of the ill will that sometimes spawns
>between ravers (yes, even (perhaps especially) me) and security.  (But
>promoters actually respecting the people who attend their parties would go 
>even
>further.)
>
>Or am I wrong?
>
>I, for a change, suceeded in staying pretty levelheaded and non-flameish
>throughout writing it.  So I'll just repost the whole thing below here:
>
>
>I think the level of security shows a fundamental hipocracy in some 
>promoters.
>Sure, you need a couple of guys around in order to eject someone unruly, 
>but...
>
>Perhaps it's a bit cheezy to mention it, but what doed the "R" in PLUR 
>stand
>for?  RESPECT.
>
>Promoters tell us all the time on flyers, on infolines, on messageboards, 
>and
>the like, to "respect the venue" or "respect the party" or "respect the 
>scene"
>or "respect the underground".  But then, from before we even get in the 
>door,
>promoters have their hirelings treating the attendees with complete 
>DISrespect,
>as though we were criminals before the fact.  This sort of "do as I say, 
>not as
>I do" hipocracy has annoyed the living crap out of me for as long as I can
>remember.
>
>And I don't buy the "we HAVE to do it to keep the party from being busted"
>line.  While that mat be true at some *venues*, I could list plenty of 
>parties
>that, if they had security at all, had completely invisible and 
>non-intrusive
>security, and did NOT get busted.
>
>It seems like there was a shift somewhere...  Parties used to avoid getting
>busted by not overuseing venues, by being discrete, by employing map and
>shuttle points.  Somewhere along the line, the way parties avoided getting
>busted changed to "have them all in Campbell and have increasingly 
>draconian
>security".  It's not a change I like at all.  And even THEN, I've heard of 
>some
>Campbell parties shutting down early.
>
>All that said though, I do have to agree that if security *IS* going to be
>strict, Arnie and crew are the way to go.  At least they generally behave
>professionally and courteously about it.  I ESPECIALLY like the way that, 
>if
>the line's not too busy, they'll let you go back and drop off whatever 
>they're
>not allowing in in your car, and come right back to the front of the line.  
>And
>Arnie himself will often be near the end of the line to fill you in in 
>advance.
>  (Tho even Arnie is pretty random about what he will allow into the party
>sometimes.  Once (at Circuit Breaker) he even made me go put my Photon 
>Lights
>back in the car.)
>
>I can't think of any security crew other than Arnie's that I've actually 
>ever
>actually liked.  I've been indifferent toward a few others.  But, by and 
>large,
>outside of Arnie's crew they're just a bunch of thugs.
>
>Tho I think that a lot of the ill will that some people have for security 
>would
>go away if they (including even Arnie) were to acknowledge some basic 
>common
>sence:
>
>  1)  People HATE to wait in line.  It's just human nature, especially if 
>they
>can hear the music just on the other side of the wall or if they drove 
>alone
>and are meeting their friends inside.  If people have to wait more than 
>ten,
>fifteen minutes tops, after parking to get into the party then you're going 
>too
>slow.  If you have to be less strict to speed things up, suck it up and 
>bring
>more people next time.  The half-hour to an hour waits at SOME parties in
>recent memory are just flat out inexcusable.
>
>  2)  Nothing short of a strip-search is going to stop every twerp with one 
>or
>two pills for his own use from getting them in.  A decent patdown WILL find 
>the
>thugs with the guns, and it WILL find the bag of 200 pills taped to the 
>thigh
>of a dealer.  The whole "empty your pockets onto the table" routine is just
>flat-out insulting.
>
>  3)  If something doesn't need to be in the party, it doesn't need to be 
>in the
>party.  And it shouldn't make a damn bit of difference if it's stuffed into 
>a
>pocket or in a BACKPACK!  This is doubly annoying, as it's a long 
>established
>tradition that some ravers make parties into something of a costume affair,
>with cutsey backpacks completing the outfit.
>
>  4)  While we're at it... it seems that certian securtity types missed the 
>ACLU
>slapping down the cops and establishing, in federal court, that the various
>raver toys (glowsticks, bottled water, binkies, Photons, candy beads, etc) 
>are
>*NOT*, in fact, drug paraphanelia.
>
>  5)  Believe it or not, some ravers don't bring pens and paper/books into
>parties to make drug connections.  Some of us (*GASP*) make new *friends* 
>at
>parties, and would like to exchange contact information so we can keep in
>touch.
>
>  and finally... (this one is rapidly becoming my pet peeve...)
>
>  6)  If someone's decided to do drugs at that party, they're going to do 
>them.
>Taking away or disallowing gum and candy (edible this time... like 
>blow-pops,
>jolly ranchers, breath mints, and the like) won't stop them.  It just 
>annoys
>those of us who plan to be sober that night, but would like to taste 
>something
>other than the inside of our own mouth for the next eight hours!!!
>
>
>  cya,
>  john
>

>http://mailplus.yahoo.com

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  A new opposition front in the drug war

--=====================_14885403==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

A new opposition front in the drug war.


Criminalizing peaceful people who use psychoactive drugs to deepen their
spiritual life is criminal itself, some groups are arguing.


Salim Muwakkil. Salim Muwakkil is a senior editor at In These Times.


January 20, 2003


A new front has opened in opposition to the war on drugs--a religious
front.


Several newly formed groups are contesting our prohibitionist, anti-drug
strategies because they restrict religious freedom and "cognitive
liberty."


Drugs alter consciousness and "the right to control one's own
consciousness is the quintessence of freedom," reads part of a manifesto
of the Journal of Cognitive Liberties. The journal is one of many projects
of the four-year-old Center for Cognitive Liberty & Ethics, a
California-based, non-profit group that promotes intellectual freedom. The
group defines cognitive liberty as "the right of each individual to think
independently and autonomously, to use the full spectrum of his or her
mind and to engage in multiple modes of thoughts and alternative states of
consciousness."


The group is involved in several projects designed to raise issues of
cognitive liberty in relation to the war on drugs. In the journal's Summer
2000 edition, center co-director Richard Glen Boire wrote "the so-called
`war on drugs' is not a war on pills, powder, plants and potions, it is
war on mental states--a war on consciousness itself-- how much, what sort
we are permitted to experience, and who gets to control it." Boire argued
that much of the motivation for the war on drugs is an attack on
"entheogenic" drugs (roughly, God evoking) that provoke "transcendent and
beatific states of communication with the deity."


With this point, Boire lends his argument to a growing movement of
Americans devoted to the use of entheogens. One branch of this movement
calls itself "neo-shamanistic" and seeks out shamanic inebriants that have
been used for centuries. They cite examples like peyote cactus and
psilocybin mushrooms among Native Americans, ibogaine among indigenous
Africans, soma in India and ayahuasca in the Amazonian rain forest.


Others are just spiritual seekers who argue that criminal sanctions on the
use of these psychoactive sacraments restrict their religious freedom.
Some make the argument that the state takes its cue from organized
religions, which historically have demonized entheogens because they
lessen the need for a clergy to connect God to humanity.


Many of the substances they champion (psilocybin, peyote/mescaline, LSD,
marijuana, etc.) are the same drugs that were called psychedelic during
the 1960s. These substances are now called entheogenic to distance them
from the hedonistic excesses of the '60s drug culture.


Along with some newly discovered substances (salvia divinorium, phalaris
grass, ibogaine, ayahuasca/yage, etc), some of which are still
precariously legal, this fledgling movement is taking the spiritual high
road in its opposition to the drug war.


Another one of the groups leading the charge is the Council on Spiritual
Practices. Founded by Robert Jesse, 43, a former vice president of Oracle,
the group focuses on evoking "primary religious experiences," which they
believe can be evoked by many practices, including fasting, meditation,
prayer, yoga and ingesting entheogenic drugs.


The group's signature text is "Psychoactive Sacramentals: Essays on
Entheogens and Religion," which explores many facets of entheogenic use.
The book is an account of a 1995 conference held at the Chicago
Theological Seminary that was devoted to the subject of entheogens and
religion.


The council also has published Huston Smith's book, "Cleansing the Doors
of Perception: The Religious Significance of Entheogenic Plants and
Chemicals," a text that tackles the issue of drugs and spirituality in a
series of wide-ranging essays.


Smith, 83, is a religious scholar and author of many books, including "The
World's Religions," the most widely used textbook on its subject for more
than 30 years. He also has produced three series for public television:
"The Religions of Man," "The Search for America" and (with Arthur Compton)
"Science and Human Responsibility."


In other words, Smith certainly is no fly-by-night bohemian just looking
for a high. "I was extremely fortunate in having some entheogenic
experiences, while the substances were not only legal, but respectable,"
Smith said, talking about his early experimentation with LSD, in a 2001
Salon magazine interview. "It seemed like only fair play that since I
value those experiences immensely to do anything I could to enable a new
generation to also have such experiences without the threat of going to
jail."


Criminalizing peaceful people who use psychoactive drugs to deepen their
spiritual experience or widen their cognitive horizons is criminal itself,
these groups argue.


Their arguments are catching on.

http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/oped/chi-0301200183jan20,1,186936=
7.s

okay, lipstick: so, i had a little cash, and i've been
going kook-a-monga on the cosmetics lately, and in the
interim (sp?), i have been learning a few things about
lipsticks...for the extra girlie girl or boy, of
course...goes without saying, but then again, i do
know that i am sort
of writing to an audience of sorts, and i know what
that means....anyway, i was having a chat with a group
of ladies who were in a good mood, and we were all
enjoying
speaking freely about lace and cosmetics as many girls
do, and one of them recommended this book that is
called something like, "Don't Go To The Cosmetics
Counter Without Me",
and basically what that book and our conversation
is/was about is that you should be careful not to get
too
wound up in how much your products cost, but buy for
quality...okay? okay...so, back to lipsticks
again...i've been buying a few lipsticks...there are
some new kinds...you can get lipstick with a sunscreen
in
it now...there are also a lot of sheer color lipsticks
available (i've been wearing a few different sheers
made by loreal...they are all very pretty and they
smell sweet)....some of them are shiney...like a lip
gloss, but are rich in color like a lipstick...oh, and
then there are still the ones that are creme, frost or
have a matte finish to them...one girl recommended
that i try one
of those kinds of lipsticks that you paint the color
on first, then let it dry, and then you paint a
moisterizer over the top of it, and then when you kiss
or drink tea, it doesn't come off....i think that i
might not like those, so i haven't bought any
yet...maybe later...i imagine that they might be
drying, and i don't mind reapplying...that is part of
the fun....reapplying...especially in public
places...i have some lipsticks that aren't supposed to
be long wearing like
that, but they do just basically stain your lips and
not come off anyway for whatever reason, and i don't
like that...i mean, once, i put vaseline on my lips
something like three times in a row and wiped firmly
across
my mouth, and there was still i pink stain there, and
it was kind of disturbing..maybe i might like
something like that at another time, which is why i
didn't throw the two
lipstick that i have like that that aren't supposed
to be long wearing but are away...oh, this is getting
kind of long...i can't believe your still reading,
especially if your not interested...why do you do
that...just delete..i do...okay, so bondage...i used
to have a
really good book on bondage and i can't remember the
name of it, but it had a black cover and it was
hardcovered, and well, you can make your own decisions
and all
about lipsticks and bondage and such, but there are
some things that you should make yourself aware of, if
you are not already aware...like things like flogging
can potentially kill a person or tying them up the
wrong way could seriously injure them...there's a
whole science
behind the bondage s/m scene...so, if i can remember
the name of the book, i'll try to remember to post it,
but basically do your homework and read up on stuff,
and don't let someone you don't trust put their hands
on you...i haven't come across too many people in my
life who are totally hardcore, but i have had some
things come up where basically, i had to help
people...i had to do things like find a good and
trustworthy
professional take care of my mates for me...so,
anyway, i guess you could learn a few things from the
folsom street fair or something...i've just been
thinking about
this a lot lately, because i see a lot of people
becoming more interested in the scene, but also, maybe
they shouldn't
be becoming directly involved in any serious s/m role
playing games until they know what they are
doing...you have to be completly honest with
yourself...i mean, firstly, you have to be emotionally
mature...there's purpose and intent in
everything...good intentions are meaningless when
anyone gets hurt..also, just because you are enjoying
your fantasy, doesn't mean that anyone else
is.....like, for example, when i go out dancing or to
a small party, i don't like the smell of some
strangers or
even friends having sex...body odor is just that, and
also, i don't get off on anyone else's
business....things happen though, i know, i see, and i
am just tolerant up to a point....okay, over and out,
even though this was probably gett'in darned good for
you. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...

--=====================_7722732==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I'm in perfect agreement with you, John.  This whole intrusive security 
issue is a relatively recent development in the EDM community.  I can tell 
you from personal experience --  prior to the late nineties the only 
security check at 21+ club parties was presentation of a driver's license 
or other "official" ID.  There was no body pat or, even worse, examination 
of personal items.  At "raves" or other underground events there was no or 
minimal "security":  usually some big guy to run the door so that crowds 
didn't build on the street and alert the authorities to the event.

When this practice began at 1015 I was horrified.  And I stopped going to 
1015.  Period.  Further, if I know I must undergo intrusive security check 
at a party I will avoid that event, that's how strongly I feel about 
this.  I really detest having some stranger violate my person as the price 
of admission to a party.  Ruins my vibe.  I believe this is no way to 
welcome guests.

Love,

Apollo




>>From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
>>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>Subject: [sfraves] Security at parties...
>>Date: Tue, 21 Jan 2003 13:19:15 -0800 (PST)
>>
>>A friend of mine pointed me, earlier today, to a thread over on bayraves 
>>asking
>>what everyong thinks about security at parties thesedays.  I sat down to 
>>make a
>>quick reply.  And, as is my habit, wound up with more of a short article, 
>>about
>>five times longer than the post I intended.
>>
>>As I sat back and re-read it, I think I made some good points.  And, 
>>honestly,
>>I care more about SFRaves' opinion than I do about bayraves'.
>>
>>So I'm curious as to wether or not you my points, especially the six I
>>enumerated and the ones about simple respect and how parties used to avoid
>>getting busted, have any validity.  It really does seem to me like fixing 
>>those
>>six points alone would fix up a LOT of the ill will that sometimes spawns
>>between ravers (yes, even (perhaps especially) me) and security.  (But
>>promoters actually respecting the people who attend their parties would 
>>go even
>>further.)
>>
>>Or am I wrong?
>>
>>I, for a change, suceeded in staying pretty levelheaded and non-flameish
>>throughout writing it.  So I'll just repost the whole thing below here:
>>
>>
>>I think the level of security shows a fundamental hipocracy in some 
>>promoters.
>>Sure, you need a couple of guys around in order to eject someone unruly, 
>>but...
>>
>>Perhaps it's a bit cheezy to mention it, but what doed the "R" in PLUR stand
>>for?  RESPECT.
>>
>>Promoters tell us all the time on flyers, on infolines, on messageboards, and
>>the like, to "respect the venue" or "respect the party" or "respect the 
>>scene"
>>or "respect the underground".  But then, from before we even get in the door,
>>promoters have their hirelings treating the attendees with complete 
>>DISrespect,
>>as though we were criminals before the fact.  This sort of "do as I say, 
>>not as
>>I do" hipocracy has annoyed the living crap out of me for as long as I can
>>remember.
>>
>>And I don't buy the "we HAVE to do it to keep the party from being busted"
>>line.  While that mat be true at some *venues*, I could list plenty of 
>>parties
>>that, if they had security at all, had completely invisible and non-intrusive
>>security, and did NOT get busted.
>>
>>It seems like there was a shift somewhere...  Parties used to avoid getting
>>busted by not overuseing venues, by being discrete, by employing map and
>>shuttle points.  Somewhere along the line, the way parties avoided getting
>>busted changed to "have them all in Campbell and have increasingly draconian
>>security".  It's not a change I like at all.  And even THEN, I've heard 
>>of some
>>Campbell parties shutting down early.
>>
>>All that said though, I do have to agree that if security *IS* going to be
>>strict, Arnie and crew are the way to go.  At least they generally behave
>>professionally and courteously about it.  I ESPECIALLY like the way that, if
>>the line's not too busy, they'll let you go back and drop off whatever 
>>they're
>>not allowing in in your car, and come right back to the front of the line.
>>And
>>Arnie himself will often be near the end of the line to fill you in in 
>>advance.
>>  (Tho even Arnie is pretty random about what he will allow into the party
>>sometimes.  Once (at Circuit Breaker) he even made me go put my Photon Lights
>>back in the car.)
>>
>>I can't think of any security crew other than Arnie's that I've actually ever
>>actually liked.  I've been indifferent toward a few others.  But, by and 
>>large,
>>outside of Arnie's crew they're just a bunch of thugs.
>>
>>Tho I think that a lot of the ill will that some people have for security 
>>would
>>go away if they (including even Arnie) were to acknowledge some basic common
>>sence:
>>
>>  1)  People HATE to wait in line.  It's just human nature, especially if 
>> they
>>can hear the music just on the other side of the wall or if they drove alone
>>and are meeting their friends inside.  If people have to wait more than ten,
>>fifteen minutes tops, after parking to get into the party then you're 
>>going too
>>slow.  If you have to be less strict to speed things up, suck it up and bring
>>more people next time.  The half-hour to an hour waits at SOME parties in
>>recent memory are just flat out inexcusable.
>>
>>  2)  Nothing short of a strip-search is going to stop every twerp with 
>> one or
>>two pills for his own use from getting them in.  A decent patdown WILL 
>>find the
>>thugs with the guns, and it WILL find the bag of 200 pills taped to the thigh
>>of a dealer.  The whole "empty your pockets onto the table" routine is just
>>flat-out insulting.
>>
>>  3)  If something doesn't need to be in the party, it doesn't need to be 
>> in the
>>party.  And it shouldn't make a damn bit of difference if it's stuffed into a
>>pocket or in a BACKPACK!  This is doubly annoying, as it's a long established
>>tradition that some ravers make parties into something of a costume affair,
>>with cutsey backpacks completing the outfit.
>>
>>  4)  While we're at it... it seems that certian securtity types missed 
>> the ACLU
>>slapping down the cops and establishing, in federal court, that the various
>>raver toys (glowsticks, bottled water, binkies, Photons, candy beads, 
>>etc) are
>>*NOT*, in fact, drug paraphanelia.
>>
>>  5)  Believe it or not, some ravers don't bring pens and paper/books into
>>parties to make drug connections.  Some of us (*GASP*) make new *friends* at
>>parties, and would like to exchange contact information so we can keep in
>>touch.
>>
>>  and finally... (this one is rapidly becoming my pet peeve...)
>>
>>  6)  If someone's decided to do drugs at that party, they're going to do 
>> them.
>>Taking away or disallowing gum and candy (edible this time... like blow-pops,
>>jolly ranchers, breath mints, and the like) won't stop them.  It just annoys
>>those of us who plan to be sober that night, but would like to taste 
>>something
>>other than the inside of our own mouth for the next eight hours!!!
>>
>>
>>  cya,

From sfraves-return-97993-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jan 22 00:59:12 2003

From: Yarrow220@aol.com
Message-ID: <1ac.f50914f.2b5f46ca@aol.com>
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 2003 19:58:50 EST
To: apollo@speakeasy.org, svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Mac sub 39
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...



I'll weigh in on this topic.

 First there are a handful of good security outfits. Arnie is great, so ASSEM 
event management, as well as Centennial Security. Security, in certain 
numbers, is often a requirement for permits in SF and Oak. And a requirement 
for renting certain venues. Often there is more than enough security because 
non ravers set security standards that don't really apply to the needs of a 
rave. The general rule of thumb for events is 1 per 100 people. I can't speak 
to underground's but it is not hypocritical for a promoter to ask attendee's 
to "respect the underground" and than have lisc., fully bonded security. 
 Also searches aren't always to stop drugs or pens. How about weapons? I was 
at an event where a stick of dynamite was confiscated.
 There were no old days without security except pre-94, its just that now 
they are licensed and wear a uniform. This sucks and hurts the vibe, but its 
better than some buffed friend of the promoters stealing some kids bag of pot 
under the guise of security.
 The best most constructive thing to do is to email promoter and tell them 
what security companies you liked and why. Did a certain company treat the 
people kindly and without using fear tactics? Was a certain company rude or 
rough? By dialoging with promoter you can help shape the type of companies 
that are used, because security is here to stay.
 I agree that the "empty out your pockets and slow down the line routine" is 
unless and not effective. 
 And once ravers understand the concept of a trash can maybe candy and gum 
will be allowed to venues on a more regular basis. Anyone who has scraped gum 
off the floor the day after will tell you that candy than becomes a 
privilege, not a right, for attendees. Partially people have themselves to 
blame. If people want to have pens in events how about stopping tagers and 
being a little self policing around issues like that. How about pointing out 
destructive tager in events.
 The R in PLUR stands for respect. And while I won't defend bad security and 
their behavior I must say that:...... If ravers want respect than they at 
this point need to earn it by acting without destruction and with some 
mindfulness as to what has to happen to venues after they leave. There are 
venues that won't rent to rave promoters because of the reputation of ravers 
as being especially messy and leaving a ton of trash. The worst thing about 
the reputation is it is true. Ravers leave more trash than clubbers, hip 
hoppers, hippies and granola folk. Ravers are the most trash intensive group 
ever and certainly promoters flyers all on the ground contributes to that.
 It like the thread about what happened to cheep parties but no one wants to 
acknowledge that janitorial is now a thousands of dollars expense for a mid 
size party.
 Also having security is a good buffer for quasi-permitted parties from not 
getting shut down. It shows thought and planning and an attempt at 
responsibility by the promoter. It is also not cheep, so promoter who do hire 
security are not cutting conners.
 On the other hand the security at 1015 IS exactly why I don't go there 
either.

.


Sincerely,

Yarrow Kubrin
M3, L.L.C., CEO
Mystical Mayhem, Proprietor 
PO Box  14248
Santa Rosa, CA 95402

From sfraves-return-97995-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jan 22 03:39:49 2003

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 28682 invoked from network); 22 Jan 2003 03:39:48 -0000
Message-ID: <20030122033958.16246.qmail@web12305.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 2003 19:39:58 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: Yarrow220@aol.com, apollo@speakeasy.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <1ac.f50914f.2b5f46ca@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...

You know, I'm probably more guilty than most about over-emphesizing the
negative, and skipping over the positive when I talk about parties after the
fact.  Suffice it to say, when I go out I *DO* have a good time usually, these
negatives aside.  Obviously, I wouldn't keep going to parties if I didn't.  And
yeah... promoters don't get enough credit.  Hell, just having been on the crew
of a few parties in these last few months showed me just how crap they have to
go through.

--- Yarrow220@aol.com wrote:

>  First there are a handful of good security outfits. Arnie is great, so ASSEM
>  event management, as well as Centennial Security.

Thing with security COMPANIES, is that I don't trust organizations.  I trust
individuals.  I'm more likely, by far, to remember what security was like by
the party then what it was like by the company.  Hell, I don't even know what
Arnie calls his group.

And, from a partie-goer's POV, Arnie is tops if you HAVE to have strict
security.  All of the other times security has been hella strict, it's been
VERY thug-like.  Cases in point: 1015, the maratime, and the sweets parties
including and following Hope.

If *I* were throwing my own party, and I had no choice but it have tight
security (ie. the venue forces me to do so at the last minute, or the popo's
threaten me with arrest otherwise, and in both cases it's too late to switch to
a new venue/town) I'd hire Arnie.  And if he wasn't available, I'd reschedule
the party.  My more natural inclination though, is to go with my prior example:
"Treat everyone with respect and dignity at the door, and have a couple of big
people on staff in case someone needs to be ejected.".

>  Also searches aren't always to stop drugs or pens. How about weapons? I was 
>  at an event where a stick of dynamite was confiscated.

See, to my mind, the sort of people who would carry or own most weapons should
never have found out about the party in the first place, and said example is an
example of someone giving a flyer to the wrong person.  Tho when I think in
terms of intercepting weapons, I'm thinking of guns and knives.  And I have to
admit... that stick of dynamite stumps me.  Granted, I played with my share of
explosives (For a long time, my anti-drug was blowing stuff up.) back in school
when I had access to chemistry labs.  But I can't even fathom what would prompt
someone to bring dynamite to a party.

>  There were no old days without security except pre-94,

I don't want to get in a big arguement about what constitutes the "old days",
but recent parties off the top of my head:

Imagine Us In Wonderland
One of the Family
Camp Unity
Amalgamation
'Ard Attack
Herbonium
DisFUNKshun
When the Nightmare Ends
Deviance (Not sure if this one really counts... the cops DID show up and make
them shut down the music, but they didn't clear the place out... everyone
stayed and chilled sans music)

Now, I was not on the crew for any of these, and have only a small bit of
"behind the scenes" info on them.  For all I know, there could've been a dozen
or more security types disguised in the crowd.  Though knowing the promoters of
most of those, I doubt it.  But they're all examples of EXCELLENT parties I had
a badass time at, where security (if any) was completely invisible.  And if
there WERE any "incidents" they were taken care of discretely and without
disrupting the party.  And with the exception of Deviance, did not suffer from
porcine disruption.

Do *I* know how to do it?  No.  But it CAN be done.  I've SEEN it happen.

>  The best most constructive thing to do is to email promoter and tell them 
>  what security companies you liked and why.

Yah... I *DO* fall too much on the "bitch on mailing lists side".  I'll try to
remember this one.

>  And once ravers understand the concept of a trash can maybe candy and gum 
>  will be allowed to venues on a more regular basis. Anyone who has scraped
gum
>  off the floor

I feel your pain on the "gum on the floor" thing.  Hell... I've SAT in enough
gum (and had to take the WD-40 to the pants) to want to throttle those bastards
who spit their gum out on the floor.  But I'm sure that MOST people don't dump
theit gum on the floor, and we're back to another of my (gawd, I feel like I'm
being self-centered today) pet peeves: collective punishment.  I could rant for
hours about how despicable it is to punish the innocent for the actions of the
guilty.  I won't, though, as I want to get off the computer SOMETIME tonight.

SFRaves has seen more than it's share of "wasteful or littering flyers"
threads.  No need to comment there.  I'm definately 100% in the "small flyers
carefully handed out to the right people" camp.

One small bit on the trash can issue tho.  All too often there are NOT ENOUGH
trash cans in a party!  That's no excuse for gum on the floor, of course.  I'll
damn well swallow MY gum if I can't get to a trash can easily.  But more cans,
more often emptied would've helped the litter situation at more than a few
parties I've been to.

I'm still suprised that water bottles are such a big part of rave litter tho. 
The bloody things are recycleable, after all.  One practice of some promoters
(UNITY, off the top of my head), which I'm suprised hasn't been adopted more
widely is to take used water bottles back at the sale area in exchange for a
discount on your next bottle.  (ie.  The first bottle is full price... say $3. 
Return an empty, and your next one is $1.  I've been in Costco as often as many
people.  Even $1/bottle turns a profit on water).  That would ease the pressure
on the trash cans.  All the empties would be in one place for easy bagging and
recycleing.  And hell... some cheapskates would do part of your cleanup for
you, just to get the discount on the water!  (Don't think it would happen? 
Hell, SFRaves' very own Osby has been known, on more than one occation, to
collect and bag up water bottles to take off for recycleing, even at parties on
which he's not on crew!).

It likely would not be economic to do the same with energy drinks and the like
(Again, I can compare prices at Costco as well as anyone).  But in a place so
environmentally concious as San Francisco, I have a hard time believing that
prominent and clearly marked bins for aluminium recycleing wouldn't recieve the
bulk of the Red Bull/Rockstar cans.  Hell, I've actually pestered the people at
water/drinks tables about recycleing bins on occasion.  (They only humored me
once, when I got to a party significantly early.  And who knows if that bin
REALLY went to recycleing instead of out with the rest of the trash.  But I DID
convince them to seperate out and mark a trashcan specificly for aluminium
once.)

I dunno.  Maybe it's stupid and naive.  But I really *DO* believe that MOST
people are basiclly good by default.  And they WILL do the right thing if you
give them the chance, instead of assumeing the worst from the beginning.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...

The thing with security, for me anyway, is that I really don't like it until 
I notice that it isn't there.  Last week at the party in Coloma there wasn't 
any door security when I went in.  No one was frisked and at first I thought 
it was cool.  But then I saw all of the "semi-shady thuggians" that were 
mean mugging all of the candy-kids and old skoolers.  That made me a little 
bit uncomfortable, but I ended up having a blast at the party and I danced 
my silly little ass off.  To my knowledge there weren't any problems other 
than the police breaking it up at 3am.  All in all a good party but I 
definately favor a moderate amount of security at public parties.
Trendy, aka Joe
