Subject: RE: [sfraves] Security at parties...

This subject is kinda funny in the sense that......

I have thrown a party that people really hated my security. I threw
another one not too long after, and people praised me for getting new
security because the security at the last party was really really bad. 

Best part was, it was the same company both times, with the exact same
crew. 

But.....

It was a different venue, with different rules, and different contract.
So I had to instruct security to do different types of searches and
confiscate different types of materials. 

It all depends on the situation and venue of your event. I have thrown
events without security, and I have thrown them that they do a full
search and don't allow anything into the venue. 

In the end, it is what the venue wants, because without the venue, you
have no event. 





andy

-----Original Message-----
From: John B. [mailto:svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, January 21, 2003 7:40 PM
To: Yarrow220@aol.com; apollo@speakeasy.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...

You know, I'm probably more guilty than most about over-emphesizing the
negative, and skipping over the positive when I talk about parties after
the
fact.  Suffice it to say, when I go out I *DO* have a good time usually,
these
negatives aside.  Obviously, I wouldn't keep going to parties if I
didn't.  And
yeah... promoters don't get enough credit.  Hell, just having been on
the crew
of a few parties in these last few months showed me just how crap they
have to
go through.

--- Yarrow220@aol.com wrote:

>  First there are a handful of good security outfits. Arnie is great,
so ASSEM
>  event management, as well as Centennial Security.

Thing with security COMPANIES, is that I don't trust organizations.  I
trust
individuals.  I'm more likely, by far, to remember what security was
like by
the party then what it was like by the company.  Hell, I don't even know
what
Arnie calls his group.

And, from a partie-goer's POV, Arnie is tops if you HAVE to have strict
security.  All of the other times security has been hella strict, it's
been
VERY thug-like.  Cases in point: 1015, the maratime, and the sweets
parties
including and following Hope.

If *I* were throwing my own party, and I had no choice but it have tight
security (ie. the venue forces me to do so at the last minute, or the
popo's
threaten me with arrest otherwise, and in both cases it's too late to
switch to
a new venue/town) I'd hire Arnie.  And if he wasn't available, I'd
reschedule
the party.  My more natural inclination though, is to go with my prior
example:
"Treat everyone with respect and dignity at the door, and have a couple
of big
people on staff in case someone needs to be ejected.".

>  Also searches aren't always to stop drugs or pens. How about weapons?
I was 
>  at an event where a stick of dynamite was confiscated.

See, to my mind, the sort of people who would carry or own most weapons
should
never have found out about the party in the first place, and said
example is an
example of someone giving a flyer to the wrong person.  Tho when I think
in
terms of intercepting weapons, I'm thinking of guns and knives.  And I
have to
admit... that stick of dynamite stumps me.  Granted, I played with my
share of
explosives (For a long time, my anti-drug was blowing stuff up.) back in
school
when I had access to chemistry labs.  But I can't even fathom what would
prompt
someone to bring dynamite to a party.

>  There were no old days without security except pre-94,

I don't want to get in a big arguement about what constitutes the "old
days",
but recent parties off the top of my head:

Imagine Us In Wonderland
One of the Family
Camp Unity
Amalgamation
'Ard Attack
Herbonium
DisFUNKshun
When the Nightmare Ends
Deviance (Not sure if this one really counts... the cops DID show up and
make
them shut down the music, but they didn't clear the place out...
everyone
stayed and chilled sans music)

Now, I was not on the crew for any of these, and have only a small bit
of
"behind the scenes" info on them.  For all I know, there could've been a
dozen
or more security types disguised in the crowd.  Though knowing the
promoters of
most of those, I doubt it.  But they're all examples of EXCELLENT
parties I had
a badass time at, where security (if any) was completely invisible.  And
if
there WERE any "incidents" they were taken care of discretely and
without
disrupting the party.  And with the exception of Deviance, did not
suffer from
porcine disruption.

Do *I* know how to do it?  No.  But it CAN be done.  I've SEEN it
happen.

>  The best most constructive thing to do is to email promoter and tell
them 
>  what security companies you liked and why.

Yah... I *DO* fall too much on the "bitch on mailing lists side".  I'll
try to
remember this one.

>  And once ravers understand the concept of a trash can maybe candy and
gum 
>  will be allowed to venues on a more regular basis. Anyone who has
scraped
gum
>  off the floor

I feel your pain on the "gum on the floor" thing.  Hell... I've SAT in
enough
gum (and had to take the WD-40 to the pants) to want to throttle those
bastards
who spit their gum out on the floor.  But I'm sure that MOST people
don't dump
theit gum on the floor, and we're back to another of my (gawd, I feel
like I'm
being self-centered today) pet peeves: collective punishment.  I could
rant for
hours about how despicable it is to punish the innocent for the actions
of the
guilty.  I won't, though, as I want to get off the computer SOMETIME
tonight.

SFRaves has seen more than it's share of "wasteful or littering flyers"
threads.  No need to comment there.  I'm definately 100% in the "small
flyers
carefully handed out to the right people" camp.

One small bit on the trash can issue tho.  All too often there are NOT
ENOUGH
trash cans in a party!  That's no excuse for gum on the floor, of
course.  I'll
damn well swallow MY gum if I can't get to a trash can easily.  But more
cans,
more often emptied would've helped the litter situation at more than a
few
parties I've been to.

I'm still suprised that water bottles are such a big part of rave litter
tho. 
The bloody things are recycleable, after all.  One practice of some
promoters
(UNITY, off the top of my head), which I'm suprised hasn't been adopted
more
widely is to take used water bottles back at the sale area in exchange
for a
discount on your next bottle.  (ie.  The first bottle is full price...
say $3. 
Return an empty, and your next one is $1.  I've been in Costco as often
as many
people.  Even $1/bottle turns a profit on water).  That would ease the
pressure
on the trash cans.  All the empties would be in one place for easy
bagging and
recycleing.  And hell... some cheapskates would do part of your cleanup
for
you, just to get the discount on the water!  (Don't think it would
happen? 
Hell, SFRaves' very own Osby has been known, on more than one occation,
to
collect and bag up water bottles to take off for recycleing, even at
parties on
which he's not on crew!).

It likely would not be economic to do the same with energy drinks and
the like
(Again, I can compare prices at Costco as well as anyone).  But in a
place so
environmentally concious as San Francisco, I have a hard time believing
that
prominent and clearly marked bins for aluminium recycleing wouldn't
recieve the
bulk of the Red Bull/Rockstar cans.  Hell, I've actually pestered the
people at
water/drinks tables about recycleing bins on occasion.  (They only
humored me
once, when I got to a party significantly early.  And who knows if that
bin
REALLY went to recycleing instead of out with the rest of the trash.
But I DID
convince them to seperate out and mark a trashcan specificly for
aluminium
once.)

I dunno.  Maybe it's stupid and naive.  But I really *DO* believe that
MOST
people are basiclly good by default.  And they WILL do the right thing
if you
give them the chance, instead of assumeing the worst from the beginning.


cya,
john

growth of our psychedelic trance scene.

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Security at parties...

it seems to me that parties where the security is the
most rigid and fascist are the ones i feel safest at -
in which case security is doing its job.

to me, the ideal security situation at a party is one
where you can just look around every once in a while
and know that someone, more than one person, is paying
attention to what's going on, taking responsibility.

working security at parties is a tough job and i don't
envy it of anyone.  some people are cut out for it, i
guess, but as for me... the fine line between just
keeping the peace or else harshing everyone's vibe is
one that would have trouble staying clear.

:)sooz

In a message dated 1/21/2003 5:00:28 PM Pacific Standard Time, 
Yarrow220@aol.com writes:

> 
> I'll weigh in on this topic.
> 
> First there are a handful of good security outfits. Arnie is great, so 
> ASSEM 
> event management, as well as Centennial Security. Security, in certain 
> numbers, is often a requirement for permits in SF and Oak. And a 
> requirement 
> for renting certain venues. Often there is more than enough security 
> because 
> non ravers set security standards that don't really apply to the needs of a 
> 
> rave. The general rule of thumb for events is 1 per 100 people. I can't 
> speak 
> to underground's but it is not hypocritical for a promoter to ask 
> attendee's 
> to "respect the underground" and than have lisc., fully bonded security. 
> Also searches aren't always to stop drugs or pens. How about weapons? I was 
> 
> at an event where a stick of dynamite was confiscated.
> There were no old days without security except pre-94, its just that now 
> they are licensed and wear a uniform. This sucks and hurts the vibe, but 
> its 
> better than some buffed friend of the promoters stealing some kids bag of 
> pot 
> under the guise of security.
> The best most constructive thing to do is to email promoter and tell them 
> what security companies you liked and why. Did a certain company treat the 
> people kindly and without using fear tactics? Was a certain company rude or 
> 
> rough? By dialoging with promoter you can help shape the type of companies 
> that are used, because security is here to stay.
> I agree that the "empty out your pockets and slow down the line routine" is 
> 
> unless and not effective. 
> And once ravers understand the concept of a trash can maybe candy and gum 
> will be allowed to venues on a more regular basis. Anyone who has scraped 
> gum 
> off the floor the day after will tell you that candy than becomes a 
> privilege, not a right, for attendees. Partially people have themselves to 
> blame. If people want to have pens in events how about stopping tagers and 
> being a little self policing around issues like that. How about pointing 
> out 
> destructive tager in events.
> The R in PLUR stands for respect. And while I won't defend bad security and 
> 
> their behavior I must say that:...... If ravers want respect than they at 
> this point need to earn it by acting without destruction and with some 
> mindfulness as to what has to happen to venues after they leave. There are 
> venues that won't rent to rave promoters because of the reputation of 
> ravers 
> as being especially messy and leaving a ton of trash. The worst thing about 
> 
> the reputation is it is true. Ravers leave more trash than clubbers, hip 
> hoppers, hippies and granola folk. Ravers are the most trash intensive 
> group 
> ever and certainly promoters flyers all on the ground contributes to that.
> It like the thread about what happened to cheep parties but no one wants to 
> 
> acknowledge that janitorial is now a thousands of dollars expense for a mid 
> 
> size party.
> Also having security is a good buffer for quasi-permitted parties from not 
> getting shut down. It shows thought and planning and an attempt at 
> responsibility by the promoter. It is also not cheep, so promoter who do 
> hire 
> security are not cutting conners.
> On the other hand the security at 1015 IS exactly why I don't go there 
> either.
> 
> .
> 
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Yarrow Kubrin
> M3, L.L.C., CEO
> Mystical Mayhem, Proprietor 
> PO Box  14248
> Santa Rosa, CA 95402

Subject: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

I have a serious question for everyone!

Is it me or is the "Scene" not only slower, but dieing a horrible =
agonizing and slow death?  I read everywhere how numbers are down, people =
arent coming out, everyone and there mom wants to hear rap or top 40 crap =
rather than house, etc.
Is a national phenomenon! =20

What is killing the scene?:
High price greedy djs/artists/record stores? Drugs? riaa?  influx of a =
million djs?  p l u r killed?  clear channel?  club owners?  sucky =
producers?

(the fcc raised the act requiring strict ownership for radio back in 96 =
and now they are trying to do the same with the media, including news.  =
BAD IDEA!!!!)
Is it bc people have turned this into a business now?
no music innovation?  economy?

Seriously!  What can we do to stop this before it is too late?  Some of us =
live for this, but it seems that anyone that has been in the "scene" for =
more than a year now is either a dj/promoter/artists or leaves it.  i have =
seen a mass turnover in my time and it seems that as the years go by the =
turnover becomes faster and more robust.
the only people who stay in the scene are the previous mentioned peoples, =
and even they have begun to realize that it seems success if futile.

In any case, if we do not stop this stuff below, this will be the final =
nail in the coffin.
i dont know about u but the govt has become too insane if you ask me.
it is time to give the people back their power, rather than giving it to =
govt.

Does anyone have a suggestion as to how, why or what can be done to at =
least stop (or reverse) the trend that seems to be going on, especially =
since 2000?
I have my own ideas, but am up for suggestions!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------=
-----------------------------------
Last year you helped the Drug Policy Alliance stop the RAVE Act from=20
becoming law. This year supporters of the draconian drug war bill are=20
back with a vengeance.  They have stopped calling it the "RAVE Act"=20
and have stuck its provisions in a popular omnibus domestic security=20
bill. This is a common Congressional ploy: put controversial bills=20
that can't go anywhere on their own into important bills, so that=20
Members of Congress are forced to vote for them.=20

Your help is needed to stop these disguised RAVE Act provisions from=20
becoming law!!!

The bill, S.22, is sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD). The=20
troubling drug war provisions are in the section entitled "Crack=20
House Statute Amendments"

ACTIONS TO TAKE

*** Call your two Senators. You can contact your Senators through the=20
Capitol Switchboard at 202-224-3121. To find out who your Senators=20
are go to: http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm. =20
Tell them:
    1) You oppose the "crack house statute" amendments in S.22.
    2) These provisions are just like the provisions in the RAVE Act=20
       last year.
    3) The provisions would endanger public health, free speech, and
       property rights.=20
    4) Urge them to contact Daschle's office and work to get these
       provisions removed from S.22.=20

** Fax Senator Daschle (even if he is not one of your two Senators).
   To fax Senator Daschle go to:=20
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=3D2&item=3D1448.

** Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. The=20
   Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.

For more information on the RAVE Act and how the S. 22 "crack house"=20
provisions will affect public health, free speech, and property=20
rights see:   http://www.nomoredrugwar.org/music/rave_act.htm=20


Please visit=20
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.ctsg.com/managesubscription.asp to=20
learn about other lists you can subscribe to, or to unsubscribe from=20
individual lists.=20

For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org .

Please consider joining the Drug Policy Alliance:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/join

You can access the new bill at: http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c108:=
S.22:
(NOTE: you must cut and paste the entire URL, including the colon,=20
into a browser to access this document.)=20

The bill can also be accessed by searching from http://thomas.loc.gov/home/=
c108query.html . The Thomas homepage is inexplicably on last year's =
session, which is why you probably couldn't find this bill initially.

http://www.dancesafe.org/new/articles/s22.pdf=20

http://www.ilw.com/lawyers/immigdaily/congress_news/2003,0113-dempriority.s=
htm

on 1/22/03 10:36 AM, Nathan Seven at scosol@yahoo.com wrote:

> And well, they're much smarter too- that's why you can buy a DVD for
> $10 but the soundtrack to that same movie costs $16 :D

Hahah.. well, I found the real mindfuck the other night. As I was going
through the Pop/Rock CD section at Tower, I thought I'd take a look at the
section for The Cure.

A couple of years ago, all of The Cure's back catalogue was raised to full
price for some reason. With current pricing, that places their albums at
$18.99 apiece. They had a few import versions of some of the CDs...
stickered at $17.99.  What's wrong with this picture?

This is the same problem that has plagued Japanese CDs for years. The
imports (American ones in particular) often ended up being cheaper than the
domestics. Of course, over there, they started adding value by putting a ton
of bonus tracks on albums, which is why the Japanese imports were always so
cool. Unfortunately, the American recording industry's take on this is to
entice buyers by putting a low-res music video on the CD and calling it
"enhanced."  Feh.

 - omid

At 11:07 AM 1/22/2003 -0800, Nick wrote:
>Agreed.. People have more fun when they don't have to worry about a big ass
>security guard breathing down their neck.

Yes, and this is the spirit of an "underground."  I don't know what parties 
people are going to, but I haven't been to an event with a "pat down" and 
such for over a year.  Even at Tantra, which was a publicly advertised 
event which attracted a couple of thousand, there was no intrusive security.

To my mind, "security" at a "rave" is absurd.  We can fuss about terms, but 
a mass market party in a venue which requires heavy security and 
confiscation of private items like breath mints, inspection of bags and 
other personal items, is not a "rave."  Raves are family events that are 
carefully promoted to those who are highly unlikely to bring spray paint, 
knives, and other dangerous items to the party.  Eh?  I mean...really.

At our parties we have what we call "safety."  The emphasis here is on the 
safety of our guests, and that includes protecting the event from being 
shut down by the authorities,  karma patrol, having an EMT available for 
any medical emergency, and the like.  Our guests are treated as one would 
treat a friend visiting one's home.  We assume that those who attend these 
parties are responsible and look after each other.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

--=====================_11359553==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 11:01 AM 1/22/2003 -0500, Chris Dooley wrote:
>I have a serious question for everyone!
>
>Is it me or is the "Scene" not only slower, but dieing a horrible 
>agonizing and slow death?  I read everywhere how numbers are down, people 
>arent coming out, everyone and there mom wants to hear rap or top 40 crap 
>rather than house, etc.
>Is a national phenomenon!
>
>What is killing the scene?:
>High price greedy djs/artists/record stores? Drugs? riaa?  influx of a 
>million djs?  p l u r killed?  clear channel?  club owners?  sucky producers?

It depends on what scene you mean:)

The club scene in San Francisco these days is in some trouble.  There are 
fewer people able and willing to pay $20.00 cover and spend $6.00 or more 
for drinks.  Those with disadvantageous lease arrangements made in the .com 
era that require heavy cover and bar take are going to have to restructure 
to survive.  On the other hand, more venue spaces seem to be opening up, 
with more realistic financial requirements, so we may see some 
revitalization of clubbing on a more modest scale in future.  The days when 
one paid someone like Donald Glaude thousands to spin and met him at the 
airport with a Hummer are gone for awhile, I think.  Not something I 
particularly miss.  Lots of good, new talent out there.

I personally have been to very few club events in the past year.  When I do 
go, I frequent places like Club 6 where "security" is non-existent and one 
can be comfortable and free inside.  I am way past the point where I am 
going to pay to be frisked.  Others feel this way, especially the old house 
crowd.  One of the problems Come-Unity had at the end was finding a place 
where people who have been dancing for over ten years didn't have to be 
treated like criminals.

I believe, therefore, that we have entered an era where mass market 
promoters, DJs and the like must have lowered expectations 
financially.  Party goers, on the other hand, expect lower prices and 
better treatment at the events they attend, especially the house music 
crowd and others who have been dancing for years and felt alienated by 
things like VIP rooms, poor treatment by staff, and lack of family vibe at 
parties.

If you are talking about the underground scene, however, I personally think 
there is a growing appetite for these parties.  Many have been 
disillusioned with the late nineties club culture in the Bay and are 
looking for off the map parties where the vibe is more intimate.  Even some 
"permitted" events these days are positioned as "undergrounds" because 
promoters are discovering that this is attractive.  Low prices.  Often the 
absence of costly booze.  Good talent.  Old friends environment.  God 
knows, in a world that is becoming increasingly dark and violent (hell, 
last night two college frat houses had a rumble and one kid was killed), 
folks aren't going to pay for more conflict and dissonance in their free 
time.  The underground did, and does, provide at its best a welcome break 
from life's turmoil -- that old temporary autonomous zone -- where people 
can be with those they prefer in non-judgmental milieu.

This change, to me, is a good thing.

As for the EDM scene outside of the Bay -- I get emails these days from 
people all over the world who have somehow got hold of House Music 101 and 
share with me their passion for house and their very energetic local 
scenes.  The most recent was from a DJ in Romania.  Many of these scenes 
are in relatively poor places where they haven't been able to make the 
equation EDM=money yet.  Exciting.  Hard times breed innovation.

Ten years ago when the rave community was beginning here there was a poor 
economy, life and death struggle with AIDS for many in the music scene, war 
with Iraq -- a time many considered dark also.  Out of that pain came one 
of the most vibrant dance and music cultures I have seen since seventies 
New York.  I say -- get ready for another paradigm buster.  Change is in 
the air.

Love,

Apollo

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Security at parties...

>>  There were no old days without security except pre-94,
>
>I don't want to get in a big arguement about what constitutes the "old days",
>but recent parties off the top of my head:
>
<snip>
>Now, I was not on the crew for any of these, and have only a small bit of
>"behind the scenes" info on them.  For all I know, there could've been a
>dozen or more security types disguised in the crowd.  Though knowing the
>promoters of most of those, I doubt it.  But they're all examples of
>EXCELLENT parties I had a badass time at, where security (if any) was
>completely invisible.  And if there WERE any "incidents" they were taken
>care of discretely and without disrupting the party.  And with the
>exception of Deviance, did not suffer from porcine disruption.
>
>Do *I* know how to do it?  No.  But it CAN be done.  I've SEEN it happen.

I think what Yarrow is referring to is security at permitted, larger
events. There was never a time when you could get away with throwing an
event at a civic center or arena without having to invest in security
presence - it's simply a requirement for getting a permit. Even the
viberation parties we did at CZ had security, because the USCA (co-op
central office) required a written contract with a bonded security company
to allow a party to hapen.

The parties you mentioned, John, were all semi-legal undergrounds, which
are held to different standards: permits and legal venues drive up the
overhead costs of an event exponentially, which need to be recouped by
larger crowds, who need to be attracted by largr flyers and pushier
advertising, and who are statistically more likely to include
unpredictable assholes, etc. etc. you get the idea. There have always been
security-free parties on the fringes of the law, but they need to remain
small by definition - woe to the underground promoter who tries to go big
without being legit as well. "Every situation contains the seeds of its
own demise."

That said, there are varying degrees of "security" in various situations.
Most undergrounds I've seen typically have Big T or the equivalent hanging
out at the front door - a far cry from all the dickwads in red jackets who
prowled the front entrance to the Maritime.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?


Thanks Apollo, some great comments as usual.

To me, it seems like there is a bored feeling that has been going around
for some time now...  It's almost as if the oldness of the /scene/ /style/
/music/ is pushing people away.

Before I go too far I should say that I still do believe there is
evolution here, the music obviously does everyday, and events do to a
certain degree.  But likie Apollo phrased it, a 'paradigm buster' would
really do it.

We see old-schoolers and grizzled veterans going off on new people in the
scene, and that has to be less than alluring to new participants.  On the
other hand, we see those same old-schoolers getting bored, and constantly
looking for something better (myself included).

In my opinion I believe that we need two things in order to rejuvinate
this culture we love:  new energy, and new ideas.

New energy:  People, groups, styles and movements.

New ideas:  Fresh clothing ideas, New event concepts, new experiential
excersises.  New ideas that don't even really relate to dance music, yet.

The /scene/ has always been about Doin' It Yourself.  Take whatever is
exciting to you, and integrate that in with groups and events.  Probably
other people will find it interesting as well.

Push it forward!

-e-


On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Apollo wrote:

> New York.  I say -- get ready for another paradigm buster.  Change is in
> the air.


esc  --  SIEGE RECORDS  --  www.siegerecords.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene? + what ya gonna do about it?

"On the other hand, we see those same old-schoolers getting bored, and
constantly looking for something better (myself included)." - Ed Colmar

This seems to be the topic of the week. I just had a fairly large thread
about my similar feelings a few days ago in livejournal. I have a partial
solution that will hopefully appease those feeling bored and dissallusioned
within our culture. One of the biggest detractors lately is motivation. A
lot of us just won't motivate ourselves to go out anymore. It's easier to
sit back and whine about how much things suck. I'm guilty of this. I want to
change it however. The focus needs to return to the friends and the energy
those friends bring with them. All of us need to be excited about being in
the same room together again.

Who's down for an SFR houseparty? Eastbay location, 2x4 setup with SWAT
Sound, plenty of parking and cool neighbors. Oh and easy freeway access.
Interested in doing something fun and meeting your fellow listers?

Lemme know... First 50 people this Friday and we can go until you pass out.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Drugs and Terror Don't Mix

--=====================_15780192==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

DRUGS AND TERROR DON'T MIX

Opinion By Glenn Backes
The San Francisco Chronicle
January 17th, 2003

It is one thing to have our intelligence insulted by advertisers
attempting to separate us from our money. It is quite another when
our own government uses our tax dollars to spread disinformation, as
with new TV ads linking drug use in America to terrorism.

In the latest attempt to bolster public support (and funding) for the
failed war on drugs, the White House has unleashed a slick ad series
featuring fictional debaters, Nick and Norm, two middle-aged white
businessmen dining at an expensive restaurant, talking drugs and
terror. In four 30-second vignettes, their argument plays out. After
initial resistance, the dark-haired one concedes a connection between
drug money and terror. He maintains, however, that the amount
is "peanuts" and that "If I buy drugs, I might be supporting terror.
Might is the moral loophole."

The gray-haired hero, appalled by this rationalization, responds, "If
you buy drugs, you might be helping drug dealers shoot little kids --
and you might be helping terrorists do things so awful that we cannot
conceive of them yet."

What is especially galling about this campaign is that it propagates
lies about not one, but two of the Bush administration's priorities:
a moral crusade to end drug use in America, and a military crusade to
control the Middle East. It suggests that our allies, the good guys
who helped depose the Taliban and search for bin Laden don't deal
drugs (they do), and that Americans who buy drugs fund terrorism
(they don't).

In the days before the attack on the World Trade Center, the Taliban
was an ally to the Bush administration in the war on drugs. Less than
four months before al Qaeda's horrifying attacks in 2001, officials
of the State Department and the Drug Enforcement Administration
certified that the Taliban had effectively eradicated opium
production in the sections of Afghanistan that they controlled, with
remaining production coming primarily from sectors under control of
the Northern Alliance.

After the attacks, the Bush administration chose to ally itself with
the Northern Alliance. Since the fall of the Taliban, opium
production in Afghanistan has reached levels never before seen in
that country.

The State Department getting into bed with Afghan drug dealers is old
hat, of course. In the 1980s, the United States turned a blind eye to
the drug money commingling with our tax dollars in the fight against
the Soviets. In Central America, the Reagan covert war machine
condoned (if not facilitated) cocaine trafficking to the United
States in order to fund the Contras against the Sandinista government
in Nicaragua.

Bush's claim that U.S. drug use funds terrorism is not only
hypocritical, it is untrue. The illegal drug Americans prefer is
marijuana, grown for the most part within our own borders by American
citizens with no connections to international drug cartels, much less
terror networks. Ecstasy and LSD are either made here or imported
from Western Europe. Cocaine, and to a growing extent heroin, is
imported from South America and Mexico. Heroin continues to flow into
the United States from Southeast Asia.

Both Bush's foreign enemies (such as the Marxist rebel FARC in
Colombia) and allies (the Northern Alliance and numerous officials of
all Latin American governments) gain wealth from the drug trade. But
if the FARC and Northern Alliance were destroyed and every corrupt
official from here to the tip of Chile died of old age, the drug
cartels would still prosper, enriched by the drug prohibition
economy.

What "moral loophole" justifies Bush's lies and hypocrisy? Does he
think that if he tells us that drug use is as bad as terrorism, we
might let him waste billions more again next year on prisons in
pursuit of his utopian vision of a drug-free society?

The American public is clearly sick of the failed drug war. The
majority of us support alternatives to prison for nonviolent drug
offenders and other alternatives to this cruel and expensive farce.

Glenn Backes is director of the California capital office of the Drug
Policy Alliance.


This article is online at:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?
file=/chronicle/archive/2003/01/17/ED192385.DTL


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_15780192==_.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Drugs and Terror Don't Mix


This is a pretty deep issue that I'm sure has been scoured on every level
by the good ol boys.

Unfortunately, the statement that 'drug sales fund terroism' is true, just
not in the way they are intending it.

Contrary to many people's beliefs that drug sales are not taxed, and none
of that money finds its way into the hands of the government.  Much of the
high level sales are in fact taxed.  Not that people are claiming drug
sales on thier income taxes, but writing them into thier small businesses,
or claiming the cash as ticket sales.  Somehow making it seem like this
huge wad of cash they just aquired illegaly can make it into thier bank
account, and it is hence getting taxed.  So we can say, that "drug sales
fund the United States".

As the US is the number one terroist organization in the world.  The
statement "paying your taxes fuels terrorism" is true, and equally true
is the statement in question "drug sales fund terroism".

I find it really amusing that they can admit this fact so openly.

-e-

> Bush's claim that U.S. drug use funds terrorism is not only
> hypocritical, it is untrue.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

  Time for an old fart to pip in. Here is my two cents.
Back in the day, 91, the scene was all new to everyone.
So we open up ourselves to the music, people and the vibe.
But as time went on and people got more and more jaded from greedy promoters, fat headed DJ's and people who did not hole the truths of PEACE,LOVE,UNITY and RESPECT above them selves.
 I teach teens in a group I'm with to hole PLUR as a way of life.Do unto others, ya know. But to me the scene is like watching TV. The shows just start getting old. Do we turn off the TV and do something more with our life's? Or do we pull together and start something new?
 I went to my first Friends and Family Camp out last summer.
It renewed my faith in what we can do to create an vibe about Peace Love Unity and Respect. I truly believe it must come from the people putting on the parties. By creating a place where people who deserve to be there come together. Make it invite only, map point.Then when people get to the spot. They are greeted and given a gift. This gift is the party. They should treat it and the people who are there as such.Mostly they should treat themselves with as much love and respect as they would expect it from others. 
 I hope I was not to long winded and I got my point across.
Love is the LAW.
Rodney
Funkybaby productions

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

on 1/22/03 5:37 PM, Funkybaby2001@aol.com at Funkybaby2001@aol.com wrote:

> But to me the scene is like watching TV. The shows just start
> getting old. Do we turn off the TV and do something more with our life's? Or
> do we pull together and start something new?

Uh oh.. With the exception of the odd event or special, I gave up and
stopped watching TV over a year ago. d'Oh!

> By creating a place where people who deserve to be there come
> together. Make it invite only, map point.Then when people get to the spot.
> They are greeted and given a gift. This gift is the party.

I think that would make for a great party, sure - but it's short-sighted,
IMO. The party would be great, only people you want to be with are there,
which might be fun - but then what? Like TV, the same old thing with the
same old people will get old. And as far as I'm concerned, having an
invite-only party might be exclusive and unlikely to get busted, but it goes
against the spirit of raving that I learned back in the day.

One of my first raves was in some ways stereotypical. It was in some
warehouse, thrown by a collective of artists, and a friend who wasn't all
that close took me, after he had heard about it from an acquaintance of his.
I only knew that one person, and we were pretty much strangers to the whole
crowd. However, from the moment we arrived, we were made very welcome. I was
a complete stranger but there were no harsh stares, no silent looks of "who
brought YOU?" and no judgements. I knew at that point that it would be a
great night.

I know things have changed since then. I know that things have become more
commercialized. I know that it's harder to keep something small and special
since it's all become so big and public. But I hardly think that roping off
a party is the solution to all that. In my eyes, it's not much better than a
club with a VIP room...

 - omid :)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

--=====================_6201071==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 05:49 PM 1/22/2003 -0800, Omid Tavallai wrote:


>I know things have changed since then. I know that things have become more
>commercialized. I know that it's harder to keep something small and special
>since it's all become so big and public. But I hardly think that roping off
>a party is the solution to all that. In my eyes, it's not much better than a
>club with a VIP room...
>
>  - omid :)

Rave or club, the whole scene is in need of more innovation.  Fat times 
usually create boredom and repetition.  Consider, for example, the gay club 
scene.  Used to be when one went to a queer underground club one heard 
cutting edge music and experienced a tight subcultural vibe.  Then came 
assimilation, commercialization, and the circuit scene.  Same DJs at EVERY 
event, same music, same look -- formulaic, like the porn side of it 
all.  Predictable.  And then, there was no longer a "philosophical" or 
political side to the subculture become mainstream -- oppression creates 
one hell of a party vibe:)

Now consider most of the "commercial" parties around town, rave or 
otherwise.  Again, one usually sees the same names spinning.  Lack of 
creative production values.  Everyone marketing to the same 
crowd.  Segmentation of parties by genres.  Lack of content beyond music.

I think we are seeing some break out of this mold.  People are 
experimenting with new genres at some parties.  Some promoters are seeing 
the value of bringing together the often separated tribes, like psytrance, 
house, techno, hip hop and breaks dancers under one roof.  There have been 
events not advertised on this list where there are regular dance contests 
with prizes, BMX competitions at parties, and art collaborations.  I see 
more and more altars and symbology at events.

Parties in the early nineties were often the merger of new, fresh music 
with the visual arts.  Participants created their own "body" 
art.  Performance art was the rule rather than the exception.  Lots of new, 
unknown DJs and talent.  The emergence of a subculture with implied shared 
values.  Content.

As I said in a prior post, these times are much like those days.  Boredom 
and some pain and darkness are great motivators.  If you're a good promoter 
and you see people aren't coming to your parties, you seek new ways to 
entertain and delight your guests.  And I don't mean by this that you 
plaster naked boobs and pecs all over your fliers....been there, overdone 
that:)

Love,

Apollo



>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Subject: RE: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

Speaking of, I just went to a Psytrance event this past weekend that was
also promoted to the goth/ industrial scene and consciously outreached
to that scene. So we have psytrance, which is pretty much known for its
freaky, kinda more earthly flavor (mention campout to a psytrance junky
and witness the drool) -- getting along with the goth and industrial
sector, a place where psy has its roots in. It was promoted to both
usually separate and distinct groups.

We need more parties like these, where the various flavors of freaks mix
and meld into one. It was a conscious effort to promote SCENE
GLOBABLIZATION.

The idea isn't original, but the creativity that was spawned is. So why
is it that we don't have an 80's / indie rock room next to our techno?
Or how about early industrial mixed with house? I wonder the types of
people that would show up for that....

-tim

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org] 
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 6:20 PM
To: Omid Tavallai; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death? what scene?

At 05:49 PM 1/22/2003 -0800, Omid Tavallai wrote:


>I know things have changed since then. I know that things have become
more
>commercialized. I know that it's harder to keep something small and
special
>since it's all become so big and public. But I hardly think that roping
off
>a party is the solution to all that. In my eyes, it's not much better
than a
>club with a VIP room...
>
>  - omid :)

Rave or club, the whole scene is in need of more innovation.  Fat times 
usually create boredom and repetition.  Consider, for example, the gay
club 
scene.  Used to be when one went to a queer underground club one heard 
cutting edge music and experienced a tight subcultural vibe.  Then came 
assimilation, commercialization, and the circuit scene.  Same DJs at
EVERY 
event, same music, same look -- formulaic, like the porn side of it 
all.  Predictable.  And then, there was no longer a "philosophical" or 
political side to the subculture become mainstream -- oppression creates

one hell of a party vibe:)

Now consider most of the "commercial" parties around town, rave or 
otherwise.  Again, one usually sees the same names spinning.  Lack of 
creative production values.  Everyone marketing to the same 
crowd.  Segmentation of parties by genres.  Lack of content beyond
music.

I think we are seeing some break out of this mold.  People are 
experimenting with new genres at some parties.  Some promoters are
seeing 
the value of bringing together the often separated tribes, like
psytrance, 
house, techno, hip hop and breaks dancers under one roof.  There have
been 
events not advertised on this list where there are regular dance
contests 
with prizes, BMX competitions at parties, and art collaborations.  I see

more and more altars and symbology at events.

Parties in the early nineties were often the merger of new, fresh music 
with the visual arts.  Participants created their own "body" 
art.  Performance art was the rule rather than the exception.  Lots of
new, 
unknown DJs and talent.  The emergence of a subculture with implied
shared 
values.  Content.

As I said in a prior post, these times are much like those days.
Boredom 
and some pain and darkness are great motivators.  If you're a good
promoter 
and you see people aren't coming to your parties, you seek new ways to 
entertain and delight your guests.  And I don't mean by this that you 
plaster naked boobs and pecs all over your fliers....been there,
overdone 
that:)

Love,

Apollo



>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It
is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you
are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

I tend to agree with Apollo here.  I think
cross-pollentation of musical styles brings together a
more diverse and ecclectic group of people.

Also, if people are encouraged to participate and
contribute to the party in terms of the overall
experience, not just the music, then people walk away
with a greater sense of association and
accomplishment.

It is worth noting that participation does not
necessarily have to be orchestrated with the event
promoters - spontaneity is just as important.

Peace,
Thomas

>From: "Chris Dooley" <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?
>Date: Wed, 22 Jan 2003 11:01:55 -0500
>
>I have a serious question for everyone!
>
>Is it me or is the "Scene" not only slower, but dieing a horrible agonizing 
>and slow death?  I read everywhere how numbers are down, people arent 
>coming out, everyone and there mom wants to hear rap or top 40 crap rather 
>than house, etc.
>Is a national phenomenon!
>
>What is killing the scene?:
>High price greedy djs/artists/record stores? Drugs? riaa?  influx of a 
>million djs?  p l u r killed?  clear channel?  club owners?  sucky 
>producers?
>
>(the fcc raised the act requiring strict ownership for radio back in 96 and 
>now they are trying to do the same with the media, including news.  BAD 
>IDEA!!!!)
>Is it bc people have turned this into a business now?
>no music innovation?  economy?
>
>Seriously!  What can we do to stop this before it is too late?  Some of us 
>live for this, but it seems that anyone that has been in the "scene" for 
>more than a year now is either a dj/promoter/artists or leaves it.  i have 
>seen a mass turnover in my time and it seems that as the years go by the 
>turnover becomes faster and more robust.
>the only people who stay in the scene are the previous mentioned peoples, 
>and even they have begun to realize that it seems success if futile.
>
>In any case, if we do not stop this stuff below, this will be the final 
>nail in the coffin.
>i dont know about u but the govt has become too insane if you ask me.
>it is time to give the people back their power, rather than giving it to 
>govt.
>
>Does anyone have a suggestion as to how, why or what can be done to at 
>least stop (or reverse) the trend that seems to be going on, especially 
>since 2000?
>I have my own ideas, but am up for suggestions!
>
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Last year you helped the Drug Policy Alliance stop the RAVE Act from
>becoming law. This year supporters of the draconian drug war bill are
>back with a vengeance.  They have stopped calling it the "RAVE Act"
>and have stuck its provisions in a popular omnibus domestic security
>bill. This is a common Congressional ploy: put controversial bills
>that can't go anywhere on their own into important bills, so that
>Members of Congress are forced to vote for them.
>
>Your help is needed to stop these disguised RAVE Act provisions from
>becoming law!!!
>
>The bill, S.22, is sponsored by Senator Tom Daschle (D-SD). The
>troubling drug war provisions are in the section entitled "Crack
>House Statute Amendments"
>
>ACTIONS TO TAKE
>
>*** Call your two Senators. You can contact your Senators through the
>Capitol Switchboard at 202-224-3121. To find out who your Senators
>are go to: http://www.senate.gov/senators/senator_by_state.cfm.
>Tell them:
>     1) You oppose the "crack house statute" amendments in S.22.
>     2) These provisions are just like the provisions in the RAVE Act
>        last year.
>     3) The provisions would endanger public health, free speech, and
>        property rights.
>     4) Urge them to contact Daschle's office and work to get these
>        provisions removed from S.22.
>
>** Fax Senator Daschle (even if he is not one of your two Senators).
>    To fax Senator Daschle go to:
>http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=1448.
>
>** Please forward this action alert to your friends and family. The
>    Senate needs to know that voters find this bill unacceptable.
>
>For more information on the RAVE Act and how the S. 22 "crack house"
>provisions will affect public health, free speech, and property
>rights see:   http://www.nomoredrugwar.org/music/rave_act.htm
>
>
>Please visit
>http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.ctsg.com/managesubscription.asp to
>learn about other lists you can subscribe to, or to unsubscribe from
>individual lists.
>
>For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org .
>
>Please consider joining the Drug Policy Alliance:
>http://www.drugpolicy.org/join
>
>You can access the new bill at: 
>http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c108:S.22:
>(NOTE: you must cut and paste the entire URL, including the colon,
>into a browser to access this document.)
>
>The bill can also be accessed by searching from 
>http://thomas.loc.gov/home/c108query.html . The Thomas homepage is 
>inexplicably on last year's session, which is why you probably couldn't 
>find this bill initially.
>
>http://www.dancesafe.org/new/articles/s22.pdf
>
>http://www.ilw.com/lawyers/immigdaily/congress_news/2003,0113-dempriority.shtm
>

i find that the scene is very much alive. it is simply an evolving thing. there are always plenty of things to do, and every party is different and unique, so you can't judge the direction the scene is taking by what is past.  just my opinion of F-A-C-T. party on, duuuuuuuuuudddddeeeee....oh, more about undies, for the undie lover inclined...depending on where 

you started and where your headed, the scene mightly has always had a lot to do with your undies,  your tiny tops and your bikinis and latex paints...if it hasn't, you haven't been going to any REAL 

parties or, your on drugs! anyways, tis the season of love, and BIG BRAS for even the daintiest of bustlines....someone gave me a huge bra, meaning, it has tons of padding 

and wires and stuff, and when i put it on, one of my friends said, "i've never seen you quite so uplifted!".....anyone who is blessedly huge, would think i appear to be sort of average, however, i can't stop looking down at my current rack....it is ridiculous. i tend not to wear that kind of stuff too much, but i suppose it can be a fun trend to go totally varga girl, but i also rather like just looking a bit closer to my natural state....a BIG BIT closer....:)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Theatre, relevant or not?

I'm doing a survey for a class and wanted to know: 
With the advent of other forms of entertainment such as film, video and 
reality TV, is live theatre relevant? Why or why not?

*To add a little perspective:
-number of people that go to the theatre per year- 120 million
-number of people that go see top ten movies every year- 350 million + 
another billion

respond privately since this is NRR... unless all of you feel it is a 
worthwhile topic to discuss. Thanks. : )

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0301222142250.320-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
Message-ID: <20030122194045.W66632-100000@taz3.hyperreal.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0301222142250.320-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

I'm gonna try to weigh in on the whole thread, because so many great ideas
have been posted. I wrote this kinda fast, and tried to be brief, so apologies
on grammar or lack in clarity:

On scene death...
I've always thought it interesting as our scene came to rise and decline,
because (imho) the driving force of the undergrounds stayed
constant. I was in the interesting position to associate myself w/ the UG
crews, but kept tabs on the big scene by continually being booked for
massives. It got more and more ridiculous as mainstream parties broke out,
almost like the dotcoms. But just as the dotcoms have been forced to adapt
or die, mainstream parties are forced to do the same. At the same time,
the void left by UG veteran crews, who have either retreated to
their own circles or declined out of age, has not been filled...as of yet.

On fads....
I never really thought a lot of the people going to raves in the late 90's
knew enough about it to appreciate it. It was a fad. Some of us would like
to believe the rave scene is more of a movement...but is it? Surely some
of us have experienced life-changing transformations, but is our
philosophy and culture enough to be timeless? What makes us any more of a
movement than breakdancing, any less than hippies?

On subjectivity....
One thing I learned in my time with you all is that the more I
learn, I less I realize I know. Kinda like how you think you have it *all
figured out* by the time you're 18, but 10 years later you realize you
knew very little. This scene lives by the quality of its subjective
experience. The magic that I felt at a certain time in my life was not
absolute, and later on in my involvement here I found the same enjoyment
seeing others experience the same magic. So there really is no timetable,
it's what we make of it, and what we decide to share with others.

On my own involvement...
I feel like a schmuck for not contributing as much recently as I probably
could. We threw a bunch of really good parties several years ago, but now
they're probably a distant memory. The concept behind our parties really
never caught on, perhaps partially because we never threw-for-profit, and only
struck when the iron was hot and our conditions met, but we learned a lot.
I sucessfully dealt with the authorites on lots of occasions. I know how
to *not* blow a circuit. I know how to set up a party that won't fall down
at 1am. These days, I'm more concerned about keeping a roof over my head
than entertaining a bunch of folks.
It seems though, that lots of the same general party throwing questions come
up here. I noticed Yarrow came out candid on this list, which I normally
wouldn't expect from a massive promoter.I guess I'm saying that I still think
more resources are on this list than some would expect. I'm glad this dialogue
is taking place, and hope we continue to talk about it.

On elitism...
I believe this was brought about through necessity, not egomania. There
was a time, as some would remember, when Friends and Family planned
parties on this list. Eventually the list just became too big for them,
And soon after, became too dangerous to post any UG events here. Those
groups who have left the spotlight never needed to come back. It just
became way easier to *not* have an open-door to the rave community. And at this
point, I don't think any of them are coming back, which leads me to...

On reinvention....
All the ideas posted on this thread are golden. Far different than a few
years ago when the general scene mentality was "gimme gimme gimme". To
question your involvement in a scene/fad/movement and reevaluate that scene
shows that we are ready for the next step. What is the next step? I have no
idea what floats all your people's boat. Personally, I'd like to see some well
produced, family-oriented, safe, truly-innovative, from-the-heart parties
(whatever that means). I remember being a "scenester" in '96 and having my
rave world turned upside down by FnF $5 parties with full on
*everything*, that was legendary shit. I'd like to see new crews/families
emerge with the knowledge of their predecessors and make it better. It's clear
to me there are still a lot of great people in the scene, many veterans have
been scorched and are apprehensive, many others have fresh ideas to bring
to the table. Ultimately, it's up to our collective force to decide where we
go from here.

Thanks for listening, I almost feel like there was a point to everything I
said that never came out. Oh well, maybe it did, maybe it'll come out
later.

take care,

-terry

---------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org
Party guy         | http://www.viberation.com
Regular guy       | http://www.estioko.com

On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Ed Colmar wrote:

>
> Thanks Apollo, some great comments as usual.
>
> To me, it seems like there is a bored feeling that has been going around
> for some time now...  It's almost as if the oldness of the /scene/ /style/
> /music/ is pushing people away.
>
> Before I go too far I should say that I still do believe there is
> evolution here, the music obviously does everyday, and events do to a
> certain degree.  But likie Apollo phrased it, a 'paradigm buster' would
> really do it.
>
> We see old-schoolers and grizzled veterans going off on new people in the
> scene, and that has to be less than alluring to new participants.  On the
> other hand, we see those same old-schoolers getting bored, and constantly
> looking for something better (myself included).
>
> In my opinion I believe that we need two things in order to rejuvinate
> this culture we love:  new energy, and new ideas.
>
> New energy:  People, groups, styles and movements.
>
> New ideas:  Fresh clothing ideas, New event concepts, new experiential
> excersises.  New ideas that don't even really relate to dance music, yet.
>
> The /scene/ has always been about Doin' It Yourself.  Take whatever is
> exciting to you, and integrate that in with groups and events.  Probably
> other people will find it interesting as well.
>
> Push it forward!
>
> -e-
>
>
> On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Apollo wrote:
>
> > New York.  I say -- get ready for another paradigm buster.  Change is in
> > the air.
>
>
> esc  --  SIEGE RECORDS  --  www.siegerecords.com
>
>

Date: Wed, 22 Jan 2003 23:44:43 -0800
Message-ID: <MBBBKKDBHFFGJBFJGHPJOEHGDKAA.whtrabt@ix.netcom.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2911.0)
In-Reply-To: <12.2c0dad97.2b60da0d@aol.com>
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Theatre, relevant or not?(long)

***I am posting this to SFR because dammit this is something I feel
incredibly passionate about, more than most anything in my life. Whereas
raving has saved many of us on the list, theatre saved mine.***

Oh my goodness I could write a book on this subject...

I have been involved with live theatre for over 10 years now...god that
seems long! I have three associates degrees in technical theatre, acting and
direction but decided to forgo Theatre as a bachelors degree because what
director gives a crap if you have a degree. They want to know if you can DO.
I have been a techie building sets, hanging lights, running the board, and I
have been involved in 30 something (my bf counted I have not) productions
from Shakespeare, musical theatre, comedy, modern drama to vaudeville etc.

Anyway I feel that live theatre has huge relevance. I know this not only
from my standpoint, but from the view of some friends of mine who had never
been to a live performance until they had attended one of my shows.

Movies and tv may have all of the effects and glamour but there is nothing
like live theatre to suck you in. Having real, live breathing people in
front of you living the lives of wonderful characters can really give you a
charge. It's the ultimate in voyeurism. Real emotions can be seen and felt
(especially in some of the SRO, standing room only theatres I've worked in).
Of course the actors and directors have to be doing their job...sucky shows
can't do that for me though regardless of a show bombing or not I still have
that longing to be up there.

I think a lot of people don't go to theatre because they don't know about
it, or have never gone. Such was the case of several of my friends. It might
seem to be something uptight and they think they have to act a certain way
to see a show. Like it's a gala affair where you have to dress up. Sometimes
the show and what it makes them feel is threatening. TV can make you brain
dead but having three hours of Who's Afraid of Virginia Wolfe being thrown
into your face and brain is anything but. One theatre newbie friend could
hardly talk to me after that show. He kept asking questions of me as if I
was the character, like he had trouble differentiating us. That show really
screwed with his head (as it did with the actors every night) as it should
have.

I would encourage anyone to see at least one show in their life. Community
theatre is where it's happening in my opinion where you can see normal every
day folks working very hard on their craft because they love it not because
they get a paycheck. These shows are usually pretty cheap to, cheaper than a
movie and popcorn now-a-days. It may just change your life.

Rant off :)

Any more questions Alida?

Jennifer Herron
Age 30 (but still hanging on to those ingenue roles :D)
Preschool Teacher
http://www.angelfire.com/ca/chrysallys/actor.html

-----Original Message-----
From: LittleEtoile@aol.com [mailto:LittleEtoile@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 9:39 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Theatre, relevant or not?


I'm doing a survey for a class and wanted to know:
With the advent of other forms of entertainment such as film, video and
reality TV, is live theatre relevant? Why or why not?

*To add a little perspective:
-number of people that go to the theatre per year- 120 million
-number of people that go see top ten movies every year- 350 million +
another billion

When answering, please include your full name, age and occupation, and try
to
respond privately since this is NRR... unless all of you feel it is a
worthwhile topic to discuss. Thanks. : )

heart,
Alida

Subject: RE: [sfraves] JETSET DJ'S POOR PERFORMANCE

Exactly.

Moreover, this story fits the standard urban myth template of "person X told
me that person Y said blah and swears its true."  The story is never heard
directly from person Y (who supposedly actually had the first hand
experience) nor is there any supporting verifiable evidence.  Anytime you
hear a story in this form it is most likely not true but simply something
that sounds good and therefore gets repeated over and over.

Regards,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death? what scene?

Very well Put Terry..

My Sentiments exactly..

As being someone that has been around for a long time and now almost NEVER 
goes out.. My personal feel is I don't really have a connection with the 
people that are going and throwing the parties these days. I guess it has to 
do with me not being 16 yr anymore?? and most of my Peers either don't do 
parties anymore Or are so few and far between that it just isn't enough to 
sustain that spark. Not that it is gone but there are very few parties in 
the UG community to look forward to.. I can recall a time when you would get 
excited that a Cloud Factory was going down in a cool lil warhouse or a 
Viberation was going down on Halloween so you would get excited with the 
thoughts of seeing old friends or wonder how they are going to top last 
years creative props etc.. These days at least what I see and keep in mind 
im sort of out of the whole "rave" loop, kinda focused more on trying to 
keep my job ;)
But it seems that the UG parties are geared more towards a younger crowd 
either by Music or apperance of flyers. One thing about the old crews and 
the "Early 90's" it wasn't really geared towards any specific market persay 
unless you had the blantant obvious jack ass promoters that geared there 
events towards E and other drugs.. But those were not a good majority.. I 
have alot of my old Gathering and FTT flyers and if you look at those it was 
geared more towards Reflection of ones self or spirituality or nature etc..

It wasn't bubble gum, thus it attracted a more mature type of crowd even if 
persons were young the climate was of a more mature one.

So I think that is what some of the younger party crews and attendies need 
to get back to.. Sort of like what terry was saying more family based etc..


M "Still tired with no food for coffee"





>From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
>To: Ed Colmar <ed@greengraphics.net>
>CC: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>, Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>, 
>     "" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?
>Date: Wed, 22 Jan 2003 21:47:55 -0800 (PST)
>
>I'm gonna try to weigh in on the whole thread, because so many great ideas
>have been posted. I wrote this kinda fast, and tried to be brief, so 
>apologies
>on grammar or lack in clarity:
>
>On scene death...
>I've always thought it interesting as our scene came to rise and decline,
>because (imho) the driving force of the undergrounds stayed
>constant. I was in the interesting position to associate myself w/ the UG
>crews, but kept tabs on the big scene by continually being booked for
>massives. It got more and more ridiculous as mainstream parties broke out,
>almost like the dotcoms. But just as the dotcoms have been forced to adapt
>or die, mainstream parties are forced to do the same. At the same time,
>the void left by UG veteran crews, who have either retreated to
>their own circles or declined out of age, has not been filled...as of yet.
>
>On fads....
>I never really thought a lot of the people going to raves in the late 90's
>knew enough about it to appreciate it. It was a fad. Some of us would like
>to believe the rave scene is more of a movement...but is it? Surely some
>of us have experienced life-changing transformations, but is our
>philosophy and culture enough to be timeless? What makes us any more of a
>movement than breakdancing, any less than hippies?
>
>On subjectivity....
>One thing I learned in my time with you all is that the more I
>learn, I less I realize I know. Kinda like how you think you have it *all
>figured out* by the time you're 18, but 10 years later you realize you
>knew very little. This scene lives by the quality of its subjective
>experience. The magic that I felt at a certain time in my life was not
>absolute, and later on in my involvement here I found the same enjoyment
>seeing others experience the same magic. So there really is no timetable,
>it's what we make of it, and what we decide to share with others.
>
>On my own involvement...
>I feel like a schmuck for not contributing as much recently as I probably
>could. We threw a bunch of really good parties several years ago, but now
>they're probably a distant memory. The concept behind our parties really
>never caught on, perhaps partially because we never threw-for-profit, and 
>only
>struck when the iron was hot and our conditions met, but we learned a lot.
>I sucessfully dealt with the authorites on lots of occasions. I know how
>to *not* blow a circuit. I know how to set up a party that won't fall down
>at 1am. These days, I'm more concerned about keeping a roof over my head
>than entertaining a bunch of folks.
>It seems though, that lots of the same general party throwing questions 
>come
>up here. I noticed Yarrow came out candid on this list, which I normally
>wouldn't expect from a massive promoter.I guess I'm saying that I still 
>think
>more resources are on this list than some would expect. I'm glad this 
>dialogue
>is taking place, and hope we continue to talk about it.
>
>On elitism...
>I believe this was brought about through necessity, not egomania. There
>was a time, as some would remember, when Friends and Family planned
>parties on this list. Eventually the list just became too big for them,
>And soon after, became too dangerous to post any UG events here. Those
>groups who have left the spotlight never needed to come back. It just
>became way easier to *not* have an open-door to the rave community. And at 
>this
>point, I don't think any of them are coming back, which leads me to...
>
>On reinvention....
>All the ideas posted on this thread are golden. Far different than a few
>years ago when the general scene mentality was "gimme gimme gimme". To
>question your involvement in a scene/fad/movement and reevaluate that scene
>shows that we are ready for the next step. What is the next step? I have no
>idea what floats all your people's boat. Personally, I'd like to see some 
>well
>produced, family-oriented, safe, truly-innovative, from-the-heart parties
>(whatever that means). I remember being a "scenester" in '96 and having my
>rave world turned upside down by FnF $5 parties with full on
>*everything*, that was legendary shit. I'd like to see new crews/families
>emerge with the knowledge of their predecessors and make it better. It's 
>clear
>to me there are still a lot of great people in the scene, many veterans 
>have
>been scorched and are apprehensive, many others have fresh ideas to bring
>to the table. Ultimately, it's up to our collective force to decide where 
>we
>go from here.
>
>Thanks for listening, I almost feel like there was a point to everything I
>said that never came out. Oh well, maybe it did, maybe it'll come out
>later.
>
>take care,
>
>-terry
>
>---------------------------------------------
>terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
>SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org
>Party guy         | http://www.viberation.com
>Regular guy       | http://www.estioko.com
>
>On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Ed Colmar wrote:
>
> >
> > Thanks Apollo, some great comments as usual.
> >
> > To me, it seems like there is a bored feeling that has been going around
> > for some time now...  It's almost as if the oldness of the /scene/ 
>/style/
> > /music/ is pushing people away.
> >
> > Before I go too far I should say that I still do believe there is
> > evolution here, the music obviously does everyday, and events do to a
> > certain degree.  But likie Apollo phrased it, a 'paradigm buster' would
> > really do it.
> >
> > We see old-schoolers and grizzled veterans going off on new people in 
>the
> > scene, and that has to be less than alluring to new participants.  On 
>the
> > other hand, we see those same old-schoolers getting bored, and 
>constantly
> > looking for something better (myself included).
> >
> > In my opinion I believe that we need two things in order to rejuvinate
> > this culture we love:  new energy, and new ideas.
> >
> > New energy:  People, groups, styles and movements.
> >
> > New ideas:  Fresh clothing ideas, New event concepts, new experiential
> > excersises.  New ideas that don't even really relate to dance music, 
>yet.
> >
> > The /scene/ has always been about Doin' It Yourself.  Take whatever is
> > exciting to you, and integrate that in with groups and events.  Probably
> > other people will find it interesting as well.
> >
> > Push it forward!
> >
> > -e-
> >
> >
> > On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Apollo wrote:
> >
> > > New York.  I say -- get ready for another paradigm buster.  Change is 
>in
> > > the air.
> >
> >
> > esc  --  SIEGE RECORDS  --  www.siegerecords.com
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> >
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] all your fault...darn you!!

yes, I'm talking about you...

MIKE MIGURSKI!!

from you...
to ryan...
to the world...
and finally to me...

>San Francisco has always been where every precocious 20 year old with the
>slightest bohemian pretense eventually comes to do time, usually for about
>5 years. They often come in bunches from places like Denver, Chicago,
>Brighton etc. Often Artists who have made a name for themselves will come
>to San Francisco and their Artistic output will drop to zero. There is no
>hard edge to culture here; the living is easy, you get spoiled playing
>with the alterno-children dressing fun and looking for smoochies.
>DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own the place and find themselves
>caught in the mire of the 5 year status quo: If they don't show up at the
>cusp of one of these transitions it is hard to make an impact. Often you
>end up on heroin or speed and have to go home. It used to have a lot of
>LSD, it has less now. Often there are several scenes happening at once but
>there is usually an Uber Scene. The last 7 years were dominated by a
>hybrid identity of dot com/Burning Man/ravers. I think we may be on a
>transition now but have no Idea where the Cultural injection will come
>from; we have never in the past put it together ourselves. My favorite
>thing about partying in SF is that you don't frequently get beat up.

darn you, migurski!!

darn you and your words of truth found floating on the internet!!!

darn you to HECK!!

here I was, ready to return...having sold almost 400 records...having raised
travelling money...having checked my maps...having figured out where to get
6x9s so my road trip music will get the volume it deserves...having packed a
first aid kit, a set of tools, a bag of Cheetos and an extra hat...

ready, willing, and able to rise again from the ashes of my former life,
like a mystical record-playing Phoenix with java skills...

only to be reminded why I left in the first place!!

feh!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

if anybody needs me, I'll be in Arizona. :p


Giles

For those of you that read the partying sucks thread the other day =
well... I'm doing something about it.

I'm starting off the houseparty circuit with an SFR party at the house. =
I'm trying to get people that you've never met and I've never met under =
one roof for some simple fun. I think it's time to expand our circles =
and see each other again. That means whatever you're doing you need to =
be at my house sometime on Friday night. We'll be going all night, but =
kicking the level of sound down a bit in the later hours. Open decks and =
we have a 2x4 setup in the dining room now. Bring whatever you want. =
Movies, booze, food, party favors, whatever you want. I just want to see =
everyone come out and play!

were to go to a house party what would you want? It's going to be cozy =
and I'm sure memorable. Bring a friend that you normally don't party =
with. I just want to see everyone again and have fun.

think I'll name one of the rooms The Den of Sin in honor of Scott.

From sfraves-return-98070-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jan 23 18:28:48 2003

Subject: [sfraves] SF Indiefest Benefit - Sat. Jan 25th

SF Indiefest is the premier UG Independant Film festival.  Come check out 
sneak previews of films, mingle with indie-film types and dance to some of 
SF best.

check out http://www.sfindie.com for more information.

SF INDIEFEST BENEFIT/LAUNCH PARTY
Saturday, January 25 9p-2a

Dancefloor by

- Jeno [Wicked]
- Joe Rice [F&F]
- Smoove [Space Cowboys]
- Syd Gris [Opel/Radiance]
- Jim Martin [Unified Beat Theory]

Rock N Roll Lounge by

- Shane [Death Rock Booty Call]
- Pandora [Amber/Bordello]

PLUS Two Screening Rooms with short film and festival previews!
AND catering provided by La Mediterranean!

DRINK SPECIALS: $1 Pints by 21st Amendment & $1 Redrum Cocktails 9p-12a!

Festival Programs and discounted passes available
at Jezebel's Joint, 510 Larkin at Turk
21 up, free off street parking off Turk between Larkin and Polk

$10, all proceeds benefit SF IndieFest.  Tix available in advance at
Jezebels, www.sfindie.com, and through TicketMaster 415.421.TIXS

more info: info@sfindie.com and 415.820.3907
The IndieFest Benefit Party is co-sponsored by the
SF Late Night Coalition
