Subject: RE: [sfraves] all your fault...darn you!!

Little fluffy clouds? ;)

I've noticed this too.  I came out here from Utah where I was into every
form of art.. After coming out here my inspiration is next to nil.
Can't make a beat to save a train.  Its just too.... Comfortable out
here... The sun is yellower, the weather's better, the people are
friendly and open-minded, everything that fed me the agression in Utah,
I no longer feel here, nothing to inspire me.  Plus, the work and hours
you have to put in just to make rent (albeit I do live a little too
comfortably) just wears you down to the point where you don't care about
going out anymore.

My plan to reverse this is to leave corporate america behind and I'm
moving to Santa Cruz to go to college since I haven't done that yet.

-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: Giles Bowkett [mailto:gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com] 
Sent: Thursday, January 23, 2003 9:10 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] all your fault...darn you!!


yes, I'm talking about you...

MIKE MIGURSKI!!

from you...
to ryan...
to the world...
and finally to me...

>San Francisco has always been where every precocious 20 year old with 
>the slightest bohemian pretense eventually comes to do time, usually 
>for about 5 years. They often come in bunches from places like Denver, 
>Chicago, Brighton etc. Often Artists who have made a name for 
>themselves will come to San Francisco and their Artistic output will 
>drop to zero. There is no hard edge to culture here; the living is 
>easy, you get spoiled playing with the alterno-children dressing fun 
>and looking for smoochies. DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own

>the place and find themselves caught in the mire of the 5 year status 
>quo: If they don't show up at the cusp of one of these transitions it 
>is hard to make an impact. Often you end up on heroin or speed and have

>to go home. It used to have a lot of LSD, it has less now. Often there 
>are several scenes happening at once but there is usually an Uber 
>Scene. The last 7 years were dominated by a hybrid identity of dot 
>com/Burning Man/ravers. I think we may be on a transition now but have 
>no Idea where the Cultural injection will come from; we have never in 
>the past put it together ourselves. My favorite thing about partying in

>SF is that you don't frequently get beat up.

darn you, migurski!!

darn you and your words of truth found floating on the internet!!!

darn you to HECK!!

here I was, ready to return...having sold almost 400 records...having
raised travelling money...having checked my maps...having figured out
where to get 6x9s so my road trip music will get the volume it
deserves...having packed a first aid kit, a set of tools, a bag of
Cheetos and an extra hat...

ready, willing, and able to rise again from the ashes of my former life,
like a mystical record-playing Phoenix with java skills...

only to be reminded why I left in the first place!!

feh!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

if anybody needs me, I'll be in Arizona. :p


Giles

plant-as-artist VJ performance. Really.

Subject: [sfraves] Victory for Racine Rave-Goers

--=====================_8935268==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Victory for Racine Rave-Goers
Fri Jan 17, 2003


The City of Racine agreed to drop all charges against 442 people who were 
ticketed at a benefit electronic music concert simply for being in 
proximity to a drug arrest on the premises. The decision marks a 
significant victory for the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) who 
argued that Racine authorities violated the constitutional rights of the 
partygoers.

"The ACLU urges the City of Racine to respect the First Amendment rights of 
electronic music attendees in the future," said Micabil Diaz, Legal 
Director of the ACLU of Wisconsin. "We also applaud the hundreds of 
attendees who defended their constitutional rights".

Last November, police raided an electronic music concert held by the Uptown 
Theater Group, Inc. raising funds for restorations to an historic landmark 
theater in downtown Racine, Wisconsin. Four people at the party were 
arrested on drug charges. The police department claimed that the mere 
presence of the 442 concertgoers at a location in which four persons were 
arrested on drug charges violated the city's "inmates of a disorderly 
house" ordinance.

The citations were challenged on the basis that the ordinance violated the 
First Amendment right to freedom of association since it was imposed on 
individuals whose only actions were peaceably assembling to hear electronic 
music. In dismissing the charges, the city acknowledged that the law needs 
to be changed.

With the reintroduction in Congress of an anti-Rave bill that targets music 
promoters, the ACLU, along with Drug Policy Alliance, fear that this will 
not be the last unconstitutional attempt at prosecution of innocent people. 
The Drug Policy Alliance is spearheading a legislative campaign to prevent 
this harm maximization bill from passing. By targeting individual property 
owners or event attendees the bill will only drive raves and other musical 
events further underground and away from public health and safety regulations.

  http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/01_17_03racine.cfm



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 09:47 PM 1/22/2003 -0800, Terry Estioko wrote:

>On fads....
>I never really thought a lot of the people going to raves in the late 90's
>knew enough about it to appreciate it. It was a fad. Some of us would like
>to believe the rave scene is more of a movement...but is it? Surely some
>of us have experienced life-changing transformations, but is our
>philosophy and culture enough to be timeless? What makes us any more of a
>movement than breakdancing, any less than hippies?
>


George Sand wrote:  "One changes from day to day...every few years one 
becomes a new being."  I think that can be said of the consistent human 
interest and involvement in the timeless and magical art and practice of 
tribal dance and music.   Dancing was there in the beginning;  it will be a 
vital part of social and spiritual interaction until the end of time.   It 
constantly reinvents itself to accommodate various cultural and social 
requirements.

Raving in the early nineties was one of many attempts in our 
post-industrial society to wed these ancient, life-giving rites to 
technology and the needs of the modern psyche.  There were those of us who 
believed in those days that we were creating a revolutionary approach to 
human interaction in an increasingly alienating and homogeneous social 
structure.  Some even thought that we had rediscovered an ancient 
connection to the spiritual life.  Certainly early house music lyrics were 
packed with allusions to the movement of the dancer from and through the 
body to the heavens.

This was not boring.  Boredom sets in within life -- and god I know this is 
true -- when you embrace, out of fatigue or social pressure, the rule of 
the mundane and quantifiable.  At some point in the mid-nineties -- and I 
can't put my finger on this because I was to busy with death and dying from 
AIDS in my personal life then -- raving moved from revolution to 
entertainment.  I suspect much of this had to do with the changing 
economics and demographics of the time, and I have yet to work through this 
process to my satisfaction.

So we gradually lost the feel of movement and moved in the direction of yet 
another commodified entertainment package.  We lost content.  Our beliefs 
were reduced to catchy slogans.  In the sixties we called this being co opted.

Now when a movement embraces the mundane those involved generally become 
more acceptable to the society at large.  When gays moved from "we are 
unique and have something special to offer" to "we are just like you" the 
road to general acceptance was much facilitated.  We lost our souls, I 
think, but we gained respect as another valuable consumer market.

Interestingly, this has not happened with raving or, if you will, dance and 
music festivals or "parties."  Lordy knows there was a lot of money in 
massives, clothing sales, and the like.  A "youth" marketer's dream.  Yet 
the more we emerged into the light, the less acceptable we became.  One 
could say, and we all did, "look at the rock concerts, look at other forms 
of entertainment -- we are no worse, even less dangerous in many ways.  We 
are Americans like you making money on entertainment and being 
entertained."  Didn't work.

Why?  Because whatever one wants to position raving as, dancing all night 
long is really a revolutionary act.  Ponder this.

It doesn't matter to me personally whether one considers this "movement" 
dead or not.  Any movement without beliefs and passion is moribund, and 
perhaps that is what raving has become.

I will, however, continue to follow my own passions here.  I will dance 
until I can no longer walk.  I will continue to throw parties based in the 
belief that dancing is a powerful, liberating and magical force that has 
the potential to change lives and enhance the larger society for the 
good.  What we do can be defined as one will.  The music will change and 
evolve.  The parties may become more wedded to other arts along with the 
music.  The guests may become more inclusive and diverse.  But we are not 
going away.  Dancing as a revolutionary, life-giving act will withstand 
this current oppression as it has before.  Fashions change, but this one 
has and will last longer than fifteen minutes.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_15258948==_.ALT--

X-Originating-IP: [65.37.141.186]
From: "Danny Picard" <blooshaman@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 23 Jan 2003 19:00:51 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F511jEXIUrIMqFoNOOj000078ba@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 24 Jan 2003 03:00:51.0673 (UTC) FILETIME=[CDC56490:01C2C354]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR)Memoirs of a San Franciscan Vol.1


Last night was incredible. I hope you can tell through the intonation of 
this email note.
Out in front of a club, yes it was a "gay" one, a tall, drunk, lanky man 
sought out my subconscious healing abilities.  A new friend named Sam stood 
to my left and observed carefully the interaction between the drunkard and 
I....

"Wuddup bro?" as the man stumbled to and fro, "Do you ever listen to God?  
Do you have any pot? I mean do you ever see what is going on?"  he pauses to 
hock a loogie..."there is so much going on that is bad!  Do you understand?"
   "Oh yeah I understand, that is probably the only reason that I'm still 
here listenning to what you are saying" I replied as my eyeballs were 
drifting at the hideous drag queen that just passed.  Sam was laughing in 
his head.
   I was saddenned yet amused that this tall drunk guy was speaking such 
verbal nonsense in the Castro, yet found it "comforting."
   He threw his giant hand on my shoulder for support...
   "Do you feel the gravity pulling on me?  It is so heavy."  He said.  He 
looked down toward the ground in a state of surreal amusement.
   "Believe it or not I CAN actually feel the gravity that is pulling you 
down cause it actually is affecting  myself as well"  I said.
Sam laughed.
  "I'm Malcovich, sorry I didn't introduce myself."
  "as  in 'Being John?' or just Malcovich,?"
  "Nah, just Malcovich" he said.
   "I'm Danny and this is my friend Sam, nice meeting you."
   "I just got my girlfriend pregnant...It's a Boy!!!!!"  Malcovich was so 
excited he stumbled right to the top of some queen's brand new BMW then fell 
to the ground...
I was trying to figure out what his sign was the whole time...Aries? maybe 
rising? Virgo? nah not too hard on himself, maybe aquarius?  Yes  
Aquarius!!!  My mind was happy because I new that was it.  He continued to 
lean against the car with his eyes trying to catch up with his spinning 
head...
   "Malcovich, are you an aquarius?"
He looked at me as if I were the great and powerful Wizard of OZ, his eyes 
were huge and looked right into mine...
  "Yes."  He didn't ask how I knew, because he knew how I knew in the simple 
statement that I had made earlier "I UNDERSTAND."
  "There are so many worlds, so many life patterns, energy, people..."
My hunch was that homeboy was a bit overwhelmed in the aquarian head of his.
  "Malcovich"
  "Yeah?"
  "Be good to yourself, there are other people out there who understand, 
really there are.  They are all just hiding in drag."  Sam had to turn away 
to not show Malcovich his roaring laughter.  "There are lots of people..."
   "You're name is Robert right?  He interrupted.
   "No, it's Danny"
   "Robert, you know I always forget names, but I remember your's for some 
reason, I don't know why.  Do you have any pot?"


So that was my San franciscan evenning last night.  Who knows what will be 
in store for the next?  I hope Malcovich finds his way, and I hope we all 
find our way as well, whatever the case maybe just know if you are ever 
impregnating somebody and are highly sensitive and drunk in search of 
marijuana, there mostlikley will be somebody you can lean on in the 
Castro...
Until next time, farewell and be good!
Danny Picard

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: interesting poll

IMMEDIATE ATTENTION NEEDED :
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL

FROM: GEORGE WALKER BUSH
202.456.1414 / 202.456.1111
FAX: 202.456.2461

DEAR SIR / MADAM,

I AM GEORGE WALKER BUSH, SON OF THE FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED
STATES OF AMERICA GEORGE HERBERT WALKER BUSH, AND CURRENTLY SERVING AS
PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. THIS LETTER MIGHT SURPRISE
YOU BECAUSE WE HAVE NOT MET NEITHER IN PERSON NOR BY CORRESPONDENCE. I
CAME TO KNOW OF YOU IN MY SEARCH FOR A RELIABLE AND REPUTABLE PERSON TO
HANDLE A VERY CONFIDENTIAL BUSINESS TRANSACTION, WHICH INVOLVES THE
TRANSFER OF A HUGE SUM OF MONEY TO AN ACCOUNT REQUIRING MAXIMUM
CONFIDENCE.

I AM WRITING YOU IN ABSOLUTE CONFIDENCE PRIMARILY TO SEEK YOUR
ASSISTANCE IN ACQUIRING OIL FUNDS THAT ARE PRESENTLY TRAPPED IN THE
REPUBLIC OF IRAQ.  MY PARTNERS AND I SOLICIT YOUR ASSISTANCE IN
COMPLETING A TRANSACTION BEGUN BY MY FATHER, WHO HAS LONG BEEN ACTIVELY
ENGAGED IN THE EXTRACTION OF PETROLEUM IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,
AND BRAVELY SERVED HIS COUNTRY AS DIRECTOR OF THE UNITED STATES CENTRAL
INTELLIGENCE AGENCY (CIA).

IN THE DECADE OF THE NINETEEN-EIGHTIES, MY FATHER, THEN VICE-PRESIDENT
OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, SOUGHT TO WORK WITH THE GOOD OFFICES OF
THE RESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF IRAQ TO REGAIN LOST OIL REVENUE SOURCES
IN THE NEIGHBORING ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN. THIS UNSUCCESSFUL VENTURE
WAS SOON FOLLOWED BY A FALLING-OUT WITH HIS IRAQI PARTNER, WHO SOUGHT TO
ACQUIRE ADDITIONAL OIL REVENUE SOURCES IN THE NEIGHBORING EMIRATE OF
KUWAIT, A WHOLLY-OWNED U.S.-BRITISH SUBSIDIARY.

MY FATHER RE-SECURED THE PETROLEUM ASSETS OF KUWAIT IN 1991 AT A COST OF
SIXTY-ONE BILLION U.S. DOLLARS ($61,000,000,000). OUT OF THAT COST,
THIRTY-SIX BILLION DOLLARS ($36,000,000,000) WERE SUPPLIED BY HIS
PARTNERS IN THE KINGDOM OF SAUDI ARABIA AND OTHER PERSIAN GULF
MONARCHIES, AND SIXTEEN BILLION DOLLARS ($16,000,000,000) BY GERMAN AND
JAPANESE PARTNERS. BUT MY FATHER'S FORMER IRAQI BUSINESS PARTNER
REMAINED IN CONTROL OF THE REPUBLIC OF IRAQ AND ITS PETROLEUM RESERVES.

MY FAMILY IS CALLING FOR YOUR URGENT ASSISTANCE IN FUNDING THE REMOVAL
OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF IRAQ AND ACQUIRING THE PETROLEUM
ASSETS OF HIS COUNTRY, AS COMPENSATION FOR THE COSTS OF REMOVING HIM
FROM POWER. UNFORTUNATELY, OUR PARTNERS FROM 1991 ARE NOT WILLING TO
SHOULDER THE BURDEN OF THIS NEW VENTURE, WHICH IN ITS UPCOMING PHASE MAY
COST THE SUM OF 100 BILLION TO 200 BILLION DOLLARS ($100,000,000,000 -
$200,000,000,000), BOTH IN THE INITIAL ACQUISITION AND IN LONG-TERM
MANAGEMENT.

WITHOUT THE FUNDS FROM OUR 1991 PARTNERS, WE WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO
ACQUIRE THE OIL REVENUE TRAPPED WITHIN IRAQ. THAT IS WHY MY FAMILY AND
OUR COLLEAGUES ARE URGENTLY SEEKING YOUR GRACIOUS ASSISTANCE. OUR
DISTINGUISHED COLLEAGUES IN THIS BUSINESS TRANSACTION INCLUDE THE
SITTING VICE-PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, RICHARD CHENEY,
WHO IS AN ORIGINAL PARTNER IN THE IRAQ VENTURE AND FORMER HEAD OF THE
HALLIBURTON OIL COMPANY, AND CONDOLEEZA RICE, WHOSE PROFESSIONAL
DEDICATION TO THE VENTURE WAS DEMONSTRATED IN THE NAMING OF A CHEVRON
OIL TANKER AFTER HER.

I WOULD BESEECH YOU TO TRANSFER A SUM EQUALING TEN TO TWENTY-FIVE
PERCENT (10-25 %) OF YOUR YEARLY INCOME TO OUR ACCOUNT TO AID IN THIS
IMPORTANT VENTURE. THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES OF
AMERICA WILL FUNCTION AS OUR TRUSTED INTERMEDIARY. I PROPOSE THAT YOU
MAKE THIS TRANSFER BEFORE THE FIFTEENTH (15TH) OF THE MONTH OF APRIL.

I KNOW THAT A TRANSACTION OF THIS MAGNITUDE WOULD MAKE ANYONE
APPREHENSIVE AND WORRIED. BUT I AM ASSURING YOU THAT ALL WILL BE WELL AT
THE END OF THE DAY. A BOLD STEP TAKEN SHALL NOT BE REGRETTED, I ASSURE
YOU. PLEASE DO BE INFORMED THAT THIS BUSINESS TRANSACTION IS 100% LEGAL.
IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO CO-OPERATE IN THIS TRANSACTION, PLEASE CONTACT OUR
INTERMEDIARY REPRESENTATIVES TO FURTHER DISCUSS THE MATTER.

I PRAY THAT YOU UNDERSTAND OUR PLIGHT. MY FAMILY AND OUR COLLEAGUES WILL
BE FOREVER GRATEFUL. PLEASE REPLY IN STRICT CONFIDENCE TO THE CONTACT
NUMBERS BELOW.

SINCERELY WITH WARM REGARDS,

GEORGE WALKER BUSH

Switchboard: 202.456.1414
Comments: 202.456.1111
Fax: 202.456.2461
Email: president@whitehouse.gov

>THIRTY-SIX BILLION DOLLARS ($36,000,000,000) WERE SUPPLIED BY HIS
>PARTNERS IN THE KINGDOM OF SAUDI ARABIA AND OTHER PERSIAN GULF
>MONARCHIES, AND SIXTEEN BILLION DOLLARS ($16,000,000,000) BY GERMAN AND
>JAPANESE PARTNERS. BUT MY FATHER'S FORMER IRAQI BUSINESS PARTNER
>REMAINED IN CONTROL OF THE REPUBLIC OF IRAQ AND ITS PETROLEUM RESERVES.
>
>MY FAMILY IS CALLING FOR YOUR URGENT ASSISTANCE IN FUNDING THE REMOVAL
>OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF IRAQ AND ACQUIRING THE PETROLEUM
>ASSETS OF HIS COUNTRY, AS COMPENSATION FOR THE COSTS OF REMOVING HIM
>FROM POWER. UNFORTUNATELY, OUR PARTNERS FROM 1991 ARE NOT WILLING TO
>SHOULDER THE BURDEN OF THIS NEW VENTURE, WHICH IN ITS UPCOMING PHASE MAY
>COST THE SUM OF 100 BILLION TO 200 BILLION DOLLARS ($100,000,000,000 -
>$200,000,000,000), BOTH IN THE INITIAL ACQUISITION AND IN LONG-TERM
>MANAGEMENT.
>
>WITHOUT THE FUNDS FROM OUR 1991 PARTNERS, WE WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO
>ACQUIRE THE OIL REVENUE TRAPPED WITHIN IRAQ. THAT IS WHY MY FAMILY AND
>OUR COLLEAGUES ARE URGENTLY SEEKING YOUR GRACIOUS ASSISTANCE. OUR
>DISTINGUISHED COLLEAGUES IN THIS BUSINESS TRANSACTION INCLUDE THE
>SITTING VICE-PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, RICHARD CHENEY,
>WHO IS AN ORIGINAL PARTNER IN THE IRAQ VENTURE AND FORMER HEAD OF THE
>HALLIBURTON OIL COMPANY, AND CONDOLEEZA RICE, WHOSE PROFESSIONAL
>DEDICATION TO THE VENTURE WAS DEMONSTRATED IN THE NAMING OF A CHEVRON
>OIL TANKER AFTER HER.
>
>I WOULD BESEECH YOU TO TRANSFER A SUM EQUALING TEN TO TWENTY-FIVE
>PERCENT (10-25 %) OF YOUR YEARLY INCOME TO OUR ACCOUNT TO AID IN THIS
>IMPORTANT VENTURE. THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES OF
>AMERICA WILL FUNCTION AS OUR TRUSTED INTERMEDIARY. I PROPOSE THAT YOU
>MAKE THIS TRANSFER BEFORE THE FIFTEENTH (15TH) OF THE MONTH OF APRIL.
>
>I KNOW THAT A TRANSACTION OF THIS MAGNITUDE WOULD MAKE ANYONE
>APPREHENSIVE AND WORRIED. BUT I AM ASSURING YOU THAT ALL WILL BE WELL AT
>THE END OF THE DAY. A BOLD STEP TAKEN SHALL NOT BE REGRETTED, I ASSURE
>YOU. PLEASE DO BE INFORMED THAT THIS BUSINESS TRANSACTION IS 100% LEGAL.
>IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO CO-OPERATE IN THIS TRANSACTION, PLEASE CONTACT OUR
>INTERMEDIARY REPRESENTATIVES TO FURTHER DISCUSS THE MATTER.
>
>I PRAY THAT YOU UNDERSTAND OUR PLIGHT. MY FAMILY AND OUR COLLEAGUES WILL
>BE FOREVER GRATEFUL. PLEASE REPLY IN STRICT CONFIDENCE TO THE CONTACT
>NUMBERS BELOW.
>
>SINCERELY WITH WARM REGARDS,
>
>GEORGE WALKER BUSH
>
>Switchboard: 202.456.1414
>Comments: 202.456.1111
>Fax: 202.456.2461
>Email: president@whitehouse.gov
>
>
>

I thought the IRS did have an e-payment option.  (Haven't used it
though.)

I've thought that a great anti-war protest would be 100s of 1000s of
people not paying their taxes this year.  Only problem is, you've
already payed much, if not more, of your taxes via deductions.  So
not filing won't really get you anywhere.  (If it weren't for that
LITTLE detail, would have been a great plan.)

The best alternative I've come up with for attacking war funding is
moving your money out of the banks and into credit unions.  They're
non-profit, and I believe primarily focus their energies on giving back
to the community.  There's an online credit union locator here:
http://www.cuna.org/data/consumer/culinks/cu_locator.html

Personally, I've been with Wells Fargo for years, mainly out of laziness
in making an effort to make a move.  With all that's going on
politically, I'm getting out of there and moving my accounts to a credit
union.

OB rave related content:  I'd assume it's primarily via banks that the
funding for cracking down on our activities cones from. Why should I
support that?

At 09:24 PM 1/23/2003, P. Sutton wrote:

>How exactly is war with Iraw going to get us a greater share of the
>output?

We replace the dictatorship with a government loyal to our cause, at least 
for the time being.  See Taliban, Nicaraguan rebels, etc

>Yknow what cracks me the hell up, this "blood for oil" b.s.
>Was there some kind of oil crisis in 1991?  I think not.  Was there one
>about 6 months ago?  I think not.

The total amount of oil reserves is a known quantity, and it's 
shrinking.  Why does it have to run out before it's a crisis?

>Are there other middle eastern
>countries capable of pumping as much oil as Iraq?  I think so.

For the same duration?  I doubt it.


>No, I think not.  Do those said countries also wish Saddam was out
>of power?  I think so.

I don't.  They could do it easily on their own.

>Blood for oil my ass!  As long as we don't
>go guns a blazin' and have *proof* of womd then it's all good.

We sold weapons to Iraq - what further proof do you need?

sarilion

Dear SFRavers,

It was very nice getting to know a very small percentage of you that I 
have actually met in person. My time has come to depart from the United 
States in exploration of what is outside of my sheltered American 
lifestyle. The end of February I am moving to Bangkok, Thailand to 
reside 'permanently' and continue my studies in school. But I am 
unsubscribing for now until sometime in the future if my fate is 
somehow again intertwined with the Bay Area's. :)


It is always fun partying with you all and the one thing I think I'll 
miss the most is the great music that is here and the great people too. 
Hopefully, when I return at some point in the future, techno will rule 
the dance music scene and everyone will submit to it's supremacy :)

unity,
Chris


"The closer you get to light, the greater your shadow becomes." ~ 
Kingdom Hearts ~


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> At 09:24 PM 1/23/2003, P. Sutton wrote:
>
> >How exactly is war with Iraw going to get us a greater share of the
> >output?
>
> We replace the dictatorship with a government loyal to our cause, at least
> for the time being.  See Taliban, Nicaraguan rebels, etc

You miss the point.  Why do we need a greater share of the output when Iraq
(sanctions or no) isn't that much of our input?  And I wasn't aware this was
the 80's (re: Taliban, re: Nicaragua)

> >Yknow what cracks me the hell up, this "blood for oil" b.s.
> >Was there some kind of oil crisis in 1991?  I think not.  Was there one
> >about 6 months ago?  I think not.
>
> The total amount of oil reserves is a known quantity, and it's
> shrinking.  Why does it have to run out before it's a crisis?

It isn't a known quantity, though it is shrinking.  A crisis doesn't
occure just because it's running out.  It wont run out for decades.
Hence, why pick on one country who's output, while significant, isn't
that much in the scheme of things, decades before a crisis caused by
oil actually is on the verge of running out?  Makes no sense, think
about it.

> >Are there other middle eastern
> >countries capable of pumping as much oil as Iraq?  I think so.
>
> For the same duration?  I doubt it.

Think about it again then.

> >No, I think not.  Do those said countries also wish Saddam was out
> >of power?  I think so.
>
> I don't.  They could do it easily on their own.

Hahahah, and so cound most European powers.  It's essentially one of
those cases where everyone knows we'll do it, so they let us.  Why
does Canada have such fabulous social services?  Oh yeah, a very low
defense budget.  Why?  Same thing.

> >Blood for oil my ass!  As long as we don't
> >go guns a blazin' and have *proof* of womd then it's all good.
>
> We sold weapons to Iraq - what further proof do you need?

Yeah, us and every other industrialized country, plus a few lesser
countries lol.  If I recall N.Korea just recently shipped some weapons
to Iraq.  No wait, there was no flag on that ship!    Falst alarm!

Subject: [sfraves] americans and their dreams of oil v.s. what's really going on nrr

i realize that a great number of americans have cars,
and with that comes the fear of an increase in oil
prices until other better and more efficient energies
and cars are more readily available (sooner than you
think, folks, but hey, we are a country of obesity,
most of which is derived from what is a culturally
learned and mostly impulsive nature reflected in the
fact that many americans spend a lot  of time, energy
and money eating as much fast food as one can fit into
a day)...if someone is american and anti-war, a
popular argument for the impending war on iraq is that
this must really have something to do with the oil,
which isn't ours, by the way....if your in cali, your
into produce and your plastic surgeon.....if your
typically american, however, and concerned with the
oil, then you believe that the impending war has
something to do with the fact that we ALL know how
important the oil is....in the first place, not
everyone is freak'in over the oil, and secondly, i
don't know if anyone's actually been paying attention
to world politics or if their just into camping out
for a day in the big cities of their dreams, leaving
trash all around, starting fights, barking at the
otherwise mostly law abiding and generally always
peaceful locals, but there's just a little problem in
the eyes of most that the leadership over in iraq have
made it most difficult for representatives from all
around the globe, otherwise known as the U.N., to do
their peace keeping job and perform a thorough
inspection of the weaponry over in iraq....do your
suppose they are  hiding nuclear capabilities? most
likely, yes...this impending war has very little to do
with your cars, people...just leave them in the
garage. most everyone, including your president, would
prefer a peaceful resolution. :)

Subject: NRR: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: interesting poll

On 23 January 2003, P. Sutton wrote:

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Sarilion" <sarilion@sarilion.org>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, January 23, 2003 9:45 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: interesting poll
>
>
> > At 09:24 PM 1/23/2003, P. Sutton wrote:
> >
> > >How exactly is war with Iraw going to get us a greater share of the
> > >output?
> >
> > We replace the dictatorship with a government loyal to our cause, at least
> > for the time being.  See Taliban, Nicaraguan rebels, etc
>
> You miss the point.  Why do we need a greater share of the output when Iraq
> (sanctions or no) isn't that much of our input?  And I wasn't aware this was
> the 80's (re: Taliban, re: Nicaragua)

http://dieoff.com/page133.htm includes stats from the BP Statistical
Review of World Energy (1961-1998) which shows the world production of
oil was 26.5 Billion gallons in '97.  Of that, Iraq produced 0.44
Billion gallons in '97.  (This equals ~ 1.67% of the overall production
that year.)  Browsing the site AndyW pointed out, you can find the
'97 data.  In '97 the US imported 3,708,970,000 barrels of total crude
oil & product in Nov. '02. of which 32,530,000 came from Iraq.  That
shows Iraq accounted for 0.877% of our overall imports.  So, in '97 Iraq
accounted for 0.877% of our overall imports, but 1.67% of the overall
production.

Note:  I use '97 because the first site I refer to above only had data
from '97.

-- 
"An Epiphany of Sound" - 90.1 FM Thursdays from 9AM-Noon Pacific.
(Also on the web at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/).  Playlists
and humor list archives at http://www.kzsu.org/~dougm

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

My late (again) and too verbose (sorry) input:

The Gulf War was not too hard to justify, at least on the surface. The US was again playing international policeman, protecting Kuwait from the invading larger country, Iraq. I can accept that. There was a reason we did not take over Iraq in full  there was no solid moral argument for doing so. And it would have been against international law. Its called national sovereignty. The same exact reason we had the right to kick Iraq out of Kuwait by force.

Now the official US goal is to "disarm" the tyrant Saddam, because he "could" one day use those weapons against us. This is a very morally weak position, that in my view (and quite a lot of others, if you listen for opinions from somewhere other than corporate controlled media) could lead to a very scary world order. The fact is, our government is being very subjective, selective, and unbalanced in their approach. That is why so many countries are politely saying, wait a minute, what the fuck do you think you are doing?

If the same criteria for a "preemptive strike" were used to analyze a dozen other counties around the world, we should be going to war with ALL of them. Are you comfortable with your country, which represents you to the rest of humanity, doing this? Since we are the biggest kid on the block, do we have the "right" to force everyone else to be and do what is in OUR best interest, fuck the rest of em?

Saddam is a sick fuck-of-a-ruler who oppresses his own people.

I think Bush is a sick fuck who does not represent his own people. His press secretary made the statement yesterday: even if the majority of the American people stated they do not want the US to invade Iraq, he would still move forward because HE fills it is the correct thing to do. I heard this on NPR radio. Please check me for accuracy. 

But regardless, my point would be, which other country has the right to come in and kick out Bush because they feel he is evil/bad/unwanted? No one. So why do we have that right to do the same thing to Iraq? What makes it morally justified? Where does this all end, except with a lot of graves. Iraqi, American, and otherwise.

Pedro.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: interesting poll

on 1/23/03 9:24 PM, P. Sutton at micromu@sbcglobal.net wrote:

> How exactly is war with Iraw going to get us a greater share of the
> output?

It doesn't matter if Iraq only produces one barrel of oil a day. Afghanista=
n
produces diddly squat (to use a technical term) of the world's oil output,
yet we had to "free" them in the War Against Terror=81 so we can have
friendlies in there to get our oil pipeline through central Asia.

By the same reasoning, it's only to the greater overall benefit to take ove=
r
resources in Iraq. It may be a small piece of the pie, but because Iraq is
centrally located in the Middle East, it stands as a great gateway for the
transport of oil. Much of the Iran/Iraq war was rooted in a territorial
dispute over the tiny Shatt al Arab waterway, which is essential for
transporting oil out of the region (which includes the former Soviet
republics around the Caspian) and into the Gulf by ship.

If you're looking at Iraq's relatively small oil output, you're not seeing
the forest for the proverbial trees.  Keep in mind that oil isn't the only
resource at hand here. While it's not an issue in the present, the region
(particularly Iran) is sitting on top of another goldmine of fossil fuel:
natural gas, which when the oil runs out could be the commodity of the
future.

Another IF... If you think that this is about Saddam Hussein's record of
civil rights, the fact that he's a dictator, the fact that he kills off
Kurds and Shiites, you're wrong. WE gave chemical and biological weapons to
Iraq during their war with Iran, fully aware of what type of leader Saddam
Hussein was. Why did we ally with Hussein to fight Iran? It wasn't because
of any student revolt at the embassy, the hostages, etc.  Well before the
Islamic revolution took place (that's when they stormed the American embass=
y
in Tehran and ceased diplomatic relations), and long before they had a
dictatorial king, the Iranian government decided to nationalize their
business in... Dum dum dum.. OIL.  Meaning that foreign companies no longer
had any control of oil production in the country. So when the Iran-Iraq war
started, many countries, including ours, sided with Iraq, in hopes of
defeating Iran and regaining the oil interests there. Just as with Iraq,
Iran doesn't represent a huge portion of the world's oil production, but
because it has half of the Caspian region (and at the other time, the other
half was in the Soviet Union) it was a key gateway to all of Central Asia.

So please - look beyond the surface, and even go beyond the secondary layer
of facts. Look at every level, and look at the big picture, before you make
a simple-minded statement like "this war isn't about oil since Iraq doesn't
produce very much" or "this war is about freeing people from the hands of a=
n
evil dictator."

  - omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

just for laughs, i just read an article in urb saying that "rave is dead".
just so you know my discussion here has no relation to this, as i just =
found out about this article.
it is just a silly coincidence.

though i thought the article a little harsh and negative..

>>> Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> 01/23/03 06:59PM >>>
At 09:47 PM 1/22/2003 -0800, Terry Estioko wrote:

>On fads....
>I never really thought a lot of the people going to raves in the late =
90's
>knew enough about it to appreciate it. It was a fad. Some of us would =
like
>to believe the rave scene is more of a movement...but is it? Surely some
>of us have experienced life-changing transformations, but is our
>philosophy and culture enough to be timeless? What makes us any more of a
>movement than breakdancing, any less than hippies?
>


George Sand wrote:  "One changes from day to day...every few years one=20
becomes a new being."  I think that can be said of the consistent human=20
interest and involvement in the timeless and magical art and practice =
of=20
tribal dance and music.   Dancing was there in the beginning;  it will be =
a=20
vital part of social and spiritual interaction until the end of time.   =
It=20
constantly reinvents itself to accommodate various cultural and social=20
requirements.

Raving in the early nineties was one of many attempts in our=20
post-industrial society to wed these ancient, life-giving rites to=20
technology and the needs of the modern psyche.  There were those of us =
who=20
believed in those days that we were creating a revolutionary approach =
to=20
human interaction in an increasingly alienating and homogeneous social=20
structure.  Some even thought that we had rediscovered an ancient=20
connection to the spiritual life.  Certainly early house music lyrics =
were=20
packed with allusions to the movement of the dancer from and through =
the=20
body to the heavens.

This was not boring.  Boredom sets in within life -- and god I know this =
is=20
true -- when you embrace, out of fatigue or social pressure, the rule =
of=20
the mundane and quantifiable.  At some point in the mid-nineties -- and =
I=20
can't put my finger on this because I was to busy with death and dying =
from=20
AIDS in my personal life then -- raving moved from revolution to=20
entertainment.  I suspect much of this had to do with the changing=20
economics and demographics of the time, and I have yet to work through =
this=20
process to my satisfaction.

So we gradually lost the feel of movement and moved in the direction of =
yet=20
another commodified entertainment package.  We lost content.  Our =
beliefs=20
were reduced to catchy slogans.  In the sixties we called this being co =
opted.

Now when a movement embraces the mundane those involved generally =
become=20
more acceptable to the society at large.  When gays moved from "we are=20
unique and have something special to offer" to "we are just like you" =
the=20
road to general acceptance was much facilitated.  We lost our souls, I=20
think, but we gained respect as another valuable consumer market.

Interestingly, this has not happened with raving or, if you will, dance =
and=20
music festivals or "parties."  Lordy knows there was a lot of money in=20
massives, clothing sales, and the like.  A "youth" marketer's dream.  =
Yet=20
the more we emerged into the light, the less acceptable we became.  One=20
could say, and we all did, "look at the rock concerts, look at other =
forms=20
of entertainment -- we are no worse, even less dangerous in many ways.  =
We=20
are Americans like you making money on entertainment and being=20
entertained."  Didn't work.

Why?  Because whatever one wants to position raving as, dancing all =
night=20
long is really a revolutionary act.  Ponder this.

It doesn't matter to me personally whether one considers this "movement"=20=

dead or not.  Any movement without beliefs and passion is moribund, and=20
perhaps that is what raving has become.

I will, however, continue to follow my own passions here.  I will dance=20
until I can no longer walk.  I will continue to throw parties based in =
the=20
belief that dancing is a powerful, liberating and magical force that =
has=20
the potential to change lives and enhance the larger society for the=20
good.  What we do can be defined as one will.  The music will change =
and=20
evolve.  The parties may become more wedded to other arts along with =
the=20
music.  The guests may become more inclusive and diverse.  But we are =
not=20
going away.  Dancing as a revolutionary, life-giving act will withstand=20
this current oppression as it has before.  Fashions change, but this =
one=20
has and will last longer than fifteen minutes.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm=20=


"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It =
is=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a =
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you =
are=20
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

last year on eBay - now I have some awesome dark tech-house on the flip of
one of my favorite breaks tracks, and I've got nothing to mix it with except
for three different remixes of the same damn Orbital song...duh...

> I've noticed this too.  I came out here from Utah where I was into every
> form of art.. After coming out here my inspiration is next to nil.
> Can't make a beat to save a train.  Its just too.... Comfortable out
> here... The sun is yellower, the weather's better, the people are

> you have to put in just to make rent (albeit I do live a little too

> going out anymore.

similar experience on my end...I lived way too comfortably when I was in
CA...and every creative endeavor I made was less effective than similar
projects from my pre-CA life...I lived in Chicago and made pretty good
tracks on a Korg M1...then I moved to California and added an MPC, a
Prophecy, a Nord Lead, and like ten other gadgets...and I sounded like
shit...

> My plan to reverse this is to leave corporate america behind and I'm
> moving to Santa Cruz to go to college since I haven't done that yet.

college!

my college experience was an interesting year...reading Aristotle in the
original Greek...that was a useful way to spend my time... ;-)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene?

ture.
to give it a name, well, that would be even harder...

general is sad.

believe cnn is where it's at, or are just apathetic.  (the worst)

apathy breeds apathy in all areas in life, and i believe this emotion/act =
is one killing not just this scene but life in general. =20

"i dont have time"
"i dont have the cash"
"i dont know anyone"
"i dont want to get involved"
"i dont understand"
"it doesnt concern me"

the worst phrase ever and most widely used.

"what difference can i make?"

the myriad of excuses i hear for people not caring.  it is almost as if =
our society is turning us into it's own robots?  unless something directly =
affects people at present (if we know about it?) they dont seem to care.  =
or someone will say "your being negative and down and dissentful, etc etc"

when you are expressing truth and the desire to progress in a positive =
manner onto brighter avenues  and better suited pastures that breed at =
least common sense.
i hear all the time "i dont watch the news or read the paper, etc etc, bc =
it is depressing"

these people are no better than the smacked out kids at every party =
sitting around and foaming at the mouth, trying to escape reality and the =
fact that they need to stand up and make a difference and stop pretending =
to be invisible.  get involved and CARE.
have a purpose.  yes there is life outside of that 2 story house and 2 car =
garage and soap operas.  it's called life....!

and not just to get ahead financially in this capitalistic society.  to =
get ahead in our soul, our mind.

which gets me back to the scene.  djs/artists vs promoters.  someone is =
trying to make out on top with the battle of fees, and the scene is the =
one losing.

wasnt it about that in the beginning.  the fact that it wasnt about =
watching an act on stage, like nirvana?  it was about being part of that =
"Act", by dancing, etc???
the focus was put onto us, not just the artist......

though i still love a good show (props to tool and jungle brothers!)=20

people have seriously lost focus....

do we need glasses?

d



>>> Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> 01/23/03 12:47AM >>>
I'm gonna try to weigh in on the whole thread, because so many great ideas
have been posted. I wrote this kinda fast, and tried to be brief, so =
apologies
on grammar or lack in clarity:

On scene death...
I've always thought it interesting as our scene came to rise and decline,
because (imho) the driving force of the undergrounds stayed
constant. I was in the interesting position to associate myself w/ the UG
crews, but kept tabs on the big scene by continually being booked for
massives. It got more and more ridiculous as mainstream parties broke out,
almost like the dotcoms. But just as the dotcoms have been forced to adapt
or die, mainstream parties are forced to do the same. At the same time,
the void left by UG veteran crews, who have either retreated to
their own circles or declined out of age, has not been filled...as of yet.

On fads....
I never really thought a lot of the people going to raves in the late 90's
knew enough about it to appreciate it. It was a fad. Some of us would like
to believe the rave scene is more of a movement...but is it? Surely some
of us have experienced life-changing transformations, but is our
philosophy and culture enough to be timeless? What makes us any more of a
movement than breakdancing, any less than hippies?

On subjectivity....
One thing I learned in my time with you all is that the more I
learn, I less I realize I know. Kinda like how you think you have it *all
figured out* by the time you're 18, but 10 years later you realize you
knew very little. This scene lives by the quality of its subjective
experience. The magic that I felt at a certain time in my life was not
absolute, and later on in my involvement here I found the same enjoyment
seeing others experience the same magic. So there really is no timetable,
it's what we make of it, and what we decide to share with others.

On my own involvement...
I feel like a schmuck for not contributing as much recently as I probably
could. We threw a bunch of really good parties several years ago, but now
they're probably a distant memory. The concept behind our parties really
never caught on, perhaps partially because we never threw-for-profit, and =
only
struck when the iron was hot and our conditions met, but we learned a lot.
I sucessfully dealt with the authorites on lots of occasions. I know how
to *not* blow a circuit. I know how to set up a party that won't fall down
at 1am. These days, I'm more concerned about keeping a roof over my head
than entertaining a bunch of folks.
It seems though, that lots of the same general party throwing questions =
come
up here. I noticed Yarrow came out candid on this list, which I normally
wouldn't expect from a massive promoter.I guess I'm saying that I still =
think
more resources are on this list than some would expect. I'm glad this =
dialogue
is taking place, and hope we continue to talk about it.

On elitism...
I believe this was brought about through necessity, not egomania. There
was a time, as some would remember, when Friends and Family planned
parties on this list. Eventually the list just became too big for them,
And soon after, became too dangerous to post any UG events here. Those
groups who have left the spotlight never needed to come back. It just
became way easier to *not* have an open-door to the rave community. And at =
this
point, I don't think any of them are coming back, which leads me to...

On reinvention....
All the ideas posted on this thread are golden. Far different than a few
years ago when the general scene mentality was "gimme gimme gimme". To
question your involvement in a scene/fad/movement and reevaluate that =
scene
shows that we are ready for the next step. What is the next step? I have =
no
idea what floats all your people's boat. Personally, I'd like to see some =
well
produced, family-oriented, safe, truly-innovative, from-the-heart parties
(whatever that means). I remember being a "scenester" in '96 and having my
rave world turned upside down by FnF $5 parties with full on
*everything*, that was legendary shit. I'd like to see new crews/families
emerge with the knowledge of their predecessors and make it better. It's =
clear
to me there are still a lot of great people in the scene, many veterans =
have
been scorched and are apprehensive, many others have fresh ideas to bring
to the table. Ultimately, it's up to our collective force to decide where =
we
go from here.

Thanks for listening, I almost feel like there was a point to everything I
said that never came out. Oh well, maybe it did, maybe it'll come out
later.

take care,

-terry

---------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org=20
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org=20
Party guy         | http://www.viberation.com=20
Regular guy       | http://www.estioko.com=20

On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Ed Colmar wrote:

>
> Thanks Apollo, some great comments as usual.
>
> To me, it seems like there is a bored feeling that has been going around
> for some time now...  It's almost as if the oldness of the /scene/ =
/style/
> /music/ is pushing people away.
>
> Before I go too far I should say that I still do believe there is
> evolution here, the music obviously does everyday, and events do to a
> certain degree.  But likie Apollo phrased it, a 'paradigm buster' would
> really do it.
>
> We see old-schoolers and grizzled veterans going off on new people in =
the
> scene, and that has to be less than alluring to new participants.  On =
the
> other hand, we see those same old-schoolers getting bored, and constantly=

> looking for something better (myself included).
>
> In my opinion I believe that we need two things in order to rejuvinate
> this culture we love:  new energy, and new ideas.
>
> New energy:  People, groups, styles and movements.
>
> New ideas:  Fresh clothing ideas, New event concepts, new experiential
> excersises.  New ideas that don't even really relate to dance music, =
yet.
>
> The /scene/ has always been about Doin' It Yourself.  Take whatever is
> exciting to you, and integrate that in with groups and events.  Probably
> other people will find it interesting as well.
>
> Push it forward!
>
> -e-
>
>
> On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Apollo wrote:
>

in
> > the air.

Subject: [sfraves] Ravers for Peace

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

As you know, some of us on this list are organizing representation for the 
next march for peace.

This march and rally has been rescheduled for Sunday, February 16th, so as 
not to conflict with the Chinese New Year celebration on the 15th.

Those interested in working with Ravers for Peace should contact me off list.

Love,

Apollo

*Mass March to Stop War On Iraq Sunday February 16 in San Francisco*


The next mass march in San Francisco to stop war on Iraq has been
rescheduled from Saturday, February 15 to Sunday, February 16, to avoid
conflicting with the Chinese New Year Day Parade.


The anti-war march gathers on Sunday February 16 at 11 AM at Embarcadero
Plaza and will march at 1 PM to a 2 PM rally at Civic Center Plaza. The
February 16 demonstration is being co-sponsored by Bay United Against War,
The Not in Our Name Project, United for Peace and Justice, and The Int'l
ANSWER (Act Now to Stop War and End Racism) Coalition and is endorsed by
thousands of organizations and individuals.


At a heavily attended press conference today at City Hall in San Francisco,
elected officials, labor, community and anti-war leaders called on people
to participate in the San Francisco Chinese New Year Parade on Saturday
February 15th as well as the Mass Anti-War March in San Francisco the
following day, Sunday February 16. Among those who spoke at the press
conference and encouraged participation in both events were Mayor Willie
Brown, Supervisor Tom Ammiano, Supervisor Fiona Ma, Supervisor Aaron
Peskin, a representative of the Chinese New Year Day Parade, Howard Wallace
of the San Francisco Labor Council, Andrea Buffa of United for Peace and
Justice, Bonnie Weinstein of Bay Area United Against War, and Richard
Becker of the Int'l ANSWER Coalition.

Subject: [sfraves] scene death?  what scene? (OK eveyone please read this, I typed it) free admission to Stamina


In a message dated 1/22/03 9:48:50 PM, terry@hyperreal.org writes:

<< I noticed Yarrow came out candid on this list, which I normally
wouldn't expect from a massive promoter.I guess I'm saying that I still think
more resources are on this list than some would expect. >>

 You can count on me to be candid, always. And for better or for worse. I 
just haven't been on this list for a while. I got tired of 80% drama and 10% 
music and 10% NRR. I recently resubscribe to post info about the spring time 
club thang I'm doing over at The Deli in SF.  But after posting the info and 
reading threads about what we as a community can do to keep our scene active 
and vibrant I was frankly astounded to see very little response, even when I 
offered free guestlist to anyone who knew me, or remotely knew me. 
 I couldn't believe the inertia. Here we did a 18+ $10 event w/ a full bar, 
Ghost, Joey, Dyloot, Dutch, etc., and offered no charge for those that 
responded by email and it was fully permitted. And yet for all the times peo
ple type about change it seems that there is very little real world 
participation.
 I wouldn't classify myself as a massive promoter. This may sound like a 
minute difference but Mystical Mayhem does do promotion for massive events 
but Mystical Mayhem events have never exceeded 4,000 people (Calaveras 1 yr. 
SERENITY) , and most were Maritime and 2nd and Jackson but a handful have 
been 500 peps (Signals, Orbit, etc.). How about midsize promoter? I have 
nothing against massives, I've just never done one.
 I'll continue to be candid as long as I am still subscribed. I totally agree 
w/ Terry's statement about there being more resources on this list than some 
would expect.
 I'll also hold out a challenge. For anyone who emails me before next Tuesday 
with their first and last names and snail mail address I will send them a 
ticket or pass or put them on the guestlist for Stamina Feb. 22 (2 days after 
my birthday, so bring kisses ladies). One person per email only. 
 Raving is a verb. Raving is an action not a mental endeavor. This list 
should be a supplement and forum, not a substitute for going out and dancing. 
And for all of those people out there who are wondering where are scene is..I 
ask where are you? Find a crew or event, support it, contribute, do art, do 
promotion, email ideas, bring awarness booths and show friends what the 
"scene" has to offer. Write a hiku about dancing and see if someone will put 
it on a flyer.
 And if you can't afford an event, plan in advance, contact the promoter, 
offer to help setup or cleanup. Not having money is a reality but using that 
as an excuse for not attending is the reasoning of the lazy, non 
contributing, not planning ahead type. If you want to be somewhere make it 
happen by adding to the experience of the event. I used to let people in for 
free who contacted me in advance and brought a drum, since they added 
production value and were participating.
 Below is the info on Stamina Feb 22 for those who leave the house.

Sincerely,
Yarrow
Mystical Mayhem/M3


SATURDAY FEB. 22, 2003 Stamina, @ 2246 Jerrold St, 18+ Dance, 21+ Drink w/ 
valid ID, 9-2AM, Every 3rd saturday of Spring w/ DJ's: Joey Mazzola 
(Solmatic, SF), Tom Slik (Skills, SF), Melanie (Macumba, SF), St. John 
(HouseNation/ 94.9, SF)
Frank Nitty (Ghostribe/ HouseNation, SF), Tecni (Mystical Mayhem, SF), Louie 
G (Mystical Mayhem, Tuff Twinz, SF), Adam G (Mystical Mayhem, Tuff Twinz, 
SF), www.staminasf.com, To purchase reduced priced tickets go to 
www.acteva.com/go/stamina, To purchase $10 tickets go to the 
following.....Clear Music (415)437-1587, F-8 (415)221-4142, Solid 
Grooves(408)248-6399,  Skills (510)704-9876, Straight Hits (510)739-1862, 
Twilight Zone (510)538-7945, Generation Rock  (925)682-9042, Rock On (707) 
422-2080, Catch Club Stamina every 3rd Saturday of Spring featuring the best 
House and Trance DJ's in the SF Bay Area. Email: info@staminasf.com,

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 11:01 AM 1/24/2003 -0500, Chris Dooley wrote:
>just for laughs, i just read an article in urb saying that "rave is dead".
>just so you know my discussion here has no relation to this, as i just 
>found out about this article.
>it is just a silly coincidence.
>
>though i thought the article a little harsh and negative..
>

Actually, when you posted this I took the time to read the article.  Not 
bad.  The core of the discussion presented is, and I quote from Bill 
Werde's piece "Rave is Dead" (Urb, p. 62, Feb. '03):

"The ideals of rave -- peace, love, unity and respect to some, DIY to 
others -- live on in truly underground events and new rave converts and 
even in other parties, such as Burning Man.  But the business...The 
business of rave is crashing like a post-binge tweaker."

OK.  Raving was never about making money in the first place.  Werde goes on 
to cite club closures, decline in music sales, DJ bookings and the like -- 
all business-related activity.  And asserts it is no longer uber fashion 
amongst the teen set.  Cool.  Raving wasn't fashionable back in the day, 
either.

As he mentions, people have been sayin' "rave is dead" pretty much since 
raving began:)  Lots of people felt that when commercial interests entered 
the mix this killed raving (1995).

So, the business is gone, it's no longer cool, and we are back to where we 
were to begin with.  Good.  Or, as Derrick Carter described the early scene:

"You could rent someone's loft for the night for like, $300.  If you knew 
someone, maybe a cat's a little low on their rent?  One hundred and fifty 
dollars, $200 for the sound system, cover the kegs and everyone gets 50 
bucks lunch money or whatever.  'Cause shit!  I got all these records 
sitting in my house.  I don't eat properly and I look stupid cause I can't 
afford good clothes.  But I got these hot-ass records.  Shit!  These 
records gonna get heard.  I'm gonna have a party and play good records and 
laugh and see people we like and it'll be cool.  That was all right.  It 
was enough."  (Urb, p.64)

Word.  The love of music and friends was enough, and it still is.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams
--=====================_28035882==_.ALT--

Xone 62, CDJ-100) running through more sound than our house really needs =
(full racks of gear).=20

want. I just want to see everyone come out and play!

normally don't party with. I just want to see everyone again and have =
fun.

think I'll name one of the rooms The Den of Sin in honor of Scott.

and more DJ wise so far.

Received: (qmail 63313 invoked from network); 25 Jan 2003 11:33:10 -0000
Date: Sat, 25 Jan 2003 03:37:53 -0800
From: Brynne and hernan <cortezco@pacbell.net>
In-reply-to: <28.3239903f.2b5dd2d3@aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-id: <IEEMJLJJCOJJJEAEDMNACEECEFAA.cortezco@pacbell.net>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Importance: Normal
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-priority: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] SRR I marched today :) Huge crowd, no war on Iraq,
 impeach Bush!


Marching is old school.

Imagine a 200,000-person protest  "Street Party"  "Dance".

(((((....Back in the day raves were held in illegal locations.
People had to sneak generators into unusual places. They would haul in sound
and lighting and decks and vinyl..

In essence these mythical ravers would build a small city of joy for 8
hours.

Imagine using these old school skills to express your opinion, and
dance....))).

I have one big beef with most marches.
They just seem to be  a __dated__ vehicle for expression of opinion.


I think you could establish and broadcast a communal message more
effectively with a VJ and or a "in-tune" DJ.

Imagine big "bed sheet" movie screens with anti-war imagery provided by
slide and video. Behind a stage.

Or *better yet* a more amoebic approach. A whole block(s) lined with
different forms of artistic expression. Video, slides, tall puppetry,
Murals.

Instead of walking in a beeline to some far off destination.
The object would be to pool the humanity into a central location. A long
march disassociates the attendees. Everyone rushes home and turns on the
news and the news people lie and say it was only 2000 people. And EVERYONE
gets depressed and never goes to another march (because after all that work,
they didn't make the news)


But the important equation would be that people would come into close
proximity with each other, share a vibe.

I have been doing the sound systems for many protests for many years and
this is what I believe needs to happen.

If anyone wants to work with me on this dream please email me.





-----Original Message-----
From: BrittyH02@aol.com [mailto:BrittyH02@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 2:32 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR I marched today :) Huge crowd, no war on Iraq,
impeach Bush!

Hi everyone-
I would just like to say how proud I am of all of you who went to the march
on Saturday. At Love Allstars, countless people from the list came up to me
and told me they went because of my post. The march was awesome. I saw on
the
news that morning that "an estimated 10,000 people will be there"...ha ha ha
try 200,000 people. All day long I ran around and told older activists about
PLUR and what it represents. One person told me if we all lived by those 4
basic principles, we wouldnt be at that march, we wouldnt need to be.
Saturday was my frist massive demonstration and I will never forget it.
Thank
you to all who came and remember, with enough people, we can make a
difference
Britty

Subject: [sfraves] SFPD Shut Down Hip Hop Event at Kelly's Mission Rock

--=====================_2454067==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

 From Davey D's Hip Hop Newsletter:


SFPD HATE ON 50 CENT


Friday nights highly anticipated 50 Cent performance at San Francisco's
Kelly's Mission Rock was shut down by the SFPD.  The ILL Trendz Productions
street team arrived as police had begun to attempt traffic control in front
of the venue.  An estimated 500 people waited to gain entrance to the club
patiently.  As ILL Trendz pulled up in a Nas Van Wrap and Mobile Billboard,
they chopped it up with Big Von, Gary Archer, DJ Spair, and Sadiki.
Suddenly the crowd near the door began to run as the SFPD approached.  4
squad car pulled up to the front of the club with various police officers
running in on foot.  As ILL Trendz departed fifteen minutes later, more
officers arrived and were seen carrying shotguns to the front club entrance.
ILL Trendz was disturbed to see such an uncordinated and large response to
the club.  The 50 Cent performance had been advertised over the past week
and was a presale only event.  Many people seemed shocked to see the SFPD
shut down the club.  Despite fears of violence at large club settings, the
evening had been uneventful.


         -Sean Kennedy and Dan Sheehan-
               ILL Trendz Productions


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"As long as you haven't experienced this:  to die and so to grow, you are 
only a troubled guest on the dark earth."
-Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

"Chaos often breeds life, where order breeds habit."
-Henry Adams

concept.

The whole idea of a protest is to gather and stand up for what you believe, 
artistic or not, but I have yet to go to a march where I did not see any 
form of beauty and creativity.  To bring more into this, art or muscic or 
whatever, would be a beautiful thing, but it seems that you are overlooking 
the reasons why people do gather to begin with.
Later,
Danny

Protest:
2. an expression of strong opposition to or disapproval of something in the 
form of a public demonstration or other action

not subject to criticism or debate, but respectful of personal choice: take a look at revolver magazine...most of the discussion revolves around rock music, but you can take it from there if your not a fan....nice layout...double sided poster in the most recent issue..one side kurt cobain...the other jenna jameson...which side to hang up first? also, big, big fun!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! there are how-to instructions for the opening riff from ac/dc's "back in black".....oh my gosh, and the instructions are fabulous, accompanied by a lucious photo of mr. angus young and a little picture of jenna dressed as a devil with a caption underneath that reads, "hot licks!" to keep your attention on the learning page.....good stuff!  :)

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 26 Jan 2003 00:33:33.0440 (UTC) FILETIME=[8E999000:01C2C4D2]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] soundforge help

I read it and don't need to register to yet another board so I will give you 
the answer to pass on. In sound forge when you record there is a selection 
for pre and post roll and that is where the gap is coming from . To change 
this go to the Options Menu then go to Preferences then from there go to 
Other the make sure all the little time measures are at 0.00 except the Loop 
time because no matter what you do it will only allow you to put it at .10 
And also another reason if that does not work is when you compress audio 
into an MP3 it can change size and sound characteristics but in Soundforge 
you can edit MP3's as well so you can trim the edges if all else fails. Hope 
that helps if not let me know what does work I am always open to learning. 
Peace
     Jason

The only other soultion I might think of is go to downloads.com and look for 
the free .wav to .mp3 encoder it works well and no gaps or space added.

>>From: "Jason Andrews" <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com>
>>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] soundforge help
>>Date: Sat, 25 Jan 2003 16:33:33 -0800
>>
>>I read it and don't need to register to yet another board so I will give 
>>you the answer to pass on. In sound forge when you record there is a 
>>selection for pre and post roll and that is where the gap is coming from . 
>>To change this go to the Options Menu then go to Preferences then from 
>>there go to Other the make sure all the little time measures are at 0.00 
>>except the Loop time because no matter what you do it will only allow you 
>>to put it at .10 And also another reason if that does not work is when you 
>>compress audio into an MP3 it can change size and sound characteristics 
>>but in Soundforge you can edit MP3's as well so you can trim the edges if 
>>all else fails. Hope that helps if not let me know what does work I am 
>>always open to learning. Peace
>>     Jason
>>
>>The only other soultion I might think of is go to downloads.com and look 
>>for the free .wav to .mp3 encoder it works well and no gaps or space 
>>added.
>>
>>

>>

X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1106

Subject: [sfraves] Review: Flex and SFR House Party

------=_NextPart_000_0241_01C2C4A1.41C6C6C0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi All,
    Wow, last night was great! I went to Flex's resurrection at the =
Black Box in downtown Oakland. I was really impressed. The venue is =
fantastic. I was talking to someone behind the bar, and she said that =
they've been open for about a year, and mostly host performance art =
shows. This was there first "club" night. There were a lot of people =
there, much more than I ever saw at Flex's East Oakland spot. I only =
heard 2 sets, Qzen and Utraviolet, but they were both off the hook! =
Ultraviolet especially is sick, and brings incredible energy. Afterwards =
I headed over to Ryan's house for the SFR House Party. It was great =
seeing some faces I haven't seen in a while, and putting faces to some =
email addresses for the first time. I got to spin a 2x4 DnB set with =
Gfunk Jeff. It was the first time I've gotten to play with 2x4 and I'm =
totally hooked! I've tagteamed with people before, but you can do so =
much with 4 tables! I finally left around 6am, came home and crashed. I =
woke up around noon and could not get the music out of my head, so I =
finally gave up on sleeping and started streaming from bassdrive.com. I =
know I should try to sleep more, since I'm going out tonight, and don't =
wanna sleep through the superbowl tomorrow, but dammit, it's just too =
nice and sunny out today! I hope you all get to enjoy it.

Happy  :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs

------=_NextPart_000_0241_01C2C4A1.41C6C6C0--

	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Date: Sun, 26 Jan 2003 09:57:38 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] good read'in for the musically inclined nrr

"also big, big fun!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"

sometimes I hate Geri, sometimes I love her.

but how did she get past my filters?

regardless...my favorite thing about reading her posts is that it makes me
feel like I'm not alone...it's good to realize sfraves has more than one
resident lunatic...

I think Geri is actually onto something. I think the next wave to hit San
Francisco will be an influx of indie rockers, punk rockers, and even
alt.country rockers. nothing wrong with this, one of my favorite songs is an
alt.country tune ("Untouchable Face" by Ani DiFranco) -- but the city won't
look or sound the way it used to.

if you want to make the most of this, you should start a band. a year from
now you'll be one of the kings of the city, and five years from now (if you
play your cards right) you'll be partying at Hugh Hefner's mansion and doing
lines of coke off of Miss October's ass.

yay for you.

I think what this will mean for the rave scene is that the distinction
between massives and undergrounds will grow less pronounced as the entire
scene submerges underground again. that's basically a positive thing.
however, I think the only scenes that will see real growth during this
period will be those which ally themselves with rock music in some way. (if
you see industrial as a form of rock, which I do, but not everybody does,
you could reasonably assert that this is in fact already happening.)

I think the future for the rave scene might be brighter in other areas. I've
got to go, tho, so expect a less ambiguous and more reasonable e-mail on
this topic later today or possibly tomorrow.


Giles

References: <NEBBJPACELONHDPALGHAIECPMDAA.rothmans@gte.net>
 <030701c2c639$6a5005e0$6401a8c0@allison>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fw: : Lyceaum shut down by DEA?

>drill down and try clicking a few links on the splash page, warning, you
>get a 'your IP is being logged' message.

That's silly.

Apache, the server software they're running, logs all IP addresses by
default. Most webservers do - and it's not a big deal if you have any clue
how such things work. Something tells me this is a script kiddy joke,
which preys on the same naivete that makes those "Warning, This Computer
Is Broadcasting An IP Address!" sham ads work.

Typically, an IP address alone provides very little information (your ISP,
the company you're working from, info that could only be linked to you
personally by subpoena), unless you have a static connection in your name,
like what Vlad Cood was doing last year with his HonestAbe shenanigans.
(Hoooooo, that was dumb ;)

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mike Migurski" <mike@saturn5.com>
To: "Adams, N" <nic@siliconsalon.com>
Cc: "Peter Rothman" <rothmans@gte.net>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 27, 2003 2:58 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fw: : Lyceaum shut down by DEA?


>drill down and try clicking a few links on the splash page, warning, you
>get a 'your IP is being logged' message.

That's silly.

Apache, the server software they're running, logs all IP addresses by
default. Most webservers do - and it's not a big deal if you have any clue
how such things work. Something tells me this is a script kiddy joke,
which preys on the same naivete that makes those "Warning, This Computer
Is Broadcasting An IP Address!" sham ads work.

Typically, an IP address alone provides very little information (your ISP,
the company you're working from, info that could only be linked to you
personally by subpoena), unless you have a static connection in your name,
like what Vlad Cood was doing last year with his HonestAbe shenanigans.
(Hoooooo, that was dumb ;)

mike

thanks Mike,

I kinda knew that already, what fooled me a bit was that I was a Federal
employee a few years back and whenever I went to a banned addy, like
craigslist.or I'd get a similar message, the difference being that I was
warned that my terminal, not my IP was being logged.

this warning message looks close to the format they used.

looks like the reason the site is like this today is that Lyceauam may be
running a disinformation campaign of sorts today for the below reasons,

regards,

nic

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

It may be a shields up by the lyceaum people. CBS is airing a "scare the
parents
internet drug-information story" today. I heard that in advance they were
led
to believe it would become a balanced story.

This was presented to me by a well informed source that went speculating
about this.

A while ago lyceaum put up the same page as an april 1st joke so dont worry
about your IP number being logged (it always is!).

You're both not understanding-

"Your IP adress is being logged"

That does not mean "the IP address of the computer you're at is being
logged"

It means YOUR IP ADDRESS!!!
Yes- the IPv6 address that was coded in to silicon and implanted in
you at birth!

Everyone's eyes are contantly adjusting focus back and forth- the chip modifies the
rate of these refocuses so as to broadcast a unique IP address to
anything designed to pick such things up.

The only way to stop this is to use the internet with your eyes
closed.
It took a few weeks to get used to it but I can do 10WPM on my braille
terminal now!

--

A man goes to a party and has too much to drink. His friends plead with him=20
to let them take him home. He says no - he only lives a mile away.=A0five=20
blocks from party, the police pull him over for weaving and ask him to get=20
out of the car and walk the line.
Just as he starts, the police radio blares out a notice of=A0 a robbery taki=
ng=20
place in a house just a block away.
The police tell the party animal to stay put, they will be right back and=20
they hop a fence and run down the street to the
robbery.=20
The guy waits and waits and finally decides to drive home. When he gets=20
there, he tells his wife he is going to bed, and to tell anyone who might=20
come looking for him that he has the flu and has been in bed all day.=20
A few hours later the police knock on the door. They
ask if Mr. X is there and his wife says yes. They ask to see him and she
replies that he is in=A0 bed with the flu and has been so all day.The police=
=20
have his driver's license. They ask to see his car and she asks why. They=20
insist on seeing his car, so she takes them to the garage and opens the door=
=20
where they find the police car, with lights still flashing.=20

True story, told by the driver at his AA meeting.=20

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mike Migurski" <mike@saturn5.com>
To: "Adams, N" <nic@siliconsalon.com>
Cc: "Peter Rothman" <rothmans@gte.net>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, January 27, 2003 2:58 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fw: : Lyceaum shut down by DEA?


>drill down and try clicking a few links on the splash page, warning, you
>get a 'your IP is being logged' message.

That's silly.

Apache, the server software they're running, logs all IP addresses by
default. Most webservers do - and it's not a big deal if you have any clue
how such things work. Something tells me this is a script kiddy joke,
which preys on the same naivete that makes those "Warning, This Computer
Is Broadcasting An IP Address!" sham ads work.

Typically, an IP address alone provides very little information (your ISP,
the company you're working from, info that could only be linked to you
personally by subpoena), unless you have a static connection in your name,
like what Vlad Cood was doing last year with his HonestAbe shenanigans.
(Hoooooo, that was dumb ;)

mike

thanks Mike,

I kinda knew that already, what fooled me a bit was that I was a Federal
employee a few years back and whenever I went to a banned addy, like
craigslist.or I'd get a similar message, the difference being that I was
warned that my terminal, not my IP was being logged.

this warning message looks close to the format they used.

looks like the reason the site is like this today is that Lyceauam may be
running a disinformation campaign of sorts today for the below reasons,

regards,

nic

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

It may be a shields up by the lyceaum people. CBS is airing a "scare the
parents
internet drug-information story" today. I heard that in advance they were
led
to believe it would become a balanced story.

This was presented to me by a well informed source that went speculating
about this.

A while ago lyceaum put up the same page as an april 1st joke so dont worry
about your IP number being logged (it always is!).
